webTitle: You won't have Darren Tackle to kick around any more

fields.headline: You won't have Darren Tackle to kick around any more
fields.trailText: So that's it then. It's all over. Never again will the so-called media and that have anything to write about. Never again will Andy Gray tut-tut as he analyses a bit of footage featuring that never to be forgotten pro. Never again will Hansen and Lawrenson shake their heads on national telly.
fields.body:
So that's it then. It's all over. Never again will the so-called media and that have anything to write about. Never again will Andy Gray tut-tut as he analyses a bit of footage featuring that never to be forgotten pro. Never again will Hansen and Lawrenson shake their heads on national telly.

No more will Gary Lineker frown and lower the pitch of his voice in a sad attempt to look like a serious grown-up. Yup, some people are on the pitch and that. It is over now. Or summat.

What you have read in the papers is true: retirement beckons. Yours truly, Darren Tackle, has hung up his boots and turned his back on the game what has been his livelihood since the days of the Stamford Park under-eights when he scythed Neal Butterworth's legs from behind and was sent off by Miss Twiss the games teacher (fat-arsed old boot).

To be honest, in the end it wasn't that difficult a decision to make, retirement. When Mr Chairman called me into his office and told me not only wasn't he going to renew me contract but he was going to make me pay back what I'd earned so far this year, it seemed a sensible option.

Getting in there first has always been the way Tackle played his game. So I chucks the keys of the club Daihatsu on his secretary's desk on the way out as he asked, and didn't look back.

The hardest part was telling the lads. I called a meeting after training, insisting they all be there, the boys what had shared this life with us for, well, longer than I care to remember. And to be honest as they shuffled into the dressing room you could have cut the atmosphere with a buzz saw.

"Lads, I've got an announcement to make," I says to them, although I could see I'd already lost Vic and Bob who'd started a card school in the corner.

"Well bleedin' hurry up," says Wattsy. "I've got a book here on who's going to win celebrity Big Brother and if I don't get it open soon, Chris Eubank will have chinned that geezer from Boyzone."

"Well, the thing is, boys," I says. "Phew, this is hard. Erm, basically I'm retiring and that. That's it, game over."

"Is that it?" says Vic and Bob together. "You bleedin' well dragged us out of a massage session for that? By the way, Wattsy, put a long'un on Jack Dee for us."

That's how you'd expect the lads to react: they don't like to show their emotions. But deep down I knew it hurt. They just wanted to try to carry on as normal, and they let me empty me locker, fill a black plastic bin-liner and leave the training ground without one of them even saying a word to me. They'd have been too choked to try.

Rodney was the next to tell. And he took it better than I thought. No "you're a long time retired, Dazz, you sure?" No "but you're just at the peak of your career". Just a quick "right" plus "any idea where Wycombe is, Dazz? Only I'm looking to sign up their lads to look after their Cup final pool and I've got to get there pronto before Eric Hall."

So I kind of knew it was the right decision. Besides, the three people who have rung me up since the news broke have all told me it's exactly the right decision. David Elleray was one, saying it was a good day for football the day Tackle took his studs home with him.

Regrets? Well, obviously there's a few. Mainly that I didn't do Alan Shearer when I had the chance. Or David Ginola. And then there's that barmaid at Raison d'Etre. But hey, life's too short for worrying. Though she did look well up for it.

All that was left then was to tell the floppy-haired student what edits this column that no longer will Darren Tackle be reporting from the front line of the footballer's lifestyle, no longer would he be able to rely on dispatches from the Armani front, no more will he be getting it quite literally from the horse's mouth.

To be honest, he didn't seem that stressed. "Right. Before you go, any chance of getting that pony back you borrowed off us at the office Christmas lunch?" was all he says. "Only I want to put it on Vanessa Feltz in Wattsy's book."

So laters then. And if anyone wants me, I'm in the Priory.

fields.headline: Sir Anthony Tuke
fields.standfirst: Controversial chairman of Barclays and Rio Tinto Zinc during South Africa's apartheid years
fields.trailText: Sir Anthony Tuke, who has died aged 80, was chairman of Barclays bank during the 70s. It was a time when the bank was under fierce attack from anti-apartheid campaigners for its heavy involvement in South Africa.
fields.body:
Sir Anthony Tuke, who has died aged 80, was chairman of Barclays bank during the 70s. It was a time when the bank was under fierce attack from anti-apartheid campaigners for its heavy involvement in South Africa.

The apartheid controversy dogged him for years, and although in most respects he was a straightforward businessman with little interest in politics, controversy pursued him from one job to another. His battle over apartheid did not end when he stepped down from the Barclays chair in 1981. He became even further embroiled when he moved straight to the chair of Rio Tinto Zinc (RTZ), the mining company.

His involvement with the apartheid debate even extended to cricket when he was president of the MCC in 1982. Back in the City he also became immersed in the long-running feud between Lord Forte and the Savoy hotel group when he began a 10-year reign as its chairman in 1984.

The lowest point in all these controversies came in 1982, when he was in charge of the RTZ annual shareholder meeting. Despite years of experience in dealing with shareholder protesters at Barclays, Tuke provoked uproar when he cut short the RTZ meeting. After a stream of questions about the group's uranium mining in Namibia, then regarded as illegally controlled by South Africa, the chairman swiftly called an end to questions and declared the meeting closed.

Angry shareholders still waiting to ask questions included two Aborigines who had travelled from Australia to raise the issue of land rights. Protesters rushed the stage, attempting to grab microphones in order to press forward their points, as the directors quickly escaped. Police were called in, resulting in an ugly scuffle and criticism of the mining giant for being undemocratic. The protesters were cock-a-hoop, believing Tuke had played into their hands and given them huge publicity.

Tuke remained implacable in his defence of the companies he chaired and their dealings with the apartheid regime. At Barclays, which was then one of South Africa's largest banks and earned an eighth of its profits in the divided country, he stuck to the position that pulling out would do more harm than good.

He attempted to follow this through when head of the MCC, with vain attempts to organise tours in breach of South Africa's exclusion from international sports. In a different context, however, as chair of the fundraising group backing British athletes at the Moscow Olympics in 1980, he supported Margaret Thatcher's boycott call when the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan.

This international politicking was a long way from his roots and the bulk of his life. Educated at Winchester College and Magdalene College, Cambridge, Tuke continued a traditional path into the Scots Guards during the second world war. It was during the war that he met his wife Emilia, in Yugoslavia.

After the war, Tuke joined Barclays which, despite its size, was virtually a family firm. The bank had been founded at the end of the 19th century through a merger of six family-controlled banks, and was still controlled by the founding families, something which continued into the 1990s. The Tukes were one of those families and both Tuke's father and grandfather had chaired the bank before he did.

Tuke began working in branches in London's West End, and spent a brief spell in South Africa before moving up the managerial ladder in Luton and Birmingham. He joined the board in 1965, with responsibilities particularly for international business, and became chairman in 1973.

He was knighted in 1979, towards the end of his spell in charge of the bank. His period as chairman was marked by two broad thrusts - marketing bank accounts to the half of the British population which was then "unbanked", and expanding internationally. He was a great believer in the power of plastic cards and oversaw the rapid expansion of Barclaycard as the leading British credit card of the time.

Both his strategic thrusts were briefly successful, making Barclays Britain's biggest bank for a while. But as a non-executive director until 1990, Tuke had to watch National Westminster overhaul his firm, and Barclays' international ambitions fizzle out. Tuke continued to be active in the City into his 70s. He was chairman of RTZ until 1985, and was also deputy chairman of Royal Insurance from 1985 to 1992.

Outside the business world, he was a great sports lover, although contenting himself with watching Arsenal at football and Hampshire at cricket. His main exercise was gardening at his home in Hampshire. Otherwise he indulged a passion for Gilbert & Sullivan, which included being vice-chairman of the D'Oyly Carte Opera Trust, and Barclays helping to rescue the opera company in 1978.

He is survived by his wife and their son and daughter.

Sir Anthony Tuke, born August 22 1920, died March 6 2001

webTitle: Old-fashioned ties put sheen back on Cup

fields.headline: Old-fashioned ties put sheen back on Cup
fields.trailText: A proper cup tie, said John Aldridge, who should know. Outside, in the window of Tranmere's club shop, the new Premiership Giant Killers T-shirt was on sale, listing the seven top-flight clubs beaten by Aldridge's team in the past 18 months. Now the manager had to face the fact that here would be no new edition with the name of Liverpool, his old club, added to those of Everton, Leeds, Sunderland, Middlesbrough, West Ham, Coventry and Southampton.
fields.body:
A proper cup tie, said John Aldridge, who should know. Outside, in the window of Tranmere's club shop, the new Premiership Giant Killers T-shirt was on sale, listing the seven top-flight clubs beaten by Aldridge's team in the past 18 months. Now the manager had to face the fact that here would be no new edition with the name of Liverpool, his old club, added to those of Everton, Leeds, Sunderland, Middlesbrough, West Ham, Coventry and Southampton.

"We knew about those seven clubs," Gérard Houllier said, "and we didn't want to be the eighth. I told the boys this morning of the danger they were facing and what kind of game it would be."

Yes, it was a proper cup tie, with rampant underdogs and panicked superstars and dizzying changes of fortune. Nobody quite knows what the Cup means any more, but this was the genuine article.

So do we take yesterday's match at Prenton Park, and the one on Saturday at Filbert Street, as evidence that the competition is alive and well, and still capable of bestowing its particular form of immortality? Or does the anticlimactic affair at Highbury, in which one manager left his best goalscorer and his midfield general on the bench while his opposite number appeared to have his mind on other priorities, give us a truer sense of the tournament's depreciated value?

These questions came to the fore once Manchester United skipped last season's competition. Although United's absence could have been accepted as a harmless one-off, its effect was to place a question mark, for the first time, against the status of the Cup. Similarly, Arsène Wenger's decision to give Thierry Henry and Patrick Vieira a rest against Blackburn could easily have been accepted as a perfectly understandable piece of footballing realpolitik, given his club's commitments. Instead it sent a different message.

But the tournament of Stanley Matthews and Bert Trautmann, of Roy Dwight and Ian Porterfield, is fighting back. Who could have imagined at the beginning of the season that Lawrie Sanchez, scorer of Wimbledon's winning goal against Liverpool in 1988, would be facing the same club as a manager in a semi-final in 2001? Or that George Graham, a winner as a player and a manager with Arsenal, would be facing his old club in the other semi-final in command of their bitterest rivals? Or that victories in those two matches for the presumed favourites, Liverpool and Arsenal, would match two French managers in an FA Cup final to be played in Wales? Such things ensure this year's competition will add to the store of memories.

"There are no underdogs at this stage," Houllier briskly remarked on the prospect of a meeting with Sanchez's team. "What Wycombe achieved against Wimbledon and Leicester shows we've got to be extremely up for it. If we play well on the day, if we have a good game, maybe we will go through."

And if they continue to play as they did for most of yesterday's second half, which is the way they played in passages recently against Birmingham in Cardiff and against Roma at Anfield, sooner or later Houllier's team will come a big and painful cropper. "We didn't take Tranmere lightly," the Frenchman said, which was true. But the Nationwide League team were restricted to two goals only by a considerable amount of luck, because of the Liverpool defence's inability to play the ball out of their zone with any accuracy and to the midfield's failure to hold it and move it around with any fluency. As a result, Sami Hyypia and Markus Babbel were constantly on the back foot.

But, the result apart, Houllier had a reason to be proud. "Did you see something about the team?" he asked. What he meant was that there were seven Englishmen in the starting line-up, all aged 26 or under, and four of them scored the goals. The lesson the rest of us can take is that, even in the modern world, tradition and progress can still go hand in hand.

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: While the destination of the First Division title may be all but settled, competition for the play-off places could hardly be hotter.
fields.body:
While the destination of the First Division title may be all but settled, competition for the play-off places could hardly be hotter.

West Bromwich Albion remain fifth despite a 2-1 home defeat to Sheffield Wednesday . The Owls have now won four of their last six games to rise well out of the relegation places.

Nottingham Forest move into sixth place thanks to a 3-1 win over the previous occupants, Sheffield United , at Bramall Lane. It was the Yorkshire club's third home defeat of the season.

Wimbledon remain in contention after Patrick Agyemang secured a 1-0 "home" win over Crystal Palace . The only consolation for the Eagles is that only Wednesday of those below them won. Bruce Dyer scored twice in Barnsley 's 3-1 home win over Huddersfield , ensuring that the Terriers remain stranded in the relegation zone.

Millwall returned to form at the top of the Second Division, beating Luton 1-0 at home thanks to Stuart Nethercott's first-half header. But Rotherham stayed in touch, Rob Scott scoring a last-minute winner in their 3-2 win at Oldham .

In the Third Division, Plymouth inflicted only a third defeat of the season on Chesterfield , winning 3-0. Brighton moved into second place, beating Hull 3-0 while Cardiff , who dropped to third, lost 2-0 at Lincoln .

fields.headline: The future is Tangerine
fields.standfirst: Wellens 11, Simpson 59, Walker 63
fields.trailText: If David Webb and Steve McMahon had clashed in their playing days, the Richter scale might have been recalibrated. Meeting as managers of Southend and Blackpool respectively they were as mild as the spring afternoon.
fields.body:
If David Webb and Steve McMahon had clashed in their playing days, the Richter scale might have been recalibrated. Meeting as managers of Southend and Blackpool respectively they were as mild as the spring afternoon. Perhaps seaside air has mellowed them. Or perhaps they realise that matters are out of their hands. The referee, William Jordan, might have been flown in from Sri Lanka.

On the half-hour, with Blackpool one up, Ben Abbey played the ball past Daniel Shittu and was brought down in the chase for it. Jordan denied a penalty, apparently reckoning that Abbey dived. McMahon said: "Sometimes they go for you, sometimes they don't." Webb, relaxed against a wall as a shepherd might lean on a crook, said: "Maybe we were hard done by in the first half but we had plenty of time to get level before they went 2-0."

Thus spoke the philosophers. Players can go through the motions but football, like cricket, is in the lap of the arbiters.

Destinies here were in the balance. Both sides are in the play-off shake-up. Blackpool, with three wins now in eight days, might achieve automatic promotion. In late September they lay 23rd. They have won their last seven at home and have not drawn at all in 24 matches since October. Win one, lose one is better than draw two.

Webb said beforehand: "We must be sharp and positive at both ends of the pitch." At the back they were uncertain, at the front blunt, if not offside; and in the middle they were overrun by experience. Southend had four men of 19 or 20. Blackpool had Paul Simpson and Mike Milligan, both 34, poised and perceptive. Back and front, too, the visitors were sharp and positive.

Richard Wellens skipped in for the first, Simpson drove in the second, Richard Walker headed the third. Phil Barnes made two fine saves at 1-0 but Blackpool's defensive giant was Shittu, on loan from Charlton, born in Lagos and, at 16 stone and 6ft 3in, built like a fully kitted quarterback. Never-mighty Southend had no answer.

McMahon, inheriting Swindon, took them down, then up. He could repeat it with Blackpool and by Christmas may have a half-decent stadium, too. Southend have designs on Fossetts Farm. If it lacks the ring of 21st-century ambition, it may have the edge on Roots Hall, which is bog sanded. No wonder Webb was resigned.

On the half-hour, with Blackpool one up, Ben Abbey played the ball past Daniel Shittu and was brought down in the chase for it. Jordan denied a penalty, apparently reckoning that Abbey dived. McMahon said: "Sometimes they go for you, sometimes they don't." Webb, relaxed against a wall as a shepherd might lean on a crook, said: "Maybe we were hard done by in the first half but we had plenty of time to get level before they went 2-0." Thus spoke the philosophers. Players can go through the motions but football, like cricket, is in the lap of the arbiters. Destinies here were in the balance. Both sides are in the play-off shake-up. Blackpool, with three wins now in eight days, might achieve automatic promotion. In late September they lay 23rd. They have won their last seven at home and have not drawn at all in 24 matches since October. Win one, lose one is better than draw two. Webb said beforehand: "We must be sharp and positive at both ends of the pitch." At the back they were uncertain, at the front blunt, if not offside; and in the middle they were overrun by experience. Southend had four men of 19 or 20. Blackpool had Paul Simpson and Mike Milligan, both 34, poised and perceptive. Back and front, too, the visitors were sharp and positive. Richard Wellens skipped in for the first, Simpson drove in the second, Richard Walker headed the third. Phil Barnes made two fine saves at 1-0 but Blackpool's defensive giant was Shittu, on loan from Charlton, born in Lagos and, at 16 stone and 6ft 3in, built like a fully kitted quarterback. Never-mighty Southend had no answer. McMahon, inheriting Swindon, took them down, then up. He could repeat it with Blackpool and by Christmas may have a half-decent stadium, too. Southend have designs on Fossetts Farm. If it lacks the ring of 21st-century ambition, it may have the edge on Roots Hall, which is bog sanded. fields.headline: Oxford supporters forget their manners
fields.standfirst: Robinson 29 90
fields.trailText: The Manor Ground's valedictory season has not been a happy one. Oxford, moping in last place since September, are now 22 points adrift of safety with 12 games left and it will not be long before Third Division football is bequeathed to the new ground at Minchery Farm.
fields.byline: Matthew Hancock at the Manor Ground
fields.body:
The Manor Ground's valedictory season has not been a happy one. Oxford, moping in last place since September, are now 22 points adrift of safety with 12 games left and it will not be long before Third Division football is bequeathed to the new ground at Minchery Farm.

The dreaming spires will wake from this nightmare to find Oxford in the basement for the first time since 1965. There is still pride to play for, of course, and the final visit of Swindon Town stirred the locals in this sleepy corner of town: over 7,000 packed in for a rip-roaring derby as Swindon, once high and fairly mighty themselves, scrapped for their own survival.

Their cause was aided by fast-diminishing opposition. Dean Whitehead was sent off after kicking Steve Robinson before half-time and then Matt Murphy trailed off with 25 minutes left for two bookable offences.

But anxiety, frustration and local pride are a poisonous blend and when the home fans' ire became too great they aimed coins, bottles and insults at Steve Mildenhall in the Swindon goal and the referee Paul Rejer took the players off.

Mildenhall, a convenient rather than culpable target, explained afterwards: "The referee was worried for my safety and said: 'That's it - we've got to get off for a while.' There must have been £50 in that goalmouth."

A gathering of players, substitutes, managers and stewards formed by the dugouts, like hesitant children waiting for a teacher to arrive, but Rejer soon diagnosed a calm after the storm and waved the players back on to play the last 12 minutes. In the best tradition of defusing a tricky situation with humour, Mildenhall fell over while restarting with a goal-kick and things slowly got back to normal.

Trailing 1-0 to Robinson's thunderous first-half volley, the nine men of Oxford were suddenly gripped with passion. With faces as red as their opponents' shirts they laid seige to Mildenhall's goal before Robinson fired in another decisive volley at the other end.

"This is Oxford United and the way things are going you get a large kick in the balls as opposed to a little tap," said the Oxford manager David Kemp of his team's woes. "The thing to do is not sulk about it but just hope that the tide turns and surely it will."

Robinson gleefully surfed that tide, scoring his first goals since arriving from Birmingham City last month.

"We've got a good team here," he said. "It's not a bottom-of-the-league side - if we keep playing as we are and stay up, it bodes well for next season."

Swindon, two points above the drop-zone and set to play five of the teams around them during the run-in, have their fate in their own hands. How Oxford must envy them.

webTitle: Wooter puts stalling Watford back on the road

fields.headline: Wooter puts stalling Watford back on the road
fields.standfirst: Wooter 9, Smith 61, Helguson 76, Nielsen 86 | Norwich City 1 Forbes 7
fields.trailText: Two years ago almost to the day Watford travelled to Oxford after three successive defeats and picked up a goalless draw. That began an unbeaten run which produced 24 points from 30, a play-off spot and ultimately a Premiership place.
fields.body:
Two years ago almost to the day Watford travelled to Oxford after three successive defeats and picked up a goalless draw. That began an unbeaten run which produced 24 points from 30, a play-off spot and ultimately a Premiership place.

So badly have Graham Taylor's team wintered this time around that despite being one of only three teams to lead this Fulham-dominated division all season (Stockport led after week one), they began the day in ninth place, as bad as it has been for 2 years, with a worried set of fans and requiring another tallish order.

Their short-term problems were soon solved. "That's the best we've played over 90 minutes this season," Taylor said. "I'm just hoping it gives us a boost, the supporters as well, so we go into the following games in an upbeat mood. We were playing like that at the start of the season and that's how we got our 15-game unbeaten run."

Better teams than Norwich will suffer at the hands of a Watford team playing in this frame of mind, though it took a flash ing header from Adrian Forbes, who met Steen Nedergaard's searching cross from the right, to get the hosts focused.

"When we went one down I thought 'this is really going to test us', not just the team but the supporters as well," Taylor added. "But [Nordin] Wooter got an exceptionally gifted goal and that set everybody alight."

The Dutchman, who had a fine game before being forced off with an ankle strain before the interval, picked up the ball on the right, turned a defender and beat two more before registering his first goal of the season with a shot which went in off the far post.

His injury meant that Tommy Smith was moved from attack to the right midfield position, but the 20-year-old put in a marvellous performance which meant that Wooter was hardly missed. He scored the second from the edge of the area after latching on to a rebound from the referee and then dispossessed Malky Mackay to set up Heidar Helguson to sidefoot home the third.

Allan Nielsen, who might have had three himself, added a fourth, a superb goal which followed some neat interplay with Helguson and Paolo Vernazza.

"Training's been very good; it's just been a case of getting the training tempo on to the pitch but we've done that today," said Smith, referring to Watford's failure to win any of their previous six league games.

"Tommy's developing and getting stronger but if he were to leave too early for the wrong club then he will disappear for a while," said Taylor, understandably worried as Smith has only two years remaining on his contract but recently refused an improved offer.

"You don't miss out if you spend an extra year or two here. Tim Sherwood and David James were good players when they left and still went on to play at he highest level."

fields.headline: Purse pulls Birmingham's strings
fields.standfirst: Purse 61pen, A Johnson 77
fields.trailText: Birmingham were delighted after this, their fifth successive league victory, but they will be even happier if they can make it six in a row on Wednesday, when Blackburn Rovers are the visitors.
fields.body:
Birmingham were delighted after this, their fifth successive league victory, but they will be even happier if they can make it six in a row on Wednesday, when Blackburn Rovers are the visitors.

A win against Graeme Souness's side, currently one place below Birmingham in fourth, would not only put six points between the two clubs, but also lift Blues above Bolton and into second place.

"This has certainly set us up to go into it in very good heart," said Trevor Francis, the Birmingham manager. And, with a trip to the Reebok to come next month, his team's chance of securing automatic promotion lies very much in their own hands.

It should be simple but simple and Birmingham City are worlds rarely mentioned in the same breath. After one of the wettest winters on record, which other club could boast a scorched pitch?

That damage is a legacy of the club's decision to use hot-air blowers to thaw out the surface in January and, for an hour here on Saturday, the combination of that treacherous surface and the heroics of Crewe's goalkeeper Ade Bankole, a triallist with Birmingham two years ago, threatened to send City's biggest league crowd of the season home disappointed.

Many among the 28,000+ were juveniles, there as a result of a promotion between the club and a local newspaper, and on occasion their shrieks put one more in mind of a swimming pool playing host to a school gala than a football stadium.

Nevertheless Crewe's manager Dario Gradi described the atmosphere as intimidating and worth a goal to City. However the hosts' first, when it came, was more of Crewe's making. Stephen Foster ille gally halted a run by Darren Purse and the Birmingham defender converted the subsequent penalty.

It was his fourth successful attempt since taking over as the club penalty-taker and is a further indication of his increasing value to the team.

"He's an inspirational guy and his level of consistency is extraordinary," said Francis. "He's a very big player for us now; [one] who is not only doing a great job for us defensively, he also sets things up."

Francis was less sure of the "Purse for England" chants which followed that goal and while the defender also has reservations about making the step up from England Under-21s to full squad, it is not due to any lack of ambition.

"That's my ultimate aim but I know I've got a long way to go," he said. "Playing in the Premiership would help and I firmly believe we'll be doing that next season. Not only will help me, it will benefit the international ambitions of three or four others."

Two of those would be Bryan Hughes and Andrew Johnson. The former gave another as sured display in midfield while Johnson crowned a superb performance with a memorable solo goal.

The 20-year-old forward went past three defenders before scoring to draw the inevitable comparisons with Michael Owen. Francis, how ever, refused to be drawn. "Andrew gets in my first team unlike Michael, who can't manage it at Liverpool," he joked.

But for how much longer? Johnson's contract expires in 2002 and it would be just like City to let him slip through their fingers.

webTitle: Maddix and Rangers running out of time

fields.headline: Maddix and Rangers running out of time
fields.standfirst: Saha 37pen, Clark 90
fields.trailText: When Ian Holloway replaced Gerry Francis as the Queens Park Rangers manager he faced an acute dilemma. Taking over a losing team with only 13 matches left to save themselves, he had to decide between minor surgery or a full-blown transplant.
fields.body:
When Ian Holloway replaced Gerry Francis as the Queens Park Rangers manager he faced an acute dilemma. Taking over a losing team with only 13 matches left to save themselves, he had to decide between minor surgery or a full-blown transplant.

For one match he allowed those who had failed Francis to stake claims for a place: defeat by Sheffield United followed and in came the paramedic. A new system and wholesale changes have since resulted in a home draw against Watford and Saturday's defeat at Fulham, yet the manager is pleased and insists survival is within their capabilities.

Time is running out, though. Anything other than victory in their next game, against fellow strugglers Grimsby, would increase the pressure.

"There is a seed of confidence growing amongst the players," Holloway said after Louis Saha's penalty and Lee Clark's late second had increased Fulham's lead at the top. "I want to teach them what their jobs are. I haven't got the doom and gloom of the rest of the season; it's not in me. I feel genuinely positive about what they are showing me; they are responding and I can only see us getting better. I don't know if we've got long enough, though. I wish there were 20 games remaining because I'd be confident that we could do it."

The manager believes his side are adapting to his methods, but plugging the leaks will require the wholehearted efforts of everyone. Holloway was not amused that he had to send home Danny Maddix, set for his first start after 16 months out injured, after he missed the team's lunch appointment.

Those who did make it showed the self-belief Holloway is searching for and should have gone in at half- time level, Gavin Peacock missing a golden chance after a rampaging run from the full-back Mark Perry.

"We've got a lot of respect for Fulham and a lot of jealousy if I'm honest," Holloway said. "The way they pass the ball around is beautiful to see, but I felt the lads contained them better than most teams."

Jean Tigana's mission is to prepare Fulham for the Premiership, a task made more difficult by the departure of Fabrice Fernandes after a row with the manager last week.

Still they had too much class for QPR and Saha's penalty, harshly awarded against Paul Murray for bringing down Steve Finnan, came after both the French striker and Clark had hit the bar. Rangers created little in the second half and Clark rounded off Fulham's win with a precise finish. Rangers are going to have to be quick learners.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Bolton still off-key despite perfect pitch

fields.headline: Bolton still off-key despite perfect pitch
fields.standfirst: Frandsen 30, Patterson 45og, Holdsworth 51 | King 35 85, Southall 68
fields.trailText: Bolton's decision to spend £80,000 on the relaying of the pitch here in time for the visit of Gillingham was intended to safeguard the promotion ambitions of Sam Allardyce's team after the old surface had begun to resemble a mudheap.
fields.byline: Mark Ogden at the Reebok Stadium
fields.body:
Bolton's decision to spend £80,000 on the relaying of the pitch here in time for the visit of Gillingham was intended to safeguard the promotion ambitions of Sam Allardyce's team after the old surface had begun to resemble a mudheap.

On this occasion, however, the grass proved to be greener for the other side as Andy Hessenthaler's side deservedly claimed a share of the points.

After occupying second place in the First Division since early December, Bolton's pursuit of automatic promotion is faltering and they have not won for two months. Allardyce admitted: "Victory today would have papered over the cracks. I thought we were going to get away with a win, but we didn't and we only have ourselves to blame. I have told the players that performances don't matter anymore. Instead of being cavalier, I just want to see us get results.

"We were 3-1 up and we were chasing a fourth goal. Why? You don't need a fourth goal when you're 3-1 up."

After taking the lead following a curled strike by Per Frandsen on the half hour, Bolton seemed ready to secure only their second League victory in seven matches.

Bo Hansen should have extended the lead a minute later when he rounded the goalkeeper Vince Bartram, but his shot was cleared off the line by Adrian Pennock.

Such wasteful finishing would prove costly as Gillingham worked their way back into the game when Marlon King pounced on a sliced Paul Warhurst clearance to score.

The playing surface was perfect, but it was another defensive error that restored the home side's lead. Dean Holdsworth's weak effort at goal appeared to be heading wide, but the defender Mark Patterson's attempted clearance was misjudged so badly that he ended up hooking the ball into his own net.

When Holdsworth scored from six yards five minutes after the restart, the three points seemed in the bag for Bolton. However, a Nicky Southall free-kick, followed by a late equaliser by King, stunned the home fans. Gillingham's reward was hardly undeserved, though, and the midfielder Southall believes that Bolton's investment in a new surface could harm their promotion ambitions.

He said: "The pitch really helped us and it will help other teams that come here. We all got a bit excited when we saw how green it was and it worked as much for us as it did for Bolton."

Despite seeing his team throw away the points, Allardyce remains bullish about Bolton's promotion chances, even though they now lead third-placed Birmingham City, who have two games in hand, only on goal difference.

"The key is not to worry about anybody else," Allardyce said. "We are still in the dominant position as other teams have to catch us." His job is now to make his players believe him.

fields.standfirst: Pearce 42, Todorov 72 | Rebrov 30 56, Doherty 61
fields.trailText: And the Spurs go marching on. At least they do in the FA Cup, where the Pioneer Corps' buckets and shovels of their Premiership season continue to be replaced by a bit of Coldstream spit and polish.
fields.body:
And the Spurs go marching on. At least they do in the FA Cup, where the Pioneer Corps' buckets and shovels of their Premiership season continue to be replaced by a bit of Coldstream spit and polish.

A victory for tactical nous, sound organisation and a combination of nerve and verve took Tottenham to the semi-finals after an enthralling sixth-round tie against West Ham United here yesterday. Now Arsenal, the club with whom George Graham will always be most closely identified, stand between his present side and the first FA Cup final at the Millennium stadium in Cardiff.

Spurs and their manager are now within sight of redemption for a disappointing season in the league. Yesterday their goalkeeper made the difference, two saves by Neil Sullivan in the closing minutes denying West Ham the replay their almost overwhelming pressure appeared certain to bring.

These and the instinctive finishing of Sergei Rebrov played a considerable part in Tottenham's victory. The little Ukrainian struck once in each half to throw West Ham on to the back foot just when they appeared to be taking control.

When Gary Doherty gave Spurs a 3-1 lead half an hour from the end this absorbing contest appeared to have taken a decisive turn. But after Svetoslav Todorov, West Ham's Bulgarian substitute, had scored with 18 minutes remaining the excitement reached an even higher pitch.

Having beaten Manchester United and Sunderland in away ties to reach the quarter-finals West Ham were a popular choice to go on to the final. That they did not was due in no small measure to Graham's enduring habit of employing the right tactics for the big occasion, a quality which brought Arsenal two championships and much more besides during his nine years at Highbury.

Tottenham set out to deny Joe Cole, Michael Carrick and Frank Lampard time on the ball and space to use it as effectively as they had done at Old Trafford and the Stadium of Light. So well was the job done that for half an hour West Ham were reduced to humping the ball long towards Frédéric Kanouté, easy stuff for Sol Campbell to deal with.

By no means are the present Tottenham team a pretty sight but yesterday's performance was undeniably impressive, with Steffen Freund dogging the footsteps of Cole and Stephen Clemence and Ledley King rarely giving Lampard or Carrick a chance to establish lines of communication.

On the flanks Steffen Iversen and Luke Young frequently exploited West Ham's lack of natural width and in the middle Les Ferdinand gave an ample demonstration of classic centre-forward play, winning much in the air and working tirelessly to bring those around him into attacking movements.

Poor defending by West Ham contributed to each of Tottenham's goals but Harry Redknapp's side should have been alerted to the likely consequences of slackness at the back in the 11th minute when Rebrov seized on an error by Igor Stimac before driving the ball over the bar. As it was the lesson went unheeded.

After 29 minutes a centre from Freund on the right reached Young, whose header beat Hislop but hit the outside of the far post. Another minute and a prodigious throw from Freund, from the left this time, found Rebrov unmarked and his sweetly struck volley put Tottenham ahead.

A rocket of a low drive from Stuart Pearce, superbly struck after a tapped free-kick from Paolo di Canio had been stunned by Lampard, sent West Ham in at half-time with a new spring in their step and had Kanouté not wastefully shot wide on the resumption Pearce might still be looking forward to another final at the age of 39.

As it was Spurs scored twice more in five minutes around the hour. First Ferdinand rose imperiously above Stimac and Pearce to nod Rebrov in for a shot through the goalkeeper's legs. Cole should have been picking the Ukrainian up and the youngster was again at fault when he failed to react at the far post as Doherty headed in from Rebrov's corner.

Todorov, pouncing after Cole's pass had taken a ricochet off Young, restored West Ham's hopes but Sullivan preserved Spurs' lead, saving one-handed from Kanouté and pushing wide Todorov's header as Upton Park finally ran out of bubbles.

"You can't give away three goals like that in matches like this," Redknapp complained, while Graham thought that "we approached the game in the right way from the off". Neither manager was wrong.

webTitle: Houllier's steady Reds hit the double trail

fields.headline: Houllier's steady Reds hit the double trail
fields.standfirst: Yates 47, Allison 58 | Murphy 12, Owen 27, Gerrard 52, Fowler 82pen
fields.trailText: Tranmere Rovers yesterday discovered that the FA Cup is loth to permit two seismic upsets in any one round. Only in those rare moments when honest endeavour threatened to eclipse true class did the First Division's bottom club seem capable of following Wycombe Wanderers into this season's semi-finals.
fields.body:
Tranmere Rovers yesterday discovered that the FA Cup is loth to permit two seismic upsets in any one round. Only in those rare moments when honest endeavour threatened to eclipse true class did the First Division's bottom club seem capable of following Wycombe Wanderers into this season's semi-finals.

Premiership flesh usually withers and dies on the Wirral peninsula. In the past two seasons John Aldridge's journeymen have beaten seven members of the English game's aristocracy on home soil. But Liverpool to their great credit bucked the trend and with only Wycombe now blocking their path to Cardiff they may well become only the second club, after Arsenal, to win both the FA and League Cups in the same season.

"I said it would be a difficult day and it was," said Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier. "Tranmere work so very, very hard; they never give you anything. I'm delighted to be through. Wycombe? That won't be easy either."

The suspicion remains that for all the household names scrapping for public acceptance within Liverpool's over-crowded ranks, the grand jigsaw puzzle is still incomplete.

Only a fool prone to debilitating bouts of xenophobia would now decry the input of Houllier, for if nothing else he has introduced order and almost reverential calm where there was seething discontent which at times appeared to verge on outright mutiny.

Tranmere's football is high-octane stuff sustained by sheer effort. Though Liverpool's defence is, of course, an admirably proficient unit, yesterday it was subjected to disruption and was thus rather less mean and watertight than of late. Indeed, in the opening, frantic exchanges it boasted all the repellent powers of sodden tissue paper.

With Markus Babbel moved to centre-back to cover for the loss of the injured Stephane Henchoz, Liverpool were exposed down their right flank where young Stephen Wright struggled, initially at least, to hang on to the coat-tails of Jason Koumas, Tranmere's most gifted player.

Had Tranmere managed to find a way through during this brief period of supremacy, the outcome might have been different. "I'm proud of them; they gave it everything they had," said Aldridge.

As it was, much as they had done in Porto three days earlier, Liverpool simply soaked up the pressure. This time, however, they were to shake off the drips and score.

After 12 decidedly uneasy minutes Tranmere caved in, Danny Murphy arriving almost unannounced at the far post to head home a fine Michael Owen cross from the left.

Thereafter there was much ado about nothing until Liverpool strolled forward to double their advantage on 27 minutes. Sami Hyypia's long and forceful clearance was craftily controlled by Murphy, who then simply ran the ball square into the path of Owen who, quite naturally, scored from no great distance.

But, Tranmere never give up, however lost the cause may appear to be. Barely 60 seconds into the second half they were back in the frame, Steve Yates heading home Koumas's cross at the far post.

Liverpool would have been forgiven had they moved into panic mode, for in the previous round Southampton had given up a three-goal advantage at the same venue. Instead, on 52 minutes the tireless Steven Gerrard rose inside a crowded area to head in a Gary McAllister corner.

Still Tranmere were not done and six minutes later, only seconds after being introduced by Aldridge, the substitute Wayne Allison put the outcome of the match back into the melting pot when he collected Robbie Fowler's weak back-pass and converted.

It was not until Fowler atoned for that error from the spot eight minutes from the end, after McAllister had been hauled down by Yates, that Liverpool were home, dry and dreaming of another day trip to south Wales.

webTitle: Hannah strike leaves Rangers facing abyss

fields.headline: Hannah strike leaves Rangers facing abyss
fields.standfirst: Hannah 61
fields.trailText: A trophy-less season with only Scotland's second Champions League place left to fight for is the bleak prospect facing Rangers after David Hannah's second-half strike put Dundee United through to a semi-final against Celtic.
fields.body:
A trophy-less season with only Scotland's second Champions League place left to fight for is the bleak prospect facing Rangers after David Hannah's second-half strike put Dundee United through to a semi-final against Celtic.

How the fortunes of these two sides have changed since the early weeks of the campaign, when Rangers were leading their Champions League group and United were rooted to the foot of the Scottish Premier League.

Dick Advocaat's side failed to muster a single shot on target all night against a United team who peppered the Rangers goalmouth and should have scored three more.

United's first clear chance fell to Jim Hamilton after Sergio Porrini, the right-footed Italian playing at left-back, gifted possession to Craig Easton, who cut into the box. Hamilton pulled the trigger but a combination of Craig Moore's lunge and Stefan Klos's hand saw the ball deflected for a corner.

Klos did it all on his own the next time after Easton sent Derek Lilley racing goalwards with his marker trailing, but the German came out to narrow the angle and Lilley fired against his body.

It wasn't an opening half to remember, but not for want of effort on the part of United's schemer Charlie Miller. Bert Konterman had been assigned to snuff out Miller's creative instincts but by the 16th minute the Dutchman's name was in the book for the second of two fouls.

Rangers had the better of the play after half-time but United broke through in the 61st minute. Easton crossed and Moore appeared to have got the better of Hamilton in the box, but the United man recovered to hook the ball back in to the danger zone where Miller was lurking. Fernando Ricksen did enough to put him off but the ball continued its path to the onrushing Hannah, who smashed it past the exposed Klos.

Rangers almost replied with an instant equaliser when Billy Dodds slid the ball across the United box to Allan Johnston at the far post. He was close enough to see the raindrops glistening off the net strings but somehow managed to put the ball across Paul Gallacher's exposed goal and wide.

Rangers' chances of retrieving the situation diminished when Konterman was sent off for his second bookable offence, this time for fouling Jamie Buchan. Ricksen departed injured soon afterwards, forcing the rookie Steven Carson into the fray.

Hamilton almost caught Klos out from long range, forcing the German to a back-tracking tip-over. Then he was required to make two world-class saves to deny Lilley in the space of seconds, with the first an amazing Gordon Banks-style deflection of a header upwards and over the bar.

Semi-final draw: Celtic v Dundee United; Hibernian v Livingston. Ties to be played April 14/15, both at Hampden Park.

webTitle: Joachim rediscovers hunger to leave Ipswich feeling empty

fields.headline: Joachim rediscovers hunger to leave Ipswich feeling empty
fields.standfirst: Joachim 53, 70 | Armstrong 30
fields.trailText: Despite an unexpected cameo appearance in the Anthony Hopkins film Hannibal, Julian Joachim was, thankfully, eating only his words here.
fields.body:
Despite an unexpected cameo appearance in the Anthony Hopkins film Hannibal, Julian Joachim was, thankfully, eating only his words here.

At the start of the season the little striker, frustrated at the lack of a starting place and new contract, publicly vowed never to play for Aston Villa again while John Gregory was in charge. But Joachim's appetite for goals has returned with a vengeance. Five in his last six games, including Saturday's two to beat third-placed Ipswich, not only helped ease Villa's relegation worries but probably saved the job of the man whom he promised never to work with again.

Gregory and Joachim have sort of made up but the player will still wait to see if he gets a decent run in the team before deciding his future in the summer.

There is one way to ensure a smooth future, though. "I've made enough mistakes so perhaps I'm not one to to give advice," said Joachim's team-mate Paul Merson. "But if you want a contract you have to perform."

Joachim's sudden goal feast has certainly helped mend bridges with the Villa Park faithful. So upset were they by Joachim's heresy at not wanting to wear the claret and blue that they booed his every touch when he was forced to turn out.

But on Saturday, as he led his team's comeback win against an unconvincing Ipswich, Joachim was a hero again, his old place on the bench now reserved for the man bought to replace him, the £9.5m Juan Pablo Angel.

"It really hurts when your own fans turn on you," said Joachim. "I said a couple of things which I regret and I've sorted it out now with John Gregory but it's very hard trying to win over your supporters. The way to convice them is to keep scoring."

In Hannibal, Joachim somehow appeared on a TV screen in the background to a scene from the cannibalisitic sequel. But he is not taking up acting.

The only rehearsals he believes in are the repetitive one-on-one drills with a goalkeeper after training, designed to ensure that once his pace has taken him clear of the defence, the finishing becomes instinctive.

Come curtain-up against Ipswich he did not fluff his lines. It was Joachim's willingness to run at defenders which carried Villa's main attacking threat all afternoon, a verve rewarded on 52 minutes when he pulled back Ipswich's early goal, wriggling past three challenges, shrugging off John McGreal's flimsy tackle and scoring via the post for 1-1.

Then with 20 minutes left, Merson's brilliant through ball sent him clear on goal for a cooly converted winner again off the post.

It brought Villa their first home league win since November, a triumph not only for Joachim, but for Gregory's decision, in search of more width, to play 4-4-2 for the first time this season and start David Ginola for the first time in nine games.

The new strategy got off to a shaky start as Villa, looking uncertain, went behind on 29 minutes. As Gareth Southgate, back from injury, tackled Alun Armstrong in the six-yard box, he saw the ball cannon off the striker's leg into the net.

But Villa tightened up in the second half and got their reward. It makes Gregory's job safe for now though he still has an awful lot of work to do at Villa Park to get anywhere near justifying the presence of a Champions Lounge in the vast new main stand.

As for Ipswich, defeat probably did them a favour. They have made the great strides under George Burley and though on Saturday they were without Titus Bramble and the leading scorer Marcus Stewart, both suspended, this sort of defeat to an average Villa side only makes one fear for the embarrassment that may follow if they win a place in the Champions League.

 You've read the piece, now have your say. Send your comments, as sharp or as stupid as you like, to football.editor@guardianunlimited.co.uk

webTitle: Shearer's season looks all but over

fields.headline: Shearer's season looks all but over
fields.trailText: Newcastle's Alan Shearer may miss the rest of this season after breaking down in training on Saturday. Shearer, the 30-year-old former England captain, has admitted playing in pain since making his first-team comeback two weeks ago and after undergoing knee surgery before Christmas.
fields.body:
Newcastle's Alan Shearer may miss the rest of this season after breaking down in training on Saturday. Shearer, the 30-year-old former England captain, has admitted playing in pain since making his first-team comeback two weeks ago and after undergoing knee surgery before Christmas.

"There was a reaction to the knee which was operated on a few months back," Shearer said. "I came off straight away as a precaution and will be seeing a specialist in the week."

The setback came just as Bobby Robson thought he was on the verge of reuniting his first-choice strike pairing as Carl Cort nears a return after being sidelined for six months.

The £7m signing from Wimbledon, has only played three league games for Newcastle, scoring once, but is expected to be in the squad for Saturday's visit of Middlesbrough.

Shearer's setback came less than 24 hours after he was granted the freedom of Newcastle. "I had a fabulous day on Friday but it goes to show how soon soccer can bring you back down to earth," he said.

Sunderland's striker Niall Quinn will see a specialist today today to get a diagnosis on the back injury which has plagued him for months.

Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's chief executive, has called for limits to be placed on the number of foreign players fielded by clubs and said that the European game's ruling body plans to hold talks about the issue with the European Union, individual governments and their sports ministers.

Aigner wants clubs to field no more than five imports a match, and has also called for a special European Union exemption to override its freedom of labour movement regulations. Failing that he would like to see clubs agree a voluntary initiative to do so.

"Teams have to play with a majority of their own [national] players," Aigner added. "If we have three English teams in the Uefa Cup they should be three English teams rather than international select teams.

"We want to have representatives of this football nation and teams are not representing their football nation. In the long run the fans will not like it."

Aigner also criticised Chelsea and Rangers for, on occasion, fielding teams lacking a single home national. "I don't like it," he said. "It is bad for football in the long run, and probably not so good for the club either. It is against the spirit in sport."

 Arsenal kept their hopes of the treble alive yesterday when they reached the Women's Premier League Cup final with a 3-0 victory against Charlton. Two goals from Angela Banks and one from Jane Ludlow set up a final against Tranmere on April 1.

The setback came just as Bobby Robson thought he was on the verge of reuniting his first-choice strike pairing as Carl Cort nears a return after being sidelined for six months. The £7m signing from Wimbledon, has only played three league games for Newcastle, scoring once, but is expected to be in the squad for Saturday's visit of Middlesbrough. Shearer's setback came less than 24 hours after he was granted the freedom of Newcastle. "I had a fabulous day on Friday but it goes to show how soon soccer can bring you back down to earth," he said. Sunderland's striker Niall Quinn will see a specialist today today to get a diagnosis on the back injury which has plagued him for months. Gerhard Aigner, Uefa's chief executive, has called for limits to be placed on the number of foreign players fielded by clubs and said that the European game's ruling body plans to hold talks about the issue with the European Union, individual governments and their sports ministers. Aigner wants clubs to field no more than five imports a match, and has also called for a special European Union exemption to override its freedom of labour movement regulations. Failing that he would like to see clubs agree a voluntary initiative to do so. "Teams have to play with a majority of their own [national] players," Aigner added. "If we have three English teams in the Uefa Cup they should be three English teams rather than international select teams. "We want to have representatives of this football nation and teams are not representing their football nation. In the long run the fans will not like it." Aigner also criticised Chelsea and Rangers for, on occasion, fielding teams lacking a single home national. "I don't like it," he said. "It is bad for football in the long run, and probably not so good for the club either. It is against the spirit in sport."  Arsenal kept their hopes of the treble alive yesterday when they reached the Women's Premier League Cup final with a 3-0 victory against Charlton. Two goals from Angela Banks and one from Jane Ludlow set up a final against Tranmere on April 1.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.trailText: I spent from December 1999 to February 2000 in Namibia: it's a fantastic place. The dunes at Sossuvlei are an absolute must. If you go to Swkopmund there are loads of things to do.
fields.body:
Hi Sam

Have just come across you all in the paper. You are heading towards Namibia. I spent from December 1999 to February 2000 there: it's a fantastic place. The dunes at Sossuvlei are an absolute must. If you go to Swkopmund there are loads of things to do. The dunes there are fab too, but I didn't spend much time there. Are you self-driving or relying on tours? I based myself in Windhoek at Chameleon Lodge and took their tours. You won't have padded cots to sleep in - it's more a backpacker thing - but very good. The trip up to Ovamboland through hours and hours of vastness and changing scenery was worth it for the scenery alone. Staying at the Kunene River and going to Koakland and meeting the Ovahimba people was the icing on the cake. Bulawayo was a relaxed place with some interesting local places to go at night.

I'll be following your progress - enjoy.

webTitle: New Harry Potter and Bridget Jones for charity

fields.headline: Extra Harry and Bridget for charity
fields.trailText: Each author is a publishing phenomenon; each has been the centre of fears over fast-approaching deadlines. Now JK Rowling, creator of boy wizard Harry Potter, and Helen Fielding, the author behind the diaries of Chardonnay-quaffing accident-prone singleton Bridget Jones, have published interim volumes to raise money for Comic Relief.
fields.body:
Each author is a publishing phenomenon; each has been the centre of fears over fast-approaching deadlines. Now JK Rowling, creator of boy wizard Harry Potter, and Helen Fielding, the author behind the diaries of Chardonnay-quaffing accident-prone singleton Bridget Jones, have published interim volumes to raise money for Comic Relief.

Rowling's Harry Potter "textbooks", which have already spent weeks at the top of the Amazon charts through advance orders, are finally in the shops, along with Fielding's guide to a successful singleton life.

Each title was written specifically for Comic Relief. The books are being sold for £2.50 each; £2 profit will go to charitable projects at home and abroad to coincide with Red Nose Day on March 16.

Rowling's Fantastic Beasts And Where to Find Them is a first-year textbook at Hogwarts School for wizards, ostensibly written by Newt Scamander and with an introduction by the school's headmaster and grand wizard, Albus Dumbledore. Quidditch Through The Ages, which details the rules of the wizard sport, reveals that there are more than 700 ways of committing a foul and that the game first evolved on Queerditch Marsh.

Rowling explained that she had plenty of material in hand, as she always writes more than she needs for the Potter novels. In fact, she said, "It was more fun than I've had writing the others."

Helen Fielding offers Bridget Jones's Guide to Life, in which the hapless heroine gives tips on how to give the perfect dinner party, keep one's finances in the black and, of course, never put on a pound in weight. The books will be sold in supermarkets and bookshops across the country with publishers, printers, typesetters and retailers all offering their services for free or at a discount. Rowling has also signed copies of the short books which will be auctioned on the Internet.

Comic Relief was set up in 1985 and has raised more than £174m. A third of the money is spent on projects for disadvantaged people in the UK and two-thirds on projects in Africa.

Buy Fantastic Beasts at BOL

webTitle: Learning councils set to change post-16 training

fields.headline: Learning councils set to change post-16 training
fields.standfirst: Will the learning and skills councils replacing the further education and funding council be able to address the skills shortage threatening parts of the voluntary sector?
fields.trailText: Post-16 learning will appear vastly different this April with the creation of a national learning and skills council to replace the further education funding council and the training and enterprise councils.Liza Ramrayka reports.
fields.body:
Post-16 learning will appear vastly different this April with the creation of a national learning and skills council (LSC) to replace the further education funding council and the training and enterprise councils.

As skills shortages continue to threaten many parts of the voluntary sector, voluntary organisations should be engaging with the new bodies now to address their future training and learning needs.

LSCs form part of the government's framework for learning for those over the age of 16, as set out in the 1999 education white paper, Learning to succeed. This proposed the creation of a national LSC for England, responsible for the planning, funding, management, quality assurance and audit of all post-16 education and training (but not higher education).

The LSC, due to be launched next month with a budget of around £6bn, will work with regional development agencies, the small business service and the youth support service, Connexions, to address employers' and learners' needs.

The national LSC will be based in Coventry and will carry out its work through 47 local branches. Former Oxfordshire council chief executive John Harwood has been appointed chief executive of the new body and Bryan Sanderson, former group managing director of BP Amoco, chairman. Each of the 47 local LSCs will have their own executive directors and chairs. Local LSCs will oversee further education, community and adult learning, and work-based training within the areas in which they operate. They will address the training needs of paid and unpaid workers, highlighted by employers from all sectors, including those from voluntary organisations.

Major tasks for the LSCs will include developing local strategies for post-16 education and training, and negotiating and agreeing the allocation of LSC funds to providers and employers in line with local priorities. They will also be encouraging local employers to invest in the training and development of their workforce.

Local LSCs are important partners for the sector. Not only are they relevant to the sector's training and learning partners but they will play a key role in supporting voluntary organisations with unmet learning needs. LSCs should encourage new types of learning providers - including the voluntary and community sectors - to apply for funding to deliver new training solutions. These could include on-the-job or internet-based training schemes.

Education and employment secretary David Blunkett wants local LSCs to work with the voluntary sector to ensure any issues affecting staff and volunteers are addressed. Speaking at the annual conference of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations in February, Mr Blunkett said, "We need to ensure that the learning and skills councils are engaged with voluntary organisations, so there is a clear emphasis on workforce development and on quality within organisations. In terms of being able to put up resources to help with the training of volunteers, we need to work through a methodology for doing that so that it can be refined at sub-regional level."

Whether or not these aims are achieved will depend on local LSCs having an accurate picture of present training needs and skills gaps in the sector. To identify local training needs each sector will be asked to draw up a workforce development plan. The voluntary sector launched its workforce development plan this month through the voluntary sector national training organisation.

The plan calls for local LSCs to fund voluntary sector skills networks in each area. The networks will offer advice and guidance to voluntary organisations on training, accreditation and how best to engage with local LSCs. The workforce plan also calls for the national LSC to sign up to the compact on relations between government and the voluntary sector.

fields.headline: Busy doing nothing
fields.standfirst: Milly takes a well-earned break from work to show her mum around her favourite haunts and take in the Mardi Gras Parade. Finding that a life of leisure agrees with them, they also plan a three-day trip to Melbourne, where sitting down is high up on their list of essential activities
fields.trailText: Week 14: Sydney to Melbourne Milly takes a well-earned break from work to show her mum around her favourite haunts and take in the Mardi Gras Parade. Finding that a life of leisure agrees with them, they also plan a three-day trip to Melbourne, where sitting down is high up on their list of essential activities
fields.body:
On Thursday, leaving my mum to sleep off any jet lag, I went to work early. I was so tired I was falling asleep on my feet, but I'd already made my first plan for that evening - surprise number one, if you like. By the time I finished work I had just long enough to get home, shower and change before heading straight out again - I was taking my mum to see a little known operetta, The Gypsy Princess, at Sydney Opera House. Despite my anxieties that we wouldn't make it on time - the lady who sold me tickets had warned me there would be no late admittance - we were fine. I'd never been to the Opera House before and it was quite an experience. The theatre itself was surprisingly small, but the production was enchanting. It was a lightweight romantic musical with fantastic costumes and sets. We both love a song and a dance, and it reminded me of being in school musicals. The moonlit view across the harbour during the interval was almost as magical as the show itself, and we both agreed it was a wonderful evening.  

Unfortunately I had to be at work early the next day. I'm starting to find this burning the candle at both ends business pretty exhausting. Still, I impressed myself by refusing to host - I do value my feet - so it was a pretty painless day. In the evening I took my mum to Darling Harbour to see if she'd be enjoy it as much as I do. She agreed with my that it was a lovely, lively area. We ate a cheap meal of moussaka and pasta, as my mum was suffering from what she called 'day two sickness'. After that we took an evening stroll round the city, only to be beaten eventually by the viciously heavy rain.  

On Saturday morning I had to drag myself into work again, although I was kept going by the prospect of a couple of days off. Besides, that night was one of the biggest nights in the Sydney calendar - the Mardi Gras! I finished work early, which was fantastic because it gave me time to buy a picnic and a box of wine before meeting my mum. From my months here I've learnt to come well-prepared for all big occasions. We headed down to the parade route pretty early so there'd be a chance of us actully seeing it, rather than just the backs of heads. For anyone who doesn't know, Sydney Mardi Gras involves one of the biggest gay and lesbian parades in the world. Thousand of people turn out to watch, dress up and generally go crazy for the weekend. We settled down with our wine, acquired some spangly headbands and enjoyed the parade. It was a fantastically colourful collection with highlights ranging from the in-your-face dykes on bikes through well co-ordinated dancers, the strongly cheered police section and some topless women on stilts who'd painted themselves green.  It was a great evening, but one of those you definitely had to be there for, because of the tremendous atmosphere. Everybody was so friendly and all around there were rainbow flags, outrageous costumes, flying ticker-tape and exploding fireworks. Not an evening we'll be able to forget easily.  

I woke up at the Dive Hotel, which I cannot praise highly enough. It has funky, spacious rooms, a homely feel, a great location and a communal breakfast, all of which really sets it apart from other faceless hotels. I love Sunday afternoons and this one was no exception. The sun was shining brightly, so we headed to the beach to be lazy and watch a surf competition where the contestants battled with dangerously large waves. In the evening we went out for dinner at Pacific Seafood Restaurant in Coogee. Before I left, Brian told me to eat swordfish for him, so I thought it would be rude not to. For those who have never tried it, it's a meaty fish which tastes almost like smoked chicken! My mum had barramundi, which was more like fish and chip shop haddock, but it was all delicious. We also went all-out with dessert and coffee, so that I could give a really professional opinion of the place. I would say it does lovely meals which aren't too pricey, and if you like fish you'll love this place. Now I feel like a young female Michael Winner (or the Guardian equivalent..!)

That night, a raging storm kept us awake which was unfortunate as Monday was the day of my second surprise - a Wonderbus day tour which included a dolphin-watching cruise and the Hunter Valley. We almost decided not to go, but somehow made it to Circular Quay for 7am - 30 minutes late. It didn't matter though because our Wonderbus (the wonder is how it gets anywhere...) was late too. Despite driving at breakneck speed in a bus with the world's worst suspension we still managed to arrive late at Port Stephens, where we boarded a catamaran in an attempt to see some dolphins. The captain seemed a little pessimistic about our chances, but towards the end of the day we were rewarded with the beautiful sight of two mother and baby bottlenoses arching gracefully through the water with perfect synchrony. I know there are dolphins off Swanage, but they're still beautiful.

After this we made it uneventfully to Oakdale Nature Farm where we could interact with various animals from sleepy koalas to tame kangaroos, vicious emus and a goat by the name of Billy who would not stop crying when we left (look at Milly's photo gallery). There were five entertaining and outspoken gay men on our bus, and they adopted Billy as their mascot. Our last stop was the Hunter Valley and this was where our driver got hopelessly confused - and my mum ended up helping him with directions. By the time we'd driven all round the area we had about 10 minutes in a couple of estates before being shepherded back onto the bus again. The driver was teased something awful all the way back, but at least it made for an amusing and again unforgettable day. It also made me decide against trying any more tours of this type, as all I wanted to do was to have a relaxed stroll round the vineries, which unfortunately wasn't to be...  

On Tuesday I had to rise early for work - it turned into a long day but I wasn't particularly concerned as tomorrow was surprise number three, and gave me three whole days off!  

Moving swiftly on to Wednesday's surprise - we were off on the plane to Melbourne! It's only a short flight, and the fares are brilliant at the moment. I was also really looking forward to a change of scenery from Coogee, much as I love the place. We were actually staying in St. Kilda's, which is just out of the city although easily accessible by tram - Melbourne's primary source of public transport. Neither of us were quite prepared for how hot it would be compared to Sydney and at first we were disheartened, especially as the beach at St Kilda's was nothing to write home about. Then we headed for the Royal Botanical Gardens, complete with fruit bats exactly like the one in Sydney, and simply relaxed in the shade under a big tree. After this we felt inspired to explore, and found that Melbourne is absolutely lovely. We walked beside the wide Yarra River with its many active rowers stopping at the giant Southbank plaza for a smoothie. Just on the opposite side of the river lay central Melbourne, with its interesting skyline and grid street layout (look at Milly's photo gallery). We wandered around the city simply looking about before heading home to try and find some dinner. Eventually we decided all we wanted was fruit and wine and I was very pleased to return to our apartment for food and a shower - long may these work-free, sunny days last!

Until next week, Milly

fields.headline: ITV slump worse than expected
fields.standfirst: 6.30pm: ITV is staring into an advertising abyss after analysts effectively wrote off its chances of recovering from a slump in the market this year, writes Dan Milmo
fields.trailText: ITV is staring into an advertising abyss after analysts effectively wrote off its chances of recovering from a slump in the market this year.
fields.body:
ITV is staring into an advertising abyss after analysts effectively wrote off its chances of recovering from a slump in the market this year.

Neil Blackley, the influential media analyst at Merrill Lynch who first highlighted the weakness of ITV advertising revenues last year, today said the advertising downturn "is far worse than expected."

The Merrill team estimated in a note that advertising revenues for May and June could fall by 13% and 16% respectively, which would make a recovery impossible in the second half of the year.

Even if revenues pick up in between July and December, advertising is expected to fall by 1% compared to last year.

It is bad news for ITV giants Granada and Carlton Communications, which have been hit by the collapsing advertising spend of dotcom start-ups and the fall in meat advertising due to the foot nad mouth crisis.

The Merrill team added that "it is now inevitable that ITV will go on satellite before the end of the year."

Granada and Carlton's shares were barely affected by the news, as it has been widely predicted that the ITV advertising recession would last all year.
fields.bodyText: ITV is staring into an advertising abyss after analysts effectively wrote off its chances of recovering from a slump in the market this year. Neil Blackley, the influential media analyst at Merrill Lynch who first highlighted the weakness of ITV advertising revenues last year, today said the advertising downturn "is far worse than expected." The Merrill team estimated in a note that advertising revenues for May and June could fall by 13% and 16% respectively, which would make a recovery impossible in the second half of the year. Even if revenues pick up in between July and December, advertising is expected to fall by 1% compared to last year. It is bad news for ITV giants Granada and Carlton Communications, which have been hit by the collapsing advertising spend of dotcom start-ups and the fall in meat advertising due to the foot nad mouth crisis. The Merrill team added that "it is now inevitable that ITV will go on satellite before the end of the year."
