webTitle: Roy Hattersley: The Tories' 'patriotism' troubles me

fields.headline: A sceptred isle, not a sceptic one
fields.standfirst: The Tories are targeting patriots. It rings a warning bell with me
fields.trailText: It is an admission which I make with much embarrassment but, on the evidence of William Hague's recent speeches, I am the "target voter" on whom the Conservatives will soon be training their general election sights
fields.body:
It is an admission which I make with much embarrassment but, on the evidence of William Hague's recent speeches, I am the "target voter" on whom the Conservatives will soon be training their general election sights. My first qualification for that distinction is that I have never previously supported the Tory party. My second is that I am unashamedly patriotic. According to the strategy which he set out last week, patriots from other parties are to be asked to "lend" him votes in order to save Britain.

To be honest, my affection is for England. Great Britain is just what it says on my passport. I justify (or at least excuse) the elusive nature of my commitment by recounting a conversation I had with John Smith while driving through Edinburgh many years ago. I said that the ancient part of that great city made me feel that Scotland was a different country. No, said Smith, England is a different country. I accepted his correction since, like my initial error, it absolved me from all responsibility for Walter Scott.

My feelings about England are, very largely, based on a composite picture of a country which never existed and never could exist. It combines Victorian enterprise, energy and self-confidence with Elizabethan dash and daring. My belief that William Shakespeare was the greatest man who ever lived is reasonable enough. But most of my patriotism is romantic, sentimental or simply subjective.

I first felt the swelling pride in this, my own native land at school when, like most little boys of my generation, I learned John of Gaunt's "This England" speech. Nobody told me he was complaining that this throne of majesty and seat of Mars had gone to the dogs. I had acquired the inclination to affection some years earlier. Chickens acquire an instant passion for the first hen they see after they burst out of the egg. I saw England. So I love its language, its literature and its landscape. It is the only place I want to live. I enjoy the variable weather which makes it a green and pleasant land. None of those preferences has much to do with judgments made on merit. In my experience genuine affection rarely has.

The irrationality of my patriotism may not be a strength but it is, since I admit it, a great protection against xenophobia. If I loved England because as a nation we were clever (Darwin and Newton), compassionate (Shaftesbury and Wilberforce), adventurous (Cook and Ralegh) or inventive (Arkwright and Telford), I might be tempted to imagine we were somehow intrinsically better than the French or Germans. But because my patriotism is based on absolutely no hard evidence about English character or English achievements, it protects me from elevating my personal preferences into a potentially dangerous political theory.

It is easy enough to transgress the line which divides emotional attachment from chauvinism. Mussolini began with a natural pride in Rome once being the greatest empire in the world and ended up invading Abyssinia. I know that the only Sudetenland William Hague wants to recapture is made up of the marginal seats which John Major lost in the south of England. But his warning that Britain was becoming a foreign country carried the subliminal message that we must resist the cultural and economic invasion of lesser breeds without the law.

A member of that unhappy band sits, all day long, under the awning of the theatre which is immediately across the road from my office. She is a woman of central European origin who spends her time selling, or trying to sell, copies of the Big Issue and feeding her baby. Mr Hague believes that to preserve the character of this country it is necessary to send her home. I would like to think that my England will one day offer her a decent life. But hard as I try, the only respectable political theory concerns her poverty, not her nationality.

Perhaps, as I look out of my office window, I ought to recognise the woman as a potential threat to all that I hold dear - the enemy of laughter learnt of friends and gentleness with hearts at peace under an English heaven, and potentially destructive of the landscape which we, the inconstant ones, are constantly homesick for because it dissolves in water. But all I see is a beggar who makes me feel hideously guilty and mildly annoyed because I do not want my conscience pricked three times a day.

Some voters may join the crusade to stop that woman and her kind Balkanising this sceptred isle. But they will be proving Keynes right. Stupidity does more damage than evil. It all makes me sad, in my patriotic way, that - being a member of a peculiarly British institution - I do not have a vote to lend the Tories. It would be a privilege to withhold it.

 Roy Hattersley is a member of the House of Lords.

fields.headline: Feedback
fields.standfirst: From Stuart
fields.trailText: The train down from Alice Springs to Adelaide really is worth the expense. The flat scenery of the outback is mesmerising as you roll by in air-conditioned luxury. I would also recommend the Adelaide Backpackers Hostel. They are an outstandingly helpful lot.
fields.body:
Hi Sue,

Really pleased you liked Jaisalmer, which must seem a distant memory now. Really enjoyed the pictures and stories especially in Malaysia - have you got the pong out of your nostrils after the Niah cave yet? Amazing how smells bring back memories, or should that be the other way around ? Also glad they are restricting the pork chops on fishing poles for the crocs. Still quite a show though. I must say how the Netjetter page is the first thing I read in the Guardian on Saturday. Hope you're still enjoying yourself. ...and finally why I'm writing. The train down from Alice Springs to Adelaide really is worth the expense. The flat scenery of the outback is mesmerising as you roll by in air-conditioned luxury. I would also recommend the Adelaide Backpackers Hostel. They are an outstandingly helpful lot. They found us a cut price camper van when we drove along the coast to Melbourne. The hire companies seem to rely on backpackers to return the vans to the base in Melbourne and do great deals if you can be flexible about when you want it. Incredible coastal scenery and sunsets. Off to Tesco now...oh, for the open road.

fields.headline: The Bogota effect
fields.standfirst: Where men stay home and do the dishes
fields.trailText: The number of women elected to Westminster in May 1997 - 119 - was a record. But that only happened because the Labour party resolved to do something about the chronic under-representation of women in the Commons by insisting on all-women shortlists in certain seats.
fields.body:
The number of women elected to Westminster in May 1997 - 119 - was a record. But that only happened because the Labour party resolved to do something about the chronic under-representation of women in the Commons by insisting on all-women shortlists in certain seats. Other parties preferred to rely on evolution, which is why 101 of these MPs were Labour, against only 13 Conservatives and a pathetic three (out of 46) Liberal Democrats. But some in the Labour party were unhappy. They challenged the legality of the rule, which was therefore dropped. Which is why the number of women Labour MPs elected in 2001 seems certain to diminish. Now, belatedly, the government is thinking of altering the law to legitimise the practice.

No doubt there will be further outrage. If so, Cherie Blair should draw the prime minister's attention to yesterday's French municipal elections, where, as the result of a law passed last year, 50% of all candidates were women. If France, a coun try whose male chauvinist credentials are at least as robust as our own, can take such drastic action, surely Labour can hardly hold back from reinstating its own more modest system?

In the same spirit of emulation, perhaps, Ken Livingstone's partner, Kate Allen, may wish to draw his attention to events this weekend in Bogota, where the mayor declared a ladies-only evening, with all men banned from the city's streets after 7.30pm unless authorised by the police. Although Colombia is hardly famous for instant obedience to the law, the ban seems to have been largely a success, with little obstruction or dissent reported. Antanas Mockus, who ordered the experiment, is a former professor described as "a philosopher turned mayor", with a reputation for japes with a serious purpose behind them. In the light of this innovatory moment in Bogota, can London's own philosopher-mayor risk his reputation by lagging behind?

webTitle: Comment:  Anne Robinson's Welsh remarks highlight mutual prejudices

fields.headline: Yes, we're irritating
fields.standfirst:
Anne Robinson's remarks about the Welsh simply highlight each nation's prejudices

MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: Anne Robinson's remarks about the Welsh simply highlight each nation's prejudices.
fields.body:
Anne Robinson is, it seems, actually under police investigation for branding the Welsh "irritating" on the comedy show Room 101, of which the BBC delightedly scheduled a repeat last night. But the poet got there before the dominatrix:

When life fails
What's the good of going to Wales?

Auden's lines sum up a certain Anglo-Saxon attitude towards the Welsh - condescension rooted in incomprehension. The Welsh ability to charm the conqueror in word, song and play- acting gets us - and you - just so far and no further. We have a talent to amuse but also an ability to baffle.

We're told that we keep a welcome and we do genuinely want to please - honest. But then something happens, just as our dance before the conqueror's throne gets increasingly frantic. We end up hurting you. We don't mean to - but we do. And we all know that those to whom hurt is done end up wanting to hurt by return of post.

What are the Welsh for, asks Anne Robinson smarting from the memory of a childhood spent in Liverpool amid the gabby, successful Welsh. Well, one legitimate role of the small nation is to annoy big brother and cruel sister. The Welsh are the Czechs of the west - ironic, prone to compromise and enjoying a tease at the expense of them next door as long as we won't be found out.

When things get awkward it's usually because of sudden self-hatred. We've spent years stifling our yawns as you recycle the cliches of chirruping miners with their sad songs. Back home there's splendidly bosomed Mam spreading butter on the door-stopper sandwiches. Bible black towns, grey chapels controlling our naturally libidinous selves, a native poetry whose metre enforces sound over sense: ah so folklorique were our valleys.

We conspire easily with all this stuff and will even guide you with craven zeal to those castles which from Caernarfon to Caerphilly are among Europe's most powerful memorials of iron-fisted subjection. The National Eisteddfod seems invented to confirm the quaintness. Teachers and preachers, dons and farmers become druids for a week and walk around some sodden field wearing those slightly kinky white boots whose toes peep out of the flowing robes. Maids of honour cradle horns of plenty and barefoot flower girls dance. Merlin's magic can disturb. It is unsurprising that Freud's first biographer, Ernest Jones, was Welsh.

At some stage, having put a welcome on the mat, we do get a bit ... well, pissed off, frankly. We like having you here all right. You're good at business and we are as anti-business as any Spanish hidalgo. Though we like to think we're a classless lot, we also think that money is vulgar. And so, with eyes averted, we leave the counter to the crooks. South Wales business, Sicilian in its habits, is something for the outsider not the native breed.

The mat having been trampled on, you think that you're in western England. It all looks the same after all. There's the mountainous north and the pastoral south. The institutional differences are trivial. Scotland has its separate established church and legal system. But until the pygmy assembly hopped into our lives, this was the country which only survived extempore, by the skin of its teeth, by the concealed but stubborn will of the people as well as by mastery of a chronic evasiveness.

Ireland has had her hatreds to keep her alive. But the Welsh are bad haters and natural chameleons. It helps of course that there are no Welsh genocides - no Bannockburn or Drogheda to light the Armalite and pass the Semtex. And so we succumb to assimilation's charms. In the US of A we all just melted away and New York records no St David's Day parade to match St Patrick's. Far better to sit around and talk. Gossip is less bad form than a rule of Welsh life. What more natural a way of showing concern for your fellow man and woman? But this agosatrwydd or closeness, which makes the Llanelli caff a distant relation to the Beirut cafe, gets under the English skin. You are a private lot and you find us just too nosey.

Sly, too, apparently. This is when things get nasty and we show our silly sensitivity. "There is much valour in this Welshman," says Shakespeare (first minter of stage Welshmen) about Llywelyn (cheekily renamed Fluellen). Plenty of impersonators have followed Wales' Uncle Tom tradition. The caperings of gaitered Mr Speaker Thomas were the latest in a line of collaboration. But when the pretence that we're really just like you tires, you find that you're in a foreign country after all. We've been the victims of our own success in arousing unfulfillable expectations. And so - enter stage right and left - Taffy, famously a thief.

Originally, the rhyme owed more to the Prince Regent and his policy of borrowing and spending. But once attributed to the unmasked enchanter, the legend has grown in the telling. Let's face it - you're just irritated that we're not more like you. Irish and Scottish differences are discounted in advance. But this - England's oldest and weirdest colonial relationship - starts with an assumption of similarity and ends in the cold acknowledgement of a difference which is much more profound than that of our Celtic cousins.

The insults fly because you discover that the language and its code is always around you - even unspoken. We - and it - were here first you know. And the name you gave us, "Welsh", which typically we accepted, is an outrage. It's your Saxon-Germanic ancestors' word for a foreigner. You drove one lot of us to the north (Glasgow is a Welsh word) and the rest of us beyond the Severn.

It's striking how otherwise virtuous English liberals find the survival of Welsh as a language an anachronistic affront. Cymraeg is certainly an alternative reality - and one which makes for ambiguity. The survival is responsible for the very Welsh view that rules and laws are there to be superficially respected but if need arises circumnavigated, because imposed by the foreigner and therefore lacking full legitimacy. Welsh has also, alas, spawned the horrible smugness of the harp in the drawing-room classes. The Welsh-speaking bourgeoisie are surely the most self-satisfied professionals in modern Britain as they crawl conventionally from subsidised quango to broadcasting studio. They are the latest sightings of an eternal beast - the Welsh "having a word" and getting on in a one-party state whether Tory or Labour. It's one of our conceits that we're a more democratic place than England, but I'm afraid that our talent for fixing the system is - as we like to say - "outstanding" (equal emphasis on all syllables please). Thank the Lord, we are in our own delicious way a hierarchical people.

Now, there's talk of summoning the errant Robinson not only before the police but also before the Welsh select committee. The assembly where all are on first name terms (less a proof of egalitarian instinct than a demonstration of chummy exclusiveness) produces a "grand remonstrance". Oh weakest of links, get a life or even perhaps a job. You should know that you only encouraged them in their initial illusions by being so eager to please. Which is how it all started to go wrong for that old, sad, green place which some of us still call home.

webTitle: Comment: government must take on challenge of urban redevelopment

fields.headline: Dirty old towns
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: Government must take on the challenge of northern inner cities, as blighted wastelands stand cheek by jowl with up-market re-development.
fields.body:
My daily walk to work takes me from a redeveloping neighbourhood in a big northern conurbation, past rubble-strewn wastelands which housed the metal bashers and mill workers of the world's first industrial city, down eerie underpasses below expressways which plough through former communities - and into the centre itself. In barely a mile, I leave new houses valued at little more than £50,000 before hitting trendy, canal-side loft apartments which can sell for up to a £1m. Manchester city centre, like the cores of Leeds, Newcastle and - increasingly - Liverpool, is thriving. Developers are falling over themselves to buy old mills and workshops written off as worthless 10 years ago. Everyone, from exclusive retailers to expensive restaurateurs, wants in.

But, as a report undertaken for the Guardian by Professor Brian Robson of Manchester University says, cheek by jowl with the new penthouses, restaurants, and up-market stores, lies "the land of the forgotten ... the endless rows of impoverished terrace housing and half empty council housing where unemployment is horrendous, where houses sell - if at all - for under £10,000, where crime ... traps people in their homes, where drugs are common currency..."

Northern cities are increasingly characterised by the reverse of the north American "doughnut" phenomenon, in which original city centres become hollowed out and deserted. In Britain's north, vibrant rebuilt centres are surrounded by wastelands, with many trapped in a cycle of negative equity.

A long the M62 corridor, from Liverpool to Manchester and the Lancashire towns, 280,000 homes (100,000 of them private properties) are blighted, according to recent research by Birmingham University. The wider north-west already has more derelict land than anywhere else in the country - tens of thousands of acres eminently suitable for redevelopment.

Ministers are now committed to an ambitious policy of neighbourhood renewal, with a promise to pump hundreds of millions into deprived communities, linked to an array of performance targets. This all seems extremely promising. The government does take poverty seriously. But, as Brian Robson points out in his report, if government policy is now to focus on the neighbourhood and the general delivery of council services (fine for London, no doubt), it will miss some of the main causes of poverty and deprivation it is trying to ameliorate in the north.

Poor communities, he argues, do not emerge in a vacuum. Their fortunes reflect the wider economies of cities in which they exist. The challenge, then, is not to wait for that elusive "trickle down", but to act positively to channel city centre wealth to the outer ring. With government grants to town halls now skewed in favour of London and the south, because northern cities and conurbations are losing people, that task is not easy, although ministers are now - belatedly - considering switching some funds from south to north by revising a complex Whitehall spending formula. The government's equally ambitious regional agenda - creating eight development agencies (RDAs) and pushing up their budgets by £500m - has yet to have any impact because it was not quite clear what the RDAs were meant to achieve: the south-east RDA, for instance, sees its task as going for yet more growth at all costs to compete with the super-regions of Europe.

It wants to keep the big corporate headquarters, and research labs along the M4 and around Oxford, with the less-favoured regions taking the more mundane back office functions. Such a policy, not surprisingly, has pushed regions such as the north-east - and the cities of the north - further down the prosperity league table.

On the day that Professor Robson produced his report, government statisticians published even more sobering figures showing - yes -that the north-south divide had actually widened under New Labour. In its first three years, GDP per head in the north-east had fallen by a point to 23% below the national average - while London was almost 30% above. Not for nothing did the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, speak of "unacceptably wide gaps" between regions. While no one doubts his commitment to the challenge, it will take more than brave words to push provincial cities and their wider regions up the prosperity league. As Richard Rogers, chairman of the government's urban task force, recently said, this should top New Labour's agenda for a second term - with a minister for urban affairs in the cabinet. He might not have to wait too long.

webTitle: Analysis: number of women Labour  MPs to fall at election

fields.headline: Ladies first
fields.standfirst:
Unless the selection process is radically overhauled, the number of women in the parliamentary Labour party will fall at the next election

Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: Unless the selection process is radically overhauled, the number of women in the parliamentary Labour party will fall at the next election.
fields.body:
The increase in women elected to the House of Commons in May 1997 was one of the most dramatic outcomes of that election. The number of female MPs doubled from 60 to 120, 18.2% of the total. The Rubicon had been crossed, the Nuffield election study declared - finally, the cultural barriers that had so often prevented the selection of women for winnable seats had been broken. For Labour at any rate, the party's former macho outlook had been decisively weakened. In this respect, where Labour led, other parties would, whether they liked it or not, be forced to follow.

It was said. But if the improvement in women's representation was pretty much universally applauded, one of the means by which it had been achieved was not. Most of the women, 101 of them, were Labour. Of the 65 new Labour women, 35 had been selected as candidates on the basis of all-women shortlists, the party's controversial policy of positive discrimination. They had been chosen before such shortlists were ruled illegal at a Leeds industrial tribunal in January 1996.

But perhaps - it was thought after the election - all-women lists had been needed for only one parliament. Just as well: aside from the question of illegality, the policy had proved unpopular, generating divisions within the party. Tony Blair, elected leader after the initiative had been launched, was lukewarm in defending all-women shortlists, insisting that they were a one-off. Their impact was such, he asserted, they would not be needed again.

Five years on, as a new general election draws near, we have a good opportunity to assess the effect of all-women shortlists. Given the huge majority it won in May 1997, Labour does not currently have target seats in the same way that it did when in opposition. It is possible, however, to compare selections in seats already held by the party.

For the 1997 general election, Labour selected candidates for 39 seats in which a Labour MP had retired. Boundary changes made the situation a bit more complicated than usual: two constituencies were lost in the revisions, and sitting Labour MPs who needed new seats were selected in six. Of the remaining 31, 10 went to women. Selections took place in a further 12 seats created by the boundary changes that were considered to be Labour-held on a simulation of the 1992 general election. Of these seven went to women. In all, women took 17 out of 43 Labour-held seats, nearly 40%. Seven of these candidates were chosen from all-women shortlists; a further nine were chosen in open selections after the Leeds judgment.

During the present parliament, 36 Labour MPs have announced their intention to retire. Eight constituencies are in the middle of selecting candidates. To date, only three women have actually been selected to fill vacancies, in Redcar, Sheffield Heeley and East Lothian. At the same time six female Labour MPs will retire at the next election. Unless there is a dramatic change in the remaining selections, the number of women in the parliamentary Labour party will fall at the next election regardless of how many seats Labour ends up losing.

The failure of more women to be selected for Labour-held seats is all the more striking given that the party's rules insist on equal numbers of men and women (and two of each on every shortlist). Women candidates are being short-listed, but they are not being selected in the one member, one vote (Omov) ballots that take place in constituencies.

Are constituencies themselves biased? Labour adopted a policy of affirmative action for women at the 1992 general election. At that time, candidates were chosen by an electoral college rather than Omov. But where a woman was nominated, there had to be at least one woman on the shortlist. The rule had little impact: a mere 12% of selections in Labour-held seats went to female candidates, the same kind of figure that is emerging in 2001.

A disappointing comparison can also be made with the proportion of women selected for Labour-held seats before the 1987 general election. In those days, the last stand of the Bennite left, activists sitting on constituency general committees dominated selection and there was no equivalent positive discrimination towards women. Of 44 such selections in 1987, a quarter went to women.

It is possible that quotas applied at the short-listing stage, as in 1992 and 2001, have a negative impact on the number of female candidates selected. They may generate resentment against those short-listed, without ensuring, as did the all-women shortlists, that any female candidates are selected.

But whatever the reason, the claim that the outcome of the 1997 general election marked the crossing of a Rubicon now seems hopelessly optimistic. Far from marking the removal of barriers, women candidates have found it extremely difficult to get selected for Labour-held seats. The other political parties have fared no better: the Conservatives have failed to replace a single one of their 25 retiring MPs with a female candidate. A further 14 MPs from other parties are leaving the Commons (including three women): men have been selected in all cases bar one. It is unsurprising in these circumstances that the Labour leadership has indicated that it is considering a change in the law to reverse the January 1996 judgment.

Two points should be noted about any new proposal to try to boost women's numbers. First, you have to focus on the selection stage of the process in order to ensure that any target is attained. Second, while new measures need not be conceived of as permanent, it is likely, given Labour's experiences since 1997, that they will be needed for the duration of several parliaments.

 Mark Wickham-Jones is at the University of Bristol. His research will be published by the Equal Opportunities Commission later this year.

M.Wickham@bristol.ac.uk

webTitle: Trimble to lift Sinn Fein ban if weapons vow is honoured

fields.headline: Trimble to lift Sinn Fein ban if weapons vow is honoured
fields.standfirst: Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, indicated yesterday that he would soon lift his ban on Sinn Fein ministers attending North/South meetings if the IRA kept its promise to re-open serious talks with the international disarmament body.
fields.body:
The Ulster Unionist leader, David Trimble, indicated yesterday that he would soon lift his ban on Sinn Fein ministers attending North/South meetings if the IRA kept its promise to re-open serious talks with the international disarmament body.

Despite Mr Trimble's caveat that he could reinstate the veto if progress stalled, and Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams' warning that fixation on the weapons issue could sink the Northern Ireland peace process, there was a quiet sense of forward movement.

Mr Trimble told the BBC's On the Record: "The sanction is flexible and we will look carefully at what is done both with regard to lifting it but also with regard to re-imposing it if there is not a continuation of progress."

The IRA's sudden announcement that it would re-engage with General John de Chastelain's decommissioning organisation came last Thursday just before Tony Blair and the Irish premier, Bertie Ahern, hosted 12 hours of talks with all sides at Hillsborough.

At the time, Mr Trimble dismissed the statement as a "publicity stunt" but yesterday hinted he was prepared to give the provisionals some room for manoeuvre, that words could initially shift the ban, as long it was clear that action would follow.

He said that while suspension of the power-sharing executive was still an option for the prime minister, it was not in the Ulster Unionists' best interests for it to collapse, signalling he would resist any attempt by his own internal opponents to pull out of Stormont before the general election.

Mr Adams told his party in Dublin on Saturday that Sinn Fein had neither the "responsibility, the obligation, nor the desire to shepherd the IRA into disarming on Ulster Unionist or British government terms".

The step-up in terrorist activity by the Real IRA, the dissident group behind last week's BBC London bomb which is opposed to Sinn Fein's peace strategy, has heightened fears of further splits in republicanism, all but ruling out any impending move on disarmament.

Security sources are also alarmed over why provisional IRA members are on intelligence-gathering missions in England, sparking worries of a return to violence if the process fails.

webTitle: Who's who in drive to improve the tube

fields.headline: Who's who in drive to improve the tube
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: A list of the main players in London Underground's overhaul.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London since May 2000, campaigned against Labour's proposals for a public private partnership (PPP) for the tube. Under the Greater London Authority Act, the mayor is responsible for transport strategy for London. Mr Livingstone has threatened to seek a judicial review, which would coincide with the election, if the government tries to impose the original PPP.

Bob Kiley was appointed by Mr Livingstone as transport commissioner, on a package including a potential salary of £2m over four years and a £2.1m London house. Mr Kiley, an American, is credited with rescuing the dilapidated New York subway while keeping it in public ownership and raising money by issuing bonds. His detailed grasp of the complicated PPP proposals and his track record have won widespread respect.

John Prescott gave a written agreement on February 2 that the PPP could be modified to ensure Mr Kiley was given the "unified management" he said was vital to the success of the tube. But by February 28 it became clear that the Treasury rather than the DETR was pulling the strings.

Gordon Brown, whom Mr Kiley characterised as the Wizard of Oz - pulling the levers behind the scenes - believes strongly that the public sector cannot be trusted to manage big investments. The chancellor wants financial risk transferred to the private sector.

The negotiators include Mr Kiley's finance director, Jay Walder, and others with track records in rail management. The Treasury's top negotiator is Mr Brown's special adviser and former corporate financier, Shriti Vadera.

The contractors bidding to renew and maintain the system include many of the engineering firms involved in the railways, such as Balfour Beatty, and firms such as Alstom, which have already built rolling stock for the tube

webTitle: Battle over London underground is key to Labour finance policy

fields.headline: High-stakes poker on rails
fields.standfirst:
The battle between Gordon Brown and Bob Kiley over London Underground may hold key to future of New Labour finance policy

Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: The battle between Gordon Brown and Bob Kiley over London Underground may hold key to future of New Labour finance policy.
fields.body:
It is crunch time for the future of London Underground. Intense negotiations continued this weekend in the political poker game, as government officials and Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, struggled to reach agreement on how the capital's crumbling infrastructure should be funded.

The outcome will have profound implications, not just for the millions of people who depend on the tube each day, but also for the way the railways, post-Hatfield, and other public services around the country are funded and structured.

At stake are the public private partnerships (PPPs) at the heart of the New Labour project. Private investment through this form of partial privatisation is a major plank of Gordon Brown's business-friendly plan to rebuild public services. The PPP for the London Underground is the flagship.

Under it, private companies are bidding for three separate bundles of London Underground assets, with packages that include trains, track, signalling, stations and escalators, which they will be required to renew and maintain for up to 30 years. The idea is that the private companies will be paid in the form of charges for services provided to the public sector.

The operation of the underground will stay with a single public sector operating company. Once the PPP contracts are signed - the deadline, already delayed by a year, is the end of March - statutory responsibility for London Underground passes to the Greater London authority.

Showdown

The current showdown is the result of months of wrangling. In December, Mr Kiley, the American credited with resuscitating the delapidated New York subway, announced that he thought the government's PPP plans for the tube were "fatally flawed" and would be "unworkable, potentially dangerous and prohibitively expensive". The public would own the system and be responsible for operating it but would not control it.

At the same time the national audit office, parliament's financial watchdog, reported that the case for the public private partnership scheme was "clearly not proved". Jeremy Colman, assistant auditor general, said: "We are giving the government a flashing amber light."

The deputy prime minister, John Prescott, met Mr Kiley that month and they agreed to work through his concerns. Mr Kiley battled on through January, hampered by the government's refusal to make available the information he needed about the bidding for the three contracts. According to sources, he put forward several proposals and felt they were given serious consideration but only briefly. He then learned that they were being rejected each time after intervention from the Treasury.

On February 1, Mr Kiley, Mr Livingstone and Mr Prescott had a last-ditch meeting to rescue the talks. Tony Blair reportedly forced the Treasury to back off and sent Mr Prescott out to announce the climbdown. On February 2, Mr Kiley got Mr Prescott's written agreement that the PPP should be modified so that London Underground retained "unified management" of the system. After this Mr Kiley's team were given all the information they needed and progress was rapid. They met the consortia bidding for the deep line contracts and discussed revising the PPP.

But suddenly everything changed again. On February 12, the Treasury intervened. Mr Brown's special adviser, Shriti Vadera, told Mr Kiley she could not sanction public control of the tube under any circumstances. "On February 14, senior government representatives, none of whom had taken part in earlier meetings, asked for a special meeting and told Mr Kiley that the government's position was that the private sector must control the infrastructure companies and that this position was 'non negotiable'," according to Mr Kiley's report to Mr Livingstone.

The stakes were quickly raised. In a difficult two-hour meeting, Mr Prescott reminded Mr Kiley that he had the power to impose the PPP. The board of GLA's Transport for London gave Mr Kiley the go-ahead to seek a judicial review, bringing the threat of politically damaging legal action during the election campaign.

Mr Kiley attacked Mr Brown for being "the Wizard of Oz" pulling levers behind the scenes. His finance director said government proposals would cost £800m more in the first 7 years than Mr Kiley's methods of raising money, which would keep ownership in the public sector.

On February 26, Mr Blair, Mr Brown and Mr Prescott met to thrash out the issues. The result was a flurry of concessions so radical they made the bidders for the contracts squeal. Mr Kiley was offered a significant measure of board control of the three private infrastructure companies and a series of voting rights and vetoes which would give him powers over budgets and appointments. The bidders said they were unbankable. Mr Kiley's team said they missed the point.

The key issues from Mr Kiley's point of view are finance and the artifical separation of "track and wheels". "Under the PPP, maintenance is transferred to the infrastructure companies and then split three ways, with each company having a monopoly over its portion. You can't maintain safety and performance like that. If you are not blinded by ideology, that is the lesson of Hatfield," an insider said.

Mr Kiley gives another example. Under PPP, the underground's two north-south lines are parcelled out to two different companies. Bidders for the contracts say they plan major upgrade projects at the same time, with the risk that there will be no north-south tube service for an extended time. Without unified management control, Mr Kiley would be powerless to do anything about it.

Mr Kiley says the bids are very high. Because private companies get a lower credit rating than government, which cannot default, raising money through them costs much more, and the bids have simply been whacked up to cover the risk.

Price worth paying

The Treasury view is that this is a price worth paying. It is determined to avoid a repeat of the £1.5bn overrun on the Jubilee Line extension, a bill the taxpayer ended up footing.

Mr Brown wants any financial risk in what will be a £12-15bn injection of capital into the tube over the next 30 years transferred to the private sector for two main reasons. He wants to take the huge investment needed off the balance sheet and he does not trust the public sector to manage the money efficiently. Private finance initiatives and PPPs also enable the Treasury to keep the reins.

Mr Kiley argues that the transfer of risk is illusory. According to government briefings, if project costs overrun by even a modest amount, the companies could start making a loss. Not so, says Mr Kiley, because he would not be able to restrict the companies from offsetting unexpected costs by cutting down on other projects. The pressure would be to cut corners. And his right to withhold funds from the infrastructure companies for poor performance appears to be limited under the PPP to only 10% of the amount payable.

The transfer of risk amounts to a one-way bet. If economics turn against the private contractor to the point of substantial loss or making it go bust, the contract becomes unenforceable. But if they turn out better, the company takes the extra profit.

The precedents are not good. Post Hatfield, Railtrack is close to bankruptcy but the government does not have the choice of leaving the country without a functioning railway and will have to bail it out.

The signs yesterday were that Mr Kiley's worries about maintenance were being addressed but that finance was still a sticking point. The Treasury said it was optimistic of a deal which preserved the essential features of the PPP. But who concedes what will have a big impact on how effectively billions in taxpayers' money is spent.

Intense negotiations continued this weekend in the political poker game, as government officials and Ken Livingstone's transport commissioner, Bob Kiley, struggled to reach agreement on how the capital's crumbling infrastructure should be funded. The outcome will have profound implications, not just for the millions of people who depend on the tube each day, but also for the way the railways, post-Hatfield, and other public services around the country are funded and structured. At stake are the public private partnerships (PPPs) at the heart of the New Labour project. Private investment through this form of partial privatisation is a major plank of Gordon Brown's business-friendly plan to rebuild public services. The PPP for the London Underground is the flagship. Under it, private companies are bidding for three separate bundles of London Underground assets, with packages that include trains, track, signalling, stations and escalators, which they will be required to renew and maintain for up to 30 years. The idea is that the private companies will be paid in the form of charges for services provided to the public sector. The operation of the underground will stay with a single public sector operating company. Once the PPP contracts are signed - the deadline, already delayed by a year, is the end of March - statutory responsibility for London Underground passes to the Greater London authority. In December, Mr Kiley, the American credited with resuscitating the delapidated New York subway, announced that he thought the government's PPP plans for the tube were "fatally flawed" and would be "unworkable, potentially dangerous and prohibitively expensive". The public would own the system and be responsible for operating it but would not control it. webTitle: Women occupy ship in Faslane protest

fields.headline: Women occupy ship in Faslane protest
fields.trailText: A group of peace protesters were arrested yesterday after they breached security at a British military fuel depot and chained themselves to the mast of a French frigate.
fields.body:
A group of peace protesters were arrested yesterday after they breached security at a British military fuel depot and chained themselves to the mast of a French frigate.

The seven women cut through wire fencing at the depot next to the Faslane naval base on the river Clyde at around 6am.

Three of the women were arrested almost immediately, but the remaining four managed to board the French ship, the Degrasse. Ministry of Defence police arrested two of the women shortly after, but the remaining two used D-locks to chain themselves to the masts of the destroyer, some 50ft up from the deck.

As the women unfurled a banner declaring "Women of the world unite for a world without war", military police struggled to break through the D-locks. The protesters were on board for almost five hours.

A spokeswoman for the peace group said the protest had been part of the international women's day celebrations to draw attention to the "global military machine and the threat it poses to women around the world".

A spokesman for the MoD denied that the protesters' boarding of the ship was an embarrassment. "These people are fairly determined to make their point and they have done so on occasions in the past. They did not get into the base and measures were in place to deal with the problem in the depot as it arose," he said.

The protesters had been attending an anti-Trident event at Faslane peace camp over the weekend.

"We wanted to draw attention to the horrors of war and we will continue to mount protests against Trident and the violence of the global war machine," said the spokeswoman for the protesters.

In February politicians, including Labour MP George Galloway, and church ministers were among 379 people arrested during a protest outside the naval base.

webTitle: Mandelson muscles in on debate over north-south divide

fields.headline: Mandelson muscles in on debate over north-south divide
fields.standfirst: Special report: Mandelson
fields.trailText: Labour is gearing up to make an historic shift of resources from the wealthy south to the poorer northern regions of Britain amid growing concern among party strategists about apathy and disaffection among heartland voters.
fields.body:
Labour is gearing up to make an historic shift of resources from the wealthy south to the poorer northern regions of Britain amid growing concern among party strategists about apathy and disaffection among heartland voters.

As Labour's Scottish conference heard repeated warnings against apathy yesterday, it also emerged that the less-favoured regions may get another vocal backbench champion, ex-cabinet minister, Peter Mandelson, now shoring up his political base at Hartlepool on Teeside.

Downing Street last night played down a leaked memo in which Jeremy Heywood, Tony Blair's economic adviser in the cabinet secretariat, wrote of the "tough decisions" soon needed after the coming election - "if we are talking about a large shift of resources from London to the north".

But a welter of statistics have underlined the deep divisions of wealth and poverty within Britain, among the sharpest in the industrialised world, most evident in the old north-south divide despite Mr Blair's insistence - shared by the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone - that the divisions within regions are just as bad.

With Gordon Brown, the chancellor, using last week's budget to show growing confidence in openly-redistributive policies, the former Northern Ireland secretary also signalled his own determination to flag up regional disparities.

After a string of weekend constituency engagements, Mr Mandelson, who has been tipped to speak out on Downing Street's behalf on such issues as Europe, added the regions to his election agenda.

"One of the themes of the election is spreading prosperity around the country. I would like to see this become a more prominent feature of the party's campaign in the coming election because everyone has to feel they have a stake in every region, every community ... they have to feel they have a stake in the government's successes ... there are very wide disparities."

His intervention in the regional debate comes as Mr Heywood's leaked memo underlines that Downing Street is keen to find new ways of compensating underperforming regions. The key mechanism for switching resources from south to north lies in revising the standard spending assessment (SSA) formula under which Whitehall distributes grants to local councils.

Staistics show why northern cabinet ministers John Reid, Alistair Darling and Helen Liddell - all Scots - warned against Tory and Scottish nationalist efforts to derail Labour's hopes of a second term.

In Mr Blair's adopted north-east, where Mr Mandelson's seat adjoins Sedgefield, the GDP per head has dropped to 23% below the national average. Mr Mandelson can claim a track record in standing up for the region.

Schools in Labour controlled Northumberland and Mr Blair's Durham receive considerably less per pupil than richer London boroughs.

In a letter to him last year, Durham head teachers complained that school buildings were falling apart through lack of funds.

webTitle: How Tories' poll plan depends on target seats

fields.headline: How Tories' poll plan depends on target seats
fields.standfirst:
In the first of a series examining the readiness of the three main parties for the general election, Nicholas Watt gets the inside track on Conservative central office

Special report: Tories in opposition
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: In the first of a series examining the readiness of the three main parties for the general election, Nicholas Watt gets the inside track on Conservative central office.
fields.body:
A look of anger briefly flickered across the face of the normally unflappable Conservative party chairman Michael Ancram as he faced the cameras at the Tories' smart new press centre.

To his horror, the Scottish aristocrat realised that a speech by William Hague was in danger of being drowned out by loud banging and drilling from a neighbouring building site. The noise, which eventually subsided, symbolised the bleak outlook for the Tories.

To all but a tiny circle, William Hague insists that he can repeat Ted Heath's surprise 1970 election victory when he came from behind to defeat Harold Wilson. Behind the scenes, however, Mr Hague's ambitions are set on winning back enough seats to place him on course for victory at the election after next.

Shadow ministers, who admit privately that they are on course for a crushing defeat, say that Mr Hague will have achieved a reasonable result if he can win more than 230 seats, up from the 165 won in 1997. This would still hand Labour a healthy majority of 80.

For public consumption Mr Hague insists he is concentrating resources on the 180 marginal seats he must win back to give him a reasonable Commons majority. In reality the Tories will target no more than two thirds of these seats.

Central office has classified seats in three ways to ensure resources are concentrated in areas where the Tories stand a realistic chance of victory and are not wasted in hopeless areas or on seats they should win easily. Around 30 of Britain's most marginal seats have been classified as "stand alone", meaning that few resources will be sent to seats such as Torbay which the Tories will win back on a swing of less than 1%.

The next rung of seats, classified as target constituencies, will receive the bulk of central office resources. Expect to see plenty of shadow cabinet ministers popping up in seats such as Wimbledon - 43rd on the target list - which the Tories would win on a swing of 3.3%.

The final set of constituencies are known as "majority seats", covering Tory seats the party will easily hold or Labour seats that will never change hands. A twinning system, designed to ensure that resources are not wasted, demonstrates how the leadership has abandoned all hope of victory. Exeter, officially on the target list, has been twinned with the nearby Tory-held seat of Teignbridge, which is regarded as vulnerable to a Liberal Democrat challenge.

The campaign in the target seats is largely being run from central office because of fears that the Tories do not have enough footsoldiers to mount a proper nationwide campaign. Lord Ashcroft's millions have been spent setting up a call centre, with a bank of 60 computer screens, on the third floor from where more than a million swing voters will be contacted by polling day.

A system of demographic profiling has been used to identify 2.5m swing voters in the 180 target seats. They were chosen by a computer that monitored personal details, such as cars, income, house, age and number of children.

Staff in the call centre, who are reinforced by volunteers and the odd MP, are calling 15,000 voters a week; by the end of February the Tories had targeted every swing voter in 30 target seats. Callers ask voters what issues matter to them. If they say education, a letter signed by Mr Hague is dispatched within days setting out the Tories' policies and attacking the government.

Call centre staff, who only have to identify themselves as Tories if asked, tell most voters that they are calling "on behalf of one of the major political parties". Most voters do not ask which party is calling, allowing the call centre to make a realistic assessment of their voting intentions. Tories took heart after the first 100,000 voters indicated that they were more likely to vote Tory. The unofficial survey put the Tories on 28%, Labour on 26%, with at least 25% undecided.

Central office has relentlessly spun the results in recent weeks, claiming that they show the national polls are wrong and make clear that nearly a third of the country's votes are still up for grabs. The spinners gloss over the fact that the survey was carried out in the most marginal of seats.

When Tony Blair finally heads off to Buckingham Palace, to ask the Queen for the dissolution of parliament, the main centre of activity in central office will move down a floor to the 60-strong war room. Under posters of Peter Mandelson and John Prescott, with their heads placed on sticks, staff will direct the campaign from two 30-day grids, one of which ends on an April 5 polling day and the other on May 3.

The grids map out the activities of every member of the shadow cabinet at 15-minute intervals throughout the 30-day campaign. Mr Hague's campaign will concentrate on the target seats, which he will visit by plane, train, helicopter, car and bus. Unlike John Major, who fronted most of the Tories' morning press conferences in 1997, Mr Hague will attend only half of the briefings to allow him to concentrate on his nationwide tour.

"We want to get our message out of London," one aide said. That message is likely to become shriller by the day - following on from Mr Hague's "foreign land" speech - as he attempts to shore up the Tories' core vote. Mr Hague will kick off every day of the campaign at central office with a 7.30am meeting with his key advisers. This will be attended by his aide, Lord Coe; his chief researcher, Rick Nye, who will liaise with the Tories' Yellow M advertising agency; his speechwriters, the Ulster expert Jonathan Cain, the fervent Eurosceptic Daniel Hannan and the former ministerial adviser Greg Clark; his main press advisers, Nick Wood and Amanda Platell; and the senior shadow cabinet ministers Michael Ancram, Andrew Lansley, Michael Portillo and Francis Maude.

After the meeting Mr Hague will either attend the Tories' main 9.30am press conference or hit the campaign trail, accompanied by his wife Ffion, Lord Coe and his press minders for the tour, the cerebral Ed Young and a formidable Australian, Nicol Hughes. He will perform for the cameras in time for the lunchtime television bulletins, followed by another event, at a different location, in the afternoon. There will be 11 evening rallies throughout the campaign. Mr Hague will be back in London by 9pm on most days for another short meeting to review the day and look forward to the next.

In Mr Hague's absence from central office, four members of the shadow cabinet will front the Tory campaign in London. Mr Portillo and Mr Maude, who are to share a desk in the war room, will take it in turns to front the main press conference to field questions on policy. When one is in London, the other will hit the campaign trail.

Mr Ancram and Mr Lansley will take it in turns acting as chief spokesman for the campaign. Rather than fielding questions on policy, they will be on hand to deal with any Tory crises. Their faces are likely to become regular features on the 7pm Channel 4 news, not least when pro-European Tory MPs publish election addresses that contradict Mr Hague's hardline policy on the euro. They, too, will hit the campaign trail on alternate days, joining the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, and the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, who have been banished from London.

All their campaigning efforts will be directed from the war room which, under the direction of the former Times journalist Nick Wood, has been set out along the lines of a newsroom. The room is dominated by a "newsdesk", run by the bright young Enfield councillor Jonathan French, which handles all incoming calls.

The war room, which will run on a 24-hour shift system, will be in three main areas. The Portillo favourites, Malcolm Gooderham and David Maudsley, will run the treasury desk, which covers areas such as education. Across the room, Adam Newton will run the home affairs desk, which covers areas such as education. In the corner, a former Times foreign correspondent, Bob Sealey, will run the foreign affairs desk.

Like their counterparts down the road at Labour's Millbank headquarters, the war room is run by young staffers whose average age is 25. They will be sustained by endless supplies of takeaway pizzas. The odd tipple will be allowed, though nobody thinks champagne will be flowing on election night.

Under posters of Peter Mandelson and John Prescott, with their heads placed on sticks, staff will direct the campaign from two 30-day grids, one of which ends on an April 5 polling day and the other on May 3. The grids map out the activities of every member of the shadow cabinet at 15-minute intervals throughout the 30-day campaign. Mr Hague's campaign will concentrate on the target seats, which he will visit by plane, train, helicopter, car and bus. Unlike John Major, who fronted most of the Tories' morning press conferences in 1997, Mr Hague will attend only half of the briefings to allow him to concentrate on his nationwide tour. "We want to get our message out of London," one aide said. That message is likely to become shriller by the day - following on from Mr Hague's "foreign land" speech - as he attempts to shore up the Tories' core vote. Mr Hague will kick off every day of the campaign at central office with a 7.30am meeting with his key advisers. This will be attended by his aide, Lord Coe; his chief researcher, Rick Nye, who will liaise with the Tories' Yellow M advertising agency; his speechwriters, the Ulster expert Jonathan Cain, the fervent Eurosceptic Daniel Hannan and the former ministerial adviser Greg Clark; his main press advisers, Nick Wood and Amanda Platell; and the senior shadow cabinet ministers Michael Ancram, Andrew Lansley, Michael Portillo and Francis Maude. After the meeting Mr Hague will either attend the Tories' main 9.30am press conference or hit the campaign trail, accompanied by his wife Ffion, Lord Coe and his press minders for the tour, the cerebral Ed Young and a formidable Australian, Nicol Hughes. He will perform for the cameras in time for the lunchtime television bulletins, followed by another event, at a different location, in the afternoon. There will be 11 evening rallies throughout the campaign. Mr Hague will be back in London by 9pm on most days for another short meeting to review the day and look forward to the next. In Mr Hague's absence from central office, four members of the shadow cabinet will front the Tory campaign in London. Mr Portillo and Mr Maude, who are to share a desk in the war room, will take it in turns to front the main press conference to field questions on policy. When one is in London, the other will hit the campaign trail. Mr Ancram and Mr Lansley will take it in turns acting as chief spokesman for the campaign. Rather than fielding questions on policy, they will be on hand to deal with any Tory crises. Their faces are likely to become regular features on the 7pm Channel 4 news, not least when pro-European Tory MPs publish election addresses that contradict Mr Hague's hardline policy on the euro. They, too, will hit the campaign trail on alternate days, joining the shadow home secretary, Ann Widdecombe, and the shadow defence secretary, Iain Duncan Smith, who have been banished from London. All their campaigning efforts will be directed from the war room which, under the direction of the former Times journalist Nick Wood, has been set out along the lines of a newsroom. The room is dominated by a "newsdesk", run by the bright young Enfield councillor Jonathan French, which handles all incoming calls. The war room, which will run on a 24-hour shift system, will be in three main areas. The Portillo favourites, Malcolm Gooderham and David Maudsley, will run the treasury desk, which covers areas such as education. Across the room, Adam Newton will run the home affairs desk, which covers areas such as education. In the corner, a former Times foreign correspondent, Bob Sealey, will run the foreign affairs desk. Like their counterparts down the road at Labour's Millbank headquarters, the war room is run by young staffers whose average age is 25. They will be sustained by endless supplies of takeaway pizzas. The odd tipple will be allowed, though nobody thinks champagne will be flowing on election night.

fields.headline: Hague poll rating slumps
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: William Hague's increasingly provocative use of language in recent speeches may be prompted by growing desperation at his failure to make a personal impact on voters, a poll suggested yesterday.
fields.body:
William Hague's increasingly provocative use of language in recent speeches may be prompted by growing desperation at his failure to make a personal impact on voters, a poll suggested yesterday.

As Francis Maude, the shadow foreign secretary, was forced to deny suggestions that Mr Hague's "foreign land" speech last weekend betrayed an underlying racism, a poll for BBC Online revealed that the Tory leader's standing as best potential prime minister had slipped 8% in a month to 14%, just 1% ahead of Charles Kennedy. The poll of 1,032 voters was conducted by ICM, the Conservatives' own pollster as well as the Guardian's, after Mr Hague's Harrogate speech and the Budget.

Its findings, including Tony Blair's dominant position (on 47%), chime with other polls. Gallup gave the prime minister a 49%-19%-13% lead over his rivals earlier this month. It It gives Mr Blair the all-clear to stage a May 3 election: 63% say he should do so despite the foot and mouth crisis.

Mr Hague attacked the government last week not just for allegedly turning Britain into a "foreign land", but also on "stealth taxes" and cronyism. Despite his vivid language, he found himself condemned, even by the Sun. His mistake was to link Europe and the single currency with the asylum issue. It allowed both Michael Heseltine and Robin Cook to deplore insular xenophobia. On BBC1's Breakfast with Frost yesterday Mr Maude said: "I know no one less racist than William Hague. I think that is an error of interpretation. It certainly wasn't intended."

Mr Hague's personal tolerance is widely accepted. But, as Enoch Powell (also no racist according to those who knew him best) found to his cost, language that can give comfort to racists requires politicians to use it with exceptional care.

What his leader was trying to say, Mr Maude said yesterday, was that "he is on to something really serious, which is this government's dislike of what is the essence of this country, with it being British, they want it to be something else". That was why ministers had been "so cavalier about casually dismantling so many of the things they make Britain distinctive" since May 1 1997, which they likened to "day zero", Mr Maude protested.

That charge might one day resonate. But the BBC/ICM poll found that, even on Europe, 34% of voters think Labour can best protect Britain's interests, compared with 30% for the Tories, a slide of 7% for Mr Hague. The government is well ahead on law and order, by 35% to 22%, and transport, by 36% to 10%. On asylum, Labour has cut the Tory lead to just 2%.

webTitle: Catholic bar to throne 'must be ended'

fields.headline: Catholic bar to throne 'must be ended'
fields.trailText: The government's senior law officer gave his backing at the weekend to the Guardian's campaign to end the ban on Roman Catholics succeeding to the throne.
fields.body:
The government's senior law officer gave his backing at the weekend to the Guardian's campaign to end the ban on Roman Catholics succeeding to the throne.

Lord Williams of Mostyn, the attorney general, said the Act of Settlement 1701, which bars Catholics and other non-Protestants from the line of succession, was discriminatory and should be amended.

Last December, the attorney general refused to give the Guardian assurances that its editor, Alan Rusbridger, would not be prosecuted under the Treason Felony Act 1848 if the paper campaigned for repeal of the Act of Settlement and a referendum on the abolition of the monarchy.

The attorney general declined to "take action which sanctions in advance conduct which may be criminal".

The Treason Felony Act makes it a serious offence, punishable by life imprisonment, to call for an end to the monarchy, even by peaceful means.

The Guardian filed a claim with the high court last month challenging the act, under the Human Rights Act, as a violation of the right to free speech. The paper plans next to challenge the Act of Settlement as a breach of another human right - that of freedom of thought, conscience and religion.

In an interview with the Daily Telegraph, the attorney general insisted he did not want a republic, but believed the institution should be reformed.

Like the Guardian, he considered the Act of Settlement discriminated against women by giving sons precedence in the line of succession and by stipulating that the monarch had to be the eldest son.

Asked about removing the ban on Catholics, he replied: "My personal view is that there should not be any such bar."

Reform of the act would raise questions about the monarch's role as head of the Church of England. Lord Williams said he favoured a debate on the Anglican church's role as official state religion.

"I am a member of the Church in Wales, which has been disestablished since the 1920s and it works very well. It's healthy to have a debate about this in a community which now has many different faiths."

The Act of Settlement also prohibits the sovereign from marrying a Catholic. The act was passed at a time of political crisis, at the dawn of the 18th century, when there was a widespread fear of Catholics.

webTitle: Two pro-hunting Labour MPs on extremists' hit list

fields.headline: Two pro-hunting Labour MPs on extremists' hit list
fields.standfirst: Special report: the hunting debate
fields.trailText: Two Labour MPs are taking extra security measures on the advice of police after their names were found on an animal extremists' hit list because of their support for hunting.
fields.body:
Two Labour MPs are taking extra security measures on the advice of police after their names were found on an animal extremists' hit list because of their support for hunting.

As the government's controversial bill arrives in the Lords tonight for a formal second reading, Kate Hoey, the sports minister, and Llin Golding, the MP for Newcastle-under-Lyme in Staffordshire, have been told to check for explosives beneath their cars and to scrutinise their post for suspicious devices.

The two women do not support a ban on hunting.

When the bill begins its committee stage on March 26 a cross-party alliance of peers, including up to 70 Labour lords, is expected to back the "middle way" option, which would allow hunting to continue amid tight controls.

The police warning comes amid fears that animal activists are employing increasingly violent tactics, including nail bombs and attacks on scientists. Last month there was a suspicious fire in the Commons office of social security minister Jeff Rooker, who also opposes a hunting ban.

Ms Hoey, the MP for Vauxhall and a defender of fox hunting, said that she was not worried about the threats, but admitted that she was being careful. "All of us in public life get nasty letters and threats and so on," she said. "But I'm quite confident what I'm saying and doing is right and I'm not really worried about this sort of thing."

Ms Golding said she returned home to find a coffin in her garden with an effigy of a dead huntsman and a skull placed on it. The garden was littered with tombstones and anti-hunting banners. The activists had targeted her home a couple of months after she was widowed.

"It was just awful and unbelievably intimidating," she said. "They are evil and sick. It is important that people do not give in to them."

She would not discuss the advice she had been given by police, but she said she was not frightened. "These people have no thought for what they do. They don't care if they injure the postmen or anyone else who is not involved," she said.

"I am sure we have been targeted because we are women and most of these people are bullying men," she added.

The attacks did not make her any less determined in her opinion about hunting. She believes she has been singled out because she is co-chairman of the parliamentary middle way group, which is promoting strict regulation of hunting as an alternative to an outright ban.

Concerns have been mounting in policing circles about the increasing militancy of animal rights activists. In recent months packages containing nail bombs were sent to 10 targets across the country ranging from pet shops to estate agents and a pest control firm. An employee of an estate agency in East Yorkshire suffered serious facial and eye injuries from a nail bomb. Nine police forces, including Scotland Yard's anti-terrorist squad and M15, were involved in the search for the bombers. Three people from Crewe in Cheshire were arrested over the bombings.

Last month, Brian Cass, the managing director of the Huntingdon Life Sciences research laboratory, was attacked by a group of animal activists wearing balaclavas. He escaped with minor head injuries but was badly shaken.

The Animal Liberation Front said it would neither condemn nor condone the extremists who targeted the MPs. A spokesman said they fully understood the anger and frustration that led people to take this kind of action. He claimed the Labour party had failed to keep all the pledges it made to animal rights campaigners in the run-up to the election.

The list of targets was likely to have been drawn up by two extreme groups which advocate violence, the Animal Rights Militia and the Justice Department.

fields.headline: Foreign Office denies Cook lied
fields.standfirst:
Minister misled Commons three times on arms affair, book claims
Special report: Sierra Leone
fields.trailText: The Foreign Office last night angrily repudiated claims that Robin Cook had lied to the Commons three times about media coverage of the arms-to-Sierra-Leone affair, and rejected Tory demands for his resignation.
fields.body:
The Foreign Office last night angrily repudiated claims that Robin Cook had lied to the Commons three times about media coverage of the arms-to-Sierra-Leone affair, and rejected Tory demands for his resignation.

In a new book on the Labour media machine, Nicholas Jones, a veteran BBC political correspondent, claims that Mr Cook rang him in person to bully him into giving more favourable coverage and then lied on three occasions to parliament, denying any such activity.

Though Mr Jones's own version of events appears to provide Mr Cook with an escape clause, the charges angered some opposition MPs enough to prompt the shadow foreign secretary, Francis Maude, to write to Tony Blair.

Only days after Sir Anthony Hammond cleared Peter Mandelson and Keith Vaz in the Hinduja passport affair, Mr Maude demanded an investigation into whether Mr Cook broke the ministerial code of conduct - and his dismissal if he had.

The allegations, which sought to revive the 1998-99 "cover-up" controversy about Sandline mercenaries' covert role in Sierra Leone's running civil war, hinge on three answers Mr Cook gave to MPs, one written, one in an oral statement and the third in evidence to a select committee.

In all three he insisted "there was no briefing, no leak to the press in advance of publication" of a critical report on the "appalling failure" of the FO crisis management, published on February 9 1999 by the Labour-controlled Commons foreign affairs committee.

On reading the written answer to the Tory MP David Wilshire, Mr Jones writes that he felt disbelief. "Not only had [John] Williams [Mr Cook's spokesman] been in touch with me an hour before the report was released, but Cook himself spoke to me nearly two hours before the embargo was lifted."

Mr Jones felt that the answer was "categorical" and did not even try to sidestep the potential problem. But it contained what may prove a crucial get-out clause for Mr Cook.

In two of the three replies he admitted his department had acted in a limited way, "in response to leaks by others to the press" - specifically hostile stories in two newspapers which may have helped inform Mr Jones's own account.

As later emerged, a version of the MPs' report had been leaked to the FO by Ernie Ross, a Labour MP who later resigned from the committee. Opposition MPs were furious and accused Mr Cook and his aides of trying to pre-empt criticism.

"Robin Cook is a very vain and self-important man. This committee was going to be very critical of him personally, and he hated that, so he was prepared to do anything," said Mr Maude.

His attack was prompted by the verbatim account, carried in Mr Jones's new book, Control Freaks, of a telephone conversation between him and Mr Cook at 8.12am on the day the report came out.

That was shortly after the BBC reporter's speculative predictions on the report's contents had been broadcast - minutes after embargoed copies had been issued (at 8am) but two hours before of ficial publication at 10am. Mr Jones, who has now written four books on New Labour's spin doctors, reveals that he was asked to telephone Mr Cook. Since he had not solicited the call, he felt under no obligation to accept the foreign secretary's initial insistence "I'm talking to you off the record", or his parting shot: "Remember, this conversation didn't take place."

In between he demanded a more "balanced" account of the report, including praise of his own "unprecedented openness". In the Mail on Sunday Mr Jones noted that Mr Cook's meticulous grasp of a detailed report 12 minutes after obtaining his official copy "suggested remarkable powers of concentration". In effect, his case is that Mr Cook not only read the leaked text but ac tively briefed him, contrary to his three assurances.

The FO last night insisted that some officials, including Mr Williams, had read the Ross leak - though not Mr Cook - and that his knowledge was based on a three-page summary given to him at 8am.

"There was no lie, there is no breach of the ministerial code, there is no story," said a Foreign Office spokesman.

webTitle: Ministry under fire as foot and mouth spreads

fields.headline: Ministry under fire as disease spreads
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The foot and mouth crisis engulfing Britain escalated alarmingly yesterday as the government reported a record rise in cases for one day.
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis engulfing Britain escalated alarmingly yesterday as the government reported a record rise in cases for one day.

The increase of 25 outbreaks brought the total of cases to 164 and prompted renewed criticism of the government and calls for the army to be brought in to dispose of infected carcasses.

Ireland's natural resources minister, Hugh Byrne, accused Britain of "totally mishandling" the situation.

He told the BBC: "They seem to have been of the opinion that this disease was just going to go away."

The Conservative agriculture spokesman, Tim Yeo, said the situation was approaching a national emergency and urged the government to call in the army to help incinerate slaughtered animals, although Ministry of Agriculture officials said that the current arrangements for disposal were adequate.

Nick Brown, the minister of agriculture, said he was "absolutely certain" that matters were under control and that the government's draconian restrictions on movement would curb the outbreak.

"I know it's hard, I know it's disruptive, but this is the right thing to do," he told reporters. "All the outbreaks trace back to the original source of infectivity - of course there are more than we would have hoped for, but it doesn't undermine the overall strategy."

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, admitted that experts had been taken by surprise by the "very rapid spread" of the disease.

Yesterday's cases included outbreaks in Cumbria, Devon, Gloucestershire, Scotland and Powys.

webTitle: Brown turns his gaze to EU productivity

fields.headline: Brown turns his gaze to EU productivity
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown must be bored. As if spawning a thousand policy initiatives to improve British productivity weren't enough to keep him busy, the chancellor has turned his gaze on Europe's record for economic efficiency and he does not like what he sees.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown must be bored. As if spawning a thousand policy initiatives to improve British productivity weren't enough to keep him busy, the chancellor has turned his gaze on Europe's record for economic efficiency and he does not like what he sees.

Output per worker is lower in Europe than in America and there are fewer able bodied people in jobs. A Treasury paper published today notes that if Europe could match the US record on productivity and employment, economic output would be 40% higher.

At the Stockholm European Council later this month, Britain will have a chance to present its vision of how to close the gap. Mr Brown wants Europe to match US spending on research and development, to complete the single market, and to become a world leader in the new e-economy.

R&D spending in Europe is only 1.8% of output, compared to 2.7% in the US. Mr Brown's idea is a tax credit to subsidise companies' research spending. That will require changes in EU rules prohibiting state subsidies to industry. It is one of Britain's priorities for Stockholm. Extending the single market in financial services and energy is another priority. The Treasury wants more action on removing cross border barriers to pension funds

At last year's Lisbon summit, member states committed themselves to making Europe the world's leading knowledge based economy. There's a long way to go, according to the Treasury. Half the US population has internet access, compared to just over a third of Britons. The hi-tech sector accounted for 7.6% of US output last year, compared to 5% for the EU.

Even the Treasury admits Britain is unlikely to achieve agreement on meeting all these goals at Stockholm. The Lamfalussy report which recommended accelerating the completion of the single market in financial services was accepted by all members last month, while things are moving in the right direction on the R&D agenda, according to a senior Treasury official. But Britain faces opposition from France on moves to extend competition in energy and rail services.
