webTitle: Tory right out for Hague's blood

fields.headline: Tory right out for Hague's blood
fields.trailText: April 29 1999: Latest eruption over attempt to rewrite Thatcher line on public spending shows weakness of leader's position
fields.body:
It was quite like old times at Conservative Party headquarters in Westminster yesterday as senior shadow ministers struggled to paper over ideological division, backstairs intrigue and a muddled message to voters.

The Tory chairman, Michael Ancram, had to explain the overnight departure of a senior party official caught leaking an early draft of Peter Lilley's controversial public services speech the previous week. Francis Maude, the hitherto hardline shadow chancellor, had to explain why he is now backing Gordon Brown's once 'reckless' £40bn spending plans for health and education.

Muddle

And the redoubtable Ann Widdecombe, shadow health secretary, tried to allay the fears expressd by voters to pollsters and election canvassers. The NHS really is 'safe with us', she insisted despite her widely reported dismay over Mr Lilley's speech, which seemed to reject the very private sector options she is championing for the NHS.

What a magnificent Major-ish muddle! All this just eight days before crucial mid-term elections which could seal William Hague's fate as a doomed leader. It is also just three days short of the second anniversary of Tony Blair's 1997 election landslide a humiliation which should have taught the Tories the price of self-indulgence and incompetence. Instead they started biting lumps out of each other as they used to do over Europe. What on earth has happened in the past week to create a damaging row?

If we believe Miss Widdecombe's magnificent explosion of frustration, caught by TV news cameras yesterday, it is a storm in a tea cup over 'an exercise in semantics' which obscured the real issue: the party's determination to concede that they must allay voters' fears about its commitment to taxpayer-funded schools, GPs and hospitals before 'moving on" to a mature debate on how they can be improved.

It was wishful thinking. The row started with party officials briefing favoured reporters on Sunday April 18 on the Lilley speech due two days later as a major policy shift, 'our version of (Blair's) Clause 4', said one. Unfortunately this absurd comparison (Blair had spent months campaigning on his historic change) was not only over-spun, it was also news to most of the shadow cabinet.

Not to all of them. The Hague inner circle, people like Ancram, Maude and chief whip, James Arbuthnot, had been shown the Lilley draft. So had Widdecombe because the speech crossed her territory. She had demanded changes, some of which were made. But Michael Howard, John Redwood, clever Iain Duncan Smith (Thatcher's latest blue-eyed boy) and other heavyweights, all years older than the leader, were not squared.

Even Sir Norman Fowler, whom Margaret Thatcher required to examine private finance options (he rejected them) for the NHS when he was health secretary in the early 80s, was unconsulted and annoyed. 'These services should basically remain publicly funded, but that does not mean we should not be looking for key word 'additional' resources from the private sector, especially when Labour is now talking about public/private partnerships,' he later told colleagues.

In other words, Lilley, the shadow cabinet's boffin, had got it wrong. But what exactly? In his crucial passage at the Carlton Club, Lilley thought he had done a classic bit of Haguery 'concede and move on" by saying the Tories had made mistakes but had now 'listened to Britain.'

Focus groups

"We all accept, and have done for 50 years, that the public services cannot be left to the free market in practice. But some [Conservatives] seem to believe that maybe they could in theory," he said. In other words Tories nearly doubled NHS spending in real terms from 1979 to 1997 but never got the credit because voters suspected they would privatise it if they could work out how to.

Correct and Mr Ancram confirmed yesterday that voters (and focus groups) still suspect that in this spring's elections. Hence the Lilley speech, hence Miss Widdecombe's six-point 'Health Guarantee" swamped by the row yesterday. All Lilley had failed to do was acknowledge that pri vate insurance, charges and other ways of drumming up extra cash could have a role to play in health provision and education (after all, Labour dared bring in student tuition fees), as he conceded they would in pensions and long-term care.

In a confident party, feeling itself to be on the mend, it should not have caused a row. But the right was livid. "Risk-takers humiliated by the risk-averse crowd around Hague," said one MP. The insult was compounded by the coincidence that the deed was done on the night of the dinner to mark the 20th anniversary of Thatcher's election.

She was offended. 'Livid' said aides, on the record. But then she always is. Disappointed in her own children she is persistently disappointed in her political ones as well. Because so many Tories see hers as the Golden Age of free market certainty, they turn nostalgically to her for guidance. She always loathed the socialist NHS but was too smart to offend Middle England affection for it. Her malign instinct is to cry 'Betrayal' at every turn.

Stern

So she did now, joined, inevitably, by Lord Tebbit. In shadow cabinet next day, Michael Howard, soon to quit and with nothing to lose, wagged a stern finger at Hague. Yet all Hague was doing was, yet again, trying to get out from under Thatcher's shadow, to be socially more liberal (inclusive for gays and minorities) and economically more pragmatic about what works best through taxes, not markets.

When Hague wrote a Times article on Friday 'he said what Lilley meant to say', as one critic put it: partnership and additionality were the key concepts. He did it again at a Euro-fundraiser last night.

But the damage has been done. When Michael Simmonds, the ex-BBC Tory marketing chief, was found (via an e-mail trace) to have leaked proof of the row to the Times, where his brother-in-law writes leaders, the blood flowed again.

With a week to polling day, Labour, laughing its collective socks off yesterday, looks united, the Tories look a shambles and the murmurs that Hague is a dead duck 'not our Neil Kinnock, but our Michael Foot' start resurfacing at Westminster. His best protection is the lack of obvious successors, apart from the Europhile Ken Clarke, whom the party will not have, though some desperate souls are wavering.

The unkindest cut of all is Labour's. Party strategists are eyeing the 25 most vulnerable Tory seats for an election probably only two years away. Halfway through the 1997 parliament Conservative MPs are contemplating the unthinkable, that they could do even worse next time.

Key players

Peter Lilley, 55: Thatcherite highbrow who salami-cut social security spending in the 1990s. Failed to make an impact as shadow chancellor, so shunted off to run the Tory policy rethink. Last week's speech tried to reassure voters on health and education, but angered free market Tories.

Francis Maude, 45: shadow chancellor and clever ex-banker, usually on the right of most shadow cabinet battles. Lambasted Gordon Brown for 'going soft on spending' last July. He now promises to spend the same £40bn on schools and NHS, after focus groups show voters mistrust Tories. Kitchen cabinet insider, loyal to Hague now, but could one day challenge his leadership.

Michael Howard, 57: set to step down as foreign affairs spokesman in July reshuffle, but still a powerful player. He angrily wagged his finger at Hague in shadow cabinet over Lilley's anti-Thatcherite heresies, but later conceded Tories 'made the right decision' to pick Hague, not him. Ann Widdecombe and Iain Duncan Smith take similar line.

Michael Ancram, 53: genial Tory lawyer with common touch, despite being heir to ancient Scots earldom. Currently Tory chairman, responsible for bringing Hague pollsters bad news from voters: 'concede and move on' is his motto. Insider and Hague loyalist, ideological moderate, surrounded by core of ex-SDP officials at party HQ.

Kenneth Clarke, 58: the man Hague defeated for the Tory leadership has said nothing in the present row. As the minister who tried to be 'tough and tender" to NHS and schools he doesn't need to. Still hopes the party will turn to him if the crisis deepens. His uncompromising pro-Europeanism remains a major barrier, but some desperate Tory rightwingers are now wavering.

webTitle: Leader: Three simple ways to lessen the plight of the poor

fields.headline: Poorest of the poor
fields.standfirst: Three simple ways to lessen their plight
fields.trailText: The Budget is over, but the election manifesto is still to come. There are three simple reforms which Labour members should insist on the party adopting.
fields.body:
True to their altruistic reputation, Guardian readers have been inundating our letters column with details of how far Gordon Brown's Budget fell short of help for the poorest of the poor. They are right. The poorest of the poor, as we noted last Thursday, received little help from the chancellor. Because their benefits are linked to prices not earnings, they will have to watch an already shameful gap between the richest and poorest 10% grow even wider. The poorest are people without work - unemployed or chronically sick - and without children.

The overwhelming proportion of the extra aid which Labour has provided through its imaginative anti-poverty programmes has gone to working families - or "hard-working families" in current ministerial jargon. No one can dispute the way this has lifted 1.2m children and 800,000 adults out of poverty. But as we noted last week, this still leaves 3m children and many more adults below the poverty line - twice the level when Labour was last in power. Yet Labour did not just promise to help the poor by assisting them into work. Its famous mantra ("work for those who can, security for those who can't") also promised to help the unemployed. What can be done? The Budget is over, but the election manifesto is still to come. There are three simple reforms which Labour members should insist on the party adopting.

First, an earnings index for income support benefits in order to prevent inequality widening. Second, help for the poorest pensioners. They are being aided by the chancellor already. His minimum income guarantee (MIG), which has been given an earnings index, lifts the April single pension of £72.50 by £20 and a couple's basic pension of £115.90 by £25. But why not restore what they have lost since Margaret Thatcher broke the earnings link in 1981? That has cost every single pensioner £30 a week, and a couple £45. MIG should be lifted to these levels. Third, restore the old role of the social fund, set up to meet emergency needs of the poor (a cooker, bed or furniture). The Tories ended the grant system and insisted that loans become the main source of help - despite the desperate plight of applicants. This is plunging poor people into even further debt. Labour's social justice commission described the system as "soul destroying". Labour condemned the loans. It should have restored grants long ago.


Bristol university centre for the study of social exclusion

webTitle: Mancini in new study of David

fields.headline: Mancini in new study of David
fields.trailText: Is Roberto Mancini the new David Platt? Consider the evidence: when the inexperienced Platt took charge of Sampdoria - minus the requisite Italian coaching certificate - Serie A coaches rose as one to condemn the appointment. Within weeks Platt's team were looking bemused by his tactics. Within months they were relegated.
fields.body:
Is Roberto Mancini the new David Platt? Consider the evidence: when the inexperienced Platt took charge of Sampdoria - minus the requisite Italian coaching certificate - Serie A coaches rose as one to condemn the appointment. Within weeks Platt's team were looking bemused by his tactics. Within months they were relegated.

Two years later, history is starting to repeat itself with another inexperienced coach, Roberto Mancini. Like Platt, Mancini is taking charge at Fiorentina without the required coaching certificate. What's more, he has already irritated his players - notably Rui Costa - by switching to a 4-4-2 formation. And worse still, the ex-Leicester City striker comes into the job knowing that Serie A coaches have risen like senate leaders under Julius Caesar in fury at his appointment.

In fairness it's not Mancini's fault. Last week the Italian Federcalcio temporary commissioner Gianni Petrucci, decided to toss out the sacred Serie A rule that prohibits anyone coaching more than one side a season, to allow Mancini - who was no.2 to Sven-Goran Eriksson at Lazio - to take charge in Florence. It's a move that hasn't impressed his counterparts.

Bari coach Eugenio Fascetti has threatened to go on strike, claiming: "In the face of such a decision you don't have to twiddle your thumbs - we could take some action, such as going on strike."

"Certainly if I used to regard myself as an unleashed dog, from now on I will be even more wild," he added, ominously.

And Parma coach Renzo Ulivieri, whose side face Fiorentina in the Coppa Italia final, was also quick to complain, saying: "I don't want to play against Roberto Mancini's Fiorentina," he said. "The Italian Cup started with one set of rules, I feel cheated if they change them during the competition."

Fortunately for Viola fans, not everything about Mancini's Fiorentina is similar to Platt's Sampdoria. After going 2-0 down away at Perugia after goals from Marco Di Loreto and Fabio Liverani, the Viola displayed a virtue that Platt's Sampdoria rarely showed: fighting spirit.

Enrico Chiesa pulled it back to 2-1 after 56 minutes with a superb back-post volley and ten minutes later Ivory Coast defender Saliou Lassissi equalised with a powerful header. Fiorentina are now just seven points off the drop - but despite their recent poor run they should be too good to go down.

Roma roll on

Look all you want for signs that Roma might be faltering: you won't find them. Yesterday Fabio Capello's notched up their seventh successive Serie A win - a club record.

It wasn't the most impressive of performances, but two goals from Vincenzo Montella and a Marcos Assuncao free-kick brought them a comfortable 3-1 win at home to Brescia.

"Montella is showing how good he is, scoring five times in the last three matches," Capello said afterwards. "To those who claim Roma are going to send Montella away at the end of the season, I say that I think a team like Roma, who play to win as much as possible, in Italy as well in Europe, need several good players. And Montella is one of them."

Elsewhere there was more good news for Roma as Lazio lost 2-0 away at Bologna. A 19th minute volley from Carlo Nervo opened the scoring before Beppe Signori made the game safe 14 minutes from time.

"I am a Lazio supporter for 32 games out of 34 in a season - but for the other two I have to support Bologna," Signori said afterwards. The result now leaves leaves Lazio eleven points behind Roma.

Juventus kept up the pressure with an unconvincing 1-0 home win at Reggina, but afterwards coach Carlo Ancelotti admitted his side hadn't played well. "I think it was just a bad day," he insisted. "We are not in crisis."

Meanwhile Capello has warned his increasingly impressive Roma side to be vigilant. "Since I used to be a Juventus player, I know that Juventus have always had a great mentality," he said. "They are used to winning and to keep going until the end. But, this year Roma also have that mentality, and we have to keep it until the end of the season."

"Last year Lazio won the title after having been many points behind Juventus, so they are not yet out of it either," he added.

Despite Capello's words the Scudetto now seems a straight fight between Roma and Juventus. But this fight might not last long: on Sunday Juve travel to the Stadio Olimpico to face Lazio. Anything less than a win will probably see Roma's six-point margin at the top increase. And if that happens the Giallorossi's first title since 1983 will be all but assured.

But, this year Roma also have that mentality, and we have to keep it until the end of the season." "Last year Lazio won the title after having been many points behind Juventus, so they are not yet out of it either," he added. Despite Capello's words the Scudetto now seems a straight fight between Roma and Juventus. But this fight might not last long: on Sunday Juve travel to the Stadio Olimpico to face Lazio. Anything less than a win will probably see Roma's six-point margin at the top increase. And if that happens the Giallorossi's first title since 1983 will be all but assured.

webTitle: MPs to have inquiry into lottery cash for charities

fields.headline: MPs to have inquiry into lottery cash for charities
fields.trailText: MPs have called for an inquiry to establish whether the national lottery has caused charities to suffer a decline in donations from the public. Patrick Butler reports
fields.body:
MPs have called for an inquiry to establish whether the national lottery has caused charities to suffer a decline in donations from the public.

A report by the Commons culture, media and sport select committee says that the lottery regulator, the National Lottery Commission, should conduct a survey to establish the impact of the lottery on charities' income.

The report, which looked at the operation of the lottery, says there is no clear evidence that charities have suffered - despite a widespread feeling among some charities that the lottery is causing them financial problems.

In another of the report's findings, the committee backs the commission's decision to award the license for to run the lottery to Camelot because of its track record of reliability.

It concludes that there is no guarantee that a not-for-profit operation would guarantee higher ticket sales - a reference to the controversy over the failed attempt by Richard Branson's not-for-profit People's Lottery to win the license from Camelot.

It says: "We believe that the primary issue is the efficient operation of the lottery to maximise the amount of money to good causes rather than whether the lottery is operated by a for-profit or not-for-profit licensee.

Camelot, it says, has a "proven record" of running the lottery, and that "reliability is paramount because of the implication of failure is the huge loss of revenue for the good causes". But it does not rule out the government reconsidering a not-for-profit operator at a later date, and says it should consider the "financial and cost implications" of this.

Committee chairman Gerald Kaufman and member Derek Wyatt said they believed that the lottery should be nationalised, but this was not an issue that was raised during the preparation of the report.

The report backs the rule that lottery funding should not be used to substitute state funding of essential services in areas such as health - the so-called principle of "additionality" - but says this principle is "not sacred".

Chief secretary to the Treasury Andrew Smith, giving evidence to the committee earlier this year, had questioned the principle saying it was perverse to consider that some things should be excluded from lottery funding because they are "too important".

The committee rejects Mr Smith's view, and concludes that there was a "fundamental unpredictability" about lottery income which does not fit comfortably with the funding of vital public services.

However, it adds: "While the additionality principle can be of use in preventing the Treasury from substituting lottery income for mainstream government spending, nevertheless we believe that at some stage the rigidity of the additionality principle should be a matter for discussion."

The report calls for a relaxation of the rules on private lotteries, a crucial source of income for many smaller charities, especially hospices.

webTitle: Chechen rebels held over murder of Britons

fields.headline: Chechen rebels held over murder of Britons
fields.standfirst: Special report: Chechnya
fields.trailText: Two prominent Chechen rebel leaders have been arrested in connection with the murder of three British engineers in 1998.
fields.body:
Two prominent Chechen rebel leaders have been arrested in connection with the murder of three British engineers in 1998.

The three Britons and a New Zealander, all engineers working for Granger Telecom, were installing a mobile phone system in the Chechen capital Grozny when they were kidnapped and later beheaded.

The rebels were arrested last week by Russian special forces and are being questioned by Russian authorities about the killings, according to reports.

A foreign office spokesman said: "We are urgently checking these reports and are in touch with the families. We cannot say anything more and do not have any more information."

Peter Kennedy, 46, from Hereford, Darren Hickey, 27, from Thames Ditton, Surrey, Rudi Petschi, 42, of Cullompton, Devon, and New Zealander Stan Shaw, 58, were abducted from their compound on October 3 1998, after guards were overwhelmed by their attackers.

Their severed heads were found in a bag by the roadside outside the city on December 8 and their bodies found later in the village of Chernorechiye, on the outskirts of Grozny.

An investigation at the time surmised that the four were the victims of "warring mercenary factions", while police believe they were killed after a rescue attempt went wrong.

Last night it was reported that Ruslan Akhmadov, a Chechen field commander, and Badrudin Murtazayev, a top aide to warlord Shamil Basayev, were arrested last Wednesday in Baku, the capital of neighbouring Azerbaijan.

They were picked up by Russian special forces and handed over to the Russian authorities, according to Orudzh Zalov, the deputy minister of Azerbaijan's internal affairs.

fields.headline: Harvard chooses its new president
fields.standfirst:
Harvard
Photo gallery of the new president
fields.trailText: Harvard's new president, Lawrence Summers, was announced yesterday amid protests from a small group of the university's students. Chanting "Hey, hey, ho, ho, plutocracy has got to go", about three dozen students banged on a recycling bin and demanded a pay hike for Harvard employees and an end to sweatshop labour in producing university souvenirs.
fields.body:
Harvard's new president, Lawrence Summers, was announced yesterday amid protests from a small group of the university's students. Chanting "Hey, hey, ho, ho, plutocracy has got to go", about three dozen students banged on a recycling bin and demanded a pay hike for Harvard employees and an end to sweatshop labour in producing university souvenirs.

But the majority of Harvard's 15,780 students welcomed Professor Summers' appointment, preferring him to his main rival for the post, Lee C Bollinger. Prof Bollinger, the president of the University of Michigan, had neither studied nor taught at Harvard. Harvard's 27th President would not outline any specific plans for the future of the Ivy League school, but said he intends to build consensus on campus, improve undergraduate education and maintain academic excellence during his term in the post, which he will take up on 1 July.

He also plans to meet with local political leaders to discuss ways in which Harvard can become a better neighbour to the region. He told reporters: "The two most important things for our country, and for the world, are the way in which we educate young people and the creation of new ideas, my heart has always been with the work of thought and ideas. That's been the base of my career and that's the world I've always wanted to come back to."

Professor Summers, a former Treasury secretary, professor and World Bank Executive, replaces Neil Rudenstine.

Over the last nine months Harvard have been searching nationwide for a suitable candidate, and at one point defeated presidential candidate Al Gore was mentioned as a possible choice. President Rudenstine commended his successor, saying: "He cares about other individuals and has a deserved reputation as a mentor. I think it's an excellent choice."

Robert G. Stone Jr, who led the search, said Summers embodied a "rare combination, as one of the most respected scholars and one of the most influential public servants of his generation."

In 1982 Summers gained a doctorate from Harvard and at 28 was one of the youngest faculty members ever granted tenure. He has no previous experience in university administration, but said: "There are similarities between a government and a university. My intention is to work as hard as I can to be accessible."

Harvard has been one of a group of top institutions - including Princeton, Columbia and New York University - which has been seeking new leaders.

fields.headline: Is it your first time?
fields.trailText: Six Manchester-based universities and colleges are launching a website designed for 'first-generation' students who are the first in their family to apply to higher education.
fields.body:
Six Manchester-based universities and colleges are launching a website designed for 'first-generation' students who are the first in their family to apply to higher education.

Uni4me.com will formally launch on Friday and aims to answer potential students' questions about qualifications, entry requirements, study techniques, costs and student life.

A timeline helps students with the application process and a 'jargon buster' helps them understand otherwise off-putting academic terminology.

Uni4me attempts to make universities more accessible and downplay the image of university students as a 'privileged few'. It will try to give some insight into university life and realistic information on costs.

The Higher Education Funding Council for England and the Further Education Funding Council are financing the new project. It is the joint work of the six universities in the Greater Manchester Widening Participation Partnership managed by the Open University in the North West, and links to local institutions.

Howard Horner, Regional Director of the Open University in the North West welcomed the new initiative, saying: "The site is designed to meet the needs of all those individuals within all groups that are under-represented at universities. The site should help those who have little or no access to informal sources of information about university life - those people whose family and peers have no experience of higher education. The site will also be a useful tool for guidance staff."

The site organisers are now planning to link to higher education providers outside Manchester on uni4me and increase awareness of full and part-time learning opportunities across a wider area.

webTitle: 'No shadow' over planning consent for Oxford school

fields.headline: 'No shadow' over planning consent for Oxford school
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Two government departments joined forces yesterday with Oxford University and one of its biggest recent benefactors to reject any hint of impropriety in the way planning consent was given for a £20m business school on a reclaimed site in the university city.
fields.body:
Two government departments joined forces yesterday with Oxford University and one of its biggest recent benefactors to reject any hint of impropriety in the way planning consent was given for a £20m business school on a reclaimed site in the university city.

Evan Harris, Liberal Democrat MP for Oxford West and Abingdon, rekindled the controversy which has long surrounded the Said Business School after he accidentally stumbled on a two-and-a-half-year-old memo.

Inadvertently sent to the MP, it appeared to suggest that "pressure from the prime minister's office" led to irregular fast-track procedures being used. The local MP was not told until 10 days after the decision.

In the current pre-election climate where allegations of influence-peddling are rife, Mr Harris, a supporter of the new business school, is demanding explanations.

"Because the Labour and Tory parties are courting rich men for party donations they have an even greater duty to ensure that quasi-judicial processes are seen to be free of political influence, bought or otherwise," he said.

There was no evidence last night of any such impropriety when Nick Raynsford, the planning minister, decided in September 1998 to allow the school to be built on the site of the old Oxford railway station.

In doing so he refused a public inquiry. At the time the grade II listed building, dating from 1851, was being used as a tyre depot. It has since been rebuilt at a nearby railway museum.

Controversy over the location was enhanced by the donor, Wafic Said, the wealthy Middle East businessman. He is friendly with leading figures in many countries, including in Britain the former Thatcher adviser, Lord (Charles) Powell, whose brother, Jonathan, is Tony Blair's chief of staff.

Last night Mr Raynsford insisted: "I took the decision quite properly with absolutely no intervention from either the prime minister or any of his staff." Oxford University denied that "any person with [its] authority or knowledge" approached No 10.

The Said school said it had employed a planning consultant to handle the issue.

"There has been no contact between Mr Said and the DETR [Mr Raynsford's ministry] or No 10 on this matter," a spokesman said.

Lord Powell, chairman of the school's trustees, also denied personal involvement.

fields.headline: Who reads what teachers write?
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Education
fields.trailText: Last week Fielding, a teacher for 30 years, forgot himself and uttered some jargon. "My CTL's fed up with the paperwork," said he. What?
fields.body:
Last week Fielding, a teacher for 30 years, forgot himself and uttered some jargon. "My CTL's fed up with the paperwork," said he. What? He meant the chap who used to be called his head of department. Obviously the new school climate is getting to him. Everyone speaks in tongues, demeanour must be either earnest or glum, every spare minute is spent covering for sick colleagues and the school is crammed with sneaks and inquisitors demanding information on performance, management and targets.

Fielding was recently asked his target for the day. "To teach something and get home alive," said he sensibly. The young line manager looked grumpy. In the new teaching ethic, there is no time for levity.

My friend Jacqueline, still slogging away in her primary school, certainly hasn't a spare moment for laughs. She's too busy writing her 30 weekly reports for 30 children on every lesson, her special interest report, the percentage of the national curriculum level each child has scored for the school tracking system, what progress was/wasn't made in 30 lots of English, maths and science, who did what in July and had they made progress by December, plus reports every half term, all the marking and lesson plans, then she gets home at 8pm and lies down in a coma.

But what is it all for? Who is reading what poor Jacqueline, Fielding and the other thousands of teachers are writing about the squillion pupils on the forests of paper? Is there a huge, secret team of interpreters who read all the teachers' notes carefully, digest them and do something beneficial as a result?

No, there is not. The poor teachers are writing it all for nothing. Or just on the off chance that in 2005 someone may want to know what Johnny did in maths on Tuesday afternoon 2001 and had he improved by Thursday. Apparently it's called Covering Your Arse, something one had to do with the likes of Inspector Woodentop, the Faultfinder General, poking about. Time he was caught by the neck with a forked stick. It takes a lot to get Fielding to the barricades, but he'll be there this week, on strike.

fields.headline: A question of honour
fields.standfirst: Sid Lowe watches things go all controversial in Spain
fields.trailText: Sid Lowe watches things go all controversial in Spain
fields.body:
Honour - or the lack of it - has been all the rage this week with the festering remains of the derbi being swiftly supplemented by Raúl's rather obvious handball against Leeds.

For some reason the Italians were particularly keen to bang on about Raúl. La Gazzetta dello Sport went nauseatingly puritanical, declaring that it was "worried" about the kids - "they'll learn to dribble, shoot and, above all, cheat. It's morally reprehensible" it preached.

Pot and kettle? Well, yes. But fear not - Marca came out fighting "Don't you lecture us, Italy" it replied, offering an impressive dossier of the tricks of the trade of Italian football - "the most unsporting in the world".

But while Raul was getting away with it, Barcelona were busy restoring their karma after all the derbi conspiracy theories. After a narrow 2-1 defeat by Barca in their midweek Uefa Cup tie, Celta Vigo were furious that referee Graham Barber ignored a blatant foul on Edu and there were a few "altercations" in the tunnel afterwards (one Celta official apparently started on Serra Ferrer, shouting "You want fair play? You go on about robberies?").

Celta coach Víctor Fernández was fuming too: "Having seen this bloke, I reckon Spanish referees are really good", he said. Hmmm, praise indeed, but Fernández might just have changed his mind after this weekend's fine displays.

Ref-ache

Barcelona again got the benefit of the doubt, this time during their 1-1 draw against Mallorca. Barça's penalty equaliser looked a bit harsh - in fact, Kluivert admitted it wasn't a penalty. Referee José Manuel Andradas Asurmendi ignored two decent shouts at the other end, too, including a blatant foul on Samuel Eto'o by keeper José Reina.

Never one to pass up the chance of a ruckus, Luis Aragonés went for the ref in the tunnel after the game while Eto'o declared "now see if Barça cry over the refereeing!".

Señor Andradas wasn't alone. Javier Turienzo Alvárez added to the fun of Alavés's 4-2 win over Rayo with two sending-offs, Evaristo Puentes Leira added two more during Málaga's 2-0 defeat of Zaragoza, and Jesús María Lacruz was given his marching orders at the Catedral as Athletic Bilbao drew 1-1 with Villarreal.

No red cards, but Carlos Megía Dávila, was pretty unpopular in Oviedo after their 2-2 draw with Espanyol - Radi Antic moaned that "the only thing he didn't do was take Espanyol's corners".

Had he been playing for Paco Flores's side, he surely couldn't done much worse than Soldevilla and Lopo who combined comically to gift Oli Oviedo's first. Not to be outdone, Paqui and Nacho González ingratiated themselves with the Sardinero crowd - together they handed Colsa Racing's opener, and Gregorio Manzano's men went on to beat Las Palmas 2-1.

And now for the football

With Barça and Mallorca drawing, it's been a good weekend for the top three. Pandiani hit a headed hat-trick against PSG in midweek and he "recorded it and watched it 1500 times". Hope he had a tape ready for Saturday - he got two more as Depor stuffed Numancia 4-1.

On Sunday, John Benjamin Toshack returned to the Bernabéu for the first time since his flying pig comment got him the sack last year. Not many happy returns, though - Real Sociedad left with a kicking from a Madrid side playing well within itself. In fact, Marca claimed that "half the players didn't need to shower - they hadn't even broken sweat". Luckily, said Marca, "Macca did the running for everyone". This column's scouse mainstay got his reward, too, with a neat goal a couple of minutes from time.

One referee that was more popular this weekend was Rafael Ramírez Domínguez - he slipped over to provide the only entertainment of a dull first half between Valencia and Osasuna, and spent the rest of the game trying very hard not to book anyone (despite Mendieta's best efforts). As for the game, Pablo Aimar produced a sensational pass, which Kily González finished off in style to secure a 1-0 win.

And finally...

Just in case you thought dishonesty was confined to referees, club owners, taxmen and the Italian sporting press, a quick mention for Espanyol's Raúl Tamudo. Not for him dodgy decisions, fake passports (a couple more of them this week), deliberate yellows or handballs, though. Tamudo's been fined half a million pesetas for getting a friend to sit the written part of his driving test for him. Total waste of time, too - when Tamudo's mate saw the examiner checking the identities of everyone there, he bottled it and did a runner. Rangers might just be double-checking their medical files.

Referee José Manuel Andradas Asurmendi ignored two decent shouts at the other end, too, including a blatant foul on Samuel Eto'o by keeper José Reina. Never one to pass up the chance of a ruckus, Luis Aragonés went for the ref in the tunnel after the game while Eto'o declared "now see if Barça cry over the refereeing!". Señor Andradas wasn't alone. Javier Turienzo Alvárez added to the fun of Alavés's 4-2 win over Rayo with two sending-offs, Evaristo Puentes Leira added two more during Málaga's 2-0 defeat of Zaragoza, and Jesús María Lacruz was given his marching orders at the Catedral as Athletic Bilbao drew 1-1 with Villarreal. No red cards, but Carlos Megía Dávila, was pretty unpopular in Oviedo after their 2-2 draw with Espanyol - Radi Antic moaned that "the only thing he didn't do was take Espanyol's corners". Had he been playing for Paco Flores's side, he surely couldn't done much worse than Soldevilla and Lopo who combined comically to gift Oli Oviedo's first. Not to be outdone, Paqui and Nacho González ingratiated themselves with the Sardinero crowd - together they handed Colsa Racing's opener, and Gregorio Manzano's men went on to beat Las Palmas 2-1. And now for the football With Barça and Mallorca drawing, it's been a good weekend for the top three. Pandiani hit a headed hat-trick against PSG in midweek and he "recorded it and watched it 1500 times". Hope he had a tape ready for Saturday - he got two more as Depor stuffed Numancia 4-1. On Sunday, John Benjamin Toshack returned to the Bernabéu for the first time since his flying pig comment got him the sack last year. Not many happy returns, though - Real Sociedad left with a kicking from a Madrid side playing well within itself. In fact, Marca claimed that "half the players didn't need to shower - they hadn't even broken sweat". Luckily, said Marca, "Macca did the running for everyone". This column's scouse mainstay got his reward, too, with a neat goal a couple of minutes from time. One referee that was more popular this weekend was Rafael Ramírez Domínguez - he slipped over to provide the only entertainment of a dull first half between Valencia and Osasuna, and spent the rest of the game trying very hard not to book anyone (despite Mendieta's best efforts). As for the game, Pablo Aimar produced a sensational pass, which Kily González finished off in style to secure a 1-0 win. And finally... Just in case you thought dishonesty was confined to referees, club owners, taxmen and the Italian sporting press, a quick mention for Espanyol's Raúl Tamudo. Not for him dodgy decisions, fake passports (a couple more of them this week), deliberate yellows or handballs, though. Tamudo's been fined half a million pesetas for getting a friend to sit the written part of his driving test for him. Total waste of time, too - when Tamudo's mate saw the examiner checking the identities of everyone there, he bottled it and did a runner. Rangers might just be double-checking their medical files.

webTitle: DD Guttenplan on the Irving trial

fields.headline: The war on truth
fields.standfirst:
Last year's libel battle between revisionist historian David Irving and American academic Deborah Lipstadt was billed as a war over the history of the Holocaust. But did Irving really matter? And what did the two-month trial actually achieve? In an exclusive extract from his remarkable new book about the case, DD Guttenplan argues that the bare facts proved in a London courtroom fell short of the whole truth about the Nazi genocide

How the case was won before it reached court
fields.trailText: Last year's libel battle between revisionist historian David Irving and American academic Deborah Lipstadt was billed as a war over the history of the Holocaust. In an exclusive extract from his remarkable new book about the case, DD Guttenplan argues that the bare facts proved in a London courtroom fell short of the whole truth about the Nazi genocide
fields.body:
A sophist, says Aristotle, is "one who makes money from an apparent but unreal wisdom". History does not tell us whether Dio Chrysostom, who lived and wrote some 400 years after Aristotle, composed his "Eleventh Discourse" as a work for hire. Nor is it known if the "Trojan Discourse", as it is also called, was intended as a kind of advertisement for his talents as a sophist - considerable enough to earn him the name Chrysostom (Golden-Mouth) - or as a cautionary example of the dangers of sophistry, written after its author's conversion to Stoicism. What can be seen, nearly two millennia later, is the rhetorical brilliance with which Dio, a Greek-speaking native of Asia Minor, sets out to convince his contemporaries in Ilium (Troy) that they have been duped by Homer into believing that their ancestors lost the Trojan war.

On one view, David Irving is simply Dio Chrysostom in a three-piece suit, offering an outwardly plausible, internally consistent fiction that plays on the prejudices of his audience. At times I have heard similar arguments from Irving's critics - and from his defenders. In my own view, these dismissals underestimate both Irving and what he represents.

If Irving were simply a "clown" - as one academic I know argued, complaining about the media's fascination with the trial - it would hardly have been necessary to commission a team of scholars to oppose him. Indeed, such a contest would have been grotesque. It would arguably have been similarly excessive if he were merely the harmless Führer-fancier depicted in Selling Hitler, Robert Harris's amusing account of the "Hitler diaries" fiasco.

In her book, Deborah Lipstadt argued that Holocaust denial "is not an assault on the history of one particular group . . . it poses a threat to all who believe that knowledge and memory are among the keystones of our civilisation". In other words, it's not just a problem for Jews.

Like a lot of the arguments in Lipstadt's book, her conclusion is correct, but her premises are deeply flawed. The idea that Irving and his band of "cracked anti-semites" at the Institute for Historical Review pose some kind of threat to "our civilisation" or the "western rationalist tradition" is simply absurd.

Yet Irving does represent a real danger. Partly this is political. The laundry list of names Hajo Funke, the expert witness who testified about Germany's far right, read out in court aren't primarily concerned with Jews. Chances are, most of the skinheads we saw marching and chanting in a video of a rally addressed by Irving in the German town of Halle have never even met a Jew. For them, Holocaust denial is just a means to an end, a verbal sign of recognition that sorts out the hard cases from the fellow travellers. Their end - Irving's project - is the rehabilitation of fascism. And given Jörg Haider's success in facing down his critics in the European Union, and Jean-Marie Le Pen's durability on the French political scene, and the rising fortunes of neo-fascists in Italy, an American must at least hesitate before assuming that fears of a far-right resurgence in Europe are purely delusional.

But not all of Irving's defenders are fascists, or anti-semites - or even rightwingers. For every cretin who laughs at Irving's jokes about the one-man gas chamber, there are probably thousands, like John Keegan, who assume Irving is wrong about the Holocaust but wonder why that should matter to them. For every goose-stepping neo-Nazi in thrall to Irving's rhetoric, there are hundreds of readers drawn in by his narratives.

And there will always be doubt. Despite the trial, despite the facts, despite the verdict, doubt persists. To pretend otherwise is to deceive ourselves.

It is, after all, one thing to say, as Mr Justice Charles Gray did in his judgment, "No objective, fair-minded historian would have serious cause to doubt that there were gas chambers at Auschwitz." It is another thing to know that in a given building hundreds of thousands of people were murdered. How do we know anything beyond what we ourselves have experienced? How do we put our doubts to rest?

I had nothing but sympathy for the reporter who, after listening in court to Irving's insistence that the elevator to the ovens simply couldn't have carried as many bodies as the defence expert had claimed, confessed: "On the way home in the train that night, to my shame, I took out a pocket calculator and began to do some sums. Ten minutes for each batch of 25. I tapped in. That makes 150 an hour. Which gives 3,600 for each 24-hour period. Which gives 1,314,000 in a year. So that's fine. It could be done. Thank God, the numbers add up."

Even for those of us who never thought Irving might be right, there was still doubt. Not about the facts, but about what would happen if the facts somehow made no difference.

What pulled me back was a memory: I am six years old and my father has brought his best friend home for dinner. After we eat, the friend takes the back off our television set and shows me the tubes lighting up inside. One is burned out, and as he replaces it I notice a line of numbers on his arm, just below the wrist. "What are those, uncle Mike?" He tells me that the Germans put them there when he was a little boy "so I wouldn't get lost".

My uncle Mike was never a little boy. When he was 12 or 13, the Germans occupied Hungary, and his entire family was put on a train to Auschwitz. Big for his age, and claiming to be older, he was sent to work in the mines. This was 1944, and Auschwitz was liberated by the Red Army in January 1945. By then the rest of his family had been gassed.

The truth is, I can't be certain of all these details, and my uncle Mike has been dead for some time. I was reminded of him while listening to Irving's response to the obvious questions: what happened to the missing Jews? If they didn't die in the camps, where were they? Irving talks about "the large number that turned up in the state of Palestine, what's now the state of Israel", and sometimes, as if acknowledging that this number isn't nearly large enough, claims that others might have been killed in Dresden. The rest, he suggests, fled to the Soviet Union or the United States. As a simple matter of accounting, this is preposterous. As an explanation, it is also monstrous. Because the assumption behind it is that, lured by the good life to the United States, or chasing the workers' paradise in Russia, or seeking the Zionist dream in Israel, people like my Uncle Mike would simply forget that they had once had mothers, fathers, sisters, brothers, grandparents, children, and wouldn't bother to look for them, which is why so many Jews are still unaccounted for. In other words, it presumes that Jews are not human beings.

When I arrived at the home of the Holocaust scholar Raul Hilberg in Vermont a few months before the trial, we began by talking about numbers. In The Destruction of the European Jews, Hilberg lists one million Jews killed at Auschwitz. His total number for the Holocaust, however, is 5.1m, not 6m, a conclusion that led Irving to cite his work at the trial, and which has caused Hilberg no end of trouble. Does it really matter? I asked.

'Yes, it matters," Hilberg said. "It matters on a variety of counts. When you segment these losses by country, you find that the major difference between my count and those who say six million . . . is the Soviet Union. Which means, if they didn't die they're there . . . That matters - because you are talking about a substantial part of Jewish history. And you're talking about current Jewish history!" I asked about gas chambers. Irving devotes so much energy to creating doubt about gas chambers. Why? "People are shot or hacked to death in other countries, even after world war two - Rwanda, for example. You built the gas chamber with a view to killing a mass of people. Once you have a gas chamber, you have a vision, and the vision is total annihilation. In a gas chamber, you don't see the victim. So the gas chamber in that sense is more dangerous, the gas chamber is more criminal. The gas chamber has wider implications. So when you deny the gas chamber, you deny not just a part of the event, you deny one of the defining concepts. And of course you deny, apart from anything else, the death of several million people."

Whatever we talked about, we seemed always to come back to numbers. "These numbers do matter," Hilberg said. "They also matter for the very simple reason - call it religious if you like." At this point he saw my gaze shift from the Teletubbies magnets on his refrigerator to the menorah balanced on top of his television set.

"I'm an atheist," he said. "All these things belong to my wife, not me. I am an atheist. But there is ultimately, if you don't want to surrender to nihilism entirely, the matter of a record. Does the record matter? In my judgment it is not discussable, it is not arguable. It matters because it matters to me - it's my life."

The sanctity of facts. As the trial wore on, I often found my mind returning to the afternoon I'd spent with Hilberg. After a lifetime of studying brutality, inhumanity, murder on an industrial scale, after personal tragedy and professional conflict, this is what he has to hold on to: the sanctity of facts. Was that enough?

Charles Gray's reasoned judgment ratified every major proposition the defence sought to establish. Irving had indeed been shown to be a liar, a bigot, and a distorter of historical evidence - a man whose word could no longer be relied upon for the smallest detail, let alone a reliable interpreter of major historical events. It had also established, if only by implication, the right of Jews and other maligned ethnic groups to respond robustly, and in an organised manner, when they are attacked. Indeed it affirmed their right to do so even when the attacks are "merely" verbal - so long as the response is also limited to speech. And, despite considerable reluctance, the judge also issued a number of findings on the destruction of the European Jews, holding that, solely on the basis of the evidence available to Irving - not the totality of the evidence - the "historical data" were clear enough to compel the conclusion that the Holocaust had indeed happened, that Hitler had at the very least been aware of what happened, and that only a prejudicial cast of mind could account for the refusal to acknowledge the reality of the gas chambers at Auschwitz. Insofar as it was attainable under the laws of libel, justice had been done. Was that enough?

Irving's ability to disturb Jews has been diminished, and will probably be curtailed further as he is forced either to pay his opponents' costs or submit his finances to the bankruptcy court. His fellow "revisionists", too, will now have to do without Irving as their respectable frontman. But it is doubtful the judge's arguments will themselves make any impact on the paranoid adherents of Holocaust denial or other believers in Jewish conspiracy. Their views are, by their very nature, impervious to reasoned judgment.

Within months of his loss, Irving was already being received in the US as a martyr to their cause. Nor does it seem likely that even this triumph will encourage Irving's opponents to relax their eternal vigilance. Lipstadt's backers among Jewish organisations have their own reasons for making sure the struggle continues. And though she and her publishers deserved to win, the encouragement their victory will give to groups such as the Anti-Defamation League or the Board of Deputies in their efforts to police public discussion, not just of the Holocaust but of American and Israeli policies, is no cause for celebration.

But there was something else that troubled me. There was something, I realised, that struck me as missing all along: witnesses. I understood perfectly why Lipstadt's lawyers had decided that calling witnesses would be a distraction. They had a case to win. Besides, they quite rightly sought to avoid giving Irving a chance to vent his hostility on people who, by definition, had already suffered more than enough.

But Irving's whole approach to history was based on the premise that witness testimony is essentially worthless. Sure, he used it when it suited him - and, as the defence proved, ignored it when it didn't. But on the larger question of whether we can really understand the Holocaust - or any historical catastrophe - without witnesses, the lawyers and the judge mostly went along with Irving's premise.

As a reporter, I know perfectly well that witnesses can mislead - not always innocently. But without them - or our own eyewitness testimony - there would be nothing to report. Even if there were sound reasons for not calling living witnesses, there might have been a place found in court for the voice of Salmen Gradowski, a member of the Sonderkommando at Auschwitz who was killed in the fall of 1944. Knowing that his own death was imminent, Gradowski took the notes he had managed to make during the previous 19 months and put them inside a metal canister, which he buried in a pit of human ash. Found after the war, Gradowski's journal asks: "Dear discoverer of these writings! I have a request of you: this is the real reason I write, that my doomed life may attain some meaning, that my hellish days and hopeless tomorrows may find a purpose in the future."

Facts are crucial. Facts are sacred. Facts are indeed what give history its dignity. But they are not the whole story. The struggle to find the right way to describe the destruction of European Jewry is sometimes depicted as a contest between history and memory. And as we have now all been taught, memory is a terribly unreliable guide to wie es eigentlich gewesen ist , "how it really was".

And so we take refuge in history, in documents, in facts - cool, detached, silent, precise.

Thanks to Deborah Lipstadt and her lawyers, the facts about the Holocaust are indeed safer - and for that, perhaps, we should be grateful.

But witnesses, memories, testimony - all that was left outside the courtroom. And that seems to me cause for regret.

Witnesses are always partial. Memory is by definition selective. And testimony - not the sworn responses of expert witnesses, but the still-vivid responses of people whose history is lived, not studied - can be treacherous.

Yet without witnesses, without human voices to put flesh on the facts, we have something that, while it may pass muster as history, can never tell the truth.

webTitle: Blunkett toughens stance on teachers' work to rule

fields.headline: Blunkett toughens stance on teachers' work to rule
fields.trailText: Education secretary David Blunkett warned that he intended to deal with the unions "in a way they could be surprised about" if the current work-to-rule by the two largest unions forces schools to close.
fields.body:
Education secretary David Blunkett warned that he intended to deal with the unions "in a way they could be surprised about" if the current work-to-rule by the two largest unions forces schools to close.

"If you walk out on a class and send the kids home, you damage their life chances," he told the Today programme this morning. But union leaders responded by saying that Government "panic measures" showed the extent of the teacher shortage.

Members of the National Union of Teachers and the National Union of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers have stopped covering unfilled posts and for colleagues who have been absent for more than three days. They estimate that a thousand schools in London and Doncaster could close for part of the week.

Mr Blunkett added: "We don't have mass action today. We have two of the unions, representing a small number in the particular schools we are talking about, threatening to walk out on children. We have a lot of teachers who are prepared to cover on the basis that they know we are taking action."

Union members voted 93% in favour of industrial action. The results of further ballots in Leicester, Middlesborough, Nottingham, Southampton and Portsmouth are due this week.

NASUWT general secretary Nigel de Gruchy said teachers would not be intimidated by "emotional claptrap."

"We are acting responsibly, and children's education is already suffering because of the shortages." Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said the Government was trying to "buy itself out of trouble in the run up to general election" and should have heeded unions' warnings earlier.

Teachers are angry that the education secretary has concentrated on attracting and recruiting new teachers rather than rewarding experienced staff who have borne the brunt of the extra workload brought about by Labour's educational reforms.

Last week's Budget also promised bonuses of between £2000-4000 for ex-teachers who return to the profession. But the basic rate of teachers' pay will only increase by an average of 3.7% from next month.

He said the bonuses for returning teachers were backed up by money for childcare, housing and transport. " We need teachers back in - some of them will just have had a family or taken early retirement and the pension rules have been relaxed so that we can deal with that."

But Peter Smith said returning teachers would find "overlarge classes, crumbling buildings and demoralised colleagues, overtired from working 50 hours a week - the very problems which drove them out of teaching in the first place."

fields.headline: Suspected Serb war criminal surrenders
fields.standfirst: Special report: Yugoslavia war crimes
fields.trailText: 12 March: A Bosnian Serb accused of "cleansing" his town has given himself up to the war crimes tribunal
fields.body:
Bosnian Serb war crimes suspect Blagoje Simic, a former mayor accused of instigating the "cleansing" of his town of Muslims and Croats, surrendered to the UN war crimes tribunal in the Hague today.

Mr Simic voluntarily boarded a plane in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, and flew to the Netherlands, where he was immediately placed in custody, a tribunal spokesman said.

The suspect, who is likely to make his first appearance in court later this week, is the first Yugoslav citizen to turn himself in to the international court. He said he was confident he would prove his innocence.

His surrender comes as the United States has stepped up pressure on Yugoslavia to cooperate with the tribunal or face a severing of aid.

Mr Simic, a trained doctor, was the municipal leader of the town of Bosanski Samac, which was overrun by Serb forces in April 1992.

Of the 17,000 Croats and Muslims, about half the town's population, fewer than 300 were left at the end of the war in 1995.

Control of the town was crucial for the Serb effort to build a corridor between Serbia and the Serbs in the Krajina district of Croatia and western Bosnia.

Non-Serbs, especially professionals and civic leaders, were rounded up and herded into camps run by Serb police. Many were killed, tortured or sexually assaulted. The rest of the non-Serbs fled or were transferred to other villages, where they were forced into slave labour.

Mr Simic remained the civilian head of the local government throughout the campaign of atrocities, and led the "Serb Crisis Staff", who directed the "ethnic cleansing" of the town, the tribunal said.

The tribunal's chief prosecutor, Carla Del Ponte, who was due to give a news conference later today, told Yugoslav authorities on a recent trip to Belgrade that she expected to see an early sign of improved cooperation.

The new government has resisted her demands to begin arresting and handing over war crimes suspects, including former president Slobodan Milosevic.

fields.headline: Bazalgette joins Channel 4 board
fields.trailText: 5.45pm: Peter Bazalgette, the man behind Big Brother and Ground Force, has been appointed to the board of Channel 4.
fields.body:
Peter Bazalgette, the man behind some of the most successful TV programmes including Big Brother and Ground Force, has been appointed to the board of Channel 4.

He will take up his position as a non-executive director of the station in April for a period of three years.

As one of the most outspoken members of the independent television industry, Baz, as he is known, will make a lively addition to the Channel 4 board at a time when it grapples with expansion into controversial territory.

In January it launched its second pay television strand E4, and there is consistent talk of privatisation.

Although the Labour party has said in the past it will oppose privatisation, it may be tempted to cash in on the new businesses set up by Channel 4 chief executive Michael Jackson further down the line.

Announcing the appointment Independent Television Commission Sir Robin Biggam said: "I am sure his contribution to the channel's continued success will be a significant one."

Mr Bazalgette, who runs Endemol Entertainment UK, first made his name as creator of the BBC's Food & Drink and Changing Rooms.

fields.headline: Quorn firm dumps Rainey Kelly
fields.trailText: 5pm: The company behind the Quorn brand of vegetarian foods has ditched its advertising agency, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
The company behind the Quorn brand of vegetarian foods has ditched its advertising agency and is on the verge of appointing St Luke's to create a new campaign for the product.

The move comes as vegetarian foods are enjoying a popular revival in the wake of BSE and other food scares.

Figures show the value of the market has increased by 67% in the past five years alone, up from £255m to £428m.

Marlow Foods last week parted company with Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R and is believed to have been in talks with St Luke's for some time about an advertising project.

Rainey Kelly won the account in November 1999 and created a TV campaign set in the fictional all-American town of Quornville.

At the time Marlow Foods pledged to spend £5m on the campaign. But the actual media spend was about £1.4m according to industry figures.

Nigel White, UK marketing controller of Marlow Foods, denied the company had split with Rainey Kelly.

"We have always worked with several companies and are always talking to new advertising agencies," he said.

fields.headline: WPP hires Pooler to lead global media arm
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: The world's largest advertising and marketing group has hired Mandy Pooler to head up a new global media unit. By Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
WPP, the world's largest advertising and marketing group, has hired Mandy Pooler to head up a new global media unit.

Ms Pooler has been named as chief executive of The Channel, a new global unit to co-ordinate WPP's media operations.

Ms Pooler, former chief executive of MindShare UK, will be based at WPP's Hay's Mews offices in London.

Her brief will be to bring WPP's various media planning and buying operations together. The Channel will also be responsible for developing media analysis tools for WPP companies.

"This appointment reflects the importance WPP places on its media activities and its desire to use all the resources at its disposal to enhance its position as the world's number one media investment management group," said the company in a statement.

Ms Pooler will also act as a consultant to WPP-owned global media agency The Media Edge in the UK.

fields.headline: Best value: the issue explained
fields.trailText:
What is best value?
Best value is a new regime aimed at improving the quality of local government services. It was introduced by the Labour government as a replacement for the competitive compulsory tendering (CCT) regime, which was widely resented by local government. It is administered by the Audit Commission which carries out regular best value inspections on all council services, from waste disposal to corporate strategy. A separate housing inspectorate within the commission deals with council's housing services.
fields.body:
What is best value?
Best value is a new regime aimed at improving the quality of local government services. It was introduced by the Labour government as a replacement for the competitive compulsory tendering (CCT) regime, which was widely resented by local government. It is administered by the Audit Commission which carries out regular best value inspections on all council services, from waste disposal to corporate strategy. A separate housing inspectorate within the commission deals with council's housing services.

How does it intend to improve services?
Under best value councils are required to apply the so-called four Cs to all of their services. They are: challenge, consult, compare, and compete. The Audit Commission carries out regular inspections of services to ensure that best value is being achieved. Each council is given a star rating depending on how it performs. If councils fail to demonstrate best value they could be forced to switch control of their services to other providers.

 Challenge This involves challenging the way that councils have traditionally approached their services. Councils have to ask themselves whether they really need certain services and identify customer needs for each activity. The Audit Commission checks whether councils have been genuinely self-critical by checking that challenges have not just been raised, but acted upon with evidence of changes.

 Consult Councils have to show that they have consulted local people and key local stakeholders as part of their best value reviews, and they need to monitor customer satisfaction on services. But council staff also need to be involved in the consultation process. Again the Audit Commission checks that this consultation has been acted on.

 Compare Under this heading councils have to benchmark their services against other councils, and private and not profit service providers. They also have to show how they are doing against national best value performance indicators, and introduce an improvement plan, however well they perform.

 Compete This is the ominous C for councils, partly because it is the aspect of best value that most resembles the old CCT regime. Councils have to show that in-house services are the most cost effective by subjecting them to external competition. If in-house services are more expensive councils may have to switch control of that activity to a private firm or the voluntary sector.

What is best value aiming for?
The aim of best value is to ensure that within five years all council services achieve performance levels that were only achieved by the top 25% of councils at the start of the five years. The emphasis of the initiative is on continuous improvement. If a council has improved its performance from poor to average it will get a better inspection report from the Audit Commission than a council whose performance has stayed at average.

How do inspection reports work?
Inspection reports, published by the commission, give each council a star rating based on performance, ranging from no stars for poor performance to three stars for excellent performance. The reports also provide an assessment of whether performance is likely to improve. If performance does not improve the government has the power to switch control of a service away from council control.

What has been achieved so far?
The new regime is currently still bedding down. There have been complaints about a "culture of over inspection", but, although few councils have so far been given good or excellent ratings, those that have been inspected have largely welcomed the process. Since best value is aimed at improvements over five years, it will not be until 2005 that a full assessment of the initiative can be made.

webTitle: Scheme looks to move Londoners north

fields.headline: Scheme looks to move Londoners north
fields.trailText: A bid to relieve London's housing crisis and at the same time help fill empty homes in the north of England, is a favourite to win cash from a new government scheme aimed at introducing more choice to social housing. Matt Weaver reports
fields.body:
A bid to relieve London's housing crisis and at the same time help fill empty homes in the north of England, is a favourite to win cash from a new government scheme aimed at introducing more choice to social housing.

A joint bid by the Association of London Government (ALG) and the Housing Organisations' Mobility and Exchange Services (Homes) looks set to be one of up to 20 to be piloted under the scheme.

The bid proposes offering Londoners homes linked with job opportunities outside the capital. It proposes to find homes and work for 450 Londoners in two years.

The government has earmarked £11m to pilot new lettings ideas. A panel, advising the government on the scheme, met today to decide which bids out of 94 submitted should get funding.

A ministerial decision on the successful bids will be announced at the end of this month. Sources close to the judging panel claimed the ALG/Homes bid is "one of the favourites".

The idea of shifting people from the south-east to the north with the offer of empty housing has tried before, notably with asylum seekers. But this is first time housing offers have been link to employment.

The bid says: "The project is aimed at ensuring that movers will be economically viable in their communities, reducing benefit dependence and the possibility of unplanned drift back to London."

The attraction of the bid is that if it works it will help London councils save some of the spiralling cost of providing temporary accommodation. But it would also help tackle low demand and community instability in areas the north and midlands.

A separate, internet-based joint bid by some of the biggest social landlords in the London has also been made to increase the chance for their tenants to move between homes.

The bid by five councils and five housing associations will pool all the participating landlords 181,000 homes, or 22 % of the capital's social housing stock.

It aims to double the landlord's current rate of transfers between homes. The scheme would give social housing tenants the same freedom to move as homeowners, by scrapping the needs-based approach to housing offers.

fields.headline: Celebrity Big Brother
fields.standfirst: Six celebs are nobly baring their souls under the gaze of the cameras. Here's our online guide to the star-spangled version of last year's TV hit
fields.trailText: 12 March: Everything you need to know about the new star-spangled version of last year's runaway TV hit.
fields.body:
1. Celebrity Big Brother, the star-packed successor to the slice-of-life international TV hit is under way on Channel 4.

2. The new manifestation of the show aims to raise money for Comic Relief and features six British celebrities who are scrapping it out over a week to be the last survivor by this Friday's Red Nose Day.

3. Boxer Chris Eubank, Brookside actress Claire Sweeney, Boyzone star Keith Duffy, comedian Jack Dee, and TV presenters Anthea Turner and Vanessa Feltz entered the house last Friday to live under the gaze of its 24 cameras.

4. The first evictee has already been chosen with Chris Eubank being given his marching orders in the viewers' poll on Saturday night, attracting more than 750,000 votes, with each telephone call raising 15.5p for the charity.

5. Anthea Turner was nominated alongside Eubank (the contestants secretly nominate each other and the two with the most nominations face a public poll) but escaped, with some help from her husband Grant Bovey, who has admitted running up a huge phone bill to help keep her in.

6. Eubank dished the dirt on Anthea afterwards, claiming she was "fragile" and upset by her negative public image. This was increased by mocking tabloid coverage of her wedding, which featured a tie-up deal with a glossy magazine and a chocolate manufacturer.

7. Meanwhile, Jack Dee has indicated he is less than enthralled at living in the UK's least private house and on Sunday tested out the night-vision cameras. As Sweeney and Duffy relaxed in the infamous hot tub, Dee was in the garden secretly digging a hole under a fence. He then spied an open gate but was quickly captured by security guards and frog-marched back.

8. Commentators have pointed out that the celebrities have been afforded more privacy in the reality TV show than their predecessors, and are living without the intrusion of 24-hour web cam coverage; instead, there are edited video clips available to internet viewers.

9. The nation was enthralled last year as 10 strangers, who started out as unknowns, lived together in the Big Brother house for nine weeks with one being evicted every week in an attempt to win the £70,000 prize money.

10. Craig Phillips won the cash and donated it to a young friend for vital surgery, but only after a blistering confrontation with 'Nasty' Nick Bateman, who had taken a very Machiavellian approach to winning at all costs.

fields.headline: Domestic violence: the basics
fields.trailText: • Every three days a woman is killed in England and Wales by her current or former partner.
fields.body:
 Every three days a woman is killed in England and Wales by her current or former partner.

 Domestic violence is about power and control. Most experts recognise that it is the result of an imbalance of power in our society.

 Domestic violence represents 25% of all recorded violent crime. It must be treated as seriously as any other violent crime.

 The cost of domestic violence to society is staggering. We are all affected and we can all play a role in seeking a solution.

 An effective solution will consist of rigorous enforcement of the arrest and charge policy, multi-agency training and funding for essential services.

 Sandra Horley is chief executive of Refuge, the national domestic violence charity

fields.headline: Domestic violence: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Domestic violence is a complex issue which affects every one of us. With one woman in four physically abused by her partner at some point in her life, the likelihood is we all know someone who lives with the terrifying threat of abuse.
fields.body:
Domestic violence is a complex issue which affects every one of us. With one woman in four physically abused by her partner at some point in her life, the likelihood is we all know someone who lives with the terrifying threat of abuse.

Domestic violence - physical or emotional abuse - reaches every corner of our society. It does not respect class, race, religion, culture or wealth. A working class mother on a run-down estate is just as likely to be abused as a professional woman used to managing teams of staff and making million-pound decisions.

Overwhelmingly domestic violence is experienced by women and the perpetrator is male. Yet although in the vast majority of cases it is male to female, we should recognise that men, children and the elderly can be abused, and that domestic violence also occurs in gay and lesbian relationships.

The cost to society is staggering. In London a minimum of £278m is spent each year responding to domestic violence, without even taking into account medical and legal costs. And then there are the lost days at work, the increase in truancy levels, the rise in juvenile crime.

Confusion over the causes of domestic violence only serves to divert attention from the severity of the problem. The myths abound but the reality is that domestic violence is not caused by alcohol, drugs, unemployment or stress. It is the result of a complex interplay of psychological and social factors which have created an imbalance of power between the sexes. Where there is an imbalance of power, it may be abused, and it is this, coupled with society's tolerance, which has allowed domestic violence to flourish.

Every time the police fail to charge an abuser, every time a case is dropped by the crown prosecution service, every time we turn a blind eye to our neighbour's bruises, we make it easier for the abuser to get away with it. We must remember that domestic violence is a serious crime which should be treated as such. It should be at least as unacceptable as drink-driving.

The last few years have seen an increase in the government's efforts to tackle abuse. A number of guidelines have been published, research has been commissioned, awareness is being raised. Yet this can only ever be a first step and the danger is that it will not translate into action. Any effective response to domestic violence has to take the form of a truly integrated central strategy which crosses government departments, the police, health and housing departments and every agency which can play a key role in tackling the problem.

To date the response to domestic violence has been piecemeal and patchy. The key element to achieving a consistent approach is funding. Domestic violence is an issue which has been woefully under-funded for decades and there is still a reliance on the voluntary sector to provide vital, life-saving services.

With a domestic violence incident occurring every six to 20 seconds in the UK, it is in all our interests to seek effective, long-lasting solutions.

 Sandra Horley is chief executive of Refuge, the national domestic violence charity. Refuge's 24-hour national domestic violence helpline is on 0870 599 5443
