fields.headline: Under starter's orders - but it's off
fields.standfirst: Number of the week: 25,000
fields.trailText: Number of the week: 25,000
fields.body:
This week was scheduled to be the Irish invasion, the three-day period when the west country goes green. At least 25,000 Irish people head over every year to the Cheltenham festival race meeting. They come to watch their horses clean up, to rub shoulders with the retired colonels in elegant pubs, to fill every available guest house between Bristol and Birmingham. And to drink.

Cheltenham racecourse during festival week is the most extraordinary sight: the way the horses run at you from out of the hills, the way the grandstands arc round the finishing line and the way tens of thousands of people get simultaneously plastered without rancour or threat. Not even the Munich beer festival offers such a concentration of good time drinking.

Led by the Irish, celebrating the happy coincidence of St Patrick's Day and a race meeting, everyone is at it. A couple of years ago, I went there with a friend who was making his first outing after joining the 10-step alcoholics anonymous programme.

As unwise moves go, this was up there with the recovering kleptomaniac taking a trip to Harrods. He had just jumped aboard the wagon and here he was surrounded by thousands of inebriates. It was like being shown a negative of a snapshot of his drinking life. Terrified of the vision, he was off home before the first race.

With a thirst like the festivalgoer's to quench, Cheltenham's businesses love the race days. The marquee firms, the local brewers and the army of waitresses and barmen. It is the biggest pay day of the year.

Not that everyone in town is welcoming of the hordes. The last time I went, I was sitting in a car full of over-excited racegoers in one of the traditional hour-long jams to get into the town, when the car's rear window suddenly exploded. Someone had shot at us with an air rifle. We didn't report the incident to the police, though - it would have wasted valuable drinking time. You don't want to be in a queue behind the Irish.

But this week there will be none of that. Cheltenham's tills won't fill up with punts, its bookies will be empty of punters. First the Irish - both the horses and the drinkers - were told not to come by their government, paralysed as it is by fear of foot and mouth. Then the racing authorities postponed the event, anyway. Perhaps they reckoned that fun - the howling, whooping, cheery jollity of the kind Cheltenham specialises in - was not the best thing to be seen promoting in the middle of the countryside at this time.

webTitle: Screen Break: Eubank counted out of the house of horrors

fields.headline: Eubank counted out of the house of horrors
fields.trailText:
I cannot remember a week-end like it: four Test matches, two FA Cup and two rugby league quarter-finals. But somehow none of it quite measured up to Chris Eubank in the Celebrity Big Brother house.
Special report: Big Brother
fields.body:
I cannot remember a week-end like it. If you were all tooled up with the right equipment, you could watch four Test matches live on TV - England v Sri Lanka and West Indies v South Africa on Sky, and India v Australia, and New Zealand v Pakistan on Asian subscription channels - as well as two FA Cup and two rugby league quarter-finals. But somehow none of it quite measured up to Chris Eubank in the Celebrity Big Brother house.

Those of us who still cherish Chris's memorable meeting with Mrs Merton, or the moment on Sky when he introduced "oral theckth" into a discussion of Mike Tyson's prospects, will seize any opportunity to witness him talking cobblerth in a quasi-live context, and here we had it in Spades. I am aware that Celebrity Big Brother is for charidee, and that any fun I poke at it will mark me down as a major league misery guts unconcerned about world poverty, who probably enjoys nothing better than pulling the wings off butterflies while leafing through recipes for cooking live baby, but that is something I am just going to have to live with. My email address appears at the foot of this article.

I mean, come on. I ask you. Comic Relief or no Comic Relief, Vanessa Feltz, Anthea Turner, Chris Eubank, Jack Dee, an actress from Brookside, and one of the least interesting members of Boyzone in a week-long popularity contest (Christopher Biggins, I assume, was unavailable)? This was not so much being trapped in a house, as trapped in a bad edition of Celebrity Squares.

One of the things that made the original Big Brother interesting was the thought that the participants, needing the cash prize, might behave disreputably. Here, the "celebrities" manifestly do not need the money, which goes to charity anyway, so the game show element of the programme is effectively removed; while, since these "celebrities" scarcely exist outside of television studios, there is little potential in seeing the cameras capturing them unawares. As if that were ever going to happen.

What happens instead is an elaborate game of double bluff in which the celebs appear to be behaving in ways they would not wish the camera to record, while clearly being aware the cameras are constantly turning. Why would they not be?

So you had episodes like Vanessa Feltz discussing female masturbation with Keith out of Boyzone (who says light entertainment is dead?), proving what a fun up-front girl she is, without a thought of how she might be ruining the evening for me and the good lady wife, what with the recurrence of unwanted visual images and that; or Anthea Turner making a bid for the Domestic Goddess vote by demonstrating how to stuff a duvet into its cover.

Call me an old cynic, but I could not help noting how these two contestants have been given a fairly rough ride by the press of late, and will have done their future career prospects no harm at all by appearing to do something for charity; while whatsisname from Boyzone and thingy from Brookside will have raised their profile considerably. But isn't that what charidee is all about?

Jack Dee I exempt from these criticisms because he is funny, and appeared to have wandered into the programme by mistake, while Eubank also escapes because he is clearly absolutely sincere in his view that he is the most famous and important person in Britain.

When Anthea asked him how he felt about going into the Big Brother house, he did a little bit of business with his walking stick, before seeming to embark on something akin to his address to the nation. "Unthettled," he said, before adding for the benefit of the little people, "It'th a thtate of mind." Thanks Chris.

My view on Comic Relief is that what comedy is all about is subversion. Comedians should not be seen to be participating in society. They need to puncture its pomposities, taking the mickey out of things like, well like Comic Relief. They could start by pointing out that if we cannot show compassion for those less fortunate than ourselves without some well-known newsreader putting on a red nose and sitting in a bath of baked beans, it is a pretty poor do.

There was subversion of sorts on Jumpers For Goalposts, Sky's new comedy quiz featuring characters from The Fast Show, including my colleague Ron Manager.

The show shamelessly pilfered ideas from other quizzes, like a Guess The Sportsman game nicked directly from A Question Of Sport; except you could not imagine Sue Barker back announcing a film of a motor-cycling footballer with, "David Batty, there, with both hands clasped firmly round his helmet."

I will return to Jumpers For Goalposts, which is very funny indeed, but for the moment I am unable to move beyond the thought of Vanessa and the lad from Boyzone. As Ron Manager might say: mmm, enduring image, isn't it?

martin@kelner.demon.co.uk

fields.headline: Can care trusts deliver?
fields.standfirst: Care trusts were billed as the big idea of last summer's NHS plan. But can these new bodies really deliver the care they have promised, asks Steve Brown
fields.trailText: Care trusts were billed as the big idea of last summer's NHS plan. But can these new bodies really deliver the care they have promised, asks Steve Brown.
fields.body:
Care trusts were one of the big ideas of last summer's NHS plan. These new bodies, which the plan said could be in place this year, were billed as the way to "remove the outdated institutional barriers between health and social services which have got in the way of people getting the care they need when they need it". But are they really such revolutionary bodies? What advantages will they offer for service users that can't be delivered under existing arrangements?

Last April new rules were introduced to sweep away the legal obstacles towards a partnership between the two areas. The Health Act 1999 gave health and social services the ability to pool budgets, and deliver services through one-stop shop arrangements or nominate a lead commissioner. The new powers were seen as the wrecking ball that would finally bring down the Berlin Wall between health and social care.

Almost before the new flexibilities had had time to sink in, the NHS plan upped the stakes and put everyone on course for more formal mergers. Why the change of pace?

The new partnership's slow rate of progress may be one explanation. The NHSplan said there were just £200m worth of Health Act schemes in operation last summer. And even now that figure has only risen to £300m covering 42 schemes - hardly the avalanche of activity ministers had wanted.

Whatever the reasons, few people can offer clear examples of what a care trust could deliver that can't be done under the Health Act. But most are happy to accept that advantages may become apparent in time. "The partnership arrangements have only been available since April last year," said Jim Kennedy, head of social affairs at the Local Government Association. "Local authorities are very far from testing the limits of those arrangements. There need to be clear advantages to local players before they enter into (care trusts)."

So far the debate around care trusts has focused on governance arrangements, with councils concerned they will become junior partners in the new NHS bodies. Despite appearances, this is not just local government fearing a loss of empire. The health department itself has accepted that care trusts have to be a "partnership of equals" if they are to function effectively, although no decisions have been taken about the exact make-up of care trust boards.

For example, in joint commissioning boards, which already exist in some areas, there are fears that elected members on the boards are concerned only with their delegated functions. With a more formal merger in a care trust, councillors will sit as full corporate members. The hope is that the blinkers will come off and all board members will start to see both health and social care activities as "their service".

Two sorts of care trust are likely to emerge - those built on primary care trusts and those built on mental health trusts. The first could see local authorities delegate responsibilities for commissioning and providing defined aspects of social care. Almost certainly the transfer of all social services departments is not on the cards. But it could involve the transfer of, say, services for the elderly. This could either be for a population coterminous with the PCT boundaries or it could be for the local authority's whole population. Councils may be more comfortable with delegating the provision of services, so care trusts delivering mental health and social care could prove attractive.

In reality, care trusts simply offer a further option for partnership. At the standard level there are the ad-hoc arrangements for working together, such as joint commissioning boards and rapid response teams. One step further are the Health Act flexibilities. Then the final step is the care trust. As long as the outcomes are judged to be right, the choice is likely to remain a local matter.

PCTs already face a massive challenge in making their new roles as commissioners and providers of health care a reality. Few will be rushing to take on further responsibilities in a hurry. "We're saying let's use the Health Act to set up joint organisations and see if the next step to care trusts is the right way to go," said Hilary Daniels, chief executive of West Norfolk primary care trust. "Care trusts are something to work towards, but it will be a step at a time."

At the moment, with the health and social care bill still going through Parliament, the focus remains on the governance arrangements. And there is an interesting twist that seems to have escaped most commentators' notice. As full board members, councillors will also be involved with the care trust's wider responsibilities. In the PCT model, elected members could find they have influence in developing primary care and commissioning hospital services. Far from a loss of power, care trusts could well prove to be the foot in the door that local government has always wanted with the NHS.

fields.headline: Japanese growth fails to cheer
fields.standfirst:
The announcement that Japan's economy is growing has not helped the mood around Tokyo

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: 12 March: Japan's economy may be growing, but its mood is decidedly grim
fields.body:
The Japanese government released a report today saying the economy had averted recession, but it did little to erase a sense of doom about prospects for recovery.

The Tokyo stock market shrugged off a better than expected economic growth figure today and plunged to its lowest close in 16 years. Fears have been growing about the US economic slowdown hurting exports and dealing a further blow to hopes for a turnaround.

Political confusion has aggravated the problem. The prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, indicated over the weekend that he would step down next month. Calls for his resignation both from his party and the public have been growing for months.

But today Mr Mori denied saying that he will resign.

Worries are deepening about the dangers of possible deflation - a situation where prices are driven down - something that might have been welcome at one time in notoriously expensive Japan.

Even the usually upbeat cabinet ministers weren't sounding optimistic. "It's hard to feel at ease," the economy minister, Taro Aso, told reporters.

Japan's gross domestic product, the value of all goods and services produced in the nation, grew by 0.8% for the quarter that ended in December. Analysts had anticipated 0.6% growth.

That was a rebound from the July-September quarter, when the Japanese economy shrank 0.6%. If the economy had failed to grow in the quarter to December 2000, it would have met the usual definition of a recession -two consecutive quarters of contraction.

For the fiscal year ending in March 2001, the government has set a target of 1.2% growth. The finance minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, told parliament today that growth may beat the official target. The figure released today shows an annual pace of expansion of 3.2%. But overriding pessimism overshadowed any glimmer of hope from such figures. The main engine for growth came from business investment, which rose 6.8% from the previous quarter. Analysts said that was likely to fade in the coming months as management grows increasingly cautious.

Lagging consumption continued to be a major obstacle to growth, slumping 0.6% for the quarter after being flat the previous quarter, as widespread uncertainties about the future prompted Japanese to curtail their purchasing.

Meanwhile prices for many items from clothing to rent are down, heralding good news for some spenders but signalling the danger of deflation and a seriously stagnant economy.

Lagging consumption continued to be a major obstacle to growth, slumping 0.6% for the quarter after being flat the previous quarter, as widespread uncertainties about the future prompted Japanese to curtail their purchasing. Meanwhile prices for many items from clothing to rent are down, heralding good news for some spenders but signalling the danger of deflation and a seriously stagnant economy. webTitle: Brown defends foot and mouth policy

fields.headline: Brown defends foot and mouth policy
fields.standfirst:
 181 cases now confirmed
 More expected, says minister
 Few regions remain problem, says chief vet

Special report: foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText:
 181 cases now confirmed
 More expected, says minister
 Few regions remain problem, says chief vet
fields.body:
As the number of confirmed cases of foot and mouth disease rose to 181 today, the agriculture minister, Nick Brown, warned that farmers must be prepared for further outbreaks before the disease is contained and eliminated.

He defended the government's handling of the crisis, saying the new cases did not mean the disease is raging out of control. "The disease was already incubating, particularly in Cumbria and Devon, and to that extent we do have it under control," he said.

The chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said the "major problem" was still characterised by a handful of regions which had been most affected by the virus. He said the "bulk of cases" were still known to have been spread by movements through Longtown market in Cumbria and by a sheep dealer in Devon.

Mr Scudamore said: "Most of these cases are linked together either by the movement of sheep or by local spread because of the movement of people, equipment or animals. The majority of the outbreaks remain in counties where the problem exists. "The problem is localised to a large extent where the sheep movements took place from Longtown market.

"That is the major problem and also in Devon, where it spread from the dealer who bought sheep in Northumberland," he said. However, Mr Scudamore's comments are unlikely to calm farmers' fears that nowhere is free from the threat of disease after the disease took hold in two new counties. Over the weekend, farmers voiced fears that the disease could spread on the wind, potentially affecting every farm in Britain.

A record daily total of 25 more outbreaks were confirmed yesterday by the Ministry of Agriculture. They include cases in Gloucestershire, in the Forest of Dean, and a farm in Kent, both of which were previously unaffected.

And four new suspected cases of foot and mouth were today being investigated in Lancashire, a regional Maff spokeswoman said. Two farms in the Withnell area and two in the Halton area of the county are suspected of having the disease. At the moment there are three confirmed cases in Lancashire and five "dangerous contact" cases.

A total of 155,000 animals have now been earmarked for slaughter, of which 116,000 have already been culled. Since the crisis began almost three weeks ago, 935 premises have been placed under restrictions, of which just under half still remain in place.

Investigations are still on going at 159 farms and other premises.

fields.headline: It came from outer Cornwall
fields.standfirst: The greenhouse has gone space age. Jonathan Glancey visits the Eden Project
fields.trailText: The greenhouse has gone space age. Jonathan Glancey visits the Eden Project.
fields.body:
Nothing quite like the Eden Project has been seen this side of Quatermass and It Came From Outer Space. Here is the biggest, oddest greenhouse ever - a mass of steel-framed bubbles moulded into the hollow of a former china-clay pit.

The intersecting "biomes" (domes sheltering plant life and ecosystems from around the globe) stretch for 858m near the Cornish town of St Austell. The biggest is 200m long, 100m wide and 65m high. The domes are so light that the air inside weighs almost as much as their tubular steel and fluoropolymer structure. In fact, the Humid Tropics biome actually weighs less than the air it encloses. It is more like an airship than a conventional building, but then almost everything about this £74m millennium project is remarkable.

As a practical project, Eden dates back to 1996. Tim Smit, a former rock-band producer and ubergardener, set out to create the "world in a day" in a sequence of dramatic greenhouses sited not far from Cornwall's beach resorts. This brilliantly engineered Garden of Eden is already proving as exciting as Burton and Turner's Palm House at Kew (1848) and Paxton's Crystal Palace at Hyde Park (1851) were in their prime. Even before Smit's bizarre bubbles are ready for the public, visitors have flocked to see them billowing out of the deep incision in the land. The design may be theatrical but it does have to attract a large audience (attendance figures of half a million in the first year, rising to 750,000, are anticipated), who will come to learn about how we can protect and care for the biosphere that we do so much to destroy. So it will be both a "visitor attraction" and a place of learning, along the lines of the Royal Botanical Gardens at Kew and its outposts, notably the Millennium Seed Bank at Wakehurst Place in West Sussex.

How radical is the architecture? The basic structure is not altogether new. Each biome is made up of galvanised, straight sections of tubular steel, raised up and bolted together like giant Meccano to form no fewer than 625 hexagons, 16 pentagons and 190 triangles. The "geodesic" domes that these shapes form were perfected in the 1930s and 1940s by American inventor Buckminster Fuller - a major influence on Nicholas Grimshaw, architect of the Eden Project, and many other architects in thrall to sophisticated modern engineering.

What is new is the way in which the hollow frame of each dome has been filled with translucent, triple-layered ethylene tetrafluoroethylene (ETFE) pillows. Grimshaw has used the same device in the tower of the National Space Centre in Leicester, which opens at the end of June, and ETFE is likely to be used to an increasing extent in new buildings. It is very light (one-hundredth the weight of glass), recyclable, easy to replace and more flexible and less dangerous to work with than glass. (At St Austell it was installed by abseilers - known locally as "sky monkeys".) Grimshaw believes the ETFE pillows may be replaced by some as yet undeveloped "breathing" skin when they come to the end of their 25-year lifespan.

The result is a structure that looks like something from a sci-fi movie. But this was the easy part. It was far more difficult to fit the bubbles into the former quarry - a deep, uneven, unstable site that was prone to flooding. It was devoid of soil, too, which isn't much help when you want to plant trees and grow plants.

So Smit's team, which, in addition to Nicholas Grimshaw and Partners, included Anthony Hunt Associates (engineers), Ove Arup and Partners (environmental engineers), McAlpine (contractors) and Land Use Consultants (landscape design), pulled off a kind of conjuring trick. In order to make a building site for the greenhouses, they sliced 13m off the top of the uneven quarry walls and hurled this down to the bottom of the 60m-deep pit, thus raising the quarry floor and giving it a natural topsoil. This required the shifting of 1.8m tonnes of earth, which took six months, or, as Smit likes to put it, the equivalent labour of 8m workers toiling for a day with shovels and wheelbarrows. The stuff of pyramid-building.

But then it rained almost continually for two months, and the quarry filled up with more than 160m litres of water. It might have been time to give up, but Ove Arup worked out a way of pumping the water out of the quarry. Then the engineers drove 2,000 rock anchors into the walls to prevent landslides and sprayed them with what they describe as a "soup" of seeds and plant food, so new roots could knit anchors and quarry walls together. The walls are now vertical fields enfolding the biomes.

The final design has evolved greatly from its original, which looked more like Grimshaw's Waterloo International Terminal. The sinuous roof of this characterful building caught the eye of the Eden team, but the uneven terrain of the St Austell site was unsuitable for such a wide-spanned arched structure. Even then, it took computer-aided modelling and manufacture to construct the frame of the biomes: each component is, in effect, a one-off.

The end result is an intriguing building that has an organic feel entirely appropriate to its function. The biomes appear to be growing from the old pit, and their hexagons and pentagons echo those seen in the structures of plants and insects. Rarely has building technology been so close to nature's blueprints.

· The Eden Project opens on Saturday. Details: 01726 811911 or www.edenproject.com

fields.headline: Alan Beith
fields.standfirst:
Berwick upon Tweed (1973- )

Ask Aristotle about Alan Beith
fields.trailText: My most vivid memory of Alan Beith, the cuddly, waddling Liberal Democrat MP is of meeting him on Victoria street in Westminster, London, sporting a broad-brimmed black fedora worthy of a Mafia don. It was during his 1988 campaign against Paddy Ashdown for the party leadership. But the black fedora was not enough to overcome his often noted 'charisma bypass'. He lost, and became a loyal deputy to Mr Ashdown and later Charles Kennedy.
fields.body:
My most vivid memory of Alan Beith, the cuddly, waddling Liberal Democrat MP is of meeting him on Victoria street in Westminster, London, sporting a broad-brimmed black fedora worthy of a Mafia don. It was during his 1988 campaign against Paddy Ashdown for the party leadership. But the black fedora was not enough to overcome his often noted 'charisma bypass'. He lost, and became a loyal deputy to Mr Ashdown and later Charles Kennedy.

Mr Beith has long been the most reliable, worthy, realistic, well-informed and conscientious member of the Liberal Democrats' front bench. But he has also been its most conservative, puritanical northern Methodist representative: opposed to drink (aside from a daily glass of red wine); tobacco; abortion; fluoridation and closer collaboration with Labour, both old and new.

An advocate for Europe (including the ERM), Nato and Israel, he was also one of the first to call for parliamentary supervision of the intelligence services.

But Mr Beith is yet to realise his full potential thanks to the conflict between his natural liberalism and his puritanical streak. This held him back early in his career when the party was held in thrall by the hedonistic behaviour of Jeremy Thorpe, the 1970s Liberal leader.

Indeed, Mr Beith's almost Catholic aversion to abortion and embryo experimentation has put him in opposition to most Lib Dems: after all, David Steel, as party leader, launched the Abortion Act.

This puritanism helped him fight his way up from his roots as a local Liberal councillor of the north-east. And when Tory Lord Lampton resigned after he was caught by a Sunday tabloid with two callgirls, Mr Beith won the 1973 Berwick upon Tweed byelection by 57 votes. He has held the seat ever since.

It was a surprise change of occupation for the lecturer son of apolitical working-class Tory parents. But he soon made his mark in the Commons and within three years he succeeded Cyril Smith as chief whip.

He has long been a stout defender of fishermen in his constituency and an enlightened supporter of educational reform. His opposition to nuclear weapons led him to oppose Trident, while urging his colleagues to back Nato. In most crises, he has used his native shrewdness to advance solutions.

In 1984 he urged the sacking of both Arthur Scargill and coal board chief Ian MacGregor to end the miners' strike. He is also a longterm supporter of the inclusion into UK law of the European convention on human rights.

After the Alliance sagged in the 1987 election, Mr Beith was part of negotiations for the Liberal-SDP merger, insisting that the "voters prefer the respectability of marriage". His own marriage having ended with the death of his wife in April 1998, Mr Beith announced in November 2000 his intention to marry Democrat Baroness Maddock, the former MP for Christchurch.

Deputy leader of the party since 1992, and defeated in the October 2000 contest for Speaker of the House of Commons, Mr Beith now looks set to continue in Parliament for one more term exactly as before - decent, often right, but just a bit dull.

webTitle: Crime and punishment: the issue explained

fields.headline: Crime and punishment: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Labour came into power with Tony Blair famously promising to be "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime". But penal reform groups believe the pledge has led to more overcrowded jails and falling standards across the prison service.
fields.body:
Labour came into power with Tony Blair famously promising to be "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime". But penal reform groups believe the pledge has led to more overcrowded jails and falling standards across the prison service.

Prior to 1997, crime had fallen in the UK for four years in a row. But in the past four years, the prison population has soared by 6,000 to more than 66,000. Thirty-six jails now have more than 100 inmates "doubled up" in single cells. Reform groups argue that no extra criminals have been caught; instead the courts are giving longer sentences, reflecting ministers' tough rhetoric.

However, the government still faces accusations that it is soft on crime. The latest Home Office figures show overall crime dropped by a negligible 0.2% in the 12 months to September 2000, while headline-grabbing violent crime rose by 8%.

Home secretary, Jack Straw, unveiled the government's new 10-year crime strategy in February, which includes plans for an extra 2,660 prison places and the commitment to longer prison sentences for persistent offenders. Judges will have more scope to consider offenders' previous convictions when passing sentences.

A third of the £700m programme will be spent on rehabilitation, with supervised community schemes replacing short-term prison sentences. On release, prisoners will be offered better drug treatment, education, and help with jobs and housing.

Whether Mr Straw's plans to see more offenders serving most of their sentence in the community will work, remains to be seen. But some prison officers fear this will lead to more prison violence. They warn that the introduction of similar detention and training orders (DTOs) for juvenile offenders, prohibiting staff from adding extra days as a punishment, could lead to a collapse in discipline.

Thousands of prisoners already serve the last weeks of their sentences at home with an electronic tag. Despite the Conservatives' attacks on the scheme, it has so far proved effective, with 96% successfully completing their sentences.

There have already been significant efforts to improve standards in Britain's prisons. The government has funded the biggest ever literacy and numeracy drive for inmates and more than 50 prisons now run drug treatment programmes. Schemes to tackle the criminal behaviour of inmates also claim to have cut the reconviction rate by one-third.

The director-general of the prison service, Martin Narey, has also presided over the first real attempt to root out corruption and brutality. Nearly 100 prison officers are currently suspended pending investigations, and racism is finally on the agenda.

Nevertheless there have been a catalogue of damning reports on Britain's prisons. In February, Mr Narey named six jails as "hellholes" and warned he would quit his job unless conditions throughout England and Wales improved.

The chief inspector of prisons, Sir David Ramsbotham, has called for the closure of several young offendersÍ institutions, following investigations that revealed serious problems with bullying, racism and suicide.

He also told the Guardian in February that 20,000 inmates - women, boys, elderly, mentally ill, petty offenders - should never have been sent to jail.

webTitle: India celebrates a festival of colour

fields.headline: India celebrates a festival of colour
fields.standfirst: The end of winter sees Hindus indulge in a riot of paint-throwing from which no one is excluded, writes Luke Harding
fields.trailText: The end of winter sees Hindus indulge in a riot of paint-throwing from which no one is excluded during one of  India's most venerable and exuberant festivals. Visitors stepping off the plane in Delhi might conclude that the country has collectively lost its marbles, says Luke Harding
fields.body:
In the pleasant suburb of central Delhi where I live, things were not quite the same yesterday. The dog that lurks at the bottom of the stairwell, for example, had a bright pink head.

In the children's playground nearby, with its rickety seesaw, the ground was thick with splodges of yellow and green. A distinguished-looking gentleman in his early 60s was enjoying the morning sunshine, seemingly unperturbed by the fact his neatly combed grey hair was streaked with orange dye.

Visitors who had just stepped off the plane in India's normally sensible capital might have concluded that the country had collectively lost its marbles sometime over the weekend - or been invaded by colour-loving Martians.

In a sense they would have been right. This was not some surrealist's fantasy but the result of Holi - one of India's most venerable and exuberant festivals, held every March. Like all Indian festivals, Holi has its origins deep in the recesses of Hindu myth.

Loosely put, the festival commemorates a loyal worshipper of Lord Vishnu, Prahlad, who together with his sister, was burned for his faith by their evil father. Miraculously, Prahlad survived the bonfire. Thus Holi is about the triumph of good over evil; but it is also a harvest festival, marking the end of winter and the banishment of cold.

Somewhere along the line the god Krishna, who spends much of his mythological time chasing Gopis or handmaidens, got involved - together with a lot of paint. It is the paint, principally, which most people associate with Holi.

For centuries, Indians have thrown coloured flour and water at each other during the festival - not just at their relatives and friends, but also at passing strangers. The paint-throwing is taken in good humour - no one seems to mind being caked from head to foot in coloured gunge, which is what happens if you step outside.

Driving on Saturday on a road up above the Ganges, close to the holy city of Rishikesh, our jeep was stopped by a gang of intoxicated youths who were out playing Holi. Being British, our immediate response was to shut all the windows and grimace. This, however, was not the correct attitude.

Our driver merely grinned as the youths forced open his door and tipped a bucket of pink paint on his head. He shook his head stoically. We then drove off. Across north India, cars, trucks, lorries, mopeds and camel carts are stopped in similar fashion - until their drivers resemble walking paint catalogues.

And it is not just ordinary folk who take part: the festival is genuinely classless. Cabinet ministers, captains of industry and cricket stars will all dig out their old clothes and throw colour at each other. (Last year, rumour spread that Chelsea Clinton, who was accompanying her father on a presidential visit to India, had been drenched in dye while staying in Rajasthan. When the pictures appeared in the paper the next day, however, only a tiny tilak or red mark could be seen on her forehead. Her crisp trouser-suit was miraculously unmarked.)

Holi's reputation for lawlessness is not, though, undeserved - groups of young men consume large quantities of bhang lassi, a powerfully hallucinogenic drink made from cannabis and milk. They then dance in the streets to the banging of drums, cause mayhem and sometimes fall over. But there is nothing malicious about Holi, which is why everybody loves it.

The festival also marks an important boundary. After Holi the summer officially begins, the temperature shoots up, and the heat becomes gradually more unbearable. Air-conditioning repair workers are at their busiest; schools enter their final stretch before the holidays in May and June, India's cruellest months.

Holi is the last chance to go outside with friends and enjoy the sunshine and the blue skies. "I have noticed this each year. After Holi you can sense the sun is there. Somehow there is some linkage between the festival and the long summer," one veteran Delhi-ite said yesterday.

fields.headline: Life after death
fields.standfirst: Eleven years ago, her daughter was killed. Now Lesley Moreland has written a book about it - and about her meeting with the murderer. Duncan Campbell reports
fields.trailText: Eleven years ago, her daughter was killed. Now Lesley Moreland has written a book about it - and about her meeting with the murderer.  Duncan Campbell  reports.
fields.body:
On February 2 1990, Lesley Moreland and her husband Vic were having an evening meal in their Hertfordshire home when the doorbell rang. "Police, Enfield," said the man on the doorstep. Their younger daughter, Ruth, lived in Enfield. "I am very sorry. I have come to tell you that your daughter, Ruth, is dead. She has been found in suspicious circumstances."

"There is no easy way to convey that sort of information," Moreland says now. "I was just stunned. It was extremely difficult to take in."

Eleven years later, Moreland has written an account of her daughter's murder and her own long battle to be able to meet, in prison, the man who carried out the killing and to find something other than bitterness and revenge in her quest. An Ordinary Murder is published this month. It is no ordinary book.

Five years ago, I was at a seminar on crime and media organised by the National Association for the Care and Resettlement of Offenders. I was there as the Guardian's crime correspondent to discuss media coverage of crime, but by far the most interesting contribution of the evening came not from the platform but from a woman in the audience - Lesley Moreland.

Her daughter, she said, had been murdered. The murderer was not a stranger but someone who had been introduced to Ruth by her ex-boyfriend. He had a history of violence towards women. After a day of drinking and taking drugs (including LSD), he had gone to her house and stabbed her to death.

The first point Moreland wanted to make was "the way victims of violent crime are portrayed in the media as people whose lives have fallen apart and will have no further meaning". She elaborates on this in her book: "While this may be their initial reaction, it is not the full reality in the longer term. This image provides no alternative role models for future victims of violent crime."

One of the most overused clichés in crime reporting is the expression "coming to terms with". Exactly how do you "come to terms with" or "make sense of" the murder of a child?

Moreland, who has worked in the voluntary sector for 30 years, decided the last thing her lively, attractive daughter would have wanted was for her to live the rest of her life in anguish. She gradually decided she wanted to meet the man who had taken her daughter's life. "I wanted to find out more about what kind of person he was and what had been going on in his life before he killed Ruth. He didn't give evidence at his trial, so there had been no opportunity to form a first-hand opinion of him. I wanted to hear from him directly, in his own words, what had happened and why he killed Ruth. I felt he owed me an explanation."

Andrew Steel was jailed for life, with a recommendation that he serve a minimum of 13 years. What troubled Moreland, she says, was that he could just "sit it out" in prison. "He would be with people who knew neither him nor us, and I couldn't see how he could be helped to understand what he had done and why. People said I should forget him but this was impossible."

The criminal justice system was not used to such requests from the relatives of victims and for years Moreland found her attempts to meet Steel rebuffed. Finally, four years later, she was given permission to meet him, in 1995, in the company of a prison probation officer.

At their meeting, Steel told Moreland that Ruth had been kind and supportive to him - which made the killing even more difficult for her to understand. He told her that when he had staggered into Ruth's home that night, she had told him to go away and had hit him, and he had "totally lost control". He explained that his own mother had said she would never forgive him for what he had done and he told Moreland that he cried every night. "You and me both, sunshine," she thought.

"Adrenalin levels were running high," Moreland says. "It was a very high-risk thing to do for everyone and it could have gone badly wrong. I wasn't scared in terms of feeling under threat, because I knew the officer who was going to be with us. My fears were that either he wouldn't be able to speak about it because he was so overcome or daunted, or that he might attempt to tough it out and not engage with me."

At the end of the 90-minute meeting, Steel said he was scared and ashamed. They shook hands before he was taken back to his cell and Moreland was told later that after the meeting, he'd had his first night of undisturbed sleep since killing Ruth.

Moreland's book has a twist to it because there is another story within it, of her correspondence, starting the year Ruth died, with Micheal, an American prisoner now in his 15th year on death row in Texas. She got in touch with him via an organisation that matches penfriends in and out of prison. Eventually she also met the daughter of the woman he had killed.

"She was the same age as Ruth and I wasn't a dissimilar age to her mother. By the time we met, we'd had a lot of email and phone contact, but I did wonder how she would feel when she came face-to-face with me. The fact was, I had this personal friendship with the man who had killed her mother." Moreland says they "negotiated the potential problems" and now have "a comfortable and warm relationship".

Through her experiences on both sides of the Atlantic, Moreland was able to explore the ways in which the relatives of murder victims and the murderers themselves are treated in the different cultures. She has traced the ways in which people can survive, can lead their lives amidst it all. People have different ways of doing it. Neither her husband nor her other daughter has read the book and she feels perhaps they never will. "They are both very private and they would not have chosen to bring the circumstances of Ruth's death into the public arena. But one of the themes of the book is that people react very differently and there has to be support for them to do that. It is much to their credit that neither of them asked me not to write it."

Many will understand the reaction of her family, but others who read the book may also feel that Lesley Moreland, by exploring a different way of confronting murder, has opened some locked doors within the criminal justice system. With luck, it will renew the sometimes floundering debate on the issue of "restorative justice".

Micheal is still on death row; Steel remains in prison and will not be released for a while. Moreland, meanwhile, has plans for another book on a different subject.

"I still struggle with the issue of forgiveness," she concludes. "It doesn't dominate my life but it niggles away in the background. I don't cry so often now but my heart still contracts painfully if, while we are eating our evening meal, the doorbell rings."

fields.headline: Alarm bells ring across Japan
fields.standfirst:
Japan is again on the brink of collapse - in terms of finances, politics and its national identity. Jonathan Watts in Tokyo reports on how it got into this mess and assesses its chances of recovery

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: 13 March: Japan is on the brink of collapse - in terms of finances, politics and its national identity. Jonathan Watts
fields.body:
Three years after Japan narrowly averted a financial crisis that threatened to bring down the global banking system, it is once again racked by self-doubt, political drift and dire economic warnings.

The stock markets are at a 16-year low, the yen at levels not seen since early 1999 and, with the biggest public debt in the world, the finance minister Kiichi Miyazawa warned last week that the fiscal situation is close to collapse.

Leadership has never been more important, nor more obviously lacking.

A political vacuum is growing around the spectacularly unpopular prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, who has indicated that he intends to resign but will not say when.

His ruling Liberal Democratic Party is racked by infighting about a successor and scorned by an electorate that is increasingly turning its back on mainstream political parties.

This is a country that is deeply unhappy with itself. Suicide rates, unemployment, bankruptcies and crime are all near or at record highs.

The comforting old stereotypes are fading. Salarymen are anxious about the loss of old certainties like lifetime employment and promotion according to age, while fearing the rising presence of foreign competitors in the domestic market.

Office ladies are disgruntled about pay inequality and the lack of promotion opportunities. They are also putting off marriage and children, which has led to one of the lowest birthrates in the world.

Even schoolchildren and the elderly are increasingly seen as a threat: the former because of rising juvenile crime, the latter because Japan's rapidly ageing society is pushing the health and pension systems close to bankruptcy.

Such is the sense of crisis that nobody batted an eyelid recently when nationalistic former prime minister Yasuhiro Nakasone dubbed Japan "the sick man of Asia."

It's a striking turnaround from 10 years ago, when Japan was held up as a model for the world. Four decades of miraculous growth had given its population of 126 million an economy second in size only to the United States.

Government redistribution policies had minimised the income gap between rich and poor, city and country to the point where it was the envy of communists.

Social scientists from across the globe flew to Tokyo to study how the country had achieved low crime rates, 100 per cent literacy levels and the longest average life-span in human history.

With asset prices inflated by an economic bubble, Japan was selling at such a premium that the imperial palace grounds in Tokyo were estimated to be worth as much as the whole of California.

It couldn't last and it didn't.

After the bubble burst in 1989, land and stock prices came crashing down - and with them went belief in the "Japanese miracle", much of which turned out to be a simple sleight of hand by banks that were too willing to extend loans.

The years since, which are seen in Japan as "the lost decade", have been marked by a near-stagnant economy and a prolonged bout of finger pointing.

In 1993, for the first time in almost four decades, the ruling Liberal Democratic party lost its grip on power as a result of a multibillion yen corruption scandal.

In the eight years since, Japan has had seven prime ministers and a series of short-lived coalition governments.

Meanwhile, the businessmen and bureaucrats who were lauded during the years of growth have been undermined by scandal after scandal. The spotlight of criticism has spread throughout society with doctors, police and judges - all of whom previously enjoyed an almost exulted position - under fire.

The education system, which was formally held up as a model for the world, is also racked by doubt as the government tracks back and forth between insisting on more focus on traditional group-oriented values and greater scope for free-thinking individualism.

Behind all these problems is the mother of all identity crises.

Japan, a country that pursued a policy of isolation for centuries, has been trying to "catch up" ever since it opened up to the west in 1853.

While stressing the uniqueness of the nation, the government and leading businesses have simultaneously tried to emulate the west. The result was the model of Japan Inc that has become the victim of its own success.

Having caught up and overtaken the west in so many ways in 1990, the country has lost its goal and been drifting ever since. How long it will continue to do so is the subject of intense debate. And a reason why many commentators and reformers hope that the current crisis will act as a purgative to get the sick man of Asia back on its feet.

webTitle: Bob the Builder a US hit

fields.headline: Bob the Builder scores US hit
fields.trailText:
11am: The success of the series in the US has boosted HIT Entertainment's pre-tax profits by 50%, reports Dan Milmo.
Feb 9: HIT confirms £190m Barney move
Feb 1: HIT suspends shares
Oct 2: Bob the Builder drives up HIT profits
fields.body:
HIT Entertainment has brushed off doubts over the enduring popularity of Bob the Builder by announcing the cartoon character has taken the US by storm with more than 12m viewers.

The children's TV company has boomed on the back of the animated series.

However, there has been mounting concern the group relies too heavily on a character that accounts for over 60% of turnover.

However, HIT said pre-tax profits for the six months to January had risen 50% to £3m.

Turnover climbed 42% to £12.8m as Bob got to grips with the US market.

Following his debut on children's channel Nickelodeon in January, Bob is already the second biggest pre-school series on cable TV in the US.

A toy range is planned to launch in the US in the summer.

HIT's determination to crack the US market was emphasised last month when it bought Lyrick, home of Barney the dinosaur, for £190m.

Although Barney has been around since the early 90s, he has recently signed up to fresh broadcasting, toy manufacturing and publishing agreements.

HIT also has high hopes for its new series, Angelina Ballerina, which is expected reduce the dependency on Bob the Builder.

Angelina will make her debut on ITV in September and the series has been pre-sold in 20 countries.

HIT has also been quick to announce a replacement for creative boss Kate Fawkes, who stepped down this month to spend more time with her family.

She will be replaced by Emmy award-winner Jocelyn Stevenson, who worked as a writer on Sesame Street and was the co-creator of Fraggle Rock.

fields.headline: BT chiefs face axe
fields.trailText:
2.45pm: The chairman and chief executive of BT are facing mounting pressure to resign, reports Dan Milmo.
Debt-ridden BT plans rights issue
Feb 8: BT hit by rising debt
Nov 8: BT set to announce flotation of mobile phone arm
fields.body:
The chairman and chief executive of BT are facing mounting pressure to resign amid rumours the telecoms giant is about to perform an abrupt u-turn in its debt reduction strategy.

Speculation is rampant that BT will ask shareholders to buy £5bn-worth of new shares in a rights issue and abandon the flotation of its BT Wireless mobile phone division.

Such a move would force the departure of chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield and chairman Sir Iain Vallance, who unveiled the original plan to reduce BT's £30bn debt burden in November.

"A rights issue will only get support if there is a management change," said Peter Caldwell, telecoms analyst at Gerrard.

"The chairman's and chief executive's jobs will be the price for a supporting a rights issue," said Peter Caldwell.

Other analysts said the departure of the top two executives will be a boon for BT's beleaguered shares, which have tumbled from 1500p to 555p in the past 12 months.

"The quid pro quo of Vallance and Bonfield going is that it will put between £1 and £2 back on the share price. If they go it is a positive for the company," said Mark Davis, telecoms analyst at WestLB Panmure.

BT has been forced to rethink plans to float 25% of the Wireless subsidiary in the face of outright market hostility towards debt-laden telecoms operators.

European telecoms companies spent £97bn over the past year, mainly on prohibitively priced next-generation mobile phone licences.

All the major telecoms operators have had their credit ratings downgraded.

This makes it harder of them to raise debt and increase investors' scepticism about the profitability of telecoms stocks.

The disastrous float of France Telecom's Orange, which immediately sank below its slashed issue price, has compounded BT's fears about the wisdom of a Wireless flotation.

"It would be very hard for BT to get any sort of mobile issue away in the current market," said Paul Mount, telecoms analyst at Nomura.

However, a BT spokeswoman today said the group was steaming ahead with the flotation, which was announced last November and is expected to raise £5bn.

"We still intend to float up to 25% of BT Wireless by the end of the year. A rights issue is not something we would rule out but we have never said we were going to do it," she said.

Attention is now likely to turn to Philip Hampton, BT's recently appointed finance director.

He had little influence on the recent restructuring plans.

Investors believe he is a fan of a complete break-up of the company, which many believe is the only way to wring value out of the former telecoms monopoly.

One analyst, who met Mr Hampton recently, supported calls for him to be given the chief executive role should Sir Bonfield be forced out.

"Philip Hampton is extremely positive for the company and we think he is in favour of breaking it up," he said.

BT's shares slipped 3.8% or 21.5p to 534p in early trading.

fields.headline: Court rules against alcohol advertising ban
fields.trailText: 2.15pm: Europe's highest court has cast doubt on the legality of Sweden's ban on alcohol advertising, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Europe's highest court has cast doubt on the legality of Sweden's ban on alcohol advertising.

The ruling could undermine many of the laws governing European advertising.

The European court of justice ruled that the total ban on alcohol advertising went against European law after a Swedish food and drink magazine complained about the ban.

Sweden, which bans all TV, press and radio advertising for spirits, wine and beer, will now have to justify the ban to the court.

EU experts say the case sets a precedent for other advertising regulation.

A European Commission spokesman said the ban puts non-domestic advertisers at a disadvantage to local competitors and is therefore discriminatory.

The decision opens the way for the advertising industry to challenge other national restrictions in the European courts.

These could include Sweden's ban on advertising aimed at children and Germany's ban on lifetime guarantees and two for the price of one sales promotions.

France also operates restrictions on alcohol advertising.

The European Commission was forced to abandon plans for a EU-wide ban on tobacco advertising last year after the European court of justice ruled it was illegal.

The court decided the issue of whether to ban cigarette advertising should instead be decided by individual member states.

Related story

fields.headline: Guardian children's fiction prize relaunched
fields.standfirst: Entry details and list of past winners
fields.trailText: The long-established Guardian children's fiction prize is being relaunched this autumn to coincide with Children's Book Week.
fields.body:
The long-established Guardian children's fiction prize is being relaunched this autumn to coincide with Children's Book Week.

In a departure for the award, which was founded in 1965, it will be run in conjunction with the education resources website from the Guardian, Learn.co.uk, which will host online discussions on the long-listed books over the summer holidays.

Previous winners of this prestigious award include Melvin Burgess, Anne Fine and Philip Pullman. Last year's winner was Jacqueline Wilson for The Illustrated Mum, the story of how two young sisters cope with their mother's increasingly erratic behaviour.

The award is open to fiction for children aged seven and above, published in the UK between January 2000 and September 2001. There is a limit of 10 entries per publisher and previous winners are not eligible.

Submissions should be made by April 31 to Julia Eccleshare, children's books editor, 21 Tanza Road, London NW3 2UA.

webTitle: Leader: Three simple ways to lessen the plight of the poor

fields.headline: Poorest of the poor
fields.standfirst: Three simple ways to lessen their plight
fields.trailText: True to their altruistic reputation, Guardian readers have been inundating our letters column with details of how far Gordon Brown's Budget fell short of help for the poorest of the poor.
fields.body:
True to their altruistic reputation, Guardian readers have been inundating our letters column with details of how far Gordon Brown's Budget fell short of help for the poorest of the poor. They are right. The poorest of the poor, as we noted last Thursday, received little help from the chancellor. Because their benefits are linked to prices not earnings, they will have to watch an already shameful gap between the richest and poorest 10% grow even wider. The poorest are people without work - unemployed or chronically sick - and without children.

The overwhelming proportion of the extra aid which Labour has provided through its imaginative anti-poverty programmes has gone to working families - or "hard-working families" in current ministerial jargon. No one can dispute the way this has lifted 1.2m children and 800,000 adults out of poverty. But as we noted last week, this still leaves 3m children and many more adults below the poverty line - twice the level when Labour was last in power. Yet Labour did not just promise to help the poor by assisting them into work. Its famous mantra ("work for those who can, security for those who can't") also promised to help the unemployed. What can be done? The Budget is over, but the election manifesto is still to come. There are three simple reforms which Labour members should insist on the party adopting.

First, an earnings index for income support benefits in order to prevent inequality widening. Second, help for the poorest pensioners. They are being aided by the chancellor already. His minimum income guarantee (MIG), which has been given an earnings index, lifts the April single pension of £72.50 by £20 and a couple's basic pension of £115.90 by £25. But why not restore what they have lost since Margaret Thatcher broke the earnings link in 1981? That has cost every single pensioner £30 a week, and a couple £45. MIG should be lifted to these levels. Third, restore the old role of the social fund, set up to meet emergency needs of the poor (a cooker, bed or furniture). The Tories ended the grant system and insisted that loans become the main source of help - despite the desperate plight of applicants. This is plunging poor people into even further debt. Labour's social justice commission described the system as "soul destroying". Labour condemned the loans. It should have restored grants long ago.

webTitle: Foot and mouth claims Westminster victims

fields.headline: Foot and mouth claims Westminster victims
fields.standfirst:
Nick Brown has proved himself as agriculture minister, but foot and mouth may prove beyond him, writes chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText: Nick Brown has proved himself as agriculture minister, but foot and mouth may prove beyond him, writes chief political correspondent Patrick Wintour.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair asked Nick Brown to switch from the post of chief whip and head for the political Siberia that is the Ministry of Agriculture, the deeply urbane Brown told the prime minister: "You do know I am a vegan". Mr Blair's smile stalled for a second before he realised that Brown was joking. Mr Blair evidently tried to share the sense of humour.

Since this unlikely transfer, his job has been anything but a joke. He has generally been seen as a success, even if the agriculture industry has struggled desperately through two successive years of fast falling income.

He handled the fall-out from the BSE crisis without seeking to make party political points, and it seemed that when the cursed luck struck farmers again in the form of floods and swine fever, it was time that the gods must finally smile down upon them.

Instead they, and Mr Brown, were given foot and mouth disease. Apart from a silly spat with his opposite number, the sensible Tim Yeo, over whether or not to stage a Commons debate, the issue has been clear of party politics.

Over the weekend, however, the tone started to change. There had been hopes that, with a two-week incubation period, the disease would show signs of coming under control. Instead the number of cases escalated and, disturbingly, many started to appear on unexpected farms.

The vets lost the trail of the disease - it seemed pretty evident it was being carried by the wind, something not even the tightest Maff regulation can control. The Ministry of Agriculture had imposed tight controls on the transport of livestock and made funeral pyres of any diseased stock.

The controls, however, were not working, as the disease spread to Gloucestershire and Kent for the first time. The number of confirmed cases reached 173 and the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, admitted surprise and concern at the speed of the outbreak.

The normally unflappable Mr Brown nevertheless insisted the disease was contained and almost every outbreak could be traced. Maff officials pointed out that there had been 80 new cases in one day in 1967.

In the reassuring manner of a chief whip, he promised all would be well. In this he has so far retained the support of the NFU president, Ben Gill, even if, in the regions, the NFU mood is much darker. They claim there are many unexplained cases.

Yet Mr Yeo pounced - if gently - by demanding tighter controls, the intervention of the army and a halt to convoys of animals going to slaughterhouses. He argued that we are facing a national emergency, that the French and Irish had taken tougher measures and that Maff were not giving sufficiently clear guidance.

However, Mr Yeo has yet to spell out in detail what he would do differently, or where Maff has gone wrong. Until he does, the political fall-out will not be that dangerous.

The big political pressure on Labour will come in the next few weeks, when it has to be decided whether or not to press on with a May 3 election. If the number of cases goes on rising, and movement restrictions remain, it will be very difficult to argue Blair has called a free and fair election. With a year of the parliamentary term to go, he will also need to explain the urgency for the election.

There may be only 150 or so constituencies in which more than 1,000 members of the electorate are directly involved in farming, but they are vocal enough to turn the election into something of a farce.

webTitle: Geoffrey Wheatcroft on the coverage given to journalists when they die.

fields.headline: Who's in charge?
fields.standfirst: Even former prime ministers cannot expect to garner as much press coverage when they die as journalists Auberon Waugh and John Diamond.  Geoffrey Wheatcroft  claims this is a sign of an disturbing shift in the balance of power
fields.trailText: Even former prime ministers cannot expect to garner as much press coverage when they die as journalists Auberon Waugh and John Diamond. Geoffrey Wheatcroft claims this is a sign of an disturbing shift in the balance of power.
fields.body:
In 1992, I was on a Mediterranean island when a friend reached me to tell me that Peter Jenkins had died. This was kind but unnecessary: the news of Peter's death had already been reported extensively on the BBC World Service and in the International Herald Tribune. Something lodged at the back of my mind, and returned over the past few weeks.

When Auberon Waugh died in January, the Daily Telegraph covered his death on five pages. As someone said, this was more space than the paper had given Graham Greene on his death. The Guardian also had two pieces on Waugh, one an unusually long obituary (by me as it happens). Then John Diamond died, and the Guardian and the Daily Telegraph lavished space on him. As for the Times, apart from a full-dress obituary, and a leader, it covered his death on pages 1, 3, 20, and 21. Very few former cabinet ministers can expect their deaths to make the World Service and the Herald Trib, and it's unlikely that the Times will devote as much space to Lord Callaghan or John Major when they die as to Diamond.

This is not said in a spirit of hostility, or "Who do they think they are?". I know who Jenkins, Waugh and Diamond were. They were colleagues and friends of mine, whom I liked and admired. And yet, as a journalist I am left with an uneasy feeling. A cynic might say that it shows no more than media solipsism, or Fleet Street up itself. A better-informed cynic would say that newspapers nowadays have more space than they know how to fill. But there is more to it. The coverage of those mens' death also reflects an objective reality, though one which also makes me even more uneasy.

Over the past half century, there has been a huge change in the "balance of trade" between politics and journalism. Once upon a time, pols were officers and gentlemen, while journos were rogues and vagabonds. Today, compared with politicians, journalists are better educated, better paid, cleverer, more important, and quite often visibly more powerful. This is a historically important development, and not a happy one for democracy.

Within living memory, journalists knew their place. Lobby correspondents habitually addressed Tory cabinet ministers as "Sir". With a Labour government, there may not have been the same social deference, but there was an assumption of intellectual superiority on the politicians' part, which, in the days of Crossman, Jenkins, Healey and Crosland, was fully justified.

Nor was Fleet Street the place to go if you wanted to make big money, not compared with the City or the Bar, or even politics. A hundred years ago, cabinet ministers were paid £5,000 a year, getting on for three times what they earn today in real terms, and very few journalists indeed, even editors, were paid as much. Even in 1974 when WF Deedes - a journalist who had become an MP and briefly a cabinet minister - was made editor of the Daily Telegraph, his salary was less than the prime minister's at the time.

Today, I doubt very much indeed whether any national newspaper editor, quite apart from Paul Dacre with his £727,000, is paid less than the £116,339 which Tony Blair will receive after his next rise. There are now plenty of columnists making £100,000 a year, several making £200,000, and a few said to be making £300,000 (this writer not among them). Such people can afford to patronise politicians, and do.

Not that money tells the whole story. There is also a question of genuine ability shifting from politics to journalism. The change can be dated to one university and one period. In the 10 years after 1945, Cambridge produced Neal Ascherson, Samuel Brittan, Michael Frayn, George Gale, Peter Jenkins, Claire and Nicholas Tomalin, Brian Redhead, Alan Watkins, Colin Welch, Mark Boxer, Richard West and Peregrine Worsthorne. This is a remarkable list of journalistic talent. As much to the point, the only notable politician I can think of who came out Cambridge at the same time was Douglas Hurd.

The change in terms of trade was consummated in 1992. On the night of Black Wednesday, Kelvin MacKenzie, the editor of the Sun, rang John Major and told him, "John, I'm holding bucket of shit in my hands and tomorrow morning it's going to be emptied over your head." Not long before, most people would have wondered whether an unelected editor (or anyone) should address the prime minister like that. By then, neither man seems to have thought the exchange remarkable. And to judge by his abject deference towards the popular press, Tony Blair accepts the same terms.

Black Wednesday came a few months after Peter Jenkins died. I think he would have seen the point, and shared my unease.
fields.bodyText: In 1992, I was on a Mediterranean island when a friend reached me to tell me that Peter Jenkins had died. This was kind but unnecessary: the news of Peter's death had already been reported extensively on the BBC World Service and in the International Herald Tribune. Something lodged at the back of my mind, and returned over the past few weeks. When Auberon Waugh died in January, the Daily Telegraph covered his death on five pages. As someone said, this was more space than the paper had given Graham Greene on his death. The Guardian also had two pieces on Waugh, one an unusually long obituary (by me as it happens). Then John Diamond died, and the Guardian and the Daily Telegraph lavished space on him. As for the Times, apart from a full-dress obituary, and a leader, it covered his death on pages 1, 3, 20, and 21. Very few former cabinet ministers can expect their deaths to make the World Service and the Herald Trib, and it's unlikely that the Times will devote as much space to Lord Callaghan or John Major when they die as to Diamond. This is not said in a spirit of hostility, or "Who do they think they are?". I know who Jenkins, Waugh and Diamond were. They were colleagues and friends of mine, whom I liked and admired. And yet, as a journalist I am left with an uneasy feeling. A cynic might say that it shows no more than media solipsism, or Fleet Street up itself. A better-informed cynic would say that newspapers nowadays have more space than they know how to fill. But there is more to it. The coverage of those mens' death also reflects an objective reality, though one which also makes me even more uneasy. Over the past half century, there has been a huge change in the "balance of trade" between politics and journalism. Once upon a time, pols were officers and gentlemen, while journos were rogues and vagabonds. Today, compared with politicians, journalists are better educated, better paid, cleverer, more important, and quite often visibly more powerful. This is a historically important development, and not a happy one for democracy. Within living memory, journalists knew their place. Lobby correspondents habitually addressed Tory cabinet ministers as "Sir". With a Labour government, there may not have been the same social deference, but there was an assumption of intellectual superiority on the politicians' part, which, in the days of Crossman, Jenkins, Healey and Crosland, was fully justified. Nor was Fleet Street the place to go if you wanted to make big money, not compared with the City or the Bar, or even politics. A hundred years ago, cabinet ministers were paid £5,000 a year, getting on for three times what they earn today in real terms, and very few journalists indeed, even editors, were paid as much. Even in 1974 when WF Deedes - a journalist who had become an MP and briefly a cabinet minister - was made editor of the Daily Telegraph, his salary was less than the prime minister's at the time. Today, I doubt very much indeed whether any national newspaper editor, quite apart from Paul Dacre with his £727,000, is paid less than the £116,339 which Tony Blair will receive after his next rise. There are now plenty of columnists making £100,000 a year, several making £200,000, and a few said to be making £300,000 (this writer not among them). Such people can afford to patronise politicians, and do. Not that money tells the whole story. There is also a question of genuine ability shifting from politics to journalism. The change can be dated to one university and one period. In the 10 years after 1945, Cambridge produced Neal Ascherson, Samuel Brittan, Michael Frayn, George Gale, Peter Jenkins, Claire and Nicholas Tomalin, Brian Redhead, Alan Watkins, Colin Welch, Mark Boxer, Richard West and Peregrine Worsthorne. This is a remarkable list of journalistic talent. As much to the point, the only notable politician I can think of who came out Cambridge at the same time was Douglas Hurd. The change in terms of trade was consummated in 1992. On the night of Black Wednesday, Kelvin MacKenzie, the editor of the Sun, rang John Major and told him, "John, I'm holding bucket of shit in my hands and tomorrow morning it's going to be emptied over your head." Not long before, most people would have wondered whether an unelected editor (or anyone) should address the prime minister like that. Black Wednesday came a few months after Peter Jenkins died. I think he would have seen the point, and shared my unease.

webTitle: Why Vaz should take his leave

fields.headline: Why Vaz should take his leave
fields.standfirst:
Keith Vaz has breached the MPs' code of conduct and refused to cooperate with the inquiry into his behaviour. If he were a Tory, Labour would roast him for sleaze

Special report: New Labour in Power
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz has breached the MPs' code of conduct. If he were a Tory, Labour would roast him, writes Nicholas Watt, political correspondent
fields.body:
If there were any justice in politics, Keith Vaz would today be sacked as Europe minister while Peter Mandelson would once again be taking up residence in Belfast as Northern Ireland secretary.

Today's commons report into Mr Vaz's business affairs damns the Europe minister for breaching the MPs' code of conduct when he recommended an acquaintance for an honour without disclosing their financial links.

In a blow to Tony Blair's claim that his government would be purer than pure, Mr Vaz is also reprimanded for high-handed behaviour towards the parliamentary standards watchdog.

Few officials come straighter than the watchdog Elizabeth Filkin - yet she was unable to complete her inquiries in eight areas because Mr Vaz, speaking through his lawyer, refused last December to answer further questions from her.

"Mr Vaz was wrong to say to the commissioner last December that he was not prepared to answer further questions from her," today's report by the Commons Standards and Privileges committee concludes. "All members have a duty to cooperate with the commissioner."

Had a Tory minister been criticised in such terms before the last election, the likes of Mr Vaz would have lined up to demand their head on a plate for breaching the MPs' code of conduct.

Yet Mr Vaz today protested his innocence after he was cleared of improper financial behaviour on all but one count.

"I am absolutely delighted at the complete rejection by the Committee on Standards and Privileges and by the Parliamentary Commissioner Elizabeth Filkin of all the allegations made against me save one, which was raised by the Commissioner herself," Mr Vaz declared.

A minister with a surer political touch would show a bit of humility in the face of the committee's criticisms.

But Mr Vaz takes a swipe at Ms Filkin's investigations. "While I fully support the need to ensure that MPs maintain the highest possible standards of probity, the present procedures give too much latitude to the purveyors of lies and malice," he said.

Downing Street will be privately dismayed by Mr Vaz's conduct throughout this entire affair.

When Tony Blair picks up the telephone to Peter Mandelson - they are said to be in regular contact once again - the prime minister will struggle to explain why Mr Vaz should hold onto his red ministerial box while his old friend has no prospect of winning his back.

Peter Mandelson

fields.headline: 'Get in there, son!'
fields.trailText:
2.15pm: Chris Evans got in on the Celebrity Big Brother act today, offering £50,000 to Comic Relief if Chris Eubank breaks back into the house, writes Jason Deans.
TV ratings: Celebs' antics win over viewers
Mar 12: Eubank evicted
The story in pictures
Special report: Big Brother
Who should be next? Talk about it

Celebrity Big Brother website
fields.body:
Chris Evans got in on the Celebrity Big Brother act this morning, offering £50,000 to Comic Relief if Chris Eubank breaks back into the house.

Mr Evans made the offer after interviewing Eubank, who was the first Celebrity Big Brother evictee yesterday, on his Virgin Radio breakfast show this morning.

"We suggested Channel 4 put in another hotline to vote people back in," Mr Evans said.

"And I will pledge £10,000 if Channel 4 let Chris run in with a white sheet over his head at 4am. And if they don't let you in, I will pledge £50,000 to Comic Relief for you to break in yourself.

Mr Evans told Virgin listeners he would get a helicopter to drop Eubank back into the Celebrity Big Brother house, or get the SAS to do the job, adding, "Get in there son!".

Eubank said: "There's vicious guard dogs outside but I'm sure I have so much good karma they will be like puppies."

A spokeswoman for the Virgin breakfast show said the producer had been in touch with Mr Eubank's agent, who said the former boxer was definitely interested in getting back into the house.

fields.headline: Celebrity antics captivate viewers
fields.trailText: 1pm TV overnights: Celebrity Big Brother kept almost 10m viewers glued to their sets, writes Lisa O'Carroll.
fields.body:
It was difficult to tell which ailed her most - learning she was one of the first up for eviction from TV's Big Brother or being forced by Vanessa Feltz to talk about something as unsavoury as female masturbation.

But the sight of Anthea Turner's face on both occasions was a voyeur's treat.

By last night, Celebrity Big Brother had caught the imagination of the nation with a combined audience of close to 10m viewers.

The half-hour special on Channel 4 was watched by 4.1m viewers, while another 5.1m viewers caught the 10-minute update on BBC1.

And the interest was enough to dent BBC1's big Sunday night drama Ballykissangel, which was left with a rather miserable 4.8m.

Comic Relief's celebrity edition of the hit Channel 4 show started on Friday night featuring six volunteer celebrities.

Ms Feltz, Ms Turner, Jack Dee, Chris Eubank, Claire Sweeney from Brookside and Boyzone star Keith Duffy are being ejected gradually from the Big Brother house over the course of a week.

The first instalment almost doubled Channel 4's normal share of viewers - it attracted an 18.4% slice of those watching TV at the time.

Saturday night's viewing made for the most drama.

Mr Eubank was unable to contain his hostility towards the Boyzone star, who a year previously grabbed the ex-boxer's gonads as a gesture of "fun" at a celebrity fashion show.

Although the pair didn't come to blows, the incident created the dramatic tension the show needed.

Last night's escape attempt by Mr Dee, however, had all the hallmarks of a scripted stunt.

On Saturday, Mr Eubank also showed his concern for the women on the team, when he took Ms Sweeney aside to mumble that her "knickers were showing".

It was a performance that probably broke all Mr Eubank's audience records - 3.7m viewers tuned in to the Channel 4 show. The update on the BBC brought in another 5.9m viewers.

Elsewhere, Channel 5 hopes it has a hit on its hands with its US import Touch the Truck.

The bizarre endurance contest, in which 20 contestants hold on to a vehicle for as long as they can, was watched by 1m viewers.
