webTitle: Opticians angry over threat of £10 'eyesight tax'

fields.headline: Opticians angry over threat of £10 'eyesight tax'
fields.trailText: Opticians warned last night that the government is about to impose an "eyesight tax" on the dispensing of spectacles and contact lenses, including those for children.
fields.body:
Opticians warned last night that the government is about to impose an "eyesight tax" on the dispensing of spectacles and contact lenses, including those for children.

The tax, which would add about £10 to the cost of every purchase, was not mentioned by the chancellor in his budget last week. It is to be levied from June after a judgment in the House of Lords with far-reaching implications for VAT law.

The Royal National Institute for Deaf People said it was told by Customs and Excise on Friday that the judgment was also likely to lead to VAT on the private dispensing of hearing aids.

A Customs spokesman told the Guardian that its move was limited to opticians, but an official told the RNID that the judgment would eventually affect other services.

This could add 10-15% to the price of the latest digital hearing aids that are not yet available on the NHS in most areas and retail for about £2,500.

The decision by Customs to move against the opticians followed years of argument about whether their dispensing services should be exempt from VAT.

The tax was imposed in 1988, but lifted in 1995 after the courts ruled that VAT should only be levied on frames and lenses - not the cost of the advice given to customers before they decided on their purchases.

Customs decided to reintroduce the tax after a recent House of Lords ruling in an apparently unrelated case about credit card protection services. The department said this redefined VAT law. The implication for opticians was that their dispensing services should be regarded as an essential part of their sale of spectacles and therefore taxable.

The Federation of Ophthalmic and Dispensing Opticians said it was seeking an urgent meeting with health ministers to overturn the decision by "irresponsible" Customs officials that could force the closure of opticians in areas and small towns threatening the availability of eye tests.

Bob Hughes, general secretary of the federation, said: "The VAT imposed would have to be passed on to patients. The current average cost for a pair of spectacles at £108.19 would need to increase by more than £10 for opticians to retain their current level of return. One result would be that the recent introduction of free eye examinations for those aged 60 and over would be mostly negated by the need to increase spectacle prices.

"For children and those on low incomes, it will become increasingly difficult to obtain corrective eyewear without paying a supplement on top of the current NHS vouchers."

A spokesman for Customs said opticians gained £275m in 1995 when the department repaid VAT that he been levied over the previous seven years. "We said they should pass that saving on to their customers. They refused. If they kept the money then, they should not pass on the tax to their customers this time," he said.

The RNID said the ruling would have a serious impact on 180,000 people who buy private hearing aids every year.

Although 88% of aids were provided free on the NHS, people in most parts of the country had to buy privately if they wanted the latest technology.

The price was already expensive. Nearly three quarters of the cost of a hearing aid went to pay for the work done by the audiologist dispensing it that until now has been exempt from VAT.

James Strachan, chief executive of RNID, said: "Far too many people, in desperation and often having to go into debt, buy hearing aids privately because of the inadequacies of the NHS. To add to this a 10-15% tax burden is astonishing. Any caring government would eliminate the effect of this decision as a priority."

webTitle: Comment: another shocking report on our jails out this week

fields.headline: Behind bars
fields.standfirst: This week the chief inspector of prisons will publish another shocking report on the state of our jails
fields.trailText: This week the chief inspector of prisons will publish another shocking report on the state of our jails.
fields.body:
Little has changed at Winson Green prison, Birmingham, since Barry Prosser, aged 32, was kicked to death in its healthcare centre. Eighteen years later it is still regarded, by common consent in the world of criminal justice, as the worst prison in Britain.

In yet another shocking inspection report to be published on Thursday, Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, will confirm that the "Prosser prison" still deserves its dismal title. "Rambo" will detail the full extent of the "appalling" and "filthy" conditions inside the Birmingham prison when he inspected it last July. He will highlight the case of a mentally ill prisoner who was denied a change of clothes for weeks on end, and conclude that things are actually worse than when he last visited the place in 1995 and 1998.

In a pre-emptive strike last month designed to shock the prison service out of its lethargy, Martin Narey, the director-general, threatened to resign and made it clear he accepts the expected Ramsbotham verdict. Indeed he went further and clearly hinted he believes that physical brutality still goes on within its walls.

To sweeten the pill, the chief inspector's report on Armley prison, Leeds, once the most destructive of the prison service's overcrowded "hellholes", will be published on the same day as the Birmingham indictment. It will reveal a prison which has been been prepared to change its approach to create a more healthy environment.

But it will only underline the tragic merry-go-round that lies at the heart of our prison system. Last year it was the young offenders' institution at Portland that was exposed as a national disgrace. Now it is said to provide the best care for juveniles in the country. Instead, Brinsford youth jail, near Wolverhampton, and Stoke Heath, in Shropshire, provide the latest examples of what has been called "the litany of failure and moral neglect". Meanwhile as last night's Panorama television programme once again demonstrated, the numbers held inside the largest of our young offender institutions, Feltham, in west London, mean it repeatedly fails to fulfil its basic duty of care. With four governors in four years, its recent history features teenage suicides and the racist murder of Zahid Mubarek.

The situation in Birmingham and Feltham represents something more fundamental than an occasional failure. It demonstrates that over a period of 20 years or more there has been an underlying malaise in the prison system which has never really been tackled.

Part of the problem is that prisons are not seen as a public service. When the chancellor, Gordon Brown, stood up last week to announce his extra billions for hospitals and schools, nobody expected him to do the same for prisons. Yet we do expect 130,000 of our citizens each year to endure conditions that are frequently condemned as indecent by those whom we appoint to inspect them. Not all of the reports are negative, but Ramsbotham only gets round the 135 establishments once every six years.

Perhaps if all prisoners were given the vote, politicians would take as much interest in them as they do in their local police station or school. It may be news to some MPs, but the punishment involved in a prison sentence is supposed to be the loss of liberty - not living in the inhumane conditions inside some of our jails.

Tony Blair may have been the first serving prime minister to visit a prison but the malaise has become so deep-seated in some parts of the prison system that more radical solutions are needed. It is time to consider publicly one option that is already being debated privately within the Home Office. The prison service has proved itself incapable of running some types of jails. The first that come to mind are young offender institutions and women's prisons - both of which are completely different propositions from the average local prison holding 800 men serving short to medium sentences.

Perhaps it is time to realise that the adult prison service is no longer fit to look after young teenage offenders or women prisoners and that "prison culture" is simply not what the punishment and rehabilitation of these groups of offenders is about. In nearly all non-violent cases they are quite simply different from the thousands of career criminals who fill some of our prisons. In the case of young offenders, the government should once again approach the children's charities and other non-profit organisations - or even local authorities - to see if they are willing to get involved in the provision of secure accommodation for such teenagers.

They turned their backs when Michael Howard came touting his secure training centres, on the grounds that they were more about punishment than education, and left it to Group 4, with initially disastrous results. Smaller but more units is the way to go, so that 900 youngsters are never held together again as they once were in the Feltham warehouse. The network of women's prisons would benefit from a similar exercise.

webTitle: SAG award boosts Julia's Oscar chances for Erin

fields.headline: SAG award boosts Julia's Oscar chances for Erin
fields.trailText: Julia Roberts, Benicio Del Toro, Judi Dench and Albert Finney were among the big winners at the SAG awards in Los Angeles last night
fields.body:
The American Actors Union, the Screen Actors Guild (SAG), currently in the middle of fierce negotiations to avert the forthcoming strikes by writers and actors in Hollywood this summer, forgot its worries last night and held its annual awards ceremony in Los Angeles.

Julia Roberts increased her Oscar chances by picking up the Best Actress award for her portrayal of a feisty legal assistant in Erin Brockovich and the actress gave an emotional acceptance speech.

 To hear Julia Roberts' speech, click here. (If you do not have Realplayer, you can download it free here)

In a surprising twist, Benicio Del Toro, nominated as Best Supporting Actor for the Academy Awards, picked up the Best Actor award for his role in Steven Soderbergh's Traffic. Del Toro thanked his fellow cast members on receiving the award, claiming: "I'm only as good as them."

The whole cast of the drugs drama then went on to win the Best Ensemble Cast award (SAG's equivalent to Best Film).

The Brits didn't do too badly, picking up the two Supporting Actor awards. Albert Finney won Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of attorney Ed Masry in Erin Brockovich and Judi Dench was awarded the Best Supporting Actress prize for her role alongside Juliette Binoche in Lasse Hallstrom's Chocolat.

Boosting his Oscar chances immeasurably, Ang Lee was named Best Film Director for Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

SAG's film awards are considered a good indicator of the Oscars, since actors make up the largest single voting block (23%) within the Academy.

The only mention of the forthcoming strike which could cripple America's film industry came from the US Guild's president who noted that not only was acting a collaborative enterprise, "But so is our hard-won collecting bargaining success."

fields.headline: Guardian website wins online award
fields.trailText: 10am: Guardian Unlimited has won best online media property for the second year running at the prestigious Revolution awards.
fields.body:
Guardian Unlimited has walked off with the award for best online media property for the second year running at the prestigious Revolution awards.

It won the judges' vote in the face of heavy competition from the recently revamped FT.com, Silicon.com, Emap Digital's Travel and ZDNet.

The top award of the evening went to Carol Dukes, who was crowned person of the year.

Agency of the year went to digital media house i-level and start-up of the year was won by food delivery service Leapingsalmon.com.

Other winners included Amazon.co.uk for online retailer of the year and Coca-Cola for integrated marketing campaign of the year.

SMS retailer Scan picked up the award for best wireless interactive service and Lateral landed yet another award for online advertising - for the agency's work on Sega.

webTitle: Mandelson muscles in on debate over north-south divide

fields.headline: Mandelson muscles in on debate over north-south divide
fields.trailText: Labour is gearing up to make an historic shift of resources from the wealthy south to the poorer northern regions of Britain amid growing concern among party strategists about apathy and disaffection among heartland voters.
fields.body:
Labour is gearing up to make an historic shift of resources from the wealthy south to the poorer northern regions of Britain amid growing concern among party strategists about apathy and disaffection among heartland voters.

As Labour's Scottish conference heard repeated warnings against apathy yesterday, it also emerged that the less-favoured regions may get another vocal backbench champion, ex-cabinet minister, Peter Mandelson, now shoring up his political base at Hartlepool on Teesside.

Downing Street last night played down a leaked memo in which Jeremy Heywood, Tony Blair's economic adviser in the cabinet secretariat, wrote of the "tough decisions" soon needed after the coming election - "if we are talking about a large shift of resources from London to the north".

But a welter of statistics have underlined the deep divisions of wealth and poverty within Britain, among the sharpest in the industrialised world, most evident in the old north-south divide despite Mr Blair's insistence - shared by the mayor of London, Ken Livingstone - that the divisions within regions are just as bad.

With Gordon Brown, the chancellor, using last week's budget to show growing confidence in openly-redistributive policies, the former Northern Ireland secretary also signalled his own determination to flag up regional disparities.

After a string of weekend constituency engagements, Mr Mandelson, who has been tipped to speak out on Downing Street's behalf on such issues as Europe, added the regions to his election agenda.

"One of the themes of the election is spreading prosperity around the country. I would like to see this become a more prominent feature of the party's campaign in the coming election because everyone has to feel they have a stake in every region, every community ... they have to feel they have a stake in the government's successes ... there are very wide disparities."

His intervention in the regional debate comes as Mr Heywood's leaked memo underlines that Downing Street is keen to find new ways of compensating underperforming regions. The key mechanism for switching resources from south to north lies in revising the standard spending assessment (SSA) formula under which Whitehall distributes grants to local councils.

Staistics show why northern cabinet ministers John Reid, Alistair Darling and Helen Liddell - all Scots - warned against Tory and Scottish nationalist efforts to derail Labour's hopes of a second term.

In Mr Blair's adopted north-east, where Mr Mandelson's seat adjoins Sedgefield, the GDP per head has dropped to 23% below the national average. Mr Mandelson can claim a track record in standing up for the region.

Schools in Labour controlled Northumberland and Mr Blair's Durham receive considerably less per pupil than richer London boroughs.

In a letter to him last year, Durham head teachers complained that school buildings were falling apart through lack of funds.

webTitle: Comment: government must take on challenge of urban redevelopment

fields.headline: Dirty old towns
fields.standfirst: Government must take on the challenge of northern inner cities, as blighted wastelands stand cheek by jowl with up-market re-development
fields.trailText: Government must take on the challenge of northern inner cities, as blighted wastelands stand cheek by jowl with up-market re-development.
fields.body:
My daily walk to work takes me from a redeveloping neighbourhood in a big northern conurbation, past rubble-strewn wastelands which housed the metal bashers and mill workers of the world's first industrial city, down eerie underpasses below expressways which plough through former communities - and into the centre itself. In barely a mile, I leave new houses valued at little more than £50,000 before hitting trendy, canal-side loft apartments which can sell for up to a £1m. Manchester city centre, like the cores of Leeds, Newcastle and - increasingly - Liverpool, is thriving. Developers are falling over themselves to buy old mills and workshops written off as worthless 10 years ago. Everyone, from exclusive retailers to expensive restaurateurs, wants in.

But, as a report undertaken for the Guardian by Professor Brian Robson of Manchester University says, cheek by jowl with the new penthouses, restaurants, and up-market stores, lies "the land of the forgotten ... the endless rows of impoverished terrace housing and half empty council housing where unemployment is horrendous, where houses sell - if at all - for under £10,000, where crime ... traps people in their homes, where drugs are common currency..."

Northern cities are increasingly characterised by the reverse of the north American "doughnut" phenomenon, in which original city centres become hollowed out and deserted. In Britain's north, vibrant rebuilt centres are surrounded by wastelands, with many trapped in a cycle of negative equity.

A long the M62 corridor, from Liverpool to Manchester and the Lancashire towns, 280,000 homes (100,000 of them private properties) are blighted, according to recent research by Birmingham University. The wider north-west already has more derelict land than anywhere else in the country - tens of thousands of acres eminently suitable for redevelopment.

Ministers are now committed to an ambitious policy of neighbourhood renewal, with a promise to pump hundreds of millions into deprived communities, linked to an array of performance targets. This all seems extremely promising. The government does take poverty seriously. But, as Brian Robson points out in his report, if government policy is now to focus on the neighbourhood and the general delivery of council services (fine for London, no doubt), it will miss some of the main causes of poverty and deprivation it is trying to ameliorate in the north.

Poor communities, he argues, do not emerge in a vacuum. Their fortunes reflect the wider economies of cities in which they exist. The challenge, then, is not to wait for that elusive "trickle down", but to act positively to channel city centre wealth to the outer ring. With government grants to town halls now skewed in favour of London and the south, because northern cities and conurbations are losing people, that task is not easy, although ministers are now - belatedly - considering switching some funds from south to north by revising a complex Whitehall spending formula. The government's equally ambitious regional agenda - creating eight development agencies (RDAs) and pushing up their budgets by £500m - has yet to have any impact because it was not quite clear what the RDAs were meant to achieve: the south-east RDA, for instance, sees its task as going for yet more growth at all costs to compete with the super-regions of Europe.

It wants to keep the big corporate headquarters, and research labs along the M4 and around Oxford, with the less-favoured regions taking the more mundane back office functions. Such a policy, not surprisingly, has pushed regions such as the north-east - and the cities of the north - further down the prosperity league table.

On the day that Professor Robson produced his report, government statisticians published even more sobering figures showing - yes -that the north-south divide had actually widened under New Labour. In its first three years, GDP per head in the north-east had fallen by a point to 23% below the national average - while London was almost 30% above. Not for nothing did the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, speak of "unacceptably wide gaps" between regions. While no one doubts his commitment to the challenge, it will take more than brave words to push provincial cities and their wider regions up the prosperity league. As Richard Rogers, chairman of the government's urban task force, recently said, this should top New Labour's agenda for a second term - with a minister for urban affairs in the cabinet. He might not have to wait too long.

fields.headline: The internet: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The internet revolution poses major challenges and opportunities for all public sector professionals, especially as the government sees it as a major factor in improving access to and quality of services
fields.body:
The internet revolution poses major challenges and opportunities for all public sector professionals, especially as the government sees it as a major factor in improving access to and quality of services.

Health care faces one of the biggest changes following the launch of the government's £500m four-year plan to wire up the NHS to the net in January.

The strategy, Building the Information Core - implementing the NHS plan, includes an electronic booking system for appointments, electronic medical records, tele-consultations and electronically transmitted laboratory test results.

Ministers believe increased use of electronic communications will reduce the delays and inefficiencies in accessing NHS care that frustrate patients.

GPs will be able to book hospital appointments for their patients directly via the internet during consultations rather than by letter, which often adds to delays.

But doctors are concerned about the proposal to use electronic patient records - now being piloted at several GP surgeries - and email consultations, warning they could undermine confidentiality. They also fear that the burgeoning number of websites offering health advice will leave them inundated with "cyberchondriacs".

The government also believes e-commerce has a key role to play in regeneration. Last November, trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers announced that money from the government's £30m phoenix fund, aimed at helping new businesses get off the ground, will be directed at boosting e-enterprises in deprived areas.

Meanwhile, councils have been given five years to start delivering all their services electronically but progress could prove slow as many local authorities are not yet fully up to speed with plans for e-government.

A survey of more than 200 heads of IT last December found that senior officers and politicians in three-quarters of local authorities have only a patchy or poor understanding of ministers' electronic service delivery plans for local government.

There are pockets of innovation, however. The royal borough of Kingston-upon-Thames, south-west of London, now offers social care online.

The children and families division of the borough's community services directorate has set up Young Livin', a help and advice website for local young people, which offers email access to a social work service.

Similar projects are being developed by charities such as the NSPCC. The voluntary sector arguably stands to gain most from the net, with the advent of online fundraising and campaigning. In January, the Charities Aid Foundation announced that it had raised £1m through its websites.

However, many charities have yet to exploit the net's full potential. A report entitled Virtual Promise published in February found that many charities only use the net for news, links to other websites and for email inquiries. Few charities use the internet for cost cutting, online training or job applications.

fields.headline: Vaz cleared over campaign donations
fields.standfirst: The full text of the report
fields.trailText: Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, was today cleared of impropriety - for the second time in four days.
fields.body:
Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe, was today cleared of impropriety - for the second time in four days.

A report by the standards and privileges committee - parliament's watchdog on sleaze - found no evidence of any wrongdoing in the campaign donations declared by the Labour MP for Leicester East.

But he is reprimanded on one minor count - a lack of openness in declaring a financial benefit from an Asian businessman whom Mr Vaz recommended for an honour in 1997.

The dossier was compiled by standards commissioner Elizabeth Filkin after allegations that Mr Vaz had accepted donations from businessmen in his constituency without declaring them.

Ms Filkin criticises members of Mr Vaz's constituency Labour party for not helping her with her inquiries - but dismisses a further eight complaints against the MP.

The conclusion comes just days after the controversial foreign office minister was cleared by the Hammond report of any impropriety in his relationship with the billionaire Hinduja brothers.

Mr Vaz has always declared his innocence during the 13-month investigation into his affairs - and friends of the MP have claimed the accusations are part of a racist witch-hunt.

The allegations surfaced when Andrew Milne, a former employee of City lawyer Sarosh Zaiwalla, claimed that his boss had paid £2,000 for an office for the then-opposition MP, and that the money was not properly declared and accounted for.

The inquiry was widened to include allegations that Mr Vaz took money from businessmen in his constituency, one of whom sought help with a planning application.

He also admitted using the Foreign Office building in Whitehall for a meeting between an Asian restaurateur and Labour party donor, and an insurance firm.

The Foreign Office confirmed the unusual meeting - but declared it did not breach the ministerial code of conduct.

webTitle: Arsenal draw plum tie against Spurs

fields.headline: Arsenal draw plum tie against Spurs
fields.trailText: An FA Cup semi-final north London will be drooling over and the police must be dreading was thrust upon the country yesterday when Tottenham beat West Ham 3-2 at Upton Park to earn a meeting with Arsenal.
fields.body:
An FA Cup semi-final north London will be drooling over and the police must be dreading was thrust upon the country yesterday when Tottenham beat West Ham 3-2 at Upton Park to earn a meeting with Arsenal.

Liverpool, 4-2 winners at Tranmere yesterday, play Second Division Wycombe Wanderers in the other semi-final. The matches will take place on April 8 at neutral stadiums, which are expected to be announced tomorrow.

With Wembley, Twickenham and Cardiff last night ruled out as possible venues for the Tottenham-Arsenal match, the Football Association and the police will have to consider taking the game outside the capital.

Villa Park - a logical choice for the other semi-final - and Old Trafford would be possibilities, though for security reasons it may be decided to stage the game at Chelsea, the largest neutral ground in London. The FA Cup semi- finals between the sides in 1991 and 1993 both took place at Wembley.

"We are hoping to make a decision on the venues within the next 48 hours," an FA spokesman, Paul Newman, said last night. "It will involve discussions with the clubs concerned, various local authorities and police.

"The fact that Arsenal and Tottenham have been drawn together doesn't pose any particular problems as big London derbies are played in the Premiership every week."

Wherever that match is staged, Tottenham fans will hope history is about to repeat itself. It is said to be lucky for Spurs when the year ends in one and in 1991 they beat Arsenal in their FA Cup semi-final, famously helped by Paul Gascoigne's long-range free-kick, and went on to lift the trophy.

Arsenal took revenge two years later, winning 1-0 with a goal from Tony Adams and going on to beat Sheffield Wednesday in the final. Both those Arsenal teams were managed by George Graham, now in charge of Spurs.

Yesterday Graham, who criticised the decision to stage the draw before Tottenham's game, saw two goals by his record signing Sergei Rebrov and another from Gary Doherty overcome West Ham in an absorbing tie.

Arsenal had comfortably beaten Blackburn 3-0 at Highbury the previous day when Wycombe grabbed the headlines by winning 2-1 at Leicester. They have never before been beyond the third round.

Their reward is a tie against Liverpool, a fixture which carries particular resonance for the Wycombe manager Lawrie Sanchez. He scored the only goal of the 1988 FA Cup final for Wimbledon against Liverpool to secure an unexpected triumph.

Liverpool's manager Gérard Houllier, looking to add the FA Cup to the Worthington Cup his team won last month, played down suggestions that they had got a favourable draw. "Maybe there will be a bit more pressure on us because we are in the Premiership and they're in the lower division," he said.

"We know at this stage that the lower team will rise to the occasion and play probably above their usual level, and we know we have to do that if we want to go through."

fields.headline: Media Business
fields.standfirst: Publication date: March 12
fields.trailText: March 12: Granada Enterprises is considering shedding staff after ITV revenues dropped by around a third.
fields.body:
Granada's sales arm Granada Enterprises is considering shedding staff after ITV revenues dropped by around a third year on year.

Debenhams has closed its customer magazine and transfered its budget to an above-the-line advertising campaign.

Initiative Media has promoted Ilker Shakir to broadcast director, replacing David Cuff.

MediaCom has won the £35m global planning and buying task for Marconi.

The relaunch of the Sunday Express - backed by an advertising campaign starring Jeremy Beadle - has failed to add any readers to the paper's falling circulation.

Nick Theakstone, MediaVest's broadcast director, has been promoted to joint deputy managing director following a restructure of the management team.

webTitle: When the law is an ass

fields.headline: When the law is an ass
fields.standfirst: After a boy was expelled from school, two local newspapers published the story. The editors followed the law to ensure he was not identified. Or so they thought. Yet last week both were found guilty in a criminal court.  Roy Greenslade on the implications for other editors
fields.trailText: March 12: Why were two editors guilty in a criminal court when they followed the law? Roy Greenslade investigates.
fields.body:
David Briffett has been a journalist for 46 years and an editor for 35 of them. For the past 24 years he has edited the West Sussex County Times in Horsham, and he expected to retire next Friday without a stain on his character after a successful and satisfying career.

Further down the county, Simon Bradshaw has edited the Brighton Evening Argus for almost three years, having spent half of his 21 years on newspapers as a senior executive. Until last week, he also had an unblemished record.

These men run papers that are the backbone of the British press, the local weeklies and regional titles that exist to serve their communities.

They are not risk-takers. They don't print scandalous kiss-and-tell stories. They try not to intrude into people's private lives unless there is good reason.

Like all editors, they are conscious of the many laws which constrain what they can and cannot publish, especially when it comes to reporting on children involved in court cases.

So on the day in February last year when a story appeared on their screens about a boy who had secured a judicial review of his expulsion from school, they noted that the court had imposed a section 39 order. This is the section of the 1933 children and young persons act which bans the media from identifying children in court hearings.

Briffett and Bradshaw knew the drill: no name of boy, no name of school, no addresses, nothing that should lead their readers to identify the boy.

The stories they published did give his age, but didn't make clear whether it was his current age or at the time he was expelled in 1998. They both stated the reasons for his expulsion, giving the exact date it happened and the exact date of his starting at another school.

After publication, the boy's mother was furious. She claimed that the stories had enabled people in her community to identify her son.

What followed was an extraordinary departure from legal precedent. After tightening the section 39 order, a judge gave a broad hint that the editors should be prosecuted for breaching the original order instead of suffering the much more usual penalty of being hauled before the high court for a contempt hearing.

Briffett and Bradshaw were therefore charged with publishing articles that contravened section 39, a case heard before Mid-Sussex magistrates in Haywards Heath. Last week, that court found them guilty and fined the pair £2,500 each, thus criminalising them.

Their barrister, Gavin Millar QC, says: "The whole exercise in taking them before a criminal court is inappropriate and disproportionate. They were making a professional judgment, and this conviction could well be in breach of the human rights act."

The editors and the owners of their papers, Newsquest and Johnston Press, are sure to appeal, but the convictions show just how difficult, if not impossible, it is to make editorial decisions while carrying out the prime task of the press: to inform.

Since I must also avoid falling foul of section 39, I cannot go into the details of the offending story, but my reading of it suggests that the boy's court victory was important for the Horsham community to know about.

As for the case against Briffett and Bradshaw, it was clearly inadequate, if not absurd. It largely consisted of the boy's family and friends telling the court that, in their view, the story had identified the boy. Well it would, wouldn't it, because they already knew about the expulsion? In passing sentence on the editors, magistrate Rosemary Scott said: "We accept that a total stranger would not be able to identify him from these reports but the question for us is to what extent persons with some knowledge of the boy would be able to identify him from the reports.

"We believe parliament's intention was to apply this law to this kind of person and not just a complete stranger."

She accepted that work colleagues of the boy's mother had identified the boy because of their background knowledge and not because of the articles.

The magistrate pointed out that another family friend, with children at the same school as the boy before he was excluded, had been able to identify him.

So what? If papers are to have any merits at all, they must be able to publish information, even about children, which is important in the wider public interest.

The editors had taken the necessary precautions by removing any details which could have led Horsham and district's 120,000 citizens who did not know the boy from discovering who he was. With six secondary schools in the area, it was also virtually impossible for anyone to recall who left one and started at another on specified dates some 21 months before.

Briffett, whose paper sells 25,000 copies a week, is baffled and upset by the action against him. He says: "We have a system here that the newsdesk flag up any section 39s. Then my deputy and I always go through the stories together. We felt it complied with the act and published in good faith. All editors face an impossible situation now. When these stories occur we have to try to ascertain who has prior information on the case without knowing what they know."

As Bradshaw points out: "Editors will be expected to second-guess what a close family friend knows. It could lead to us not reporting anything, and surely that isn't what parliament intended."

Both men have received strong support from the society of editors. Director Bob Satchwell says the case has "dangerous implications for the key principle of open justice."

He echoes the editors' solicitor, Dominic Ward, who says that "the danger of this [decision] is that it is likely to lead to a climate of self-censorship in the press."

I share that view wholeheartedly and I also want to take issue with the magistrate's final admonition to Briffett and Bradshaw. "You are both professionals in your field," she said, "and you should have taken more care."

That is manifestly unfair. They took great care. They are victims of an implausible restriction on freedom and the people's right to know.

 Six weeks ago I wrote an article criticising Peter Mandelson in robust terms. Though I do not take back most of what I wrote, which centred on my belief that his poor relationship with the press stemmed from his manipulation of it, I must put the record straight.

I accepted that he resigned because he made an inappropriate telephone call in support of Srichand Hinduja's bid to obtain a British passport.

I would not have written so trenchant a piece unless I believed that to have been the case. The Hammond Report establishes that the position was a good deal more complex than it appeared at the time, and it seems only fair to apologise for the tone of the article I wrote then. It would be good journalistic manners if all those who rushed to judgment that day say sorry too.

webTitle: Nine hurt in rush-hour train collision

fields.headline: Nine hurt in rush-hour train collision
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Nine people suffered slight injuries today when two rush-hour passenger trains collided in a London suburb.
fields.body:
Nine people suffered slight injuries today when two rush-hour passenger trains collided in a London suburb.

Both trains involved in the accident at Hither Green station in Lewisham, south-east London, were damaged, though neither was derailed, British transport police said. Forty-nine people were killed in a train crash at Hither Green in November 1967.

Emergency services arrived on the scene after the 8.08am Connex South East Networker Crayford to Cannon Street service "clipped" the back of the 7.58am Connex service from Sevenoaks to Cannon Street at 8.35am.

It is thought the 7.58am Sevenoaks train may have passed a signal at danger.

Passengers from the Crayford train were able to exit their train onto the platform at Hither Green. Customers on the Sevenoaks train were led to safety after the power to the line had been switched off and all trains halted.

The health and safety executive launched an immediate inquiry into the accident which comes less than two weeks after the Selby rail crash that claimed 10 lives.

Train services in the south-east have been disrupted, with all mainline services from the Kent coast now diverted to London's Victoria station. Connex has advised passengers to expect severe delays and cancellations at short notice. Replacement bus services are being arranged.

fields.trailText: Paul Merson has told Aston Villa manager John Gregory that the club will not become one of England's big teams simply by flashing the cash. "You can't be naïve and think that money will solve the problem and just sign big name players", he said. "You have to bring in good young players and make sure you develop your own talent through the ranks."
fields.body:
Paul Merson has told Aston Villa manager John Gregory that the club will not become one of England's big teams simply by flashing the cash. "You can't be naïve and think that money will solve the problem and just sign big name players", he said. "You have to bring in good young players and make sure you develop your own talent through the ranks."

Meanwhile John Gregory, presumably not in direct response to Merson, has declared he is still interested in signing Spanish striker Javi Moreno from Alaves. "We are still very interested in Javi Moreno", he said. "He is the top scorer in Spain this season. I am a big fan of Spanish football and we are still keeping an eye on him." Villa will move for Moreno in the summer, but he won't come cheap.

Teamtalk reports that West Ham will complete the signing of Stephen Hughes from Everton, and that one of Hammers' big name summer signings could be Paris St Germain's wantaway forward Laurent Robert.

Planet football reports that representatives from both Manchester United and Real Madrid watched young Ajax midfielder Rafael van der Vaart this weekend. The 18-year-old left midfielder scored the third goal in Ajax's 3-3 draw with Groningen.

fields.headline: BBC2 subverts soap genre
fields.trailText: 12.30pm: BBC2 is aiming to subvert the soap genre with a satirical new drama by an ex-EastEnders writer, reports Jason Deans.
fields.body:
BBC2 is aiming to subvert the soap genre with a satirical new drama about a suburban street with a racist bully, single mum who works on a phone-sex line, and newly arrived family from hell.

Residents focuses on 10 households in St George's Close, a street in what is billed as a typical English suburban estate, over a long hot summer.

Creator Tony Basgallop, who spent four years writing for EastEnders, describes Residents as an "anti soap".

"I wanted to take all the known soap cliches and crank them up a notch," he said. "What I discovered was just how fragile the sense of community actually is."

The main characters include Roger Nut, who trades racist insults with his Sikh neighbour, and Lesley Eastern, a single mum who divides her time between her three-year-old daughter and working on a phone-sex line.

But things are really stirred by the arrival of that soap staple, the family from hell, in the shape of dole-swindling hooligans the Conans.

St George's Close is also home to a gay couple, a newly-wed black couple and two ex-student slackers.

"You can choose your friends, but you can't choose your neighbours and this show explores just how unlucky you can be," said BBC2 controller Jane Root.

"Tony Basgallop is writing in the spirit of soaps without adhering to their methods," she said.

"The result is a wonderful mix of the hilarious and the astonishing."

Residents is due to go out from mid-May, with a 60-minute opener followed by six half-hour shows.

The drama was shot between August and October last year in a disused airbase in Oxfordshire.

It has been produced by Pier Wilkie and directed by Richard Heslop and Peter Lydon.

The executive producers are Ruth Caleb and Hilary Salmon.

Residents focuses on 10 households in St George's Close, a street in what is billed as a typical English suburban estate, over a long hot summer. Creator Tony Basgallop, who spent four years writing for EastEnders, describes Residents as an "anti soap". "I wanted to take all the known soap cliches and crank them up a notch," he said. "What I discovered was just how fragile the sense of community actually is." The main characters include Roger Nut, who trades racist insults with his Sikh neighbour, and Lesley Eastern, a single mum who divides her time between her three-year-old daughter and working on a phone-sex line. But things are really stirred by the arrival of that soap staple, the family from hell, in the shape of dole-swindling hooligans the Conans. St George's Close is also home to a gay couple, a newly-wed black couple and two ex-student slackers. "You can choose your friends, but you can't choose your neighbours and this show explores just how unlucky you can be," said BBC2 controller Jane Root. "Tony Basgallop is writing in the spirit of soaps without adhering to their methods," she said. "The result is a wonderful mix of the hilarious and the astonishing." Residents is due to go out from mid-May, with a 60-minute opener followed by six half-hour shows. The drama was shot between August and October last year in a disused airbase in Oxfordshire. It has been produced by Pier Wilkie and directed by Richard Heslop and Peter Lydon. The executive producers are Ruth Caleb and Hilary Salmon.

webTitle: In brief: Brad and Julia stay on top in US

fields.headline: Brad and Julia stay on top in US
fields.standfirst: Plus: Kevin Costner plugs new movie to Tony Blair; Paltrow and Streep in schizophrenic partnership; Spielberg to put Honest Abe on screen
fields.trailText: Plus: Kevin Costner plugs new movie to Tony Blair; Paltrow and Streep in schizophrenic partnership; Spielberg to put Honest Abe on screen
fields.body:
 The Brad Pitt/Julia Roberts star vehicle The Mexican has topped the US box office for the second consecutive weekend, grossing a further $12.1m (£8.24m) to take its ten-day total to over $38m (£25.89m). The media satire 15 Minutes, starring Robert de Niro and Edward Burns, debuted in second position, taking $10.5m (£7.15m), while the other big weekend opener, the teen-romance Get Over It, starring Kirsten Dunst, only managed to make number six, with a disappointing $4.4m (£2.99m).

 Kevin Costner has recommended that Tony Blair should watch his latest film Thirteen Days very closely. The Hollywood star believes that Blair and other world leaders are not taking the possibility of a nuclear conflict seriously enough. American President George W Bush has already seen the story of the 1962 Cuban missile crisis, as has Bill Clinton, but Costner, who arrives in London today for the film's British premiere, is keen for the Prime Minister to take notice as well. "This is clearly a very political movie," Costner told the Independent. "And I do want Tony Blair to see it."

 Gwyneth Paltrow is in negotiations to star alongside Meryl Streep in an adaptation of Jacki Lynden's acclaimed 1997 Memoir, Daughter of the Queen of Sheba. The book describes Lyden's Wisconsin childhood, in which her mother could be transformed by her manic depression into the Queen of Sheba or Marie Antoinette. Streep and Paltrow are set to play mother and daughter in the story which will use the memoirs as a backdrop to focus on the daughter's adult life as a war correspondent.

 DreamWorks Pictures has paid an undisclosed sum for the film rights to Pulitzer Prize-winning historian Doris Kearns Goodwin's as yet unpublished biography of Abraham Lincoln. Studio head Steven Spielberg is apparently keen to direct the project which will focus on Lincoln's White House years. If Spielberg goes ahead with the biopic, he will not be the first celebrated film-maker to do so as he will join such distinguished company as John Ford, who directed Henry Fonda as Young Mr Lincoln, and DW Griffith, who cast Walter Huston as Abraham Lincoln.

webTitle: Strident separatist takes reins in Quebec

fields.headline: Strident separatist takes reins in Quebec
fields.standfirst: Quebec's outspoken new premier, Bernard Landry, is already upsetting apple carts with his alarming tendency to speak before he thinks, writes Anne McIlroy in Ottowa
fields.trailText: 12 March: Quebec's outspoken new premier, Bernard Landry, is already upsetting apple carts, writes Anne McIlroy .
fields.body:
The new premier of Quebec is a hot-tempered separatist who, before he was even sworn in last week, angered Quebeckers and Canadians alike by calling the Maple Leaf flag a red rag.

Bernard Landry apologised for that outburst, which was provoked by the federal government having the cheek to insist that if it gave the French-speaking province millions to renovate a Quebec City zoo it wanted the Canadian flag to fly with the fleur-de-lis over the monkey pen.

Mr Landry insinuated the conditional offer of funds turned the province into a prostitute, selling herself for bits of red rag.

Speaking before he thinks is Mr Landry's biggest flaw, and many observers say his unseemly outbursts would have cost a lesser politician his career. (After the separatists lost the 1995 referendum, he yelled at an immigrant hotel clerk for voting No to sovereignty.)

Widely regarded as passionate, talented and shrewd, Mr Landry has spent the past few decades as reliable lieutenant of the sovereignty movement.

A lawyer with economic training, he brought the province's runaway deficit under control as finance minister.

When outgoing premier Lucien Bouchard stepped down earlier this winter, Mr Landry was the crown prince, and no one in the Parti Quebecois challenged him for the leadership.

He is at ease with the hard-liners in the party in a way that Mr Bouchard, a former federalist, never was.

While Mr Bouchard was attractive and charismatic, Mr Landry is less appealing to voters, but a more comfortable fit with a party that was created to make Quebec a country.

His temper means he will bring drama both to Quebec provincial politics and to the national scene, where he and the other nine premiers are permanently squabbling with the federal government over money and power.

Mr Bouchard, known for the odd flare-up himself, was surprisingly cooperative when working with his counterparts in the rest of the country.

Mr Landry, on the other hand, believes the Quebec premier is a cut above, and cannot be seen to accept parity with, say, the premier of tiny Prince Edward Island. There is no doubt he will fight with the federal government as much as he possibly can.

Aside from the red rag incident, Mr Landry raised a stink when Ottawa announced it would be giving Quebec extra money this year. (The extra cash proves how hard done by the province is, according to Mr Landry.)

He is also insisting Ottawa is gagging him by not allowing him to attend the upcoming Summit of Americas in Quebec City as an equal to the other world leaders.

For all his bombast, it is doubtful if Mr Landry will bring Quebec any further down the road to nationhood.

A recent poll found that half the people in the province oppose his plan to have the Quebec government actively promote sovereignty and only 15 per cent say they favour the outright independence of Quebec.

fields.headline: Homelessness: the basics
fields.trailText: • Homelessness has been a high profile problem since the 1960s, but it was not until 1977 that council housing departments were given a duty to help homeless people.
fields.body:
 Homelessness has been a high profile problem since the 1960s, but it was not until 1977 that council housing departments were given a duty to help homeless people.

 In 1997 homeless people lost their right to permanent housing.

 A new homes bill proposes to restore that right and extend those classed as priority need to more vulnerable groups.

 A rough sleepers unit has been set up to cut the number of people sleeping on the streets.

 The unit's policies have alarmed homelessness charities.

fields.headline: US court clears Bush advert
fields.trailText:
12pm: A Republican TV advert which appeared to call Al Gore a rat has been cleared by a top US court, reports Claire Cozens.
Sep 12: Bush gaffe forces advert withdrawal
fields.body:
A TV advert for George W Bush's election campaign which appeared to call his opponents rats has been cleared of any wrongdoing by a top US court.

The Republican campaign advert had to be pulled last September after the Democrats cried foul play, claiming it contained subliminal messages.

In the advert an image of Al Gore appeared on screen followed by the word "rats", which flashed up in capital letters for a split-second before the word "bureaucrats" appeared.

The Democrats complained, saying the advert was intended to plant a message about Mr Gore in the minds of voters.

But the US Federal Communications Commission found in favour of the Republicans, who said the word was simply a production error stemming from blowing up the word "bureaucrats".

The gaffe came just a week after Mr Bush was caught on live microphone describing a New York Times reporter as a "major league asshole".

Related story

fields.headline: Kelley takes over wheel at Ford marketing
fields.trailText: 12pm: Ford has named its e-commerce guru Brian Kelley as the company's new global marketing chief, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Ford has named its e-commerce guru Brian Kelley as the company's new global marketing chief.

The appointment is likely to see the carmaker further develop its internet-based marketing and new media initiatives.

Mr Kelley, president of Ford's e-commerce operation ConsumerConnect, has been appointed as vice-president global consumer services.

He will be responsible for global marketing, automotive consumer services group, dealer development, worldwide direct markets, Ford racing technology, and ConsumerConnect.

"Brian brought a new perspective to Ford," said Jacques Nasser, Ford president and chief executive.

"Through his leadership, we're transforming into not only the world's leading consumer company, but into the world's leading online consumer company.

"He's shown us a new way to learn about - and get closer to - the customer."

Mr Kelley, 40, will report to Mr Nasser with immediate effect.

His appointment follows the retirement of Robert Rewey, Ford group vice-president for global consumer services and north America, after 38 years with the company.

Prior to joining Ford in 1999, Mr Kelley was vice-president and general manager for sales and distribution with General Electric's appliance division and previously spent 10 years at Procter & Gamble.

General Motors executive Karen Francis, 38, succeeds Mr Kelley.

In Europe, Ford returned lead advertising agency status to Ogilvy & Mather at the end of 2000, just two years after it handed the bulk of its business to Young & Rubicam.

Related story

Feb 23: Ford rolls out voice activated services

fields.headline: Will Mir call Australia home?
fields.standfirst:
While the planned final resting place of space station Mir is in the south Pacific, if it veers off course Australians will have less than 30 minutes' warning, says Patrick Barkham

Special report: Space
fields.trailText: While the planned final resting place of space station Mir is in the south Pacific, if it veers off course Australians will have less than 30 minutes' warning, says Patrick Barkham in Sydney.
fields.body:
Next weekend, more than the usual number of Australians may look up towards the heavens and utter a quiet prayer. The long-delayed final descent of the dilapidated Russian space station Mir is now due to begin between March 17-23 and, although Australia lies 3,000 miles east of Mir's planned resting place in the middle of the South Pacific ocean, the country is anxious.

Since the departure of the final astronauts from the 135-tonne space station in June last year, atmospheric drag and gravity has gradually been pulling the 15 year-old Mir back to earth. Each day it falls another 2km.

Russian officials have mapped out its controlled descent, with engineers igniting fuel rockets on the station when Mir reaches 220km from earth, to slow its fall. Mir was not built to withstand re-entry into the atmosphere and 90% of the station is expected to burn up as it travels high above Asia.

Russian officials say there is only a one in 33 chance that Mir will veer off course and estimate the likelihood of it smashing down on Sydney or any other city in the southern hemisphere to be a pretty slim 0.02%.

But Russia admits that 1500 fragments, with four or five the size of a small car, could survive re-entry. While Mir's plotted descent sees these raining down on the empty expanse of the Pacific ocean, if the larger chunks hit land they would have an impact equivalent to a medium sized passenger jet.

Emergency Management Australia (EMA), a division of the department of defence, last week revealed its four-month preparations for Mir's descent. All the country's emergency services have been briefed, and airlines and ships in the region are monitoring the situation.

While EMA expressed its confidence in Russian scientists, if the station veers off course towards Australia people will have less than 30 minutes warning that Mir is heading for their backyard. Not entirely reassuringly, the media will apparently be asked to spread the word, while officials have warned curious people not to touch any smouldering lumps of space junk which they may find embedded in their lawn.

Science is reassuring, but history is less so. Mir has long been troubled by problems. It has suffered around 1500 computer glitches during its lifetime. A series of faults with its oxygen and air purification systems in 1997 culminated in a Russian supply ship smacking into the side of the station and nearly destroying it. In July 1997, a hapless Russian astronaut accidentally unplugged the main computer. Most worryingly of all, Russia lost contact with the station for 24 hours in December last year.

Australia has also been at the sharp end of other botched space dumpings. In 1979 the USA managed to misguide its Skylab station down onto the empty plains of Western Australia. No one was injured.

The country is surprisingly stoic about its role as a helpless accessory in the superpowers' space - and nuclear - race. Nuclear bombs have been detonated on its deserts and, like Britain, the Australian government displays a lemming-like willingness for the US to use its spy stations for the National Missile Defence programme.

Other countries have also suffered from the scrapping of space projects. Canada was on the receiving end of a Soviet satellite in 1978. In 1991, a 40-tonne Russian space station, Salyut 7, fell down onto Argentina, and five years later the plutonium-bearing Russian Mars probe splashed into the sea perilously near Chile.

These incidents are, however, just a drop in the ocean. Around 9,000 man-made objects are currently orbiting earth. One third of these are respectable satellites, but the other are more maverick pieces of metal, from tennis ball-sized lumps of metal to large spent rocket fuel capsules. On average, one piece of junk re-enters the atmosphere every day. Most, luckily, burn up.

If Australia's bit-part role in the final minutes of Mir doesn't materialise, spare a thought for the South Pacific, the designated graveyard for much of the hard rain of nuts and bolts from space missions. If bits of hot metal don't hit Fiji, Tonga, Western Samoa, New Caledonia and many of the other islands at the bottom of this space wastebin, they could yet menace marine life when they splash down into the "empty" seas.

webTitle: Rumours fly that Goldie and Kurt are to call it quits

fields.headline: Rumours fly that Goldie and Kurt are to call it quits
fields.trailText: Hollywood superstars Goldie Hawn and Kurt Russell are on the verge of separating after 17 years, according to reports in the US today
fields.body:
It looks as if another long-term Hollywood relationship has hit the rocks, as reports this morning hint that Kurt Russell and Goldie Hawn have separated after 17 years together.

According to US reports, the couple, who never married, have decided to call it a day and Hawn's current visit to the UK marks the beginning of a separation between the two. Russell has remained in Los Angeles, filming Vanilla Sky and Goldie, while in London, has reportedly been dating US newsman Charles Glass.

The couple's problems apparently began last November following rumours that Russell had visited a notorious Californian massage parlour. The pair then started attending therapy, but it was unable to solve their problems.

The pair met during the filming of Swing Shift in 1984 and they have a 15-year-old son, Wyatt. Hawn's Golden Globe-winning daughter Kate Hudson has often said that she regards Russell as her father.

It seems to be the time for Hollywood break-ups, Meg Ryan and Dennis Quaid, Tom Cruise and Nicole Kidman and Kim Basinger and Alec Baldwin have also separated in the last year.

fields.headline: Times website editor quits
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Andy Bull, editor of the Times's website, is leaving to join AOL, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Andy Bull, editor of the Times's website, is leaving to join AOL UK as general manager and director of editorial.

His move coincides with cutbacks on the website after News International boss Rupert Murdoch reined in his new media operations earlier this year.

A revamp of the Times Online was put on ice and at least 10 staff on the site were said to be have been laid off in January.

Control of the site, which has cut back on breaking news to the bare minimum of a PA news feed, is now under the Times newspaper.

The site now exists as little more than an uploaded version of the paper.

But in an email to staff, Mr Bull put a positive spin on his departure: "You should not take this as a vote of no confidence in our online operations. On the contrary, I believe we have collectively created a very robust website, and so does the editor."

It is not clear who will replace Mr Bull, as his deputy Brigid Callaghan is rumoured to have said she didn't want the job.

TheTimes.co.uk was launched in 1996 as one of the first newspapers on the web. It has suffered recently because of an inconsistent new media strategy at News International.

webTitle: West struggles to contain monster of its own making

fields.headline: West struggles to contain monster of its own making
fields.standfirst: Underestimated ethnic Albanian nationalism raises fears of new war
fields.trailText: High above Kosovo's broken cities, mules laden with rocket launchers, mines and machine guns clank through forests of oak, led by men in black. The snow is melting and the knee-high mud will soon harden, heralding the traditional fighting season on the mountainous border with Macedonia.
fields.body:
High above Kosovo's broken cities, mules laden with rocket launchers, mines and machine guns clank through forests of oak, led by men in black. The snow is melting and the knee-high mud will soon harden, heralding the traditional fighting season on the mountainous border with Macedonia.

The National Liberation Army did not feel like waiting. Its automatic weapons chatter nightly and mortars crump in reply. Refugees flee by day, their tractors churning into the valleys pulling trailers of wide-eyed infants.

The shepherds from the village of Debelde, a collection of ramshackle houses, have stayed with their flocks. They gaze in awe as gleaming A-64 Apache helicopters descend and they offer tea to the US soldiers who emerge.

The guerrillas who attack Macedonian troops slip back into Kosovo to change from black uniforms into civilian clothes. They know Debelde well. To the Americans' dismay, the people of Debelde affect to know them not at all.

"It is a mystery to me. I do not know who these men are. I never set eyes on them," says Misin Ferrati, 55. Of the more than 1,000 refugees who fled last week, not one is known to have helped identify the guerrillas. Here, ethnic Albanian nationalism runs deep.

These are two fronts in an ultra-nationalist attempt to destabilise the Balkans, with the apparent aim of extending Kosovo's territory.

The fuse that has been lit may yet ignite a conflagration. The fault lines of imperfect peace deals are already showing, as ethnic groups rediscover their dissatisfaction with the existing borders.

The west is stunned. Balkan nightmares were supposed to have ended with the fall of Slobodan Milosevic, the Yugoslav president's quest for a greater Serbia in ashes after four failed wars.

Many agree that the west fundamentally misunderstood the threat of Albanian nationalism. A series of errors, tactical and strategic, are blamed for allowing a small minority of Kosovans to seize the agenda. A recent press conference descended into slapstick when the UN spokesman, Sunil Narula, staggered from one contradiction to another trying to explain who was doing what to contain the insurgencies.

K-For intelligence officers say they face a Frankenstein-like movement, composed of different parts; it is powerful but not very bright.

However, in recent statements the guerrillas said they wanted only equal rights in a reformed Macedonia. Talk of annexation, they said, was humbug perpetuated by Skopje to distract from its record on civil rights.

Kosovo's constitutional limbo - it is technically part of Serbia but is a K-For protectorate - has created a vacuum in which frustration flourishes. It is dawning on the rebels that they may have wider support than first realised.

Eric Torch, an aid worker, believes a key mistake made by the west was failing to appreciate the power of ethnic Albanian nationalism. "Albanians trace their lineage to the Illyrans who controlled the territory in the 11th century BC. Underground schools during Milosevic's rule inculcated ethnic hatred into generations," he says.

Lirak Celaj smiles when asked if the genie is out of the bottle. An actor who studied in Britain and the director of Pristina's main theatre, he is also an ex-KLA fighter and spokesman.

"We will be a problem. We will remain a threat to stability because for us the status quo is unfair," he says. He believes that oppression in Macedonia and southern Serbia requires a violent response because peaceful means have failed.

Until the break up of Yugoslavia 10 years ago the region's ethnic Albanians were in one state. Mr Celaj's family is from Montenegro, his wife is from Macedonia. But unlike Serb nationalists who wanted to reconquer all their historical territory, Mr Celaj rules out unification with Albania, because the state is too backward. For now he will settle for those areas where ethnic Albanians are in a majority today.

He cannot believe that the US and Britain have switched allegiance to Belgrade. "I think some European countries may be against us because now we are losing the propaganda battle, but not London and Washington," he says.

Moderate Kosovan leaders such as Ibrahim Rugova have condemned the guerrillas for damaging the quest for independence. Mr Celaj is unconcerned, believes independence is inevitable, probably within five years.

But despite their thumping endorsement in the municipal elections last October, it is not the moderates who hold the balance of power.

Since the day it arrived K-For has failed to control Kosovo. Its failure to disarm the KLA, protect the Serb minority and build a multi-ethnic society has created a climate in which extremists flourish. For almost a year it ignored intellectuals who urged a crackdown on KLA members who seized assets and set up criminal networks.

"Now it's too late, the moderates won the election, but those who smuggle and run the rackets have the real power," one officer serving there admits.

Yesterday's Observer reported that the CIA encouraged rebellion in southern Serbia to undermine Milosevic but lost control after his fall.

Many Kosovans accuse the UN police force of incompetence and corruption. It has failed to establish the rule of law, allowing gangsters and militants to intimidate at will. A journalist from Koha Dittore, one of the few newspapers to resist such pressure, said freedom of speech was evaporating because of threats and assassinations.

Pristina remains broken: there are powercuts, building facades gape open, and rubbish lies uncollected. Day and night gangs of unemployed young men patrol the main Mother Theresa Street. Those with cash drink in Skifterat, a dingy basement bar where the bouncers are ex-KLA fighters in black berets and combat boots.

At a rickety table three friends, Sabit, Besin and Bardh, all in their early 20s, discuss politics. "If the Albanians in Macedonia all rose up tomorrow I'd go down to fight, but until then no way," Sabit says.

His friends nod. In fact the guerrillas, e intensely clan-based, are unlikely to trust such outsiders, but Kosovo is a vital supply depot and base.

The drinkers here, unusually for Pristina, do not speak English. "No need. We won't need to leave our land again," says Emrush, 31, a chemist. On a napkin he draws a perfect map of his land: A greater Kosovo encompassing chunks of Macedonia and Serbia.

webTitle: Yahoo cries in the advert wilderness

fields.headline: Yahoo cries in the advert wilderness
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: March 12: Do You Yahoo? asked the ads. Apparently not, writes Emily Bell.
fields.body:
Do You Yahoo? asked the ads. And last week we learned the answer: apparently not. In the already ephemeral and shaky world of the commercial dot.com, the slide of Yahoo, culminating in its second profits warning in three months and the departure of chief executive Tim Koogle, has provided further cause to blench.

As rare as hen's teeth, the internet profit margin was something founders Filo and Yang developed at Yahoo. But it seems that a prospective profit of $315m dollars for the current year has evaporated. Why? Well, one simple answer is that internet advertising has cratered. The United States and therefore the entire western world is living in fear of a recession and the very first thing to go soft is advertising.

The ad industry is showing a remarkable lack of sentimentality about the online environment - despite adpeople having laundered themselves huge revenue increases by taking dot.com venture capital money and turning it into often ill-judged marketing campaigns. Agencies themselves are not yet sure that the unaudited, infinite world of cyberspace is a suitable environment for their product.

Yahoo's dismal experience certainly adds to the overall impression that online advertising isn't working. There's a startling figure that the rate of growth for internet advertising will drop from last year's peak of more than 110% to 26% in the next three years. But the rollercoaster of the Yahoo model is a further lesson about the problems of being a facilitator rather than a destination. Yahoo did develop some of its own excellent content, like Yahoo Finance - a money site which puts many traditional publishers' websites to shame - but it still felt for many like a glorified directory. It had nothing in terms of content which would enable it, like some of its competitors, to start thinking seriously about registration and subscription. Yahoo is a great internet brand, but what does it mean to be an internet brand when all you are known for is, er, your understanding of the internet?

The other fundamental problem with Yahoo is that it was subjected to a rate of growth which was entirely unsustainable. Very few internet businesses have had the luxury of working through their growing pains in private. The market is an unforgiving place which is about making money and nothing more. The parasitical industries of venture capital and advertising will just as easily turn their collective hands to something else, if they don't like the smell of dot.com any longer. Yahoo has been part of an experiment, which, like putting the Incredible Hulk on growth-promoting hormones, was always going to have a terrible outcome.

But just as the venerable economist JK Galbraith was absolutely spot on when he said of the dot.com boom, "There are no new paradigms", there is also the point that while you can reinvent the wheel you can't uninvent it.

Nobody really believes that the internet will revert to a barren wasteland with only tumbleweed and teenagers occasionally blowing across its vast expanses. It is just another piece of spectrum which is waiting to be tamed. So what if it is infinite, so what if anyone can be a competitor? The lesson of all dot.com failures so far is that not just anyone can craft a business out of the internet. As with radio in the 1920s, we are still turning over the concept of the internet revolution and alternately thinking "Hmm, we'll never make it pay", or "Hmm, it's a revolution which will change all our businesses".

The heart of the problem is that we have had a communications revolution without a payment revolution. It's like launching a newspaper into a world where small change has not yet been invented. Or starting a TV shopping channel before the advent of the credit card. The key to the door lies in micro payments and the least painful way of extracting them. In my brief stint on the web, a number of people have volunteered random sums - anything between £5 and £500 a month - which they would be willing to pay for the sort of content the Guardian and other online services provide. But what they probably wouldn't want to do is bother with the hassle of lengthy and unreliable registration systems, surrender a credit card and remember a password, just so they can look at the crossword every lunchtime.

The answer to this almost certainly lies in a scheme hammered out between telecoms companies and content providers. The nifty idea that the price of a call is the cost of the thing, a small warning that using a site for 24 hours will cost you 20p, do you wish to proceed? Click, yes. That's what we all want, but unfortunately as with much technological expectation we may have to wait some time.

One thing is for sure - you cannot rely on the advertising industry for solutions. Just ask Jerry Yang.

 Emily Bell is editor in chief of Guardian Unlimited.

webTitle: Comment: another shocking report on our jails out this week

fields.headline: Behind bars
fields.standfirst:
This week the chief inspector of prisons will publish another shocking report on the state of our jails

Special report: deaths in custody
fields.trailText: Comment: Little has changed at Winson Green prison, Birmingham, since Barry Prosser, aged 32, was kicked to death in its healthcare centre. Eighteen years later it is still regarded, by common consent in the world of criminal justice, as the worst prison in Britain.
fields.body:
Little has changed at Winson Green prison, Birmingham, since Barry Prosser, aged 32, was kicked to death in its healthcare centre. Eighteen years later it is still regarded, by common consent in the world of criminal justice, as the worst prison in Britain.

In yet another shocking inspection report to be published on Thursday, Sir David Ramsbotham, the chief inspector of prisons, will confirm that the "Prosser prison" still deserves its dismal title. "Rambo" will detail the full extent of the "appalling" and "filthy" conditions inside the Birmingham prison when he inspected it last July. He will highlight the case of a mentally ill prisoner who was denied a change of clothes for weeks on end, and conclude that things are actually worse than when he last visited the place in 1995 and 1998.

In a pre-emptive strike last month designed to shock the prison service out of its lethargy, Martin Narey, the director-general, threatened to resign and made it clear he accepts the expected Ramsbotham verdict. Indeed he went further and clearly hinted he believes that physical brutality still goes on within its walls.

To sweeten the pill, the chief inspector's report on Armley prison, Leeds, once the most destructive of the prison service's overcrowded "hellholes", will be published on the same day as the Birmingham indictment. It will reveal a prison which has been been prepared to change its approach to create a more healthy environment.

But it will only underline the tragic merry-go-round that lies at the heart of our prison system. Last year it was the young offenders' institution at Portland that was exposed as a national disgrace. Now it is said to provide the best care for juveniles in the country. Instead, Brinsford youth jail, near Wolverhampton, and Stoke Heath, in Shropshire, provide the latest examples of what has been called "the litany of failure and moral neglect". Meanwhile as last night's Panorama television programme once again demonstrated, the numbers held inside the largest of our young offender institutions, Feltham, in west London, mean it repeatedly fails to fulfil its basic duty of care. With four governors in four years, its recent history features teenage suicides and the racist murder of Zahid Mubarek.

The situation in Birmingham and Feltham represents something more fundamental than an occasional failure. It demonstrates that over a period of 20 years or more there has been an underlying malaise in the prison system which has never really been tackled.

Part of the problem is that prisons are not seen as a public service. When the chancellor, Gordon Brown, stood up last week to announce his extra billions for hospitals and schools, nobody expected him to do the same for prisons. Yet we do expect 130,000 of our citizens each year to endure conditions that are frequently condemned as indecent by those whom we appoint to inspect them. Not all of the reports are negative, but Ramsbotham only gets round the 135 establishments once every six years.

Perhaps if all prisoners were given the vote, politicians would take as much interest in them as they do in their local police station or school. It may be news to some MPs, but the punishment involved in a prison sentence is supposed to be the loss of liberty - not living in the inhumane conditions inside some of our jails.

Tony Blair may have been the first serving prime minister to visit a prison but the malaise has become so deep-seated in some parts of the prison system that more radical solutions are needed. It is time to consider publicly one option that is already being debated privately within the Home Office. The prison service has proved itself incapable of running some types of jails. The first that come to mind are young offender institutions and women's prisons - both of which are completely different propositions from the average local prison holding 800 men serving short to medium sentences.

Perhaps it is time to realise that the adult prison service is no longer fit to look after young teenage offenders or women prisoners and that "prison culture" is simply not what the punishment and rehabilitation of these groups of offenders is about. In nearly all non-violent cases they are quite simply different from the thousands of career criminals who fill some of our prisons. In the case of young offenders, the government should once again approach the children's charities and other non-profit organisations - or even local authorities - to see if they are willing to get involved in the provision of secure accommodation for such teenagers.

They turned their backs when Michael Howard came touting his secure training centres, on the grounds that they were more about punishment than education, and left it to Group 4, with initially disastrous results. Smaller but more units is the way to go, so that 900 youngsters are never held together again as they once were in the Feltham warehouse. The network of women's prisons would benefit from a similar exercise.
