In the case of young offenders, the government should once again approach the children's charities and other non-profit organisations - or even local authorities - to see if they are willing to get involved in the provision of secure accommodation for such teenagers. They turned their backs when Michael Howard came touting his secure training centres, on the grounds that they were more about punishment than education, and left it to Group 4, with initially disastrous results. Smaller but more units is the way to go, so that 900 youngsters are never held together again as they once were in the Feltham warehouse. The network of women's prisons would benefit from a similar exercise. alan.travis@theguardian.com

webTitle: Health and social care bill: the issue explained

fields.headline: Health and social care bill: the issue explained
fields.trailText:
What is the health and social care bill?
Essentially, it is the legislative machinery that allows the government to take forward some of the reforms it outlined in the NHS plan published in July 2000 - a plan to "modernise and rebuild" the health service and "reshape" the NHS from the patients' point of view.
fields.body:
What is the health and social care bill?
Essentially, it is the legislative machinery that allows the government to take forward some of the reforms it outlined in the NHS plan published in July 2000 - a plan to "modernise and rebuild" the health service and "reshape" the NHS from the patients' point of view.

What's in the bill?
A miscellaneous range of measures relating to primary care, long-term care of the elderly, local government scrutiny of the NHS, patient advocacy, nurse prescribing, creation of care trusts, employment issues, and NHS drugs dispensing.

Doesn't sound wildly exciting..
Funnily enough, it is rumoured that the government - which announced the bill in the Queen's speech in December 2000, and published it shortly before the Christmas break - was expecting it to pass through parliament largely untroubled by controversy, mainly because of its unexciting technical nature.

Don't tell me - all hell broke loose
Well, it would be wrong to say it set the Commons ablaze, but it did cause a (partly successful) Labour backbench rebellion - over the abolition of community health councils (CHCs) - and is likely to stumble in the Lords over widely disputed proposals to give the health secretary powers to disclose confidential patient information. Care trusts have also proved controversial, as have government plans to fund long term care of the elderly.

Tell me more about these controversial issues

 CHCs - local independent NHS consumer watchdog organisations - will be scrapped on the grounds that they are outdated and largely failed to act as patient advocates. Opponents have argued that this will dilute the democratic accountability of the NHS to local communities.

 The principle of patient confidentiality is a bedrock of medical practice, and clinicians must get consent from patients to use their medical files for research. The government wants to give the health secretary powers to disclose patient information where it is in the public interest, for example cancer research. Critics have dubbed it "Orwellian" in scope.

 The government wants to pay for nursing care for elderly people in long term residential care - but it has disappointed critics by refusing to also pay for personal care, such as bathing and washing. During the passage of the bill, the Scottish Executive decided personal care would be available to patients in Scottish homes, piling further pressure on UK ministers to change tack. So far, however, they've not done so.

 Care trusts propose combining health and social services under one administrative roof to ensure "seamless delivery" of care. They will, however, be NHS bodies, and local authorities are concerned that this effectively represents a takeover of social services, which are democratically accountable to local authorities, by the NHS, which is not accountable in the same way. Some critics would also argue that the Health Act 1999 allows everything that care trusts can do to be done anyway - without the alleged NHS takeover.

Have ministers backtracked on any part of the bill?
On the whole, no. The government had a loyal majority on the all-party group scrutinising the bill at committee stage, which nodded through all its clauses, and of course, a massive majority on the floor of the Commons to ease its passage through second and third reading. Rebel backbenchers did however force the government to compromise on the abolition of CHCs (though they couldn't prevent abolition) and there may be more ructions in the Lords. Not much will happen to change the original bill, however, unless the government decides it wants to change it.

webTitle: Paris fashion week off to provocative start

fields.headline: Paris fashion week off to provocative start
fields.trailText: In Milan, the previous destination on the fashion merry-go-round, designers would never dream of showing a collection where the models were entirely covered in black make-up, or one where they walked down the catwalk in absolute silence.
fields.body:
In Milan, the previous destination on the fashion merry-go-round, designers would never dream of showing a collection where the models were entirely covered in black make-up, or one where they walked down the catwalk in absolute silence.

Yet on the first weekend of the Paris schedule, which lasts until Friday, such events were commonplace and all the more welcome for it.

Viktor & Rolf, the Dutch design duo who are renowned for combining visual stunts with assured tailoring, dubbed their collection "Black Hole".

At first the models, including Carmen Kass and Devon Aoki, appeared to be silhouetted as they walked into the harsh light. But then it became clear that all their visible skin and hair had been stained a terrifying matte-black shade, leaving only the whites of their eyes to provide visual respite. Viktor & Rolf can pull off this sort of trick because the mostly all-black clothes on display were stunning - ribbon-trim cardigans that looked made for Paris in mourning, tuxedos with a leather trim, and one of the best double-breasted schoolgirl coats yet seen in a season obsessed with uniforms.

After the show had finished, the models could be spotted desperately trying to smear the make-up off their faces, as though they'd just surfaced from a fashion coal mine.

Yohji Yamamoto's collection was less well received, partly because of the tortuous silence that accompanied the models on the catwalk, but mainly because his clothes were rigorously challenging. For this, read purposefully unwearable: the first few outfits, black jackets with white trim to match the customised Adidas trainers on the models' feet, had no sleeve for the right arm. Instead, the hand could be seen poking out of the bottom, trapped in the fabric.

Midway through the show, a few of the outfits were shown that could be adapted into everyday life. These revealed the influence of the mid-80s Buffalo movement with their juxtaposition of macho boxer styling with some great bomber jackets, combined with the fluid femininity of differing skirt lengths.

Meanwhile, Comme des Garçons protégé Junya Watanabe astounded as always, this time by playing with contrasting fabrics - panels of neon see-through plastic slashing through thick wool baby-doll dresses and coats. Although the effect was sometimes unnerving - the occasional plastic breast-plate panel bearing an uncomfortable resemblance to emergency room breathing apparatus - the overall effect was joyful and accomplished. And while you might feel worried about sweating profusely in Watanabe's see-through plastic brogues, his primary-colour houndstooth sweaters and great Americana-inspired slacks in natural fibres would cause you no problems.

fields.headline: Celebrity Big Brother catch-up
fields.trailText: Did you miss the spectacle of six celebrities, with the faint whiff of yesterday's news, locked together in the Big Brother house in east London? Don't fret, MediaGuardian.co.uk was glued. And we will bring you the performances every day.
fields.body:
Sunday night: Jack Dee decided to vote to evict Anthea Turner for a second time. And he didn't mince his words. She is "too jolly by half", he said.

Saturday night: Chris "concerned of Brighton" Eubank taking Claire Sweeney from Brookside aside to tell her her knickers were visible above her jeans. Doesn't he know that's what thongs are for these days?

The prize for the most nauseating performance goes to Anthea Turner on Saturday night. "I have done so much live telly and this is really terrible," she said as she cast her votes for the first night's eviction.

And the most disturbing sight of the night: Vanessa Feltz raising her new leopard skin pyjama to take off a big black pair of knickers. Thankfully the camera was held at a distance.

fields.headline: TV's new face
fields.standfirst: Can Wellbeing, a new website and digital channel, change daytime viewing? Amy Vickers examines its health
fields.trailText: March 12: Can Wellbeing, a new website and digital channel, change daytime viewing? Amy Vickers examines its health.
fields.body:
Just when you thought it was safe to take a day off sick, draw the curtains and wrap yourself in a duvet in front of the telly, along comes a TV channel that could either be welcome medicine or the biggest annoyance ever for a malingering wreck.

This Wednesday sees the launch of Wellbeing, a new Granada digital TV channel that will transform the soft-centred, cosy world of daytime TV as defined by Richard and Judy. The format will be similar to This Morning in that it will be studio based and smattered with video inserts and outside broadcasts - but the content will be focused entirely on health, beauty and the somewhat nebulous and holistic concept of "wellbeing".

Primarily aimed at housewives, and perhaps workers prone to sickies, Wellbeing will be screened between 9am and 9pm each day and may eventually be promoted to a 24-hour channel. The full list of presenters is still being kept under wraps, but expect a number of high-profile women such as Toyah Wilcox, athlete Diane Modahl and Coleen Nolan.

To launch its efforts into the world of health and beauty, Granada has teamed up with Boots the Chemist in a 40:60 deal which, on the surface, seems to be a retail broadcast match made in heaven. But it is not the first of its kind. Last year Carlton and Sainsbury's got together to work on Taste, a similar retail broadcast hybrid that will come to life as a TV channel and website on May 1.

Of course, Wellbeing, like all new channels these days, is not just a TV channel. It's one of those "multi-platform propositions" that has all the right buzzwords: an integrated website, interactive TV within a year, ADSL, PDA and Wap, and so on.

In the first instance, though, it is a website, Wellbeing.com, and a TV channel on Sky Digital and ONdigital. Eventually the plan is to feed content from the website onto an interactive version of the channel, but Paula Carter, former Granada health director and now joint managing director of Wellbeing with former Boots internet boss Richard Holmes, is cautious about doing too much with the business before working out what their audience wants.

"We've done a lot of research and we know there is a potential audience out there, but we're going to hold off making [Wellbeing] 24 hours until we find out what's working. Likewise, we are going to do interactive TV, but not necessarily sell products through it until we're sure how the audience is using interactive TV," says Carter.

With operating costs for Wellbeing's first year - to the end of this month - already said to be close to £18m, and a £10m marketing campaign in the pipeline, it may take some time to move into the black. Revenues are expected to come from the sale of products and advertising, although it is questionable whether Wellbeing will be able to generate wads of cash given the current depressed advertising climate and its reluctance to sell products through the TV. Experts warn of a shortage of advertisers looking to target a small niche audience of women, particularly when the advertisers may not take too kindly to the involvement of Boots in the channel. Keith Rattray, director of interactive TV at Carat, says: "If extremely specialist interest services such as health channels are vying for a share of total TV revenue spent on traditional 'spot' advertising, then they're going to struggle. Reason being that they can not offer advertisers sufficient volume of impacts to make any difference to their coverage-building schedules." Rattray suggests that traditional advertising spots will be relatively scarce on Wellbeing, with advertorials, sponsorships and interactive workshops becoming more lucrative money-spinners for the channel instead.

Simon Shaps, managing director at Granada Broadband, is expecting revenues to come from sponsors and advertising, bolstered by transactional revenues from products sold on the website. But will these be enough to sustain the business in the medium term, bearing in mind that Boots has recently lost its sparkle in the City?

Competitors are naturally questioning the economics of launching a TV channel that may take time to make consumers aware of its existence, and a website trying to make a business for itself in a tumultuous sector that has already killed off ClickMango.

Carol Dukes, chief executive at internet health and beauty retailer ThinkNatural, says: "More specialist sites find that a lot of their appeal lies in the fact that people can find, research and order online those types of things that are a bit harder to find or which would require a special shopping trip. That motivation won't exist for Boots' products online, because everyone can easily pop into a Boots - they're on every high street and in every shopping mall."

But Wellbeing remains bullish. It expects to take a bite out of the £11bn UK health and beauty retail market and then expand into the bigger £90bn area of healthcare provision. For Boots, the launch is part of its efforts to evolve from a health and beauty retailer into a generic brand for health, beauty and wellbeing. Such is the retailer's confidence that Boots.co.uk has been absorbed into the Wellbeing website, which will exist as the cornerstone of Boots' digital strategy.

Whether viewers will sit down and lap up 12 hours a day of this type of programming has yet to be established. Granada's research indicates widespread support for a health and beauty channel and associated website. Shaps thinks Granada is onto a mass-market opportunity. "The combination of an encyclopaedic website and an information-based TV channel will have wide appeal. This is a large scale venture that will have universal interest because everybody has a profound interest in their own wellbeing."

Dukes thinks Wellbeing may have its work cut out trying to create demand for such category-specific programming. "It's very brave of Granada and Boots to launch into the expensive territory of television when general non-drama health programming is such an untested area for popular viewing."

Potential pitfalls aside, Granada is making a brave move. Over the next 12 months, more and more broadcasters and retailers will also experiment with "brandcasting" - the term for advertisers becoming broadcasters - driven by the advent of new technology that allows for cross-media commercial avenues to be explored. This is central to the broadband vision of the future, and a development that pundits expect to change the face of broadcasting as we know it.

webTitle: Middle East stares war in the face

fields.headline: Middle East stares war in the face
fields.standfirst: Speculation is rife that with Israel busy on the Palestinian front, Hizbullah guerrillas may decide to start attacking from the north. Some observers believe this could swiftly escalate into war, writes Brian Whitaker in Israel
fields.trailText: With Israel busy on the Palestinian front, Hizbullah guerrillas may start attacking from the north, writes Brian Whitaker.
fields.body:
Twice in the last few days people have suggested to me that the Middle East is sliding towards war. One person saw it as no more than a possibility; the other as a near certainty.

A typical scenario goes like this: with Israeli forces hard-pressed to combat the Palestinian uprising, Hizbullah guerrillas in southern Lebanon seize the opportunity to open up a second front across Israel's northern border.

Israel responds by bombing Lebanon and Syria (since it holds the Syrians largely responsible for Hizbullah's actions).

Saddam Hussein, who has been raring to have a go at Israel, then sends Iraqi troops to help the Syrians.

The scenario sounds plausible if we accept the popular view of Hizbullah ("The Party of God") as a bunch of trigger-happy headbangers, but that is to misunderstand the nature of Hizbullah.

It's a highly disciplined organisation with some sharp political thinkers at the top.

Hizbullah certainly does not recognise Israel, which it regards as "an illegitimate entity", and would like it to disappear off the map.

It also has rockets capable of striking deep into Israel - though that does not necessarily mean it intends to use them.

While Hizbullah is convinced that Israel will eventually be defeated, it seems in no particular hurry.

"The Crusaders stayed in Palestine for 200 years and have gone. Israelis have only been in Palestine since 1948," the party's spokesman, Hussein Naboulsi, told me in Beirut last week.

While anti-Israeli propaganda may be useful to mobilise the masses, the real focus of Hizbullah's attention is within Lebanon. The aim of its 18-year guerrilla struggle against the Israelis was to end the occupation of southern Lebanon - a goal finally achieved last May.

Hizbullah still has a specific quarrel with the Israelis because their withdrawal did not include the tiny Sheba'a Farms area on the Lebanese-Syrian border. Israel says the area belongs to Syria, though both Syria and Lebanon say it is Lebanese.

Last week, Mr Naboulsi he was not exactly breathing fire over that issue.

"Whenever we find a target in the Sheba'a Farms, we attack if it's easy to hit without casualties," he said. "But it's very hard to launch an operation there."

Hizbullah took the credit for forcing Israel's withdrawal from the south and, as a result, gained enormous prestige, not just among its core Shi'ite supporters, but throughout Lebanon.

Since last year, most of its efforts have been devoted to capitalising on that and becoming a major force in Lebanese politics.

To start another conflict now, or provoke the Israelis into starting one, could easily cost Hizbullah all the goodwill it has won. The Lebanese are still recovering from years of war and want nothing better than peace and stability.

Hizbullah certainly recognises that and seems unlikely to do anything to jeopardise its position.

Another reason some people predict war in the Middle East is the election of Ariel Sharon as Israeli prime minister.

This arises mainly from European and American perceptions that Ehud Barak, the previous prime minister, was a man of peace, whereas Sharon is not.

Arab perceptions, however, are very different. The general view is that there is little to distinguish between the two men, except that Sharon is likely to cause more problems for Israel than Barak did.

In any case, Sharon's government is such a mish-mash of political elements that it is likely to stay in office only so long as it avoids doing anything controversial.

Perversely, to western eyes, many Arabs see events since the start of the uprising last October in a positive light - a turning of the tide that has given the Palestinians a psychological advantage, if not a military one.

One of the first effects was that Israel's painstaking efforts over many years to normalise its relations with moderate Arab states unravelled, almost overnight.

Although Palestinian casualties far exceed those on the Israeli side, the number of Israeli Jews killed since the start of the intifada - at least 65 - is not insignificant. It is more than during the last year of the war in Lebanon, where casualties were considered unacceptably high.

The increasing numbers of attacks within Israel's 1967 border are also likely to bring the conflict home to people in a way that the Lebanese war never did.

Israelis may be prepared to tolerate this, along with the accompanying security measures, for a time - but only if they can see an end in sight: at present there is no sign of one.

On the economic side, the full impact is still to be felt.

Perceptions that Israel is a dangerous place to visit (it was recently classified as such by the US State Department) have begun to affect tourism and will eventually affect long-term investment.

Added to all that, the country's political system now looks incapable of producing a long-lasting, stable government.

Those Arabs who regard Israel's collapse as a historical inevitability - just like the departure of the Crusaders - hail this as the writing on the wall. Almost certainly it is not, but there is no doubt that Israel has got problems.

Once demoralisation sets in, it could spread rapidly. That might force Israel into desperate measures, which could conceivably lead to war.

More likely, it could shift Israeli opinion towards making the necessary compromises for peace.

fields.bodyText: Twice in the last few days people have suggested to me that the Middle East is sliding towards war. One person saw it as no more than a possibility; the other as a near certainty. A typical scenario goes like this: with Israeli forces hard-pressed to combat the Palestinian uprising, Hizbullah guerrillas in southern Lebanon seize the opportunity to open up a second front across Israel's northern border. Israel responds by bombing Lebanon and Syria (since it holds the Syrians largely responsible for Hizbullah's actions). Saddam Hussein, who has been raring to have a go at Israel, then sends Iraqi troops to help the Syrians. The scenario sounds plausible if we accept the popular view of Hizbullah ("The Party of God") as a bunch of trigger-happy headbangers, but that is to misunderstand the nature of Hizbullah. It's a highly disciplined organisation with some sharp political thinkers at the top. Hizbullah certainly does not recognise Israel, which it regards as "an illegitimate entity", and would like it to disappear off the map. It also has rockets capable of striking deep into Israel - though that does not necessarily mean it intends to use them. While Hizbullah is convinced that Israel will eventually be defeated, it seems in no particular hurry. "The Crusaders stayed in Palestine for 200 years and have gone. Israelis have only been in Palestine since 1948," the party's spokesman, Hussein Naboulsi, told me in Beirut last week. While anti-Israeli propaganda may be useful to mobilise the masses, the real focus of Hizbullah's attention is within Lebanon. The aim of its 18-year guerrilla struggle against the Israelis was to end the occupation of southern Lebanon - a goal finally achieved last May. Hizbullah still has a specific quarrel with the Israelis because their withdrawal did not include the tiny Sheba'a Farms area on the Lebanese-Syrian border. Israel says the area belongs to Syria, though both Syria and Lebanon say it is Lebanese. Last week, Mr Naboulsi he was not exactly breathing fire over that issue. "Whenever we find a target in the Sheba'a Farms, we attack if it's easy to hit without casualties," he said. "But it's very hard to launch an operation there." Hizbullah took the credit for forcing Israel's withdrawal from the south and, as a result, gained enormous prestige, not just among its core Shi'ite supporters, but throughout Lebanon. Since last year, most of its efforts have been devoted to capitalising on that and becoming a major force in Lebanese politics. To start another conflict now, or provoke the Israelis into starting one, could easily cost Hizbullah all the goodwill it has won. The Lebanese are still recovering from years of war and want nothing better than peace and stability. Hizbullah certainly recognises that and seems unlikely to do anything to jeopardise its position. Another reason some people predict war in the Middle East is the election of Ariel Sharon as Israeli prime minister. This arises mainly from European and American perceptions that Ehud Barak, the previous prime minister, was a man of peace, whereas Sharon is not. Arab perceptions, however, are very different. The general view is that there is little to distinguish between the two men, except that Sharon is likely to cause more problems for Israel than Barak did. In any case, Sharon's government is such a mish-mash of political elements that it is likely to stay in office only so long as it avoids doing anything controversial. Perversely, to western eyes, many Arabs see events since the start of the uprising last October in a positive light - a turning of the tide that has given the Palestinians a psychological advantage, if not a military one. One of the first effects was that Israel's painstaking efforts over many years to normalise its relations with moderate Arab states unravelled, almost overnight. Although Palestinian casualties far exceed those on the Israeli side, the number of Israeli Jews killed since the start of the intifada - at least 65 - is not insignificant. It is more than during the last year of the war in Lebanon, where casualties were considered unacceptably high. The increasing numbers of attacks within Israel's 1967 border are also likely to bring the conflict home to people in a way that the Lebanese war never did. Israelis may be prepared to tolerate this, along with the accompanying security measures, for a time - but only if they can see an end in sight: at present there is no sign of one. On the economic side, the full impact is still to be felt. Perceptions that Israel is a dangerous place to visit (it was recently classified as such by the US State Department) have begun to affect tourism and will eventually affect long-term investment. Added to all that, the country's political system now looks incapable of producing a long-lasting, stable government. Those Arabs who regard Israel's collapse as a historical inevitability - just like the departure of the Crusaders - hail this as the writing on the wall. Almost certainly it is not, but there is no doubt that Israel has got problems. Once demoralisation sets in, it could spread rapidly. That might force Israel into desperate measures, which could conceivably lead to war. More likely, it could shift Israeli opinion towards making the necessary compromises for peace. webTitle: Foot and mouth crisis: tourist trade may get help

fields.headline: Hard-hit tourist trade may get help
fields.standfirst:
Minister tries to calm anxieties as outbreaks grow at record daily rate
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Minister tries to calm anxieties as outbreaks grow at record daily rate.
fields.body:
The government yesterday held out the possibility that it could pay out millions of pounds in compensation to the rural tourist industry as it tried to damp down anxieties about the extent of the foot and mouth crisis.

Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, admitted that the government might provide aid packages to business people affected by the disease as well as members of the farming community, despite repeatedly dismissing such proposals over the past two weeks.

As reports suggested that the tourist trade - which dwarfs farming in this country - had already lost up to £200m because of the disease, Mr Brown did not rule out compensation. He said: "The government remains vigilant and is monitoring all of these things."

But a spokeswoman for the Ministry of Agriculture Fisheries and Food played down his comments, saying: "The disease is still running and that is our first major obstacle. The minister isn't ruling anything out, but that [financial aid] isn't something we can look at in any detail yet."

The numbers of confirmed outbreaks of foot and mouth disease in the UK had risen to 164 by yesterday evening, following the highest daily recorded increase in cases since the crisis began.

The rural tourist industry - worth £12bn a year, according to the English Tourism Council - would normally be gearing up for Easter, the start of the high season.

But reports yesterday suggested that business is 75% below its usual levels, causing losses of more than £100m a week. The cost to farmers has so far been estimated at less than £30m.

Hoteliers, caterers and others in the industry had been angered by the government's refusal to discuss compensation for them before yesterday. Since it is as yet unclear what form aid could take, it is not clear if they will be mollified by any assistance the government can offer.

Mr Brown insisted: "We are very much aware of the wider impact, but the solution to these problems, no matter how you look at them, is the same - to get the disease under control. Foot and mouth is not compatible with a thriving tourist industry, any more than it is with a thriving farming industry. If overseas tourists think there is a risk of bringing foot and mouth out of our country and into their own, surely they will think twice about coming here.

"The industries complement each other. The shape of the countryside that people come to visit is defined by the animals which graze it. In many places, such as the south-west, there is a great food tourism industry."

He dismissed suggestions made in Cumbria that all the sheep in the area could be slaughtered to allow the resumption of the lucrative tourist trade, saying it would be wrong to "gratuitously" kill animals.

Mr Brown rejected reported criticism from the Irish agriculture minister, Joe Walsh, about the government's handling of the crisis.

"The disease had spread before it emerged, before we caught it," Mr Brown said. "As soon as we realised what we had to deal with, we put these movement restrictions in place. I was criticised for overreacting and for being too tough. In fact, what we have done is absolutely right."

Maff dismissed suggestions that the disease could be spread by the transport of slaughtered animals to a rendering plant in Widnes, Cheshire, where carcases are being burnt. The county has so far escaped the outbreak.

David Lloyd-Griffiths, the deputy leader of Cheshire county council, yesterday said the authority had not been consulted about the transportation and would be asking animal health officers to check the arrangements.

But Maff insisted that the lorries used were safe. They were sprayed with disinfectant, covered with polythene sheeting and tarpaulins were placed over the top. They were disinfected again and cleaned before making return journeys.

Mr Brown also told reporters that the first animals were being moved short distances yesterday under a localised licensing scheme, enabling farmers to milk cattle and move pregnant ewes from fields to birthing quarters.

Animals were also being slaughtered at what is believed to be Britain's first organic farm with foot-and-mouth disease.

Maff revealed two new confirmed cases near Crediton, east Devon.

One at Venny Tedburn is an organic farm run by Trevor Cligg, who was today helping with the slaughter of his 300 cattle and 100 sheep.

fields.headline: Boots ups Health & Beauty print run
fields.trailText:
10.30am: Boots is boosting the print run of its Health & Beauty magazine by 1m copies, writes Julia Day.
Mar 6: Granada and Boots set website launch date
fields.body:
Boots is boosting the print run of its Health & Beauty magazine by 1m copies in an attempt to drive sales and increase loyalty.

Health & Beauty will increase its print run to 3m from May.

It is currently mailed free of charge to the top 2m Boots Advantage Card holders.

The magazine is ranked fifth in the top 100 UK lifestyle/fashion magazines, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.

In-store sales of the products featured in the title have risen "significantly", according to the company.

The latest edition of the magazine included a voucher giving readers double Advantage Card points for two separate visits to the store.

There are 12.7m Advantage Card holders in the UK.

"Health & Beauty magazine is a powerful tool for reaching our customers," said Zoe Morgan, Boots director of marketing.

"The impact of features and advertisements in the magazine can be seen immediately in our stores.

"We can measure its success from the data from our loyalty card," she said.

Boots awarded Redwood Publishing the contract to publish Health & Beauty magazine in 1999. Four issues are published a year.

Redwood board director Keith Grainger said: "This move endorses the power of well-targeted customer magazines in influencing customer behaviour."

The UK health and beauty retail market is worth £14bn.

Related story

webTitle: Powell losing policy battle to hardliners

fields.headline: Powell losing policy battle to hardliners
fields.standfirst:
From Korea to Kosovo, the pragmatic secretary of state is being forced into increasing isolation

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: From Korea to Kosovo, the pragmatic secretary of state is being forced into increasing isolation.
fields.body:
Less than two months after George Bush's inauguration there are signs that the secretary of state, Colin Powell, is losing the struggle to shape key foreign and defence policies.

Mr Powell seems out of step with his Pentagon and White House colleagues on a range of issues, including Korea, Kosovo, Iraq and European defence, raising the fear in foreign capitals that the Bush administration is not speaking with one voice on vital issues.

The most visible example came last week when Mr Powell said that the Republican team intended to pick up the Clinton policy of cautious engagement with North Korea.

He made a humiliating u-turn the next day after President Bush said that he had no intention of resuming talks with Pyongyang, to the dismay of South Korea's visiting president, Kim Dae-jung.

Mr Powell appeared to be isolated again at the end of the week, this time on US peacekeeping in Kosovo. Two weeks ago in Brussels, He delighted Nato ministers with a declaration that the US and its allies had "gone in together" and would "come out together".

But the defence secretary, Donald Rumsfeld, conspicuously avoided any such pledge at a Washington press conference with the Nato secretary general, Lord Robertson, on Thursday.

On Iraq, Mr Powell clearly indicated that Washington supported the reformulation of the sanctions policy in favour of narrower "smart" sanctions on military-related imports.

But that line was not echoed by his harder-line colleagues, including Mr Rumsfeld and Vice-President Dick Cheney.

Mr Powell has also appeared readier than Mr Rumsfeld or Mr Cheney to welcome the European rapid-reaction defence force, even though Mr Bush himself appeared to side with Mr Powell during talks with Tony Blair at Camp David last month.

Mr Powell suffered a severe defeat at the outset when he failed to have his ally Richard Armitage appointed deputy defence secretary under Mr Rumsfeld.

Mr Bush appointed Paul Wolfowitz, a key Cheney ally who, along with Mr Rumsfeld, keenly supports the overthrow of Saddam Hussein: a stance Mr Powell opposes.

Mr Powell also opposed one of Mr Bush's first foreign policy initiatives - the ban on US funding of international groups supporting abortion services.

Senior British diplomatic sources say that it is too soon to pronounce Mr Powell the loser, but the split has become the focus of increasing attention in the US media.

Last week the senior New York Times foreign affairs specialist Thomas Friedman said there was a battle between "hard-nosed internationalists" such as Mr Powell and "ideologically driven hardliners" such as Mr Rumsfeld and Mr Cheney.

"Which is Mr Bush's approach?" Mr Friedman wrote. "You have to wonder whether Mr Bush knows."

webTitle: John Patterson on the new US movies

fields.headline: Indecent exposure
fields.standfirst: Even Robert De Niro as a fame-hungry cop can't save 15 Minutes. John Patterson takes his weekly look at the new US movies
fields.trailText: Even Robert De Niro as a fame-hungry cop can't save 15 Minutes. John Patterson takes his weekly look at the new US movies
fields.body:
I'm standing in line for 15 Minutes, the new thriller starring Robert De Niro and Edward Burns, when the guy in front of me looks at his change and says to the teenager at the box office: "Eight bucks for 15 Minutes? Is this a movie-house or a whorehouse?"

And that was pretty much the best thing about the movie, one of those buddy-buddy thrillers that pass the time merrily enough while you're watching them, but disintegrate like soggy toilet paper in the time it takes to get from cinema to parking lot. Which is a pity, because 15 Minutes has ambitions - or perhaps they're just pretensions - to be something more substantial.

The title comes from Warhol's overquoted aperçu about how in the future everyone will be famous for 15 minutes. The media seduces everyone in the film, from De Niro's celebrity cop and Kelsey Grammer's tabloid-TV host to a couple of TV- obsessed villains, and nearly every character's face brightens noticeably when it looks like they might get to stand in front of a camera.

De Niro is a grizzled old NYPD homicide cop who calls Grammer's sleazy show every time a telegenic bust is going down. Burns is a camera-shy arson investigator (with all the powers of a regular cop) who hooks up with De Niro to catch two arsonist killers from eastern Europe. They are not a pretty couple. One, Czech Emil, is a hair-trigger psychotic with messianic delusions of supercriminality, while the other, Russian Oleg, is a slow-witted media-obsessive who films every killing with his stolen digital video camera.

As this pair leaves a trail of corpses and burnt-out buildings across Manhattan, the two cops match them step for step by combining their special knowledge of killers and conflagrations.

The police-procedural material is shopworn and short on inspiration, so one has to look to the villains for originality. Emil is a garden-variety nutter who carves up everyone who crosses him, and constantly disparages his new homeland - which he only knows via "cry-baby talkshows" like Jerry Springer and Ricki Lake - with sarcastic tributes like: "I love America! No one's responsible for what they do!" (This is also the basis for his planned defence should he be apprehended.) Oleg, on the other hand, is a semi-retarded naïf, a Frank Capra fan prone to rewinding the latest killing footage and saying things like: "See? Iss more dramatic dis vay - like Silence off de Sheeps!"

Perhaps it's not surprising that their criminal partnership finally dissolves over creative differences and who gets final cut. Somehow one senses that these very same issues were to blame for 15 Minutes' narrative slackness and lack of focus.

"Slack" and "lack" were two words that also flickered through my bored brain as I watched the Kennedy-era comedy Company Man, starring John Turturro and Sigourney Weaver - both looking totally stranded. We're well overdue for a comedy that skewers all the mythologising hero worship surrounding Jack'n'Jackie's Camelot and the CIA's involvement with the Cuban Missile Crisis. This isn't it, though. Oliver Stone's JFK was much, much funnier - even if that wasn't its intention - and so was Thirteen Days, at least when Kevin Costner was doing his Boston Brahmin accent.

Which leaves us with my favourite movie in an admittedly weak week, the teen romantic comedy Get Over It. This stars Kirsten Dunst, who, ever since she played that nasty little bad-hair bloodsucker in Interview With a Vampire (aged all of 11) has been busy knocking out one winner after another. Either the girl's as smart as a whip or she has really good handlers, because Dick, The Virgin Suicides, Bring It On, Drop Dead Gorgeous and Small Soldiers all add up to a solid, well-chosen record for an actress who has yet to turn 19.

Gussying up a teen-appeal story by basing it on an acknowledged literary classic has become quite a cottage industry over the past few years, and Get Over It is loosely derived from A Midsummer Night's Dream, centring on a school production of the play.

Our hapless lead is Ben Foster, whose girlfriend dumps him for a gruesome British boy. In desperation, he tries out for the play, in which she and the Brit are starring, and gets a boost during his catastrophic audition from Dunst, his best friend's sister, who moons over him though he's too blind to realise.

Martin Short makes the best impression as the teacher in charge of the production - Desmond Forest Oakes, a repressed gay smalltown failure aiming for the big league. Of the 12 songs he has written for the play, he says: "Bill Shakespeare was a wonderful poet, but Burt Bacharach he was not!" You half expect him to say: "If Shakespeare were alive today, he'd be making high school romantic comedies!"

No, he wouldn't. But plenty of others are doing it for him.

fields.headline: Channel 5 tracks life and death of... a gerbil
fields.standfirst: Click here to see Yahoo!'s gerbil
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Channel 5 is following 'the drama of gerbil life' from birth to death in a £2m sponsorship deal with Yahoo!. By Amy Vickers.
Click here to see Yahoo!'s gerbil
fields.body:
Forget Kevin the hamster, TV is going to get a new real-life rodent as part of a £2m year-long sponsorship deal.

And in a move that could outrage animal lovers, millions of viewers will follow the little animal right to his pet funeral in exactly a year's time.

Viewers tuning into Channel 5 at 9pm tonight will witness the birth of a gerbil, which will form the cornerstone of Yahoo!'s sponsorship of the station's nightly movie slot.

Over the 12-month period, the sponsorship either side of the movies will follow the life of the yet-to-be-named gerbil.

Gerbils only live for a year and insiders at Channel 5 reckon they may even capture the animal's death live on TV.

"It would only be proper that we follow his full lifespan," said one executive at the station.

Viewers will be asked to name the gerbil in a public vote being run on the Yahoo! website.

And once the sponsorship deal kicks in, the life and times of the gerbil will be webcast live through Yahoo! 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

The animal-friendly folk at Yahoo! are also planning to launch a campaign to find a partner for the wee rodent.

Charles Saatchi has indicated that the 'two offending pictures' at his London gallery will remain on display. P1

Debt-ridden BT is considering a record-breaking £5bn cash call on its shareholders to shore up finances. P1

TV show Time Team has been affected by the foot and mouth crisis - producers of the Channel 4 show have been banned from filming at 10 out of 13 locations. P4

Anthea Turner finds a celebrity even less popular than her - Chris Eubank is picked over her for eviction from the Celebrity Big Brother house. P7

More than 30% of all homes in Britain will still be watching analogue TV by 2006, the date which the government wants to switch off the analogue signal. P23

Director Stewart Lee on Attention Scum, the cancelled BBC2 show that is in line for a Golden Rose award. P3

Rachel Newsome, new editor of Dazed & Confused, on why she has dedicated her first issue to rebellion. P6

The power of the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre, which many within advertising feel stifles creativity. P8

Geoffrey Wheatcroft on the media coverage of John Diamond's death. P10 The end of door-to-door selling leaves financial brands in an identity crisis. P35

David Teather interviews Stephen Carter, boss of the British arm of NTL. P50

Amy Vickers looks at Wellbeing, the health and beauty TV channel and website from Granada and Boots. P52

Anne Robinson was booted out of a private convent for tampering with a tapestry. P1

Robin Cook is the latest politician in deep water over a phonecall with BBC political correspondent Nicholas Jones. P1-2

A campaign to promote the benefits of boarding school education is launched today using Harry Potter. P3

Anthea Turner is reduced to tears over Celebrity Big Brother. P7

Lord Birt, the former BBC director general, is being tipped as the leading contender to head up Ofcom. P3

Napster is today racing to block 135,000 copyrighted songs or face closure if it has not done so by Wednesday. P8

ITV companies should find out this week how much extra they must pay the government over the next 10 years for their operating licences. P29

Internet investment firm Antfactory has cut staff by 30% since September and expected another round of streamlining. P30

Italian media mogul Silvio Berlusconi could be back in power soon. He is favourite to win the Italian election on May 13. P3

Breakingviews.com says it would make perfect sense for Vivendi Universal to snap up Yahoo!. P24

Institutions are demanding the resignation of BT boss Sir Iain Vallance as the price for supporting its £5bn rights issue. P26

Amazon.com boss Jeff Bezos has warned small investors they would be better off not investing in his battered online book retailer. P26

Culture secretary Chris Smith has spoken out against censorship in art after the row about the Saatchi gallery's 'family snapshots'. P3

Michael Jackson has threatened to sue Express boss Richard Desmond for allegedly reneging on a £50,000 exclusive deal to picture rights of his trip to the UK. P5

WH Smith is expanding overseas, having quietly opened stores in South America. P17

DAILY MAIL

Celebrity Big Brother has pushed back the boundaries of screen tastelessness. "Lurid", "lewd", "downmarket" and "sleeze" are just some of the words the Mail uses to describe it. P4

DAILY EXPRESS

A French doctor has provoked anger by saying Princess Diana could have been saved. P1

Anthea is cracking up. P1&P21

Blind Date contestant says she was set up and humiliated. P15

THE SUN

TV's Robson Green marries his Page 3 girl. P1

The Bill's Bob Cryer is being killed off when he is shot by a bungling colleague. P2

The probe into the Mirror share dealing scandal is being widened to investigate alleged insider dealing involving pools firm Zetters. P6

Jack Dee is caught escaping Celebrity Big Brother. P11

Nasty Nigel is a big hit with Dustin Hoffman. P21

Helen Worth, the actress who plays Gail Platt in Coronation Street, talks of how her world fell apart when she was dumped by her husband. P1

TV star Robson Green ties the knot with former topless model Vanya Seager. P3

The Mirror wishes News International owner Rupert Murdoch a happy birthday by having a pop at the Sun's declining circulation. P2

If Hear'Say make it to number one then it has cost them £631,000. P6

Jack Dee tries to escape from Celebrity Big Brother. P13

Jack Flee. Ten million tune in to watch Jack Dee's bungled escape from the Big Brother house. P5

Anthea Turner is showing herself to be an emotional wreck in the Big Brother house, bursting into tears after being nominated. Even her husband has called up the hotline to vote her out. Telegraph P7. The Star says the show is vital for Anthea's flagging career, so it looks like she's going to have to stick with it.

webTitle: What are you like? Silver surfers.

fields.headline: What are you like?
fields.standfirst: Silver surfers
fields.trailText: Silver surfers
fields.body:
Who are they? More than a million retirees with access to the internet at home. Two-thirds of them are male, they typically live in the south of England and, in these days of early retirement, they can be as young as 50.

So what do they do online? Silver surfers are regular visitors to gardening, history and travel sites. They have embraced the joys of email and the web - as this is a fairly affluent group they like to check their shares. When they shop online they buy books and music.

And when they're not online? Typically, they're more mechanically minded than the average adult and enjoy fixing things. They are also more likely to agree with the single currency, read newspaper financial pages and consult a financial adviser. They prefer to holiday off the beaten track and believe they have a healthy diet.

Do they ever slip on their slippers and watch the box? They're much more likely to have satellite or cable TV than other people the same age. Nearly 40% have pay-TV, largely for the sport, the History Channel and National Geographic.

A pretty serious lot: Not half and they're resistant to the charms of advertising - 56% think that the ad breaks are too long and 41% say they would pay more for a paper with no ads.

I suppose they prefer the wireless? Radio is popular. Radio 4, Radio 2 and Classic FM are top of the hit parade.

What are they reading? The Daily Telegraph and the Times. Reader's Digest and National Geographic.

So how can you spot a silver surfer? When someone says: "Email has just changed my life - I can chat to my daughter and my two grandchildren in New Zealand every week," you know they're riding the online wave.

 Data supplied by MediaCom Compiled by Alastair Ray

webTitle: They're all scum: BBC2's Attention Scum is in line for a Golden Rose award. But it's already been cancelled.

fields.headline: They're all scum
fields.standfirst: BBC2's Attention Scum is in line for a Golden Rose award. But it's already been cancelled. Director  Stewart Lee  knows why
fields.trailText: BBC2's Attention Scum is in line for a Golden Rose award. But it's already been cancelled. Director Stewart Lee knows why.
fields.body:
The last TV programme I worked on was cancelled before broadcast. Three weeks in advance of the comedy show Attention Scum's BBC2 run we were told there would not be a second series as "it didn't fit the new profile of the channel." It is currently showing at 11.50 pm on Sunday nights, without any trailers, following apologetic announcements warning that it "may not be to all tastes".

But last week Attention Scum was nominated for a Golden Rose of Montreux, the neutral Swiss accolade of excellence that makes a British Comedy Award look like the worthless industry back-hander it obviously is. I wonder if the BBC will fly us out to Switzerland to acknowledge support for a show they have shrugged off?

There is a precedent for shows apparently buried by the broadcaster receiving unexpected international accolades. Now so much television is a damp photocopy of Cold Feet, it's hard to believe its pilot was originally scheduled in a graveyard slot, and only repeated in primetime after this programme nobody in the UK had seen or heard of won the Golden Rose. And the rest, as they say, is indicative of the fact that commissioning editors can never truly second guess how broad-minded the public might be.

Attention Scum was originally commissioned as a block of four, to be shown, inexplicably, on consecutive nights, after BBC2 controller Jane Root had seen the 1999 Edinburgh Fringe show by writer and protagonist Simon Munnery. Munnery had been developing his League Against Tedium character, an impotent and frustrated would-be intellectual and dictator, for more than a decade, and the shows were given a budget of £60,000 each, which is between a third and a quarter of normal spending on BBC2 comedy half-hours. A small top-up fee was agreed, if there could be six shows instead of four, and the pointless idea of showing it on successive nights was abandoned for a mid-week slot.

Producer Richard Webb asked me to direct Munnery, traversing the country lecturing to random crowds from the top of a specially constructed van. The fact that our uninvited audiences accumulated like leaves in village squares and rural car parks rather than studios saved money, though the ungainly repetition of certain locations and characters still reflects budgetary limitations. The Fast Show used repetition as a stylistic device. For much new comedy, it is a financial imperative.

On viewing the rushes, word from above was encouraging and we were enormously proud of the final result and I expected that Attention Scum would be recommissioned on a budget that allowed us to do it justice. Then we heard, having been teased with prime time, that Attention Scum was scheduled for Sunday at 11.50pm, and then dismissed.

On BBC Choice's Liquid News, £250,000 info-face Christopher Price called Attention Scum a success, only to be informed by Simon that it had already been cancelled. Price assumed this was due to its huge cost, but it was made for little more than his fee. On the whole, the show has garnered superlative reviews (particularly given its low profile) and the buzz on internet comedy message boards has been plentiful and supportive.

"BBC2 really has lost all its charm to judge from the placement of Attention Scum in the death slot, and the refusal to follow through with a second series. It doesn't look remotely like a ratings winner, but this is exactly the reason I care about television. It ain't worth switching on the box without programmes this unorthodox," lamented one anonymous correspondent.

The sharp end of Root's reprofiling of BBC2, and the planned shift of all new comedy onto BBC Choice, where there is not enough money to make anything look accessible enough to "cross over", means that current Christmas Day bankers like French and Saunders and The Royle Family would also, like Simon Munnery, be shot in their incubators. In the meantime, the edition of Attention Scum currently scheduled for April 1 features a sequence with a monkey, a banana, and a Russian tank, which is the single moment of television I am most proud to be associated with. I hope the Swiss feel the same.

webTitle: Eubank evicted, Dee stuck on the inside

fields.headline: Eubank evicted, Dee stuck on the inside
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText:
Troubled presenter Anthea Turner found there was a celebrity even less popular than herself in Celebrity Big Brother, writes Rebecca Allison.
Special report: Big Brother
fields.body:
The nomination for eviction could hardly have been a surprise given the recent string of unfortunate events which have blighted Anthea Turner's once charmed life.

But unlike the "Flakegate" fiasco and the bombing of her book, this particular nightmare failed to become reality as the troubled presenter found that there was a celebrity even less popular than herself.

In what can only be described as a night of high drama, more than 750,000 Celebrity Big Brother viewers rang to cast their vote on whether Turner or former boxer Chris Eubank should be the first evictee.

As Eubank left the house on Saturday night, a victorious Turner could smile in the knowledge that she does have friends on the outside after all.

Meanwhile, the real action was unfolding behind the seemingly innocuous facade of comedian Jack Dee.

In a move which must have delighted television bosses eager to increase viewing figures, the deadpan celebrity hatched and executed an escape plan.

As Brookside actress Claire Sweeney, Boyzone star Keith Duffy and Turner relaxed in the infamous Big Brother hot tub, Dee was in the garden secretly attempting to dig a hole under the fence with a rake.

Discovering an easier escape route, in the form of an open garden gate, he made his bid for freedom under the cover of night, but, alas, was unable to avoid the gaze of the cameras.

The unfortunate comic was quickly discovered by security guards and promptly frog-marched back to the house.

After his eviction, Chris Eubank dug the dirt on his fellow contestants, describing Turner as "fragile" and upset by her negative public image.

Turner's mood should improve as it emerged she has not been nominated in the second round of evictions. The celebrities voted for Dee and Feltz, who are now put to the public vote. Each call raises 15.5p for Comic Relief. The winner will be chosen on Red Nose Day on Friday.

webTitle: Picking up the poisoned chalice: Interview with Stephen Carter, new head of the British arm of cable company NTL.

fields.headline: Picking up the poisoned chalice
fields.standfirst:
Ex-adman Stephen Carter, new head of the British arm of cable company NTL, has a mammoth task - restoring customer confidence and generating profits. He tells David Teather how he intends to go about it

More net news
fields.trailText: Ex-adman Stephen Carter, new head of the British arm of cable company NTL, has a mammoth task - restoring customer confidence and generating profits. He tells David Teather how he intends to go about it.
fields.body:
After 15 years of working in advertising, Stephen Carter had, in his own words, started to "recycle my own bullshit". At 36, the man who joined J Walter Thompson as a graduate trainee and rose to chief executive decided in the latter part of last year that it was time to move on. He came close to accepting the still vacant top job at the ITV network but then took a call in the back of a car in the US from NTL chief executive Barclay Knapp. This time, he was persuaded to take the leap and in doing so accepted a job where any whiff of bullshit will be hard to miss.

Carter, who became managing director of the cable operator's UK and Ireland business four months ago, has joined the company at a crucial time. After a frenetic period of acquisition and expansion, of digging roads and laying cable and most of all of promise after promise, NTL is at the stage where it needs to begin performing. Carter will be judged by the empirical evidence of revenues per subscriber, the success of the digital roll-out and customer numbers. NTL is, in the words of Knapp last week, "getting down to business."

NTL's excuses for letting BSkyB steal such a significant march, particularly in the roll-out of digital TV, have been valid enough. While Sky was powering ahead last year, much of NTL's time was spent in getting to grips with regulators and then the logistics of untangling the Cable & Wireless Communications business from its parent and merging it with its existing network.

But in doing so, it doubled in size and gained metropolitan networks in London, Manchester and Leeds. In effect, it became a national company, despite the small matter of Telewest - a legacy of the last government's decision to offer cable companies only small franchises, which has hampered the development of cable. It has been, Carter says, "a seismic year" for NTL.

The company now finds itself in a position where it is able to compete more effectively with Sky and British Telecom for consumer and business accounts, and to reap the economic benefits of scale. NTL has also built debts of $15bn, which are due to peak at $20bn, and investors will be watching its promises of being cash flow-positive by 2003. It lost $3bn last year and can't afford any slippage on the targets for revenue growth.

Carter is disarmingly frank about the failure of the cable industry to grapple with digital, which has proven to be the catalyst for the current burst of growth in pay TV. "We were stuffed," he says. "There is no doubt that when the history of cable is written, being late to market with digital will be judged as one of the things that held us back. But last year we launched three new products and bought a company the same size as ourselves.

"Sky and ONdigital had a six-month window to get out there while we were focused on the machinations of regulation. There's no doubt a couple of googlies last year slightly knocked us off our stride. That's why 2001 will be so interesting because digital is coming off the conveyor belt, people like it and it's genuinely a bloody good product."

After the delays of last year - not helped by a shortage of components in the company's set-top boxes - the group has finally begun to put its weight behind digital. It has 600,000 digital subscribers and has set a target for the end of the year of 1.25m. Carter believes the entire network will be using digital by the end of 2002.

With the focus at last on operations instead of deal-making, cable has a significant opportunity to make its mark in broadband. The technical limitations on satellite and the debacle surrounding the "unbundling of the local loop" to make DSL widely available have put NTL and Telewest in a strong position.

"I reckon we have an 18-month window to really steal a march on everyone else in both the consumer and business telecoms area," Carter says. "We want to realise the assets we have within the group. We can take BT on in broadband with product quality and we will price it aggressively."

The company so far has only 12,800 broadband subscribers but is aiming for 100,000 by year end. The difference in revenues is significant. Analogue customers are paying an average £36 a month, digital customers are paying £42 and cable modem customers more like £66.

The other priority for Carter is a tighter control on costs in an organisation which has naturally become unwieldy - in the UK alone, NTL has made 11 acquisitions in the past 18 months. As well as the inevitable job losses, he has to wrestle with the merging of different cultures and systems which all have a knock-on effect on the cable industry's biggest failing, its reputation for execrable customer service.

Alongside a profile marking his arrival in NTL's internal magazine, United, was a letters page which demonstrated that the company is anything but. "What do you plan to do about call centres?" asked a technician. "Every customer I go to complains of not being able to get through to report a fault." Another commented that in the company's head office in Hook, Hampshire, "there seems to be a vast sense of despair, doom and gloom".

Much of NTL's efforts this year will be focused on improving the service in London, where repeated changes of ownership from Videotron to CWC have grotesquely illustrated the cable industry's problems, and where penetration is as low as 25%. "Whether we like it or not, reputations are made or broken there, so we have made the decision to invest 30% of our infrastructure expenditure in London this year," Carter says.

One of his first moves was to rationalise all the company's content, including its football club stakes, British Eurosport and its shares in the ITN cable channel, Front Row and Universal movie channel, into a single division. He has also made it clear that NTL will not be trying to emulate Sky, or even Telewest, in content. The programming is there, he says, to leverage better deals with "real" content providers.

From 1999 onwards, Carter worked as a consultant to NTL at JWT. The agency came up with the branding campaign "technology tamed", which has put NTL on the map for consumers, and his appointment was clearly viewed as an acknowledgment by the company that it needed a little marketing nous.

"The cable industry has had a reputation for pretty poor service and amateur marketing and by and large the companies have been run by technologists, engineers and financial executives. Now, any company needs those people but when you get to the position we have where you've got scale, you've got network, and you've got the best part of 4m customers, what you need is well designed products that are packaged in a way that people understand and want to buy, priced and promoted elegantly and effectively," he says. "I want the company run by the product managers."

Raised in Edinburgh and educated at the local comprehensive, Carter went on to study law at Aberdeen University. When he graduated in the early 1980s the career to go into was advertising just as it would be investment banking now, he says. The clear message is that he is a businessman rather than a stereotypical adman. Before taking over as chief executive at JWT he did a stint at Harvard. Nor, he insists, is it too much of a wrench to leave the excesses of a Soho agency for a large corporation. Advertising, he notes, is not the playground it once was and industry has loosened up a bit.

"There are things peculiar to the cable industry, that's true, but there are a lot of things about running a company which are transferable and a lot of things about marketing products which are transferable," he says.

His years spent in adland have clearly left their mark. He repeatedly draws parallels between NTL and other consumer brands. NTL should be like Tesco, he says, "fantastically good" at providing products supplied by others and ever-reliable. It should be like a gas supplier: with customer service so good that it is invisible.

In a flourish, he describes moving from consultant to running a business as akin to walking through the looking glass. "But it's fantastically empowering because you do get to do all those things you say should be done as a consultant."

As he says, spotting that the cable industry has been plagued by poor customer service and ineffectual marketing is the easy bit. Now the hard work begins.

webTitle: Censorship fear in Saatchi gallery row

fields.headline: Censorship fear in Saatchi gallery row
fields.trailText: Charles Saatchi has indicated that two "offending" pictures will remain on display at his London gallery despite warnings from Scotland Yard, reports Alan Travis.
fields.body:
Chris Smith, the culture secretary, warned of the dangers of censorship as the advertising tycoon Charles Saatchi indicated yesterday that two "offending" pictures will remain on display at his London gallery despite warnings from Scotland Yard's obscene publications unit.

Mr Smith said he considered child pornography on the internet to be a far greater danger than what might be found in a London art gallery. Although he would not comment specifically on last week's raid by the Met on the Saatchi gallery, he made plain that he believed there was a danger of censorship in the case.

Mr Saatchi, after taking legal advice, has said the pictures of partly nude children will remain on display. They were taken by their mother, the American photographer Tierney Gearon, as part of Saatchi's I Am a Camera exhibition, which is drawn from his collection of photographs and has been running for eight weeks to critical acclaim and without public complaint.

Senior officers from the Met's obscene publications and internet unit last week twice visited the gallery. They viewed the pictures and then returned, after taking legal advice, to warn the curator that the photographs could be seized with a possible prosecution to follow if they were not removed before the gallery opens its doors to the public again this Thursday. The police also officially warned an international fine art publisher, Edward Booth-Clibborn, to withdraw his book on which the exhibition is based.

Asked if he supported the police's action, Mr Smith told Sky Television: "Before I rush to any judgment in this particular case I want to see the evidence with my own eyes. I am much more worried about paedophile material that's available on the internet than about an art gallery somewhere in the middle of London."

Mr Smith said it was difficult to strike the balance between the need to protect children from exploitation and free speech. "Balancing those two objectives is what difficult questions of this kind have to be about. We must be very careful in this country before we start censoring things that are happening, either in newspapers or in art galleries."

The gallery owners could face up to three years in prison under the 1978 Protection of Children Act, which makes it a criminal offence to take or display indecent photographs of children. A legal opinion by Geoffrey Robertson, a leading QC on freedom of expression, is to be sent to the director of public prosecutions today. It is believed to argue that court precedents show that the depiction of naked children without any sexual overtones or lewdness does not amount to indecency.

It also became clear yesterday that the News of the World worked closely with the police over the raid. Although the newspaper said the police were "acting on complaints from concerned members of the public", the police had told the Saatchi gallery that they were following up complaints from journalists.

In an editorial, the Sunday tabloid called for the closure of the exhibition which it condemned as "a revolting exhibition of perversion under the guise of art" and quoted police sources as claiming: "It is time someone decided what is art and what is porn and looked after the interests of the children who have been photographed." The tabloid also attacked the Independent on Sunday for sponsoring the exhibition and accused it of hypocrisy for daring to criticise the NoW's now abandoned "name and shame" anti-paedophile campaign.

The raid on the gallery provoked dismay from leading artistic figures, including the film-maker Lord Puttnam, the moral philosopher Baroness Warnock, cultural critic Germaine Greer, and the BBC's director of drama, Alan Yentob.

"I am sure they are completely innocent pictures. The implication of obscenity has only been made as a consequence of the vice squad going to the gallery in a lumbering way. Have they not got better things to do?" Mr Yentob was reported as saying.

But Andreas Whittam Smith, president of the British Board of Film Classification and a founding editor of the Independent, said the Protection of Children Act was specific in banning pictures of children in sexually compromising positions.

He did not think the fact that it was a parent taking the pictures gave her any authority to do that.

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.trailText: Bad news for Michael "Tarzan" Heseltine. His publishing house Haymarket is having a few problems launching its all-singing, all-dancing media/marketing portal, Brand Republic. No relation to Banana Republic or Coffee Republic. Seems that Brand Republic is running about six months behind schedule and may not launch until July. Rumour has it a law suit with the former development agency Diverse could be on the cards. Diary must confess an interest and, yes, Haymarket's delay does give the super-soaraway Mediaguardian.co.uk a massive head start, but you do wonder how the Brand Republic staff, ready for a January launch, are filling their days.
fields.body:
Bad news for Michael "Tarzan" Heseltine. His publishing house Haymarket is having a few problems launching its all-singing, all-dancing media/marketing portal, Brand Republic. No relation to Banana Republic or Coffee Republic. Seems that Brand Republic is running about six months behind schedule and may not launch until July. Rumour has it a law suit with the former development agency Diverse could be on the cards. Diary must confess an interest and, yes, Haymarket's delay does give the super-soaraway Mediatheguardian.com a massive head start, but you do wonder how the Brand Republic staff, ready for a January launch, are filling their days.

 Staying with the trade press, did New Media Age experience a spot of calendar-confusion last week with its splash on former Currantbun.com head baker Ellis Watson getting a top job at Celador? Diary is not suggesting that the affable Ellis is not big news, but it was old news - the announcement was made at the beginning of February. Surely everyone's favourite new media trade rag couldn't have not known of Ellis's re-emergence? When contacted, Ellis said: "They're quick like that. Next week they're splashing on ClickMango going tits up."

 Rumours persist about QXL making cutbacks. Not unusual in this bearish dot.com day and age, but vehemently denied by QXL's rather forceful PR manager. For the record, QXL has not laid off any staff, the rumour that a number of staff that were employed within the now defunct QXL Direct (the company for the consumer side of the business), have gone is "completely untrue" - they have simply been "offered different roles within QXL". Yet spies insist that at least three people were laid off when QXL Direct, previously the core of the business, was shut down (sorry, migrated to a consumer-to-consumer model) at the end of February. Diary awaits QXL's next results statement in May.

 Diary followers will be wondering why last week we mentioned Russell Grant in connection with astrological warfare and Keen.co.uk when, by the time we published, the lovely pic of said mystic had disappeared from the front of Keen.co.uk. It was there the Thursday before, honest. What happened was something not even Russell could have predicted. It all blew up on Friday afternoon, after Keen decided it didn't like RG's exclusive tech deal with arch-rival Questico and promptly called up one of RG's men. RG's man rightly said none of your beeswax and Keen got very angry and shouted at RG's man, who withdrew Mr Mystic from any deal with Keen. The upshot of the fracas is that RG will not appear on Keen. The moral is: treat astrologers with respect, or else.

Amy Vickers (amy.vickers@theguardian.com) is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

fields.headline: My new media
fields.standfirst: Benjamin Cohen
fields.trailText: Benjamin Cohen
fields.body:
Favourite websites? www.qeboys.da.ru It's a weird website about the school I went to in Barnet called Queen Elizabeth. The site is subtitled "QE: The Truth" and basically tells lots of funny stories about teachers at the school. Also I like totallyjewish.com, aside from the fact that my company was bought by them. I'm normally quoted as saying I hate them but recently I've started liking them.

Ever been in a chatroom?

It's not really me. It's like walking into a party that you're not invited to. I'm surprised at how addicted people become to chatrooms. Real life is far better than internet chat.

Most recent technological faux pas?

Sending text messages for my girlfriend to the wrong person. I've got her phone number in a memory thing and yet I consistently manage to text the wrong person.

Last online purchase?

I like buying things on the internet but I've not really splashed out on anything more exciting then the bog standard books and CDs.

Most useful site?

news.bbc.co.uk.which I visit at least five times a day. It has the most in-depth news on the internet and upholds a high standard of journalism.

Least useful site?

Probably useless.com, what else?

Which site is least likely to succeed?

The JC.com [the Jewish Chronicle site]. A lot of time and effort was put into this site but it lacks functionality and is so much worse than the offline version. I just can't see how it's going to make money without diminishing the sales of the newspaper.

Time spent on the web?

Too much. From 10am till 6pm every day at work and sometimes more time afterwards.

Screensaver?

The Ed Harcourt one from skipmusic.com.

Most irritating thing about the web?

People's misconceptions about it. People are scared to look at our site but when they do they see that we're just a search engine and we have a porn search engine in addition to all the other stuff that we do. A lot of people don't know what a search engine is and think that we are actually making porn.

Do you bother with old media?

Yes. I read newspapers and watch some television. The relationship between old and new media is really important. They have to work together, but people mistakenly think they've got to be separate.

 18-year-old Benjamin Cohen is the founder and CEO of cyberbritain.com He appears in Trouble at the Top on BBC2 this Thursday.
