fields.headline: Media monitor
fields.trailText: So the Sun is backing the most dangerous man in Britain. The country's biggest tabloid is a weather vane rather than a signpost, and Rupert Murdoch's public blessing of Tony Blair was inevitable because most of its readers intend to vote Labour.
fields.body:
So the Sun is backing the most dangerous man in Britain. The country's biggest tabloid is a weather vane rather than a signpost, and Rupert Murdoch's public blessing of Tony Blair was inevitable because most of its readers intend to vote Labour.

Of course it never was the Sun wot won it in 1992 for the Tories (that dubious honour must go to the paper's readers), but Labour will be happy that, unlike in 1997, it will not have to wait for the campaign to start before receiving the Wapping endorsement.

The euro, the issue that excites Wapping above all others and led a few years ago to the paper dubbing Blair a liability, was forgotten last Thursday when the tabloid decided to back a dead cert. And with the feared low turnout threatening to cost Labour seats, Blair will be delighted to have such an effective propaganda machine lauding the party.

The Sun's declaration of support was triggered by a budget that must go down as one of the best-received in the national press. The government's spinners managed to highlight its giveaways while simultaneously making a virtue of the fact that there were so few giveaways.

Philip Stephens, a columnist in the Financial Times - which produced a backbreaking 32-page supplement - wrote: "Voters do not watch the budget speech. It is the headlines that count."

Those headlines were overwhelmingly in Labour's favour, ranging from the Sun's "It's In The Bag, Tony" to the Express's "Everyone a Winner". There were even favourable pieces in the Mail and Telegraph, the Tories' last press allies.

Columnists in the Tory redoubts were true to form and largely hostile. For the Mail's Simon Heffer it was, "And how much for the hard-working middle class? Precious little", while Boris Johnson, a Tory election candidate, could only manage: "What can you expect from a man who dyes his hair?"

Johnson, no oil painting himself, could have done worse than look at the headline on the centre-page spread in his own paper's budget pull-out: "Middle Britain's verdict: grateful for the good news on the NHS and schools."

The spinning before and immediately after last week's budget surpassed even the whirl of Gordon Brown's previous efforts, and is likely to prove as intense as any operation outside the campaign itself. Virtually every announcement had been leaked in advance (including a few that were untrue, such as the 1p off income tax announced in the Independent) to gain early coverage before Labour went into overdrive on the big day.

The Treasury had put all the figures through its computer to test the impact of tax changes not just on Mondeo Man, Worcester Woman or Pebbledash Man, but also on a family invented by the Tories and in the past portrayed as £670 a year worse off under Labour. Now that family is £135 better off.

Labour understands the trick is not only to achieve favourable coverage for the party, but to deny the Tories the oxygen of publicity, and the slickness of the machine was demonstrated as soon as Brown sat down at the end of his 52-minute speech.

Alastair Campbell, who had followed the statement line by line perched on his usual bench high above the Commons chamber, jumped up to leave immediately it ended. So as William Hague got on his feet to put the Tory case, more than 40 journalists headed for the doors behind the Pied Piper of spin to the lower press gallery antechamber.

There, the prime minister's press secretary was joined by Ed Balls, Brown's chief economic adviser, who spent another half an hour "helpfully" taking Fleet Street's finest through the details, pointing out tables and pages in the red book.

The only impact the Tory leader had was to delay the briefing for 20 seconds while Campbell had the sound turned down on a TV monitor to avoid the leader of the loyal opposition distracting the hacks.

So to echo Philip Stephens's comment in the FT, it's headlines that count, and last week Labour won by a landslide.

 John Kampfner is away.

webTitle: Dismal digital TV take-up upsets government plans

fields.headline: Dismal digital TV take-up upsets government plans
fields.standfirst: BSkyB and ONdigital will miss subscriber target
fields.trailText: More than 30% of homes in Britain will still be watching analogue television by the start of 2006, writes David Teather.
fields.body:
More than 30% of homes in Britain will still be watching analogue television by the start of 2006, the first trigger date at which the government had hoped to switch off the analogue signal.

The estimate comes from leading media buying and research agency Optimedia, which forecasts a sharp slowdown in the take-up of digital TV services in the next few years. According to the recently published research on digital and interactive services, both BSkyB and ONdigital will miss their stated targets for numbers of digital subscribers by a wide margin.

BSkyB, the market leader in pay TV, has set a target of 7m customers by the end of 2003 but will secure just 6.2m, the research says, up from its current level of 5m.

ONdigital, which has said it will double its subscriber base to 2m by the end of next year will reach just 1.4m, according to Optimedia.

The estimates will be unwelcome news to culture secretary Chris Smith. The switch-off of the analogue signal is a potentially incendiary issue and so far the government has committed only to a range of 2006-2010, depending on the rate at which consumers turn to digital.

Switching off the signal with a large number of households still using analogue could be politically damaging but estimates of the number of households with no interest in paying for multi-channel TV services vary widely.

What happens to second or third TV sets in the home, which will be rendered useless without their own set top boxes, is also uncertain.

Italy last week became the first country in Europe to set a hard date for switch-off of 2007, which will add pressure to the government to make a firm commitment.

Optimedia suggests that the fastest growth in the next few years will come from the cable sector. The cable companies, NTL and Telewest, have been late to launch digital services but will rapidly close the gap on BSkyB, largely as a result of converting their existing analogue subscriber base.

By the end of 2005, the Optimedia research estimates that cable will have 5.9m customers, or 23.6% of homes. BSkyB will have 6.3m or 25.3% by the end of 2005 and ONdigital will have 1.9m, around 7.6% of homes.

"Undoubtedly the further concentration of ITV ownership (ONdigital is owned by Granada and Carlton), and the rumoured stock market flotation will add impetus," the report says. "However, we feel that terrestrial digital will be the weakest of the three platforms."

webTitle: Drop the sexy donkey: Belinda Archer on  the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre (BACC).

fields.headline: Drop the sexy donkey
fields.standfirst: Menacing cows and a call to infect the country with the common cold. Should we be subjected to such things in our front rooms?  Belinda Archer  delves into some puzzling decisions from the people who regulate our TV adverts
fields.trailText: Menacing cows and a call to infect the country with the common cold. Should we be subjected to such things in our front rooms? Belinda Archer delves into some puzzling decisions from the people who regulate our TV adverts.
fields.body:
You might think that advertising is all about long lunches down the Ivy, but there is something that makes the average executive's life a misery. Mention it in Soho circles and you will prompt the filthiest of curses and trigger an instant greyness around the gills.

It is the Broadcast Advertising Clearance Centre (BACC). This august body, funded by the nation's broadcasters, is solely responsible for pre-vetting all commercials before they go on air in the UK. It makes sure that each ad abides by the independent television commission's (ITC) code of advertising standards and practice which stipulates, loosely, that all ads should be legal, decent, honest, and truthful.

Perhaps unsurprisingly, adfolk hate it. They claim the watchdog has far too much power, that it stifles creativity and is too anal and humourless in its application of the ITC code. In adland BACC is the ultimate four-letter word.

Only last week the latest furore blew up over yet another arguably dozy piece of decision-making. The brouhaha surrounded a new fcuk commercial for French Connection which depicted a young couple talking a bit dirty to each other while getting undressed. The BACC rejected it on the grounds that it contained "an unacceptable level of sexual innuendo", a judgment that prompted Trevor Beattie, who created it, to stage an impromptu press conference and even stick a statement in the window of the fashion chain's Oxford Circus branch, railing against the authorities.

Beattie's antics aside, there are plenty more contentious examples of ads that have fallen under the BACC's knife. There was the drinks script that featured a group of young men running after a donkey. This was stopped "because of its sexual overtones". Another spot, for a supermarket special offer, was disallowed because it showed a cashpoint paying out more cash than the person ordered (deemed "irresponsible" because it suggested that banks didn't know how to distribute cash properly).

There was also the recent jokey Cravendale milk ad that ran into trouble (although it eventually aired) for depicting a herd of cows as "too menacing", and the Tunes commercial barred from the screen for showing a woman deliberately trying to get a cold because she loved the cough sweets so much. This, too, was judged "irresponsible" because it "encouraged the public to get ill".

Just who exactly are these people who think a Tunes ad will incite members of the public to infect themselves, and how are they qualified to be the ultimate arbiters of all taste and decency in our TV commercials? Put simply, should the BACC itself be banned?

Uisdean Maclean is the body's director: "Our remit is to ensure that all advertising abides by the ITC code on advertising standards. We are charged by the broadcasters to work on their behalf, to avoid offending the mass audience. We have to stick by this, regardless of whether people say we are living in the dark ages."

Maclean is assisted in his grand task by 20 executives, ranging in age from 23 to 50, who represent a "broad cross-section of society". Some have a legal background, some come from broadcasting, and the rest are recruited from the Advertising Standards Authority (the BACC's print ad equivalent).

Every script is first read by a small group of at least three executives. If there is anything vaguely contentious, it is then passed on to a daily meeting of several more senior people, including the director himself.

"If we can't reach a decision we refer it to a monthly BACC copy committee which includes several heavyweight representatives from the broadcasters," explains Maclean.

It would seem, therefore, that there is a pretty robust system in place to guarantee against highly individual, subjective, irrational rulings - all the things, in fact, that the BACC is accused of.

So where does it go wrong? For go wrong it does. Surely something is seriously awry if a committee of grown-ups stops a script advertising Ragu Chunky Vegetables because they think there is "sexual innuendo" in the product name.

Tim Mellors, chief creative officer of Grey London, says: "They are too literal. They err on the side of safety rather than reason. They are basically arse-coverers because if an ad goes on air and it gets taken off, they look silly."

Dave Droga, executive creative director of Saatchi and Saatchi, goes further: "They pander to a very small minority of vocal people who complain about everything. It is actually damaging our advertising. We are very shackled - the world has moved on, programming has moved on, the consumer has moved on, but advertising stays the same."

Maclean nobly admits that the BACC has "made mistakes", and that in those rare instances it has simply admitted that it misjudged a situation. On balance, however, he insists that the body acts in a responsible, unhysterical way.

"We don't just think about any potential complaint from anywhere - we think about whether it could be justified. We want the advertising on air, but we want it to stay on air. If an ad is suspended then it is tears all round."

But what about the particular charges, that the BACC cramps creativity, lacks any sense of humour, and, most common of all, that it is inconsistent?

"I would look at any criticism and decide whether there was any justification, but we try to be as consistent as possible - a lot depends on the context in which the scenes are shown. And I would not agree at all that we stifle creativity. In fact it has often been said that we stimulate creativity to get round the problems."

It would certainly appear that the BACC has a thankless task. If an ad is broadcast without controversy, it gets no praise, and if it is banned by the ITC, it is blamed. The pre-vetting agency is often, in fact, the first line of defence if an ad is taken off - agencies say "but the BACC okayed it".

However, a few adfolk do have some sympathy for the TV watchdog and the job it is charged with. "I feel sorry for them. They are under an avalanche of scripts, they are undermanned and underfunded. The number of scripts has quadrupled - they are hideously overworked and so are not working in the best way," says Robert Campbell, creative director of Rainey Kelly Campbell Roalfe/Y&R.

Mellors believes things could be worse: "The BACC is voluntary so it is not as awful as a governmental department would be. They are recruited from the business so they largely understand the issues. There has to be some kind of watchdog and it is better that it is from within the industry than outside it."

The verdict, then, would appear to be that the BACC should not be banned, it should simply be given more money and more experienced staff. Plus it should get out a bit more. In this age of deregulated TV programming, in which, as Beattie said, "murder, pillage, cannibalism and mediocrity routinely passes for family entertainment", those in control of the nation's commercials should relax a little.

webTitle: Debt-ridden BT plan for £5bn rights issue

fields.headline: Debt-ridden BT plan for £5bn rights issue
fields.trailText: British Telecom is considering a record-breaking £5bn cash call on its shareholders to shore up its finances.
fields.body:
British Telecom is considering a record-breaking £5bn cash call on its shareholders to shore up its finances.

The telecoms company has a £30bn debt mountain - equal to three quarters of its stock market valuation - and had hoped to pay back some of its loans by selling off parts of its business and demerging others as separate listed companies.

But the world's stockmarkets have recently turned against heavily indebted telecoms and technology companies and the operations BT is ready to unload, such as its mobile phone business, would fetch far lower prices now than even a couple of months ago.

However, it is understood some major City investors have indicated they would support a £5bn rights issue - but only if it is accompanied by the departure of BT's chairman, Sir Iain Vallance, and chief executive, Sir Peter Bonfield.

Sir Iain, who is also the current chairman of the Confederation of British Industry, and Sir Peter are viewed as jointly responsible for the company's predicament, which has seen its share price tumble from £15 to £ 5.55in the last year.

A £5bn cash call would dwarf all previous rights issues in British corporate history. The biggest to date was the £1.7bn raised by media group Pearson last summer to finance an acquisition.

BT admitted yesterday it was considering asking its shareholders for cash. "We are still hoping to reduce debt through disposals and listings, but we have to remain flexible given the current market conditions," a spokesman said.

In an interview over the weekend, BT's new finance director, Philip Hampton, also implied that a cash call was on the cards. He said that if BT had to sell assets at cut prices, he would rather the discount went to BT's shareholders. He added: "We need to do something a bit different."

With a rights issue, shareholders would be offered the opportunity to buy new shares at a deep discount to the current share price. But it is far from certain that shareholders would put up extra money, especially in the current stockmarket climate.

BT could get the issue underwritten by City banks to guarantee they get their cash - but that would cost the telecoms company a fortune, as the banks would demand huge fees to cover the risk of being landed with a sinking stock.

BT, once regarded as a potential global telecoms giant, is now regarded as little more than a bit part player on the world stage. It is more heavily indebted than almost all its European rivals.

Analysts say BT's management has spent too much time and energy trying to hold on to its old monopolies and fighting the telecoms regulator when it should have been getting into new markets.

Sir Peter, who joined the company as a supposed new broom five years ago, recently admitted that BT paid £10bn more than it had expected to secure third generation mobile telephone licences.

fields.headline: Don't mention the war
fields.trailText: National newspaper circulation: Whenever Richard Desmond's name crops up, and it tends to rather often, it's hard not to recall that Fawlty Towers episode when Basil can't help mentioning the war. In Desmond's case, we must not mention pornography, but we aren't bound by deals as the Mail group is.
fields.body:
Whenever Richard Desmond's name crops up, and it tends to rather often, it's hard not to recall that Fawlty Towers episode when Basil can't help mentioning the war. In Desmond's case, we must not mention pornography, but we aren't bound by deals as the Mail group is.

Pornography speaks volumes about the man. His marketing of it in magazines, on websites and on television showed a willingness to do anything to make a fast buck. His desire not to be associated with it any longer reveals his embarrassment.

There is more though. Pornographers, by the nature of their trade, operate in the margins, ducking and diving, often stretching the rules, careless about ethics. So it really shouldn't surprise us that he has pulled a stroke by offering a version of his OK! magazine through the Sunday Express for 1p.

I understand that the council of the Audit Bureau of Circulations (ABC) will have to decide whether the tactic, which is likely to add some 40,000 copies to OK!'s sale, is fair or not. Naturally enough, the rival Hello! is planning to complain, but if it doesn't get satisfaction don't be surprised if it doesn't join forces with the Mail on Sunday to match the offer.

As I studied the latest national paper sales figures, what struck me as amusing was the reasoning of Desmond's spokesman who said: "We are simply maximising the brand value of our different titles."

The brand value of the Sunday Express is hard to divine nowadays. Its sale has plunged to barely 830,000, more than 9% down on a year ago. A showy revamp, with an extra section called Enjoy! which provides more entertainment content just in case readers have not been sated by the stuff in the main paper, has done nothing to arrest the decline.

But the paper has cleaned up part of its circulation act. Last February it included more than 53,000 bulks in its headline figure. That went down last month to just over 39,000.

That set me on a trail to discover what other titles have done about their multiple sales. Of the 25 titles in our chart, 15 have increased bulks in the past 12 months, seven have reduced them, and three are almost the same. Some papers have enlarged their multiple sales dramatically. The Observer is up 18,000 on a year ago, the People up 16,000 and the Times by 13,000, pushing its total bulk sale to more than 51,000, the highest user of the lot. Next highest is the Daily Telegraph with more than 48,000.

With the overall market in such bad shape, it is sobering to reflect that not only have the total of bulk sales increased for dailies and Sundays, but so have pre-paid subscriptions and discounted sales. Yet fewer people are buying papers: the daily market has slipped by 1.52% in a year while the Sunday market has dropped by 3.6%.

Doubtless, in spite of claims about the freely distributed Metro being consumed by new, young readers, it has had some impact on buyers of the paid-for papers. It has been Britain's sixth highest circulation paper for a couple of months now and could well overtake the Daily Express by the end of this year.

Looking at the longer trend, the six-monthly averages, there are reasons for some owners and editors to smile. It's hard to recall that the Observer was once thought to be in terminal decline; the Sunday Times seems impervious to sales fluctuations; and the Mail titles remain strong. Oh yes, and the Daily Star is enjoying continued success, a singular plus for Desmond. But, please, don't mention that he's a . . .

webTitle: The end of door-to-door selling leaves financial brands with an identity crisis, says  Julia Day.

fields.headline: Death of the salesmen
fields.standfirst: The end of door-to-door selling leaves financial brands with an identity crisis, says  Julia Day
fields.trailText: The end of door-to-door selling leaves financial brands with an identity crisis, says Julia Day.
fields.body:
As the men from the Pru, Britannic Assurance and Sun Life of Canada hang up their hats and make their last house calls, financial brands built on friendly face-to-face contact are re-evaluating the way they market their brands. The death of the life assurance salesmen mirrors a move across the financial industry to shun direct customer contact in favour of "remote" communication via the telephone and the internet.

Last year, banks came under fire for closing branches, now financial services are trying to market themselves as being as hip as mobile phones. Witness Halifax employees gyrating to the thumping bassline of Tom Jones' Sexbomb in an ad which screams "We're funky, friendly, cute little movers". Natwest asks to be applauded for not turning all its branches into wine bars and Lloyds TSB soothes away doubts to the strains of "What can we do to make you happy?"

But both the Britannic and Prudential brands are based on face-to-face advice. Now the companies must maintain the personable feel of their brands, and consumers' trust. "The entire positioning of these companies is built on a face-to-face service: it's their brand promise. When you take the personal touch away, that promise is broken. It risks damaging the brand equity," says David Gray, director of Creative Leap, the branding agency for Marks and Spencer's financial services.

"The direct sales force and branch staff have been the face of the brand. But the bean-counters have made the decisions from a cost-cutting point of view, not a branding one. It leaves them with questions about who they are and what they stand for. Consumers are already disappointed with financial services: this is just another nail in the coffin," says Gray.

John Elbourne, chief executive of Prudential UK operations, believes the Pru brand is strong enough to withstand the changes. But it is taking measures to protect the brand, including revamping the famous bowler hat logo and introducing direct response advertising next year. "We've got to keep a high profile through advertising," says Elbourne. "We've got to say there won't always be a man at the door but we will always be there to help customers."

The Pru is boosting its direct marketing campaigns and improving its databases to target customers by lifestyle. And it is the lifestyle of the "mass affluent" that is causing excitement. The financial giants are transferring their affections to customers who can offer higher margins.

Elbourne is adamant the Pru will continue to service lower value customers, through initiatives such as workplace marketing. But wealthy customers will benefit from an elite squad of 250 direct salesmen.

Britannic is doing the same. "Our strategy allows customers to buy in their workplace, through partners such as Spicer Haart Estate Agents, the Britannia Building Society, over the telephone, by post or over the internet. Or in their homes, as we are retaining a small specialist salesforce," says head of marketing David Newman. He believes the brand's products and services are important, not how they are distributed. "We can serve our customers optimally by contacting them on their terms, not just face to face in their homes."

Meanwhile, J Rothschild Assurance has renamed itself St James Place and put 1,000 direct salesmen on the road to target wealthy customers. Lucian Camp, chairman of CCHM, the direct marketing agency for St James Place, Barclays, Axa and Zurich Financial Services, says a "relationship" with a customer is now about cross-selling. "The man from the Pru didn't want to flog ISAs, he genuinely maintained a kind of customer relationship that is now finished, except for the rich."

Internet banks, such as Prudential's Egg and the Co-op's Smile, have built new financial brands without any face-to-face customer contact. But it didn't stop Smile launching its brand based entirely on a warm, friendly personality and Egg presenting itself as a cuddly partner in the "k-i-s-s-i-n-g in a tree" ads. Nigel Long, chief executive of Partners BDDH, the ad agency which launched Smile, says: "We tried to give a mood and spirit to the bank, not just a set of facts and products."

It is straight out of the Orange book of brand building. The mobile phone brand's sunny personality and scant regard for boring details revolutionised marketing. But established financial service providers, saddled with decades of tradition, will have to struggle to maintain the human touch.

webTitle: All clubbed out: The Groucho Club, is up for grabs. Owner and founder Tony Mackintosh tells why he's selling.

fields.headline: All clubbed out
fields.standfirst: London's classic hangout for media folk is up for grabs, but is it too late to recapture lost glory now its rivals are drawing in the younger crowd? Owner and founder Tony Mackintosh tells why he's selling, while  Matt Wells  and  Maggie Brown  get their application forms ready
fields.trailText: London's classic hangout for media folk is up for grabs, but is it too late to recapture lost glory now its rivals are drawing in the younger crowd? Owner and founder Tony Mackintosh tells why he's selling, while Matt Wells and Maggie Brown get their application forms ready.
fields.body:
Elites are never smashed, only replaced. The Groucho Club, formed to break the cosy establishment coterie of St James, appears in no mood to have its own hard-won position challenged by a vulgar upstart.

Benjamin Fry, whose detractors like to paint him as a fully paid-up member of the Fulham Sloane set, had Groucho members clutching their gins in fear with a well-timed bid to take over the dusty Soho drinking den. Just as the place looked as if it could do with a fresh pair of hands on the optics, along came the old Etonian with a plan to open a chain of Groucho hotels from here to Los Angeles.

It was as if the fires of hell were about to descend upon Dean Street. Dick Bradsell, London's foremost cocktail mixologist and a long-term Groucho member, spoke for all when the first Fry bid was filed last year: "Benji Fry is the kind of person who would make an excellent dinner for Groucho members. I hate him already."

Just as well, then, that the Groucho should be saved from this ignominy by one of the leading members of the new elite: PR guru and socialite Matthew Freud. As soon as Fry's interest became apparent last year, he put himself forward as a white knight. Nine months of negotiations have just been completed, and a £12m offer is being finalised. It will almost certainly be recommended by the Groucho board, and is equally certain to be accepted. The Groucho shareholders - the 350 publishers, writers and assorted glitterati who wrote out cheques to Tony Mackintosh for £1,500 or so in 1984 - are a loyal bunch. If Tony says sell to Matthew, the chances are they probably will.

"It's not even Coke versus Pepsi, it's Coke versus a Soda Stream," says one Freud-supporting source with knowledge of the deal.

Normally, such a catfight over a faintly tatty members' club would barely merit a couple of paragraphs in a society journal, far less national newspaper interest. Yet it is the Groucho members' list that excites: 3,984 of the hottest names in the media, music and the arts. From Nigella Lawson to Lord Archer via Julie Burchill and Keith Allen, since 1984 the Groucho has catered for the irrepressible desire of media folk to mingle, flirt, gossip, deal, booze, and (sometimes) eat. It usurped the grubby Fleet Street pubs that used to provide after-hours shelter to hacks - and made a chattering class feel a bit more exclusive than it really deserves.

"Our whole basis was to try and develop a place that was open, equal to men and women, and that had no family or corporate membership, somewhere where members would be treated as individuals," says Mackintosh, who is now 63. "It was for people working in the media - that we were to offer the same facilities and courtesies that you got from traditional clubs but in a contemporary setting in terms of rules, services, atmosphere and design, and that is what we have tried to do over the past 16 years."

But the membership list remained exclusive: many applications are unsuccessful. Those who are accepted must wait months before they can take up the membership benefits: it would not do to overcrowd the place. The name, of course, comes from Groucho Marx's line: "I don't care to belong to any club that would accept me as a member."

The current Groucho crowd is wary that a bottom line-obsessed new breed would ruin the magic. But Fry says that the Groucho management are stuck in the past, and warns that it will head straight for the bankruptcy courts if it continues to be managed in the way it is. He wants to merge the Groucho into his Zoo hotel group, which has sent the Groucho set apoplectic.

Hence the interest in the Freud deal, which teams the PR man with Joel Cadbury, a bar and restaurant entrepreneur from the chocolate dynasty, and Rupert Hambro, who hails from the City merchant banking family. Their approach will not set the Groucho members' teeth on edge. Little has been said so far of the Freud plans, but Media Guardian understands that they are based on a cautious extension of the Groucho brand - and certainly no major changes to the club itself. "They've got no intention of turning the Groucho into Virgin," says one club member who knows of Freud's plans.

It is likely that the Freud management would seek to emulate the success of its younger rival Soho House, which under founder Nick Jones has also launched a country offshoot, Babington House. It is also possible that Groucho products - such as the highly regarded house wine - could be made more widely available to non-members (but only in certain hand-picked restaurants, or perhaps by order, of course).

While the Groucho lot liked to paint themselves as anti-establish ment, they are a pretty conservative bunch at heart, and the Freud deal is far more attractive. It helps that Freud is a member; and it helps even more that his bid is in cash. (Fry is offering to swap one Groucho share for two or three Zoo shares.)

For the moment, Mackintosh is careful not to prejudice the due diligence process (the Groucho is listed on the Ofex small business stock exchange), but it is clear where his preferance lies. "One offer has got paper with the Queen's head on it; the other has Zoo Hotel's logo on it." But one thing is certain: the Groucho will be sold. While Mackintosh insists there is still "fire in his belly", he acknowledges it is time to give someone younger a go.

Mackintosh is revered among the membership, but many would agree with him. Times have changed: as with all successful ventures, it has spawned imitators that have overtaken it. Venues such as Soho House and Black's, both within vomiting distance of the Groucho, have attracted a younger and trendier crowd, and cater better to their changing tastes.

Soho House, in particular, has succeeded in getting the e-kids though the door in a way that the Groucho never attempted. The Groucho - where Private Eye founder Richard Ingrams famously courted the waitress and his now live-in companion Deborah Bosely - has its feet and heart firmly in the 1980s.

The two clubs' members are two tribes, divided largely (though not exclusively) by age and media speciality. The Groucho set tends to be drawn from journalism, publishing and television; and consists of established, if not establishment figures. They include Simon Kelner, editor of the Independent, Nick Clarke, presenter of The World at One ("I only go there for lunch, and not that often."). This is where Angus Deayton and Nigella Lawson recently held a joint 40th birthday party. It is where Sarah Helm, accompanied by her partner Jonathan Powell, the prime minister's chief of staff, chooses to dine. And it is where the founders of Women in Journalism go for their annual lunch. Soho House is younger in spirit and appeals to the newer advertising, film and internet set.

The divide is neatly illustrated by two contrasting launches. Lord Bragg, old school, introduced the latest series of the South Bank Show last autumn in a rather cramped room at the Groucho; last week, David Liddiment, ITV's director of programmes and most certainly a "new ITV" man, showed off a historical documentary series, Time of our Lives, at Soho House's private cinema.

David Docherty, head of broadband content at Flextech/Telewest, launched his novel at Soho House last year, as Alan Yentob and Jane Root looked on. But Dianne Thompson, chief executive of Camelot, opted for Groucho's for a packed farewell party last month for Louise White, the outgoing director of communications. Camelot chairman Sir George Russell felt far more at home in the louche glamour of the Groucho than the rather less subtle stylishness of Soho House.

"I prefer the Groucho Club but that's an age thing partly," says Victor Sebestyen, an Evening Standard writer who belongs to both.

Anne Spackman, now a property writer for The Financial Times, and Guardian journalist Charles Burgess held a huge wedding reception at the Groucho in September 1987, when it was still young. Many journalist guests had to be given instructions on how to find the club.

"We could hire the whole place for £500, because, believe it or not, it didn't open then on Saturdays," Spackman says. "We had dancing in the back room downstairs, now the dining room, and another room where children could just grind their crisps into the carpet. It just seemed more appropriate to be there than a City livery company. Whenever I occasionally go there now, it seems very much smarter."

There is a sense, however, that the Groucho has somehow lost its way. Philip Kerr, novelist and screenwriter, says: "It is so changed from the 1990s, when it seemed full of fun people, lots of hacks you knew. I find it a ghost of its former self."

Freud intends gently to reinvigorate the Groucho. But as the club crowd grows old, he may find a new danger: that the whole members' club scene is on the wane. One 30-year-old new media professional has shunned both. "Soho House is too camp, young and attitude-ridden. The Groucho is dusty enough to have some more interesting characters. But I have actively chosen not to be a member of either. Why would I want to buy into a mass-market 'elitist club', full of precisely the kind of people who you would join a club to avoid? There are many better places to go when you have friends, rather than places to go to try and make contacts. They are just media dating agencies."

Anne Spackman, now a property writer for The Financial Times, and Guardian journalist Charles Burgess held a huge wedding reception at the Groucho in September 1987, when it was still young. Many journalist guests had to be given instructions on how to find the club. "We could hire the whole place for £500, because, believe it or not, it didn't open then on Saturdays," Spackman says. "We had dancing in the back room downstairs, now the dining room, and another room where children could just grind their crisps into the carpet. It just seemed more appropriate to be there than a City livery company. Whenever I occasionally go there now, it seems very much smarter." There is a sense, however, that the Groucho has somehow lost its way. Philip Kerr, novelist and screenwriter, says: "It is so changed from the 1990s, when it seemed full of fun people, lots of hacks you knew. I find it a ghost of its former self." Freud intends gently to reinvigorate the Groucho. But as the club crowd grows old, he may find a new danger: that the whole members' club scene is on the wane. One 30-year-old new media professional has shunned both. "Soho House is too camp, young and attitude-ridden. The Groucho is dusty enough to have some more interesting characters. But I have actively chosen not to be a member of either. Why would I want to buy into a mass-market 'elitist club', full of precisely the kind of people who you would join a club to avoid? There are many better places to go when you have friends, rather than places to go to try and make contacts. They are just media dating agencies." webTitle: Interview with Rachel Newsome, the new editor of Dazed & Confused.

fields.headline: Confused? You won't be
fields.standfirst: Rachel Newsome, the new editor of Dazed & Confused, has dedicated her first issue, out this week, to rebellion. And she plans to use this former style bible as a platform to change society's values, she tells  Sean Dodson
fields.trailText: Rachel Newsome, the new editor of Dazed & Confused, has dedicated her first issue, out this week, to rebellion. And she plans to use this former style bible as a platform to change society's values, she tells Sean Dodson.
fields.body:
Rachel Newsome is sitting in a quiet pub in east London, sipping cappuccino and insisting that she is no rebel. The 28-year-old bottle-blonde who won the Guardian's Student Media Award and then dropped out of journalism school after one term has just been appointed editor of the glossy style bible, Dazed & Confused. She's no rebel, she says, because, frankly, no one knows what the word means anymore.

Newsome's first issue in charge -out this Thursday - will focus on the nature of youth rebellion. Tagged "Rebellion is dead: long live rebellion," the April edition is, she says, no less than a call-to-arms to British teenagers. It's time to wise up, stop taking so many drugs, work out what you believe in and get political.

Born in Teesside, but raised in south Manchester, Newsome describes herself as a "posh northerner". She cut her teeth at Sheffield University, editing the student paper's first women's section, for which she won the Guardian award. After a "disastrous" term on the University of Cardiff's postgraduate diploma course, Newsome returned to Manchester, where she worked for Jockey Slut and Muzik magazines. It was three and a half years ago when she joined Dazed & Confused and, after a lengthy period as deputy, she finally inherited the editor's chair last month.

Dazed & Confused was established in 1991 by Rankin Waddell, Jefferson Hack and Ian Taylor, who were all then still studying at the London College of Printing. Initially the magazine was free, and operated an open-access policy with contributors often working for nothing. It quickly gained a reputation as an irreverent title with visual flair that refused to pander to what Hack calls the "empty egos of the rich and famous". Today, Dazed sells 48,000 copies in the UK and 18,000 overseas.

Next month's Rebellion edition is "very much a manifesto for where I want to take the direction of the magazine," says Newsome. "It's about understanding that our world is saturated with this idea of lifestyle culture, but at the same time asking: 'If all that is important is the good life, then where do we work out our values, where do we work out what we believe in?'"

The Rebellion edition is the first in a series of themed issues that Newsome claims will help to establish the magazine's own agenda. This, she hopes, will lead to "a way of us turning the whole marketing system around. So instead of waiting to see who has got a record or film coming out, it is about us exploring things that we are interested in. We don't want to just reflect back the latest pop phenomenon."

This, she says, is not being addressed by any of her rivals. Their old agenda of trend-spotting is becoming increasingly redundant, she says. "There is no such thing as an underground anymore, because corporate culture has infiltrated and co-opted youth culture."

Last month a report by the European School Survey Project claimed that British teenagers are more likely than their continental counterparts to take drugs, drink alcohol or smoke. For Newsome, this means that drug-taking - once perceived as a radical gesture - has become nothing more than consumer conformity. Thursday's issue simply wants to ask, where does British youth go from here?

"We are living in an economic boom time," says Newsome. "People have more money than ever before, we spend more on going out, more on drinking, more on all sorts of illegal things. But we're reaching a point where that's coming apart. At the same time, there are deeper cultural trends in terms of rising numbers of depression cases, and reports coming out detailing escalating numbers of male suicides at university."

Newsome's mantra seems to be that you can't look at culture without looking at society. Her plan is to develop the social consciousness of the magazine, to the point where the writing in Dazed wins as many plaudits as its photography. Newsome is coy when asked for specific details, saying only that investigative and social reportage are high on the agenda.

"I think we've reached saturation point, where the party's almost over. Our generation have got what we wanted. There are more opportunities for young people to set up their own label or start their own club. People travel more than ever before, but I think people are still looking for something to believe in."

Youth culture is no longer underground, she says. "It's not an elite thing, it's penetrated our whole society. But there is also a reemergence of interest in having a global vision, especially through the anti-capitalism movement. Now it's a question of what we do next? Do we just carry on partying with our eyes closed or do we use our clout to enforce change?"

Last year Dazed instigated a campaign with Jubilee 2000 - the pressure group calling for an end to third world debt. The collaboration was syndicated to 17 magazines throughout the world, including Colors, Nylon and Papers in New York.

"The whole landscape of style magazines has changed since the Face and I-D started 20 years ago," explains Newsome. "Then, nobody else understood the relationship between street fashion, style and music. Whereas now, every Sunday supplement has its own style section, you can read music reviews in the Guardian and get club listings in the Evening Standard and the Sun. So what are we getting from style magazines that we cannot get elsewhere?"

But if tabloid newspapers are wearing the style mags' clothes where does that leave a magazine like Dazed & Confused?

"It's really interesting if you look at the amount of column space given to Eminem by well-respected, broadsheet columnists," she says. "But they completely misunderstand Eminem and the culture he is coming from and what he represents. It's embarrassing, misinformed and not saying anything that is relevant."

The new issue also features an article about straight edges - the no-drugs, no-alcohol punk scene that is gaining a small but significant foothold among Britain's youth. "Although they are very small, that's the extreme that will eventually filter down into people's attitudes," she says.

Beyond that Dazed will this autumn launch two new titles. The first is a car magazine, Refuel, that will "look at car culture in the way that Wallpaper looks at interiors". The car mag will be followed by the launch of a stand-alone fashion magazine.

But for now there is the new direction to worry about. Although it is significant that a magazine such as Dazed & Confused is even questioning the nature of rebellion, Newsome insists that Dazed isn't about to denounce the level of decadence we've seen in the past 20 years. For her, hedonism and ideology can co-exist. It's a question of balance, she says.

webTitle: Bad times catch up with TV team

fields.headline: Bad times catch up with TV team
fields.standfirst:
MediaGuardian.co.uk
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: TV show Time Team has fallen prey to foot and mouth as it was unable to film on sites it planned to excavate, write Tania Branigan and Martin Wainwright.
fields.body:
Their stock-in-trade is ancient history, but yesterday archaeologists fell prey to the very modern problem of foot and mouth restrictions as the television show Time Team learned it was unable to film on most of the sites it planned to excavate for the next season.

Producers of the Channel 4 show have been banned from 10 out of 13 locations, including a dairy farm in Hampshire where they hoped to begin filming on Friday.

They have turned instead to urban sites - including what may be the remains of London's oldest bridge, near Vauxhall, south London - but fear they may soon run out of possibilities.

Serious academic work has also been affected, with virtually all field work ceasing as dozens of locations are deemed out of bounds to archaeologists.

The outbreak has claimed several unlikely victims. In Cornwall, the owners of the £80m Eden Project warned that the opening of the giant hothouses might be postponed from Saturday due to fears the mass movement of people could spread disease.

Deborah Clark, spokeswoman for the attraction, said: "If Eden doesn't open ... it would signal that Cornwall has shut down and would be a massive body blow for tourism in the south-west."

So far only the disease has produced only one victor: East Yorkshire farmer Stephen Crawford, who is certain to win what will be literally a one-horse race this week.

The four-mile Kiplingcotes Derby is England's oldest race, an amateurs' gallop on the Yorkshire Wolds every March since 1519. But this year, the usual scores of entrants and spectators have been banned and it will be held only in stylised form to keep its place in the record books.

"The foot and mouth crisis is serious and no one wants to trivialise it, but this race has been going for such a long time," said Mr Crawford, 50, the nearest farmer with horses to the course.

"Hopefully in 200 years' time foot and mouth will be forgotten, but this race will still be run."

fields.headline: 'Man from the Pru' shown the door
fields.trailText: 8.30am: The Prudential is to revamp its image and marketing strategy, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The Prudential is to revamp its image and marketing strategy in the aftermath of axing its 2,000-strong direct sales force.

The insurance firm decided last month to ditch its famously bowler-hatted 'Man from the Pru' doorstep sales force in favour of communicating with its customers via the telephone and internet.

A squad of 250 financial planning experts will make home visits, but only to wealthy customers with complex financial needs rather than the traditional pensions and insurance business conducted through home visits.

John Elbourne, chief executive of Prudential UK operations, said the company's logo would also be updated.

"We will freshen up the logo to make it appropriate to today's environment. The Man from the Pru is no longer an appropriate strapline," he said.

Mr Elbourne said a new direct response advertising campaign would be launched next year incorporating product promotion and new branding.

The Pru also intends to step up its direct marketing campaign in order to remain in close contact with its customers.

Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and Duckworth Finn Grubb Waters handle the Prudential Assurance company's creative advertising accounts while WWAV Rapp Collins and Tri-Direct handle direct marketing and New PHD the media account.

webTitle: Cainer may sue Express over copy changes

fields.headline: Cainer may sue Express over copy changes
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Britain's highest-paid astrologer Jonathan Cainer may sue the Express after changes to his last horoscope threatened to leave him out of pocket, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Jonathan Cainer, Britain's highest-paid astrologer, is considering legal action against the Express as eleventh-hour changes to his last horoscope threatened to leave him out of pocket.

The astrologer was livid when the Express edited out references to his phone lines and his website in the last ever page he wrote for last Saturday's paper, before leaving to join the Mirror.

"I'm considering suing in the way that a cross person does after something like this," said Mr Cainer.

"My moon in Scorpio tells me that revenge is a dish best served cold," he told MediaGuardian.co.uk.

"I bent over backwards to be nice and make sure I left the paper on a good note. I wrote a little piece saying 'my replacement's wonderful and the Express is a good paper' and I left a phone number where I could be contacted."

But he claims the number was edited out by Express bosses who feared Mr Cainer would take too many readers with him to the Mirror.

Mr Cainer had a contract with the Express which allowed him to publicise his lucrative phone lines which allowed him to take a cut of all calls made.

And he claims that the last-minute action by the paper is a breach of contract.

Asked why the changes were made, Mr Cainer said: "I'll lay money on it not being from Chris Williams. He's a lovely bloke and a competent editor and I can't imagine he would have undergone the personality transfer necessary to have done something so nasty."

Mr Cainer said he suspected the move had been ordered by the paper's overall boss, Richard Desmond, who last year purchased the Express, the Express on Sunday and the Daily Star.

Mr Cainer has already been in legal wrangles with the Daily Mail, where he worked before he was poached by the former Express editor Rosie Boycott.

Earlier this year Mr Cainer defected once again to the Mirror.

The Express said it had "no comment" on the matter.

fields.headline: Miles Calcraft picks up £7m P&O account
fields.trailText: 8.30am: P&O Cruises has awarded its £7m advertising account to Miles Calcraft Briginshaw Duffy, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
P&O Cruises has awarded its £7m advertising account to Miles Calcraft Briginshaw Duffy after a pitch against rival agencies Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO and Publicis.

The appointment marks the first time the founders of Miles Calcraft, the agency formed in 1999 by a breakaway group of AMV directors, have won a pitch against their former employer.

AMV is the UK's biggest agency.

Miles Calcraft is one of the UK's most successful start-ups of recent years, picking up £28m-worth of business since it launched. Its clients include UDV, BT and Dyson.

P&O put its £7m advertising account up for pitch earlier this year after the incumbent advertising agency, Leo Burnett, resigned the account after only eight months.

Leo Burnett cited a conflict with its Walt Disney client, which also offers holiday cruises.

fields.headline: Kirch's World Cup auction in jeopardy
fields.trailText:
8.30am: The German media group's plans to auction off World Cup rights are in chaos as potential bidders boycott the process. By Dan Milmo.

Mar 7: Kirch heads for World Cup talks.

Mar 6: Leo Kirch profile

Mar 5: BBC slams Kirch over World Cup
fields.body:
German media group Kirch's plans to auction off the World Cup broadcasting rights are in chaos as potential bidders boycott the process.

Kirch has sparked fury in the UK over plans to sell the franchise for the 2002 tournament to the highest bidder, which could see the BBC and ITV lose out to a pay-TV predator.

But sources close to pay-TV companies including BSkyB, ONdigital and U>Direct said they would not break UK broadcasting laws.

The rules, which are hotly disputed by Kirch, state that free-to-air broadcasters must have access to the entire World Cup.

"If the tournament has to go to a free-to-air broadcaster then it is not worth a pay-TV service bidding for it. I would be surprised if we get involved," said one source.

Another source said that taking part in an auction was out of the question.

"It would be illegal for Kirch to sell the rights to us, so the matter of an auction does not arise," said the source.

Kirch put its case for an auction to officials at the department of culture, media and sports last week, but it is increasingly likely the German group will have to resume stalled negotiations with the BBC and ITV.

The group threw out the consortium's bid of around £40m several weeks ago and told BBC and ITV representatives it would start an auction, but sources close to the UK broadcasters say nothing has happened since.

"We are still awaiting information from Kirch about their planned auction of the rights," said one source.

BBC and ITV insiders hope Kirch will be forced into a compromise similar to the one it reached with German public broadcasters last week, who paid an undisclosed sum for the rights following the intervention of chancellor Gerhard Schroeder.

Although Kirch has lodged a complaint with the European Court of Justice over the UK broadcasting laws, its plans for an auction are likely to buckle under government pressure and a pay-TV boycott.

Mar 5: BBC slams Kirch over World Cup
fields.bodyText: German media group Kirch's plans to auction off the World Cup broadcasting rights are in chaos as potential bidders boycott the process. Kirch has sparked fury in the UK over plans to sell the franchise for the 2002 tournament to the highest bidder, which could see the BBC and ITV lose out to a pay-TV predator. But sources close to pay-TV companies including BSkyB, ONdigital and U>Direct said they would not break UK broadcasting laws. The rules, which are hotly disputed by Kirch, state that free-to-air broadcasters must have access to the entire World Cup. "If the tournament has to go to a free-to-air broadcaster then it is not worth a pay-TV service bidding for it. I would be surprised if we get involved," said one source. Another source said that taking part in an auction was out of the question. "It would be illegal for Kirch to sell the rights to us, so the matter of an auction does not arise," said the source. Kirch put its case for an auction to officials at the department of culture, media and sports last week, but it is increasingly likely the German group will have to resume stalled negotiations with the BBC and ITV. The group threw out the consortium's bid of around £40m several weeks ago and told BBC and ITV representatives it would start an auction, but sources close to the UK broadcasters say nothing has happened since. "We are still awaiting information from Kirch about their planned auction of the rights," said one source. BBC and ITV insiders hope Kirch will be forced into a compromise similar to the one it reached with German public broadcasters last week, who paid an undisclosed sum for the rights following the intervention of chancellor Gerhard Schroeder. Although Kirch has lodged a complaint with the European Court of Justice over the UK broadcasting laws, its plans for an auction are likely to buckle under government pressure and a pay-TV boycott. fields.headline: Media Monkey's Diary
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's budget may have largely met with an ecstatic reception in the press. But one corner of Fleet Street was less delighted when it managed to crash the Telegraph's entire computer system. So many people were checking the newswires that the poor old ancient Atex (rumoured to be powered by a cageful of scampering hamsters) couldn't cope and packed up for half an hour just short of deadline on Wednesday. Gordon's dulcet tones were drowned out, apparently, by the sound of systems management pleading over the PA system for everyone to stop using their computers immediately. Time to join the 21st century, guys.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's budget may have largely met with an ecstatic reception in the press. But one corner of Fleet Street was less delighted when it managed to crash the Telegraph's entire computer system. So many people were checking the newswires that the poor old ancient Atex (rumoured to be powered by a cageful of scampering hamsters) couldn't cope and packed up for half an hour just short of deadline on Wednesday. Gordon's dulcet tones were drowned out, apparently, by the sound of systems management pleading over the PA system for everyone to stop using their computers immediately. Time to join the 21st century, guys.

 Monkey hears that in the new spirit of One BBC, all the walls have been ripped down at BBC Sport to make it more open plan. Except for one individual. A little office has been carved out of the vast new space for Olympics ubermeister Martin Hopkins OBE who is being given his own special space beneath an air conditioning duct on account of his penchant for cigarettes. Monkey is dismayed by this unsporting ethos.

 Our PR correspondent writes: "While delighted to support Anthea Turner's decision to enter the celebrity Big Brother house in the name of charity, I can't help thinking that her official quote on the press release ('Richard Curtis bribed me with Hobnobs') is unfortunate. Wasn't it just that kind of chocolate product endorsement that led to trouble last time?" Good point.

 One of Monkey's favourite aspects of broadcasting has always been the appreciation index - a score given to a programme revealing how much the audience actually enjoyed it and frequently employed by broadcasters to justify high-budget flops ("yes, but the three viewers really, really loved it"). But sadly, ITV wants to abandon the AI, which costs it £1m a year. Clearly it no longer matters whether the viewers like the show, as long as they damn-well watch it.

 Monkey's favourite read, the BBC staff magazine Ariel, runs a telling letter in its current issue. "Greg Dyke's dream of putting money into programme making and cutting a swathe through middle management is simply not happening", says one Sue Ward. She has analysed the previous issue's job ads: "There are a grand total of six vacancies advertised in programme-making areas, whereas there are 27 in business and support management." To paraphrase the great man: it's the corporate centre, stupid.

 It seems that OK!TV's hopes of a return to ITV have been dashed. Instead the network, which tried to go solo with a Desmond-free, five nights a week version called Celebrity! is having another go. It is now planning a once a week celeb show because, apparently, there just aren't enough stars to fill up a nightly half hour. In the spirit of friendship, Monkey is willing to open up for an "at home" feature. But just this once.

fields.headline: £1m record contract for schoolgirl, 14
fields.trailText: An unknown schoolgirl aged 14, from south London, has signed a two-year, four-album record contract reportedly worth more than £1m.
fields.body:
An unknown schoolgirl aged 14, from south London, has signed a two-year, four-album record contract reportedly worth more than £1m.

Rhythm and blues singer Lisa Roxanne Naraine is backed by Chris Blackwell, the legendary producer credited with discovering Bob Marley in Jamaica.

"She has the potential to become a global success," Mr Blackwell told the Sunday Telegraph yesterday, while announcing Lisa's deal with his New York-based Palm Pictures label, under which she will release a debut single, No Flow, in May, and later an album, Diary of my Dreams. A record company spokesman refused to disclose the exact amount involved, but called it "a seven-figure sum".

Lisa's mother, Tricia, a former singer with the soul group Loose Ends, said: "It took her a long time to convince me that she had the stamina necessary to succeed."

The singer insisted that she was staying focused on schoolwork although that may prove harder to manage when she flies to Miami this month to shoot a video for her single.

"I'm usually up by 6am doing my schoolwork, and after school I'm in rehearsals," she told the paper. "I am determined, energetic and really into it. Everyone's being very supportive."

webTitle: 'Wide' verbal abuse of the mentally ill

fields.headline: 'Wide' verbal abuse of the mentally ill
fields.trailText: Most young people admit to hurling terms such as "loony" or "nutter" at people they think may have a mental health problem, according to government research published today.
fields.body:
Most young people admit to hurling terms such as "loony" or "nutter" at people they think may have a mental health problem, according to government research published today.

While two thirds of the 16 to 24-year-olds considered it wrong to use racist language, only one third thought it was unacceptable to call people "schizo" or "psycho", a poll by Opinion Leader Research showed.

The findings were published as the government launched a £1m campaign to challenge the stigma and discrimination suffered by people with mental health problems.

The poll findings were based on telephone interviews with a national representative sample of 500 young people. Some 80% thought that having a mental health problem would lead to discrimination and 55% would not want anyone else to know if they had a mental health problem.

When asked which words they had used to describe someone with a mental health problem, 61% said "nutter, psycho, schizo, loon", 51% said "mental", and 44% said "mad".

The government's "mind out for mental health" campaign is supported by the National Union of Students. Rachel Cashman, its vice-president for welfare, said: "The prevalence and severity of mental illness in students is increasing."

Paul Farmer, director of public affairs for the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "It's the fear of discrimination that perpetuates the stigma of having a mental health problem."

fields.headline: ITV slump worse than expected
fields.trailText: 6.30pm: ITV is staring into an advertising abyss after analysts effectively wrote off its chances of recovering from a slump in the market this year, writes Dan Milmo .
fields.body:
ITV is staring into an advertising abyss after analysts effectively wrote off its chances of recovering from a slump in the market this year.

Neil Blackley, the influential media analyst at Merrill Lynch who first highlighted the weakness of ITV advertising revenues last year, today said the advertising downturn "is far worse than expected."

The Merrill team estimated in a note that advertising revenues for May and June could fall by 13% and 16% respectively, which would make a recovery impossible in the second half of the year.

Even if revenues pick up in between July and December, advertising is expected to fall by 1% compared to last year.

It is bad news for ITV giants Granada and Carlton Communications, which have been hit by the collapsing advertising spend of dotcom start-ups and the fall in meat advertising due to the foot nad mouth crisis.

The Merrill team added that "it is now inevitable that ITV will go on satellite before the end of the year."

Granada and Carlton's shares were barely affected by the news, as it has been widely predicted that the ITV advertising recession would last all year.

webTitle: Mexico's masked man strides into the capital

fields.headline: Mexico's masked man strides into the capital
fields.standfirst: A seven year fight
fields.trailText:
The unimaginable happened. The Zapatistas, led by
their masked commandantes and their enigmatic
leader, Subcommandante Marcos, finally entered the
heart of the capital of the nation with which they have
been at war for seven years.
fields.byline: Duncan Campbell and Jo Tuckman in Mexico City
fields.body:
The unimaginable happened. The Zapatistas, led by their masked commandantes and their enigmatic leader, Subcommandante Marcos, finally entered the heart of the capital of the nation with which they have been at war for seven years.

Their entrance was remarkable in that these rebels not only came unarmed but also with a welcome from the president of the country that made them outlaws.

"We came here only to say we are here," Subcommandante Marcos told an enraptured crowd of 150,000 in the Zocalo, the main square of the capital. "We are a reflection and a cry and we will always be there. We can be with or without a face, armed or without fire. But we are Zapatistas as we will always be."

He had arrived with the 23 Zapatista commandantes on the back of an open lorry bearing the slogan "Never again a Mexico without us". Helicopters circled over as the caravan finally reached the end of its historic journey.

In an appeal to all of Mexico for a fairer society, he called on "indigenous brothers and sisters, workers, peasants, teachers, students, farmworkers, housewives, drivers, fishermen, taxi-drivers, office workers, street vendors, gangs, the unemployed, journalists, professionals, nuns and monks, homosexuals, lesbians, transsexuals, artists, intellectuals, sailors,soldiers, athletes and legislators, men, women, children, young people and old, brothers and sisters", all to join with them.

But despite the enormous turnout and the success of the long march, the mood was not triumphalist in recognition, perhaps, of the uncertainty that lies ahead.

Before Marcos spoke, other commandantes made brief appeals for greater respect for indigenous people. Commandante Tacho told the crowd: "We are Mexicans, too, so we say the homeland is ours as well," signing off as he spoke in the name of the "Zapatista high command". Each read their speeches, as they have done throughout the march, from spiral notebooks and then took their places back in the line as Marcos directed proceedings.

The Mexican press was in no doubt as to the significance of the day. "Marcos takes the capital!" said one paper. "They're taking the plaza!" said another. La Prensa summed up the mood with the word "unimaginable".

At dawn, the caravan of the Zapatistas and their supporters was already breakfasting on tamales in a sports complex on the outskirts of Mexico City where they had been billeted for the last night of their 16-day pilgrimage from Chiapas.

They had come in pursuit of constitutional rights for the country's 10m indigenous people, around 10% of the population, and yesterday was the culmination of the journey that had taken them through 12 states. As the 2,100-mile, 16-day trek from Chiapas ended, they were joined by public figures from around the world: human rights ambassador Danielle Mitterand, Portuguese Nobel prizewinning author Jose Saramago, and the French anti-multinational activist Jose Bove.

The Zocalo, the largest city square in the world after Red Square, greeted them, but the only sights trained from the rooftops and behind the belfries were those of the photographers and camera crews from around the world and the only explosions were of firecrackers and rockets.

Triumph

It was in 1914 that Emiliano Zapata, the man who gave his name to the current movement, rode in revolutionary triumph into the same Zocalo. There had been rumours that the new Zapatistas would also gallop into the square on horseback but this, like many of the rumours that have shrouded the march and the Zapatistas, proved unfounded.

But yesterday Marcos and the Zapatistas did indeed stand below the balcony of the palace where Zapata and Pancho Villa had greeted their own adoring crowds nearly 90 years earlier. Throughout the morning the street vendors there were busily selling their Zapatista masks, T-shirts, mugs, jugs and recorded music, their Marcos scarves and action dolls complete with pipe and balaclava, mixed in with images of Che Guevara.

Watching the Zapatistas on their final push, Santos Orozco, 67, a canal boatman said: "They are the defenders of the poor, not just the indigenous." His views were reflected by many in the square.

The Zapatistas finally marched on the capital, disdaining an invitation issued over the weekend by President Vicente Fox to meet in the presidential palace.

Marcos accused Mr Fox of trivialising the indigenous cause. "He wants to turn a serious movement into a prime time event," said Marcos. "It would be a hollow media event."

The transformation of the Zapatistas from a tiny, ill-armed, barely trained guerrilla fighting force to what is effectively an international cultural movement was emphasised by the remarkable mixture of supporters flocking the streets, from the capital's smartly turned-out bourgeoisie to body-pierced and pink-haired punks carrying placards proclaiming the Zapatistas as their inspiration, and dungareed Italian anti-globalisers.

Even hours before the march was due to arrive, as bands played and Aztec dancers performed, the Zocalo was crowded and alive with excitement.

President Fox was not in the Zocalo. However he was generous in his welcome, which he hopes will bring him a major political gain with a peace accord. "Welcome subcommandante Marcos, welcome Zapatistas, welcome to the political arena," was his message. Not that Marcos is yet ready to take off his mask and his guerrilla uniform.

In a 20-minute address to the crowd and the nation beyond, Marcos referred to the way that the "first people" of Mexico had become the last in terms of how they had been treated. "We are the people of the colour of the earth. We ask you not to let another dawn break before that flag has a place for us, we who are the colour of the earth," he said in reference to the gigantic Mexican flag that was billowing from its pole in the centre of the Zocalo.

His speech referred by name to many of the dozens of Mexican indigenous peoples in a list more poetic than polemical. But he made it clear that the Zapatistas' presence was seeking a political response and they wanted "the democracy, freedom and justice" which they felt they had been denied for too long.

While opinion polls do show overwhelming support for the march, a peace accord and Mexico's need to act over trampled indigenous rights, not everyone is sympathetic to the Zapatistas. With the rebels already on the fringes of the capital the head of the country's biggest employers' organisation, Jorge Espina Reyes, called them "irresponsible utopian demagogues". But in the square yesterday the banners and the T-shirts proclaimed "We are all Marcos" and "You are not alone". For a moment at least, the Zapatistas who have made such an astonishing physical and metaphorical journey from Chiapas into the consciousness of the world must have felt it was true.

webTitle: John Sutherland: David Lodge's clever new novel

fields.headline: Just think of that
fields.standfirst: Is there a tiny bit of me in David Lodge's clever new novel? I think . . . not
fields.trailText: Is there a tiny bit of me in David Lodge's clever new novel? I think . . . not
fields.body:
I'm rooting for David Lodge's novel Thinks . . . to win the big prize. It shouldn't raise the author's hopes too much. The last novel I lobbied for didn't even get on the Booker shortlist. And I was a judge that year.

Lodge's latest comedy of campus manners revisits Malcolm Bradbury's 1975 novel The History Man. In that novel, liberalism, in the trim shape of a nice young lady from the English department at Watermouth University, is screwed (literally and metaphorically) by barbarism, in the shape of the reptilian sociologist Howard Kirk.

In Thinks . . . a novelist, Helen Reed, who embodies traditional literary values (and has rather a nice body), spends a term as visiting lecturer in the creative writing course at Gloucester University. There she falls victim to a sexual predator from the artificial intelligence department, Ralph Messenger.

Thinks . . . does clever things. Lodge plays wittily with the techniques of stream of consciousness. The narrative dips, innovatively, into the email-epistolary mode. There are Bremnerish pastiches of the literary greats. And, inevitably, the gloomy Catholic skull pokes through the novel's comic skin.

It's also a roman à clef, although Lodge is more cautious than Bradbury about the "any resemblance is coincidental" business. Watermouth was, transparently, the (then) new University of East Anglia. Gloucester University seems to be wholly fictional - although its creative writing course may owe something to that famous one at UEA (headed by Bradbury) where Lodge, like his heroine, spent a visiting term.

It was one of Bradbury's running jokes that Kirk either was or wasn't - as knowing people told each other - the country's best-known professor of sociology, Laurie Taylor. Taylor also got a lot of comic mileage out of the (mis)identification.

The same wannabe insiders will, of course, "know" who Messenger "is". I'd like to think there is a tiny bit of me in him. Before he came to Gloucester, he was 10 years at Caltech, the California Institute of Technology. I was there at the same time as Messenger - though I never met him (or his original). But I did once invite Lodge to the Pasadena campus. At Gloucester, Messenger habitually wears a Caltech sweatshirt. I think I'm only one of two professors in this country seen at work in that particular article of clothing. Can it be? I think . . . not.

Lodge's big idea is that the humane novelist and the scientific researcher into AI are both in the same business: exploring consciousness. But although Messenger and Reed can go to bed together, their disciplines can't. At the end of the day, the computer centre and the house of fiction are separate worlds. Forever.

Recent events confirm Lodge's techno-pessimism. After the crashing failure of his e-novel, The Plant, Stephen King - once literature's biggest booster for silicon - has returned, for his latest effort, "to the world's finest word processor, a Waterman cartridge fountain pen".

So is the computer doomed to be nothing more than a servo-mechanism for creative writing? Novelists will use laptops as a superior typewriter. Computerised presses will print the book. Amazon.com will dispatch it to you. But the ghost in the machine will always be human. Artificial intelligence? Yes. Artificial creativity? Never.

Jerome J McGann would disagree. He's a professor of literature at the University of Virginia and director of its institute of advanced technology in the humanities. McGann is currently teaching in London. For the past couple of years he and his collaborator, Johanna Drucker, have been proselytising for what they call The Ivanhoe Game.

The game "uses digital tools and digital space to think critically about received aesthetic works (like novels) and on the processes of critical reflection that one brings to such works". It aims to raise the computer from servo-mechanism to interpretative (or thinking) agent.

In that novel, liberalism, in the trim shape of a nice young lady from the English department at Watermouth University, is screwed (literally and metaphorically) by barbarism, in the shape of the reptilian sociologist Howard Kirk.
