webTitle: Peter Preston: Let's not get too caught up in US political life

fields.headline: American politics fascinate, but let's leave it at that
fields.standfirst: A superannuated lecher is now the queen mum of US political life
fields.trailText: In the fashion of the times, let us imagine a foreign country. Our leaders and would-be leaders journey to it constantly, seeking favours, electoral inspiration, marketing gambits and focus group wisdom.
fields.body:
In the fashion of the times, let us imagine a foreign country. Our leaders and would-be leaders journey to it constantly, seeking favours, electoral inspiration, marketing gambits and focus group wisdom. Meanwhile, its own experts in such disciplines are even now voyaging to these shores, ready to hone and shape responses. Welcome to Jimmy Carville et al. If you couldn't fix it for Al Gore, you'll sure fix it for Tony. But you still come from a foreign country.

British political reverence for the American way is a given, unquestioning, almost unremarked. When William Hague denounces the alien hordes, he excludes all true gum-chewers. (Indeed, having been in Philadelphia when George W was crowned, he's pathetically desperate to worship at the Washington court.) Gordon Brown perennially finds inspiration on Cape Cod vacations, a kind of honorary Kennedy. Mr B is the anxiously flexible friend of whoever inhabits the West Wing. Wham, bang, thank you for Son of Stars Wars, man.

From Millbank to Smith Square, the lessons of last autumn are read and reread. Why did Gore blow it? Why didn't he claim the Clinton boom as his own? You don't find the chancellor leaving gaps like that. Nor letting the case for public spending drift away. It's going to be November all over again: but this time the good guys and their pollsters (actually, the same pollsters) are going to win.

Time to call a natural break. Time to accentuate the positive difference, to talk processes and people. Time, by way of melodramatic illustration, to invoke Strom Thurmond.

You have to be pretty old to remember Thurmond's great charge for the presidency in 1948 and the four southern states his cornpole racism denied Harry S Truman. But then, Thurmond is pretty old. Still there, still stirring, and still - 49 interminable years after his election - a United States senator for South Carolina. Strom Thurmond is 98. If he makes it to the end of his last term in 2003, he'll be the queen mother of Capitol Hill: and a darned sight more dangerous. Why is Thurmond back in the headlines? Because he isn't dead yet, and because he soon may be.

In December, when there was no president-elect, only judges and lawyers arguing, the undead Strom might have moved into the White House himself. He is president pro tempore (basically the longest toothed senator around). He plays chair of the Senate when the vice-president's away. Constitutionally, sheer longevity puts him fourth in line to the presidency itself - and if the supreme court had continued sucking its thumb on inauguration day, he'd have been sworn in pro tempore, acting leader of the western world.

But in death, too, the importance of being (or not being) Strom remains. The Republicans, remember, hold the presidency plus majorities in the House of Representatives and, on the casting vote of Vice-President Dicky Ticker, the Senate. I have no hot line to the Almighty, but the senator is ailing at last. When George W looks at him, he can only take one day at a time: for any day, amid fast failing health, there might be no Thurmond - only a Democrat nominated in his stead by the Democrat governor of South Carolina. So much for the Bush majority. It hangs by the bizarre orange strands of hair matted across Thurmond's head.

Let's look at the man a little more closely. He fought for decades against giving blacks their civil rights, but when at last they had voting strength, he courted them. After he jumped party and joined the Republicans four decades ago, he masterminded the southern (overtly racist) strategy Nixon used to win in 1968. He believes in flogging and hanging (and wants more executions, not fewer). He was a cold warrior of the armed services committee and an injudicious pillager of pork barrels on the judiciary committee. He does not wear hearing aids, and thus hears nothing that is said around him. He is Jurassic Park 3.

His main claim to fame lies not in legislation initiated or majestic speeches delivered - rather, and quite openly, in beauty queens bedded. He married Miss South Carolina (22) when he was 69, and had four kids by her. He is a legendary lecher. "When he dies," Senator John Tower once said, "they'll have to beat his pecker down with a baseball bat to close the coffin lid."

Well, the moment self- evidently approaches. Trent Lott prepares not to be leader of the Senate any more; George Bush polishes persuasion skills as mortality mists his new administration. And it is vital to think of the difference.

The temptation is to think of Thurmond (like his baleful mate, Jesse Helms) as a relic rendered endearing by the weight of years, a gargoyle from history miraculously preserved. We've got Ted Heath; they've got Strom. Surely Thurmond is the weird exception, not the rule? Surely he has no part in the world which Tony and Gordon and George all share?

Thurmond's final election in 1996 came when Bob Dole ran for president. Dole was young enough to be Thurmond's son. Thurmond far out-paced Dole in South Carolina. He won 51% of women voters, 20% of black voters (as opposed to Dole's 10%) and 20% of those who said they were Democrats. No fluke. At 94, too crocked to campaign much, too tired for anything beyond televi sion commercials, he was still a force. His pork barrel was never empty.

If Strom Thurmond, on his record, ran in Austria, Brussels would frown. If he ran in Germany or Italy, the Daily Mail might be moved to wrath. He could not, on that record, run in Britain. He would be detritus on the 1948 beach.

Yet here he is and here we go (or he goes). It isn't just the American electoral system which is full of debilitating anomalies: the people that system produces, and sustains, can be anomalies, too. Anne Robinson lives? For Welsh, read Yanks? Not at all. It is an endlessly fascinating, endlessly dynamic country where politicians from far afield can see lives they recognise played out in the raw. But it isn't our country. Its history pulls in odd ways. (Anyone who is 98 is history). Its system, at state level, asks not: "What can I do for my country?" but "What can my country do for me?" Its dinosaurs never perish.

The people who will orchestrate this election - from Hague, pinching George W's schools' policy, to the heirs of Mandelson with their drawls and rasps - will ask us to believe that there is no difference, that (the Mail again) Jesse Helms should prescribe what defence policies we follow. It is, as I might say to Strom, pure tripe: but, even with a hearing aid on, he still wouldn't understand me.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Contestants in a bizarre Channel 5 endurance test, Touch a Truck, which started last night, are being tested for drugs to ensure they are not cheating.
fields.body:
TV contestants face drugs test

Contestants in a bizarre Channel 5 endurance test, Touch a Truck, which started last night, are being tested for drugs to ensure they are not cheating. The programme sees 20 contestants hanging on to a vehicle for as long as they can without nodding off and the winner collects the £33,800 vehicle.

Russian sub for Faslane party

Submarines from at least 12 foreign countries, including Russia and the United States, are to converge on the Faslane nuclear base on the Clyde for the Royal Navy's submarine centenary celebrations in May and June. British vessels will include at least one nuclear submarine.

Police keen on the job

When a women of 70 called in at Heavitree police station, Exeter, to see a detective about a family matter, she was given a typing test and interviewed for a job in the typing pool. Only when she asked when she could see a detective did they realise their mistake.

Women's income lagging

Women's income from employment, pensions, benefits and investments is just half that of men's, according to equal opportunities commission research. Average pay for a woman in a full-time job is around 82% of that paid to a man.

Five share jackpot

Five people shared the £6.7m national lottery jackpot, each receiving £1,345,576. The numbers were 2, 4, 12, 21, 36, 37. Bonus ball was 46. There was no Lottery Extra winner but two won the £250,000 Thunderball, matching 8, 16, 18, 26, 33. Thunderball was 10.

webTitle: No mod cons for pilots tackling the Kangaroo Route

fields.headline: No mod cons for pilots tackling the Kangaroo Route
fields.trailText: Even in a modern airliner it can be a lengthy, arduous and expensive journey. But for the motley assortment of vintage aircraft which left Biggin Hill airfield in Kent yesterday morning in a restaging of the historic London to Sydney air race, the route promised four weeks of flying, any number of stopovers and a marked lack of on-board creature comforts.
fields.body:
Even in a modern airliner it can be a lengthy, arduous and expensive journey. But for the motley assortment of vintage aircraft which left Biggin Hill airfield in Kent yesterday morning in a restaging of the historic London to Sydney air race, the route promised four weeks of flying, any number of stopovers and a marked lack of on-board creature comforts.

Covering everything from a HU-16 Albatross to modern Cessna jets, the fog which delayed the departure of the 36 crews looked set to be the least of their worries on a route which will take them across Europe to Corfu, through Crete, Cairo, Luxor and Singapore, before passing over Ayers Rock in the final stages.

The event - five years in the planning, and scheduled to coincide with the centenary of the Australian Federation - is only the fourth time the so-called "Kangaroo route" has been raced. The first time, in 1919, the winning aircraft was a Vickers Vimy piloted by Australians Sir Ross and Sir Keith Smith, who completed the route in 28 days to pocket the £10,000 prize. Another crew took nine more months to show up.

Race organisers revealed that a special trophy would be awarded in memory of two entrants who died on Tuesday en route to the starting-point. Gwen Bloomingdale, 58, a lawyer, and Barbara Gard, 52, a former US marine, both from Massachusetts, died when their Aero Commander plane crashed into the sea minutes after taking off from Keflavik airport in Iceland.

The oldest aircraft making the journey this year is a 1940s Piper J-3 Cub, formerly used by General George Patton as he led US troops across France in the second world war. Speaking shortly before departure yesterday, its solo pilot Maurice Kirk - the 55-year-old son of the UK's first flying vet - acknowledged the challenges he faced.

"It was not until I got to Biggin Hill that I fully realised how arduous this race will be," said Mr Kirk. "As far as I know, I am the only one flying solo [and] my plane will only fly at 75mph, and so if there is a head wind of 40mph I will just be crawling along."

There are five rest-days in the schedule, but, he said: "I'll have to fly on each of those to catch up. I expect I will be last across the line - some of the planes can fly three times faster than me."

Finishing first, though, is hardly the point. Entrants in the 1919 were required merely to complete the trip in 720 hours to qualify for the prize.

Unsurprisingly, the journey has not been without its terrifying moments. In a 1934 re-run of the race, a violent electrical storm forced the pilots of a KLM Douglas DC2 to make a night-time emergency landing on a racecourse near the Australian town of Albury, mere hours from the finishing-point. Local residents marked out a makeshift runway using their car headlights.

Race spokesman Leon D'Borg, who was joined at Biggin Hill yesterday by the Australian high commissioner, Michael L'Estrange, to see off the crews, did not rule out similarly hair-raising experiences this time around. "I think what has attracted people to the event is the great sense of adventure," said Mr D'Borg. "Many see this as a great opportunity. It is a unique air race, the longest in the world, and one that crosses very varied terrain: not easy, by any means."

fields.headline: Joe Chisholm
fields.standfirst: Jazz dancer and acrobat who combined speed with elegance
fields.trailText: The career of the American jazz dancer and acrobat, Joe Chisholm, who has died of cancer aged 75, began in 40s Harlem, took in many of the great swing bands, and flourished in Britain in the late 60s and 70s.
fields.body:
The career of the American jazz dancer and acrobat, Joe Chisholm, who has died of cancer aged 75, began in 40s Harlem, took in many of the great swing bands, and flourished in Britain in the late 60s and 70s. Chisholm could bring an audience to him through jokes, impossibly fast cane moves, and elegant tap dance, all used in rapid succession, and influenced by his experience with the Crackerjacks black acrobatic act during the second world war.

Hip hop's roots can be traced back to the likes of the Crackerjacks. They incorporated different strands of European and Arabic tumbling traditions into jazz dance, astonishing their original mentors and audiences when they toured Europe with their ability to always hit the beat while executing and completing somersaults.

Born in Brooklyn, the teenage Chisholm made weekly treks on the A-train to Harlem's Savoy Ballroom, where he imbibed the litany of swing through evenings of hard lindy-hopping. In 1942, he formed an act with Jimmie "Tricky" Field and, in keeping with the then new cool ethos, they left behind the boisterous acrobatics and adopted a studied, nonchalant style. The new act lasted only a short while - Field was drafted - but a booking at Harlem's Apollo brought Chisholm to the notice of the Crackerjacks, who were looking for a new cane exponent, and Chisholm spent four years with the group. His baton-whirling provided another dimension to the group performance.

He then turned solo and and had no problem finding work with some of the top bands of the time. From the mid-1950s he toured America, Europe and the Pacific Rim. His reputation led him to a revival of the Cotton Club Revue, featuring the Cab Calloway Orchestra.

In 1968, Chisholm joined the musical, Lady Be Good, with Lionel Blair at London's Saville Theatre. He later appeared in the royal variety show, Bubbling Brown Sugar, the Al Jolson Story - and on the northern club circuit.

Chisholm briefly returned to the US in 1972 but, back in Britain, joined an American expatriate jazz dance group. Later, a small-scale revival of the Cotton Club Revue enabled him to exert his charm on larger audiences again.

By the mid-1980s, arthritis forced him to give up cane whirling, but he continued performing, even when it was only lunchtime spots in senior citizens' day centres.

Joe Chisholm, dancer and acrobat, born April 25 1925; died January 30 2001

Chisholm briefly returned to the US in 1972 but, back in Britain, joined an American expatriate jazz dance group. Later, a small-scale revival of the Cotton Club Revue enabled him to exert his charm on larger audiences again. webTitle: Shareholders gang up on one-man-band bosses

fields.headline: Shareholders gang up on one-man-band bosses
fields.trailText: Top executives who insist on flouting corporate governance rules by combining the role of chairman and chief executive will encounter fierce opposition from City investors when they face their shareholders at this year's round of annual general meetings.
fields.body:
Top executives who insist on flouting corporate governance rules by combining the role of chairman and chief executive will encounter fierce opposition from City investors when they face their shareholders at this year's round of annual general meetings.

In tough new guidelines drawn up by Pensions and Investment Research Consultants, a group which advises major investors on the best boardroom practice, chairmen are also being told that their positions should only be held in a non-executive capacity. The guidelines have been sent to the 800 biggest companies in the country, and investors are being urged to use their votes to pull directors into line.

This suggests that a number of chairmen could face votes against their appointments from major shareholders. About 20 FTSE companies contravene the guidelines.

Pirc believes that shareholders at the 800 companies in the FTSE All Share index should be allowed to vote on the remuneration policy of the directors on the board.

The group is also demanding that boards contain no more than 15 people, and that the independence of the non-executives - who should be in the majority - be proven.

Shareholders should not tolerate the chief executive becoming chairman, a practice adopted in recent years by the likes of Lloyds TSB, whose long-standing chief executive Sir Brian Pitman took over as chairman.

At a time when other shareholder groups, such as the powerful Association of British Insurers, are taking a tougher stance on boardroom pay, Pirc says that companies should not be "overgenerous" in their rewards to directors. Top executive pay should not be "out of line" with the benefits received by the rest of a company's employees.

Payments such as "golden hellos", offered as incentives to recruit executives, and guaranteed bonuses, should be regarded as excessive.

Alan MacDougall, managing director of Pirc, said that while boardrooms had rectified many of their practices there was more to be done. "There can be no room for complacency," Mr MacDougall said.

Pirc gives guidelines to investors on how to use their votes at company AGMs. It advises shareholders to vote against resolutions if they judge that rules are being broken.

Its calls for an annual vote on remuneration may provoke some controversy as this is not necessarily endorsed by the ABI, and it was not supported last week by the government, which issued watered-down guidelines on curbing boardroom excess.

fields.headline: Rogue states of America
fields.standfirst: Why Bush needs the bad guys
fields.trailText: US presidents have always had a penchant for bogeymen. Such personifications of evil make a complex world easier to explain to American voters, and they provide moral underpinning for actions subsequently taken in pursuit of US interests.
fields.body:
US presidents have always had a penchant for bogeymen. Such personifications of evil make a complex world easier to explain to American voters, and they provide moral underpinning for actions subsequently taken in pursuit of US interests. Thus in recent years Iran's Ayatollah Khomeini, Libya's Colonel Gadafy, Panama's Manuel Noriega, Haiti's Raoul Cedras and Serbia's Slobodan Milosevic have all been cast in the role of bad guy. Top of the current bogeyman charts is the ever menacing Saddam Hussein, with a lifetime's achievement award going to Cuba's Fidel Castro.

During the Clinton presidency, the bogey concept broadened to include entire countries, known as "rogue states'. Former secretary of state Madeleine Albright, trying to be diplomatic, changed this to "states of concern". But the rogues are back with a vengeance. Twice in the past fortnight President George Bush has highlighted the threat to the US posed by "rogue nations", thereby further expanding the definition to embrace whole peoples and not just their governments. To qualify for such pariah status, a nation must actively support terrorism, be building nuclear or other weapons of mass destruction, or be busy exporting the same to suspicious customers. Top of Mr Bush's list are North Korea, Iran, Libya and, of course, Iraq.

Rogue nations, it is already clear, are the cornerstone of Mr Bush's otherwise still unstable foreign and security edifice. On their shifty shoulders rests the entire raison d' tre of national missile defence (NMD). Dubya may have little or no idea what to do about Ariel Sharon or Japan's economic crisis, but he is absolutely certain of one thing: those missiles are essential to deter the rogues. The distorting effect of this puerile thinking was on display in Washington last week when, to secretary of state Colin Powell's evident discomfiture, Mr Bush told South Korea's President Kim Dae-jung he was ending the policy of engagement and negotiation with the Pyongyang regime pursued by Bill Clinton.

Even though Mr Kim, a key US ally, is desperate to advance the dialogue begun at last year's historic summit with Kim Jong-il, and even though the future of the deprived, half-starved northern population depends on his success, Mr Bush said bluntly he did not trust North Korea and effectively pulled the plug on détente. Pyongyang now warns that it may be forced to resume building nukes and missiles. To which Mr Bush and his hawkish advisers smilingly reply: all the more reason to build NMD!

There is a cynical pattern to be discerned here. While the Clinton administration made tentative gestures towards Iran, Mr Bush's people demonise Tehran as recipient and purveyor of threatening weapons and policies. Iran's internal struggle between reformers and the forces of clerical reaction is ignored; the obvious need of embattled President Mohammad Khatami, facing elections this June, to be able to demonstrate the benefits of his guarded opening to the west goes unrecognised. An opportunity exists to end Iran's isolation that may soon be lost. But what does Mr Bush do? Instead of offering a hand, he cries "mad mullahs!" and demands more missiles.

There is another way, if Mr Bush would only look. Britain and many EU countries are working hard to develop links with North Korea, Iran and Libya. Most also now agree that endless, thoughtless ostracism of the Iraqi nation is no longer a viable policy. So why not stop posturing and start talking? Because Mr Bush wants his missiles. And to get his missiles, the president needs rogues.

fields.headline: I hate you!
fields.standfirst: What is it that drives young girls' intense dislike of each other? Anna Davis recalls how she and Hog-face fought it out
fields.trailText: What is it that drives young girls' intense dislike of each other?  Anna Davis  recalls how she and Hog-face fought it out.
fields.body:
Last week, in a Roman Catholic high school in Pennsylvania, a 14-year-old girl shot and wounded in the shoulder another girl who was described as her "enemy", with whom she'd had a long-standing feud. A police spokesman said: "This is a situation of a student who was upset with another student."

The emotions ascribed to the girl are all too familiar. Never in my 30 years of life have I hated anyone so much as I hated Katie Hogg when I was only 12.

Hog-face is what I imaginatively call her, though actually she is pretty. Prettier than me. I know it and she knows I know it, which gives her the edge. She has clear skin and thick black hair and a small neat body which zips around the netball court with speed and precision while I'm gangling about on my long white legs down at the defence end. She stands there jeering at me and she gets away with it because she's the team captain. Off the netball court, I can compete with her - my grades are always a few per cent higher. This gives me secret pleasure but doesn't really help me because you can't make a big deal of high grades - nobody likes a swot.

We were friends when we first came to the school - before she froze me out and surrounded herself with all those sneery girls she hangs out with. I used to love Art but I dread it now be cause the bitches are all in my class while my friends have taken other options. They don't do anything too overt to me - just the odd catty comment or flick of ink. Until the day when Hog-face puts red paint on the back of my skirt to look like period blood. This ups the ante and I get her back by breaking into her locker and wrecking her maths book just before the lesson - enough so that she gets a detention because the stupid teacher thinks she's done it herself. I rip the cover off and pour Tipp-Ex over her neatly written pages, and while I'm doing it I'm feeling this massive rush of happiness.

She steals my games kit, so I steal hers. She puts a rumour round that my dad is an alcoholic, so I tell everyone her house is full of cat shit. At the school disco she snogs Jason Car with tongues, and while she's doing it she looks over his shoulder at me and reaches up to give me the finger. I've fancied Jason for ages and she knows it - I can't compete with that. Lying in bed afterwards, I am so full of hate and jealousy that I can't sleep. I just lie there boiling up inside.

The next day we fight in the schoolyard. When boys fight they get down on the floor and roll around in the dirt punching each other, but girls have a different way, more snidey. I'm not sure which of us starts the fight but we're dragging each other around by the hair - great handfuls of hair which you yank really hard - and we're kicking at shins and scramming each other's faces. My nails are longer, so I get her good. She bites my hand, though, drawing blood. The kids come crowding around, shouting, and in no time the duty teacher drags us off each other and sends us to the deputy head. I don't even care about the punishment - I've got that rush of exhilaration again and, weirdly, for just a moment, I really like Katie. I want to turn to her and say: "Hey, that was great. Let's do it again." I'm remembering that we started out as friends. But then the momentary comradely feeling is overtaken by hurt. What did I do to make her reject my friendship? And the hate is back, strong and fierce.

When I was 13, my family moved away from the area and Katie Hogg disappeared from my life. If we had stayed, would Hog-face and I have got over this childish but intense rivalry or would it have continued to build between us? Girl-hate is irrational, self-fuelling and all-consuming. Ironically, it is at its worst when you don't really know what it's all about, and when you actually don't want to hate or be hated at all.

fields.headline: Atomic dustbin
fields.standfirst: John Darwell risked his life when he photographed the Chernobyl exclusion zone. But at least they gave him a pair of protective wellies. Phil Daoust reports
fields.trailText: John Darwell risked his life when he photographed the Chernobyl exclusion zone. But at least they gave him a pair of protective wellies.
fields.body:
John Darwell knows a thing or two about nuclear contamination. He lives 20 miles from the Sellafield reprocessing plant and has spent most of the past six years photographing the landmarks of the atomic age: Los Alamos, where the Americans developed the atom bomb; Trinity, where they first tested it; Three Mile Island in Pennsylvania, where a power station came terrifyingly close to meltdown. And he was in Japan in 1995 for the 50th anniversary of the nuclear attacks on Hiroshima and Nagasaki.

Nevertheless, he still felt worried as he neared the exclusion zone around Chernobyl power station, site of the world's worst nuclear accident. Thirty-one people died immediately after the reactor fire in 1986; Ukraine has blamed the radiation that spewed out for at least 8,000 more deaths. More than 130,000 people had to be evacuated, and, 15 years on, soldiers still bar entry to 2,800 sq km of land around the power station.

"It was grey and overcast, one of those really murky days," Darwell recalls. "I was thinking, 'What am I doing here? What am I doing here? ' And then my driver started playing The Road to Hell, by Chris Rea. And I thought, 'That about sums it up.' "

Yet what he found on the other side of the checkpoint was far more complex. "Part of me was expecting a devastated wasteland but everything was growing and lush. The locals did point out mutations - like branches growing on trees where they shouldn't be - but the zone is almost like a wildlife park. There's no folk, so you see herds of elk and wild boar wandering around. Mind you, some of them were showing mutations too."

Darwell's photographs from that trip in late 1999 can now be seen in a book and exhibition called Legacy. There's the snap he took while waiting to pass through the outer cordon, still 30km from the power station - a dog resting in the middle of the road, as if that's the last place it would be disturbed. It brings to mind the beautiful beast from Stalker, Andrey Tarkovsky's eerie 1979 movie. That too featured a danger zone guarded by gun-toting guards, almost empty of humans and green with an obscene fertility.

Inside Chernobyl's exclusion zone, weeds grow knee-high, trees poke up through abandoned homes, flowers bloom among fire engines used during the crisis and too radioactive ever to serve again.

There's no artifice to Darwell's pictures, no fancy filters or tricksy angles, so you have to think about the subject rather than its presentation. One shot shows half a dozen military helicopters slowly rotting in a field, the red stars on their fuselages still visible. How bad must things get, you marvel, for a government to throw away aircraft? And then you remember the pilots who died after dumping their loads of sand and chemicals onto the flaming core of reactor number four.

The Ukrainians spent six months removing and burying contaminated material from around the reactor: machinery, buildings, trees, soil. Of course, the clean-up claimed more lives. Darwell visited a landfill site at Buryakovka, and there's something shocking about his picture of a nondescript field with a radiation hazard sign planted where a scarecrow should be. He was led around by workers with Geiger counters, who steered him away from any hot spots.

The Ukrainians were protected by the sort of paper masks used by decorators. Darwell was slightly better off: he had been lent a pair of wellies when he passed through the zone's inner cordon, 10km from the power station. He also wore a special badge to record his exposure, but could not have it checked until he returned to Britain. "The best way to describe it is a miner's canary - only you don't know it's dead until three weeks later."

When Chernobyl went mushroom-shaped, it took the authorities a day and a half to begin bussing the locals out. At first they claimed the power plant was simply venting steam as usual. Darwell's pictures suggest the panic that ruled once the truth got out: a kindergarten floor scattered with crushed dolls; dodgem cars abandoned between bumps; portraits gathering mildew on mantelpieces; washing left on clothes lines.

It took Darwell 18 months to get permission to visit the exclusion zone, so he made the most of his three weeks there. He took in the power station itself, which only closed down last December ("It was like visiting a factory - we went and had tea at the canteen"), many of the 70 empty villages and the city of Pripyat, which bars visitors whenever the radiation readings blip upwards. "It's all concrete," he explains. "It absorbs radiation like a giant sponge. They can't even knock it down because the dust would be too dangerous."

In the world's most radioactive city, among all the rubble and rust and peeling paint, he photographed a lecture room full of charts cataloguing enemy nuclear weapons and the pointless precautions to be taken in the event of a missile strike.

The zone's guards were relaxed chaps, keen to talk about fishing and show their snapshots of the giant catfish they caught in Chernobyl's outflow. So Darwell's scene of a militia man standing alone in the middle of a field "to prevent homeless people from moving into the village" may raise a hollow laugh. Yet a few of the older locals have returned, feeling safer in their old homes than in the prefab blocks on the edge of Kiev, where too many of their friends have sickened and died. The government seems to have decided it's not worth trying to kick them out again.

So there they are living off the contaminated land, growing crops, using wells, keeping cattle. In the village of Opachichi, Darwell drank the milk from the local cows, which was "rather frightening". "A little radiation is very good for you," one of the locals told him. "It will make your hair grow - look at the vegetables and flowers." There's a lovely shot of a couple called Nicholai and Anastasia, who must be in their 60s or 70s, sitting in their Soviet-floral-horror sitting room and looking as if they've got a bit of a buzz on. The villagers make their own vodka and, when Darwell dropped in, the pair plied him with moonshine for five hours. "I was absolutely out of my mind," he says.

Elsewhere, three babushkas from the same village pose with their buckets by a well; one of them tells a great story that sadly finds no place in the book's brief introduction. She was a PoW in Germany during the second world war and walked all the way back to Ukraine. "Later," says Darwell, "her husband left her and the house burned down . . . and then there was Chernobyl." But she returned a second time.

Darwell's book gives her no words, so let's use what Tarkovsky's Stalker said when he found himself back in his own strange world: "Everything I have is here. Here in the zone. My happiness, my freedom, my dignity." Chernobyl's returnees may be happy to live with the risks of low-level radiation, but Legacy ends on a sombre note. "The concrete sarcophagus surrounding the damaged reactor is now in imminent danger of collapse. This would lead to a second Chernobyl disaster, with tons of highly radioactive dust released into the atmosphere. Some scientists believe the probability of this happening within the next few years to be 'extremely high'."

So is this the most alarming trip Darwell has ever made? Oh no, he says. "There's only one place I've ever had trouble. They actually came with dogs and guns when I was photo-graphing. I was on the public highway but they didn't seem to appreciate that fact. As soon as I turned up, the police would arrive. It got to a point where they'd just recognise my car.

"Yes, Sellafield was slightly hairy."

 Legacy the book is published by Dewi Lewis, price £10.99. The exhibition is at Tullie House, Carlisle (01228 534781), until April 1.

Yet a few of the older locals have returned, feeling safer in their old homes than in the prefab blocks on the edge of Kiev, where too many of their friends have sickened and died. The government seems to have decided it's not worth trying to kick them out again. So there they are living off the contaminated land, growing crops, using wells, keeping cattle. In the village of Opachichi, Darwell drank the milk from the local cows, which was "rather frightening". "A little radiation is very good for you," one of the locals told him. "It will make your hair grow - look at the vegetables and flowers." There's a lovely shot of a couple called Nicholai and Anastasia, who must be in their 60s or 70s, sitting in their Soviet-floral-horror sitting room and looking as if they've got a bit of a buzz on. The villagers make their own vodka and, when Darwell dropped in, the pair plied him with moonshine for five hours. "I was absolutely out of my mind," he says. Elsewhere, three babushkas from the same village pose with their buckets by a well; one of them tells a great story that sadly finds no place in the book's brief introduction. She was a PoW in Germany during the second world war and walked all the way back to Ukraine. "Later," says Darwell, "her husband left her and the house burned down . . . and then there was Chernobyl." But she returned a second time. Darwell's book gives her no words, so let's use what Tarkovsky's Stalker said when he found himself back in his own strange world: "Everything I have is here. Here in the zone. My happiness, my freedom, my dignity." Chernobyl's returnees may be happy to live with the risks of low-level radiation, but Legacy ends on a sombre note. "The concrete sarcophagus surrounding the damaged reactor is now in imminent danger of collapse. This would lead to a second Chernobyl disaster, with tons of highly radioactive dust released into the atmosphere. Some scientists believe the probability of this happening within the next few years to be 'extremely high'." So is this the most alarming trip Darwell has ever made? Oh no, he says. "There's only one place I've ever had trouble. They actually came with dogs and guns when I was photo-graphing. I was on the public highway but they didn't seem to appreciate that fact. As soon as I turned up, the police would arrive. It got to a point where they'd just recognise my car. "Yes, Sellafield was slightly hairy."  Legacy the book is published by Dewi Lewis, price £10.99. The exhibition is at Tullie House, Carlisle (01228 534781), until April 1.

webTitle: A sneak preview of The Sopranos

fields.headline: Tony Soprano must die
fields.standfirst: America is once again enthralled by the antics of New Jersey's first family of crime. John Patterson offers a sneak preview of The Sopranos' third season
fields.trailText: America is once again enthralled by the antics of New Jersey's first family of crime. John Patterson offers a sneak preview of The Sopranos' third season
fields.body:
If everything goes the way creator David Chase has planned it, The Sopranos will only run for four seasons. We've had two already, and the third is now airing in the United States, so already we're at the half-way point. The end is in sight, only 26 episodes away from us.

This will be heartbreaking news for fans who assume that, like many a successful American import, The Sopranos will run for years and years. It won't, but you only have to watch the last few miserable seasons of such formerly hardy perennials as M*A*S*H and LA Law to realise that that is actually a good thing. American TV shows always outstay their welcome, especially if they rise to the status of a national institution, as The Sopranos has. Given enough time, network executives will grind a good show into fine powder, as long as the sponsors' dollars keep pouring in, and no matter if the aging show is rapidly haemorrhaging energy, inspiration and original cast members.

But David Chase is on HBO, not at a network, and the special freedoms he has found there are what have made The Sopranos so successful. His characters can swear like troopers, spill all the blood they want and cavort with all the naked Russian hookers they can handle. But the real liberties Chase enjoys are quite separate from issues of censorship. They include being able to take his time as a writer (he asked to delay the start of this season to get the script right), trafficking in contradictions and ambiguities rather than the moral monotones sanctioned by the networks' Standards-and-Practices lawyers, and assuming a higher intelligence on the part of his audience than has ever been fashionable in mainstream TV circles.

The greatest privilege a show's creator could have though, is the right to name the date that his show bites the dust, rather than have some suit whack it for him - typically over the phone at 4.30 on a Friday afternoon. For Chase this means the chance to work creatively with the dramatic architecture of The Sopranos, to set up themes and storylines that may not pay off for another year or more, to delve ever more deeply, like a North Jersey Balzac or Dos Passos, into the overlapping milieux - suburban America and "this thing of ours" - that he's staked out, and to stage a structured, orderly withdrawal and climax in two years time.

There will be no reunion specials "taped before a live studio audience", no sequels, no excuses, and no Godfather III-style aesthetic betrayals. Just an Italian-American symphony with four movements, a quartet of great American novels, a quadruple-decker wedding cake iced with the dried blood of dead wise guys.

So here we stand at the mid-point. When series two faded out, Chase had rather bravely killed off two of the show's favourite characters. Tormented stoolie Big Pussy Bompensiero, Tony's best friend, was thoroughly ventilated before being tossed into the Atlantic, and David Proval's tightly wound psycho-upstart Richie Aprile was dispatched prematurely into the hereafter by Tony's scheming sister, New Age welfare-cheat Janice (Aida Turturro). Chase ended the series by pulling away from Meadow Soprano's graduation party to images of mafia foot soldiers and their myriad victims, culminating with a desolate shot of David Scatino (Robert Patrick, who'll also be missed), the "dee-generate fuckin' gambler" and neighbour on whom Tony and his crew feasted like locusts, fleeing to his doom in Las Vegas.

With perfect symmetry, season three starts outside and works its way inwards, through the perspective of the FBI's North Jersey Organized Crime Division, as its officers make two trips to install a wire in the basement of the Soprano house. While the installation takes place, the Feds watch each member of the family, from Carmela and Adriana at the tennis club (whose lesbian tennis coach is all twitchy for Adriana), to Anthony Jr ducking school and smoking with his skate-punk pals, and Meadow, now ensconced in the dorms at Columbia University in Manhattan. This episode (one of two making up the US season premiere) works mainly as an overture, updating each cast member, introducing newcomers and bringing hitherto minor characters into the foreground.

There's more symmetry in the resemblances between the Feds and the wise guys: each have their rituals, their uniforms, their beer guts, their professional argots, their codes of masculinity and their fatal delusions. And both value systems, Chase suggests, are equally full of shit, with Tony whacking whoever needs to be whacked and the FBI breaking the very laws they've sworn to uphold in order to nail their man. Their crudity and invasiveness very nearly puts us on Tony's side.

Then just as we get comfortable, it's episode two, the narrative proper commences and immediately reality slaps us in the face. Fat cuddly Tony makes a series of brutal racist remarks to a half-black, half-Jewish male friend of Meadow (they're home watching The Public Enemy for a course called, hysterically, "Images of Hyper-Capitalist Self-Advancement in the Age of the Studio System") in an attempt to ensure that he won't date her.

No one will be surprised to learn that Livia Soprano's oft-expressed fondest wish - "I wish the Lord would take me now!" - has finally been granted. There wasn't much choice. Actress Nancy Marchand had suffered from lung cancer since the show started and she died after last season had aired. Then again, what better way to open a new season than with a mob funeral for someone so universally loathed? The gruesome wake that ensues is one of the best sequences ever shot for American television.

Anyone who thought that last season was inferior to the first (and I'm not one of them) is advised to stick around. Season three offers new characters such as Joe Pantoliano as an ambitious earner being held back by Tony. He seems more ordered and less impulsive than Richie Aprile, and therefore a more formidable opponent. Not to mention the show's enduring pleasures, like Tony Jr's blank little face and foul little mouth ("what - no fuckin' zitti?"), Carmela's Jersey hair'n'nails, Adriana's transcendent trashiness, the magnificent pug-mug of James Gandolfini, Furio's obsession with pricey consumer electronics and bad TV shows, and the way that Paulie and Silvio never, ever stop twitching.

As Silvio keeps saying, quoting Michael Corleone in The Godfather III, "Just when I thought I was out... they pulled me back in!"

 The Sopranos, season three, starts on E4 on Sunday 24 June at 10.30pm, and on Channel 4 from September

webTitle: You say stadiums, I say stadia

fields.headline: You say stadiums, I say stadia
fields.standfirst: A fine new TV documentary on the revolution in football charts the arrival of big money, superstardom, decent hair-dos and the middle-classes in the game
fields.trailText: A fine new TV documentary on the revolution in football charts the arrival of big money, superstardom, decent hair-dos and the middle-classes in the game
fields.body:
On the Chiles On Saturday show on Radio 5 Live recently, the former footballer Ralph Coates was interviewed about his startling barnet, an optimistic bald man's comb-over, the second most famous hairstyle in the game after Bobby Charlton's. While such an ambitious thatch might just have worked for a librarian or clerk, it's strange in retrospect that men even attempted it in football, a sport involving fast running, high winds and the frequent need to propel the ball with your head.

After discussing his tonsorial oddity, Coates was introduced on the telephone to an ex-punk singer who had written a 70s song called Grease Your Ralph, a tribute to the player's eccentric tresses. The conversation was then joined by a listener who had changed his name by deed poll to Ralph Burnley, the player's name and most famous club.

This surreal piece of radio, a little miracle of wit and research, was a measure of the way football broadcasting has changed. Originally limited to simple coverage of goals and post-game clichés, the game on television and radio now attracts two new sets of supporters: the serious analysts and the ironic nostalgics. Playing for that second team are shows such as Chiles's and the new Sky 1 football quiz show, Jumpers For Goalposts, its title a Proustian moment for most middle-aged men. Joining the first side this week is The Men Who Changed Football, a three-part BBC 2 series which attempts to bring to the sport the kind of documentary investigation previously reserved for politics and war: a sort of Fanorama.

You can tell that the series is aimed more at the prawn-sandwich than the meat-pie section of the football audience because, when narrator Paul McGann refers to more than one football ground, he says "stadia". Intriguingly, one reference is immediately followed by a clip of David Mellor in an interview saying "stadiums". In his time at the Home Office, Mellor used the Latin plural, but it disappeared as part of a phraseology makeover when he became a host of football radio phone-ins. The question of how you refer to several playing arenas is now a key one in football, distinguishing the core middle-class audience from the recently arriving middle classes. You say stadiums, I say stadia, let's call the whole match off.

Directed by Annabel Hobley (her presence an example of the feminising which is another recent shift in soccer coverage), The Men Who Changed Football shows how the ownership of football clubs changed from a weekend pastime of industrialists to an industry in itself. A footballer in the baggy-shorts era famously left a blank page in his memoirs headed: What The Average Football Club Director Knows About The Game. This documentary focuses on a new kind of fan-owner, men who handed over coins for turnstile tickets when young and then returned in adulthood to offer stacks of bank-notes for the whole club: the likes of Irving Scholar at Spurs and David Dein at Arsenal.

A series of this kind requires two things for success: intelligent connections, and archive which swings between the familiar and the surprising. In both cases here, the girl done good. Establishing management methods of the past, there's splendid black-and-white film of a board meeting in which an aldermanic chap in bottle-top specs instructs the manager: "Archie, I'd now like you to give your views of Saturday's match for the benefit of directors who weren't there."

In several sequences like this, smart picture research and historical links play a neat one-two. Shots of Glen Hoddle, in a previous life, singing on Top Of The Pops add comedy value, but also illustrate the crucial way in which 80s footballers changed from athletes to superstar entertainers. In the same way, gruesome footage of a bubble-permed Kevin Keegan kissing Margaret Thatcher on the cheeks outside Number 10 is not only amusing in a Rock'n'Roll Years way, but kicks off the film's most important point: the way in which this anti-soccer mum prime minister with her rugby referee husband was largely responsible for giving English football its balls.

Tycoons produced by Thatcher's economic boom bought the clubs they'd loved as boys, and then used cash from her chum Rupert Murdoch's expansion of television to finance the reshaping of the sport for the bourgeois. Like Alan Hansen or Andy Gray with their freeze-frames and highlighter pens, the programme shows how each goal resulted from a series of mistakes and inspirations: Bradford to Heysel to Hillsborough to Thatcher to Murdoch and there's Sir Alex Ferguson to finish it off.

The middle-class writers who have created a new literature of football in recent years have been accused of over-complicating the game. The Men Who Changed Football, though, intelligently simplifies the history of the sport's development from kick-about to corporation by isolating the significant moments. Irving Scholar wonders if a football club might not be floated on the Stock Exchange. Robert Maxwell tells his fellow club chairmen that football rights are worth 25 times what they're getting. A clothing manufacturer has the idea that fans might just buy replica shirts. These films may say "stadia", but they should be watched by everyone who sits in the stadiums.

 The Men Who Changed Football, Tuesday, 9pm, BBC2

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: A walk on the safe side
fields.trailText: A walk on the safe side
fields.body:
The Lake District

Denied access to the fells recently - in superb winter conditions, with sunlit snows and extensive distant views - we were reduced, the other day, to a few miles saunter along Morecambe Promenade. But at least there were views of the snowbound Lakeland fells across the water, the shrimpers out on the edge of the sands, huge, wheeling flocks of birds quartering the bay, and plenty of fresh air. On the way, we had passed the shore at Hest Bank and seen dozens of walkers far out on the sands - an inspiration for later walks. We could tackle the fascinating coastline, exploring for miles, and keep well away from fell and farmland. Several times we encountered other walkers, in boots and balaclavas, and exchanged smiles and wry glances. No need for words. We were all on the same job - seeking a bit of exercise away from the hills.

How well I remember the last foot and mouth epidemic in 1967, when we were denied the fells for the whole of November and December, and only allowed back again halfway through January - a very long deprivation that tested us sorely. Will the present restrictions last as long? - or longer? The current outbreak is much more widespread than the one 34 years ago, which was mostly confined to Cheshire and Shropshire. Of course, I remember the exasperation of 1967, but people complied with the regulations and certainly the fells were quite deserted for 10 weeks. But, mostly, I recall that November 1967 was, infuriatingly, a superb month, with day after day of unbroken, late autumn sunshine, little wind and superb views.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: Maria Fernandes: An article published on February 13 reported a complaint made by a Tory MP of a potential conflict of interest between Keith Vaz's office and his wife's legal work and included the allegation that Keith Vaz had breached the ministerial code of conduct by allowing his wife Maria Fernandes to advise Amin Ali on obtaining work permits for restaurant staff from India. Ms Fernandes has told us that while her firm has advised a company in which Mr Ali is a shareholder she has never acted for or advised Mr Ali herself. Ms Fernandes is an immigration lawyer in her own right. We did not intend to suggest that her husband had any involvement in the running of her practice or that she seeks to use her husband's office to the advantage of her clients. We regret any contrary impression given by the article.

fields.headline: Screen grabs
fields.standfirst: Coming to a box near you
fields.trailText: Coming to a box near you
fields.body:
 Reports of Frasier's imminent demise have been kicking around for nearly as long as the show. But NBC, which broadcasts it, last week struck a deal with the producers for another three years' worth of the programme. More tossed salad, anyone?

 Academics in America, meanwhile, are embroiled in a row about the homoerotic subtext to the classic 60s TV adaptation of Batman. Burt Ward, who played Robin in the series, famously speculated on the nature of the dynamic duo in his 1995 autobiography. "A mature man, unmarried and rarely seen in the company of women, takes a naive teenage boy under his wing... They share many secrets and spend long hours alone in remote areas...." fields.headline: Radio review
fields.standfirst: When hearing is believing
fields.trailText: When hearing is believing
fields.body:
I've never really forgiven Johnny Mathis. Christmas 1976, and When A Child Is Born was top of the pops instead of my favourite, Abba's Money Money Money. He stayed there for three weeks and it seemed an eternity.

But that's nothing compared to the time Radio 2 is dedicating to him in its new six-part series, Johnny Mathis. Sounds a bit OTT? I thought so, too, until David Jacobs pointed out that only Elvis, Sinatra and Bing Crosby have outsold him. Johnny's Greatest Hits was in the US charts for nine and a half years.

But still, with six programmes to fill, Jacobs proceeds slowly. We heard from Mathis's best friends in the first programme, and were treated to unattributed tantalising snippets from future episodes. "When he sings, it curls your hair," said one enthusiast. "I call John Mr Velvet," said another. Despite the 25-year grudge, I'm hooked, but only to find out who these fabulous fools are.

Away from the soft focus world of Mathis, others had taller broadcasting orders. Having tried to talk about art on the radio, I winced at the confidence of the press notes for Art Atlas (Radio 4), a "ground-breaking" new series demonstrating that "pictures really can be better on the radio". It doesn't say better than what, but Robert McNab's "highly personal" take on visual culture does have a winning verve about it.

In the first programme, he looked at Paint Rage - the violence of painting and the sexual brutality of art produced in equally brutal times. McNab took in Berlin, George Grosz, Jackson Pollock, Otto Dix and some diverting true crime stories from the 1920s. One chap chewed open the arteries of his sleeping victims; another "kept their pickled fingers in his flat". Robert Crumb, said McNab, is the Grosz of our time. "What is it about certain types of honesty that sends them running from the room to call the police," he pondered, with unintended timeliness, given the goings on at the Saatchi gallery.

Art on the wireless is nothing compared to attempting The African Queen (Radio 4), without pictures, Hepburn and Bogey. But Mike Lewis did, adapting CS Forester's tale of sensible middle-class Rose Sayer and diamond cockney geezer Charlie Allnut stuck on a steamboat in Africa during the First World War. Tara Fitzgerald shone as Sayer, and as the sound effects department went gaga with the flies and toads, the love affair seemed as real as it did in the Hollywood version. Pictures aren't always better on the radio, but this was as good as, I realised, sobbing like a twit at the end.

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Bushman Tales | Wild Europe | Night Waves
fields.body:
A British colonial officer in Western Kalahari offered reassurance to doubtful incoming settlers. "The region has a beautiful climate and is perfect for cattle ranching. There is water on the ridge and no natives living here, only a few wild bushmen." That was in 1895 but, as Sue Armstrong shows this week in Bushman Tales (3.45pm, Radio 4), the refusal to regard indigenous tribesmen as human beings persisted long after that.

One of the areas which Holland recovered from the sea in the 1960s was intended for industrial development. However, when the subsequent oil crisis made the project uneconomic, the land was gradually taken over by reeds, trees, and birds. Now, as Lionel Kelleway reports in Wild Europe (9.0pm, Radio 4), a project conceived by naturalist Frans Vera has turned it into a sort of Dutch Serengeti. Wild cattle, horses and deer follow the undisturbed routines of a world without humans - but there is increasing opposition from animal rights campaigners.

For 40 years comic artist Robert Crumb has savaged suburban America through such creations as Mr Natural, Angelfood McSpade, and Flakey Foont. Actor Kerry Shale is a long-time admirer of the artist he describes as a "vicious social satirist forever throwing pies in the face of the world". He pays tribute in Night Waves (9.30pm, Radio 3).

webTitle: Letters: Bel, more tributes flood in

fields.headline: Bel: more tributes flood in
fields.trailText: After a suitable period of mourning I feel able to express my feelings at the sad demise of Bel, as I feel privileged to call her (Farewell, Bel, March 9) .
fields.body:
After a suitable period of mourning I feel able to express my feelings at the sad demise of Bel, as I feel privileged to call her (Farewell, Bel, March 9) .

I remember vividly where I was when I heard (or rather read) the news. I was sitting at this very table, on this very chair: my breakfast toast turned to ashes and my breakfast coffee became a tasteless brown sludge - which often happens, as a matter of fact.

A light is gone out - or perhaps has gone out. A stuttering, guttering, nay muttering candle has been extinguished. We shall not look upon her like again.

One solitary shaft of light illumines the sombre scene. Let us hope that Craig Brown, after a suitable period of mourning, will be able to devote the whole of his considerable energies towards steering the Scottish football squad to victory in the World Cup. Go for it Craig! Win it for Bel! Sydney Clayton Manchester

 She bestrode Comment & Analysis like a Millennium Dome, with her shadow throwing the rest of its writers into sharp relief. She can never be replaced, and from that tragedy comes a new hope: a chance for the Guardian to break through the limitations of the columnist form. It won't be easy to do better than Bel. But we can hope. John Dallman Cambridge

 Sorry to hear of Bel's demise, even if her total years of experience did add up to several lifetimes. But Leanda de Lisle can now have even more fun pretending to be a disgruntled one-nation Tory, right?

Patrick Graham Cardiff

fields.headline: Pick of the day
fields.trailText: Babe | The Matrix | Miller's Crossing | Fitzcarraldo | Bob And Carol And Ted And Alice
fields.body:
Films

Babe (Chris Noonan, 1995) 5.15pm, The Studio About five minutes into Noonan's delightful, Oscar-winning adaptation of the Dick King-Smith book, disbelief is entirely suspended and it seems perfectly natural that these farmyard animals should natter away to each other. Best is the grouchy old sheepdog, growling at the flock: "Now listen to me, you morons..." James Cromwell, the cynical police captain in LA Confidential, is Farmer Hoggett in an inspired comedy.

The Matrix (Larry Wachowski, Andy Wachowski, 1999) 10pm, Sky Premier Sci-fi action movie that's a kinetic thrill-a-minute joyride. Full of cool kung fu, bodies flying around the trajectory of bullets, it makes John Woo look like Anthony Asquith. The labyrinthine plot feels reminiscent of Philip K Dick, with mankind unknowingly enslaved in a virtual reality.

Miller's Crossing (Joel Coen, 1990) 10.25pm, 3.35am, Sky Cinema The gangster movie gets a witty and ironic update from the mercurial Coen brothers. Gabriel Byrne's Tom is lieutenant to crimelord Leo (Albert Finney) in a 1930s neo-Chicago: Tom's attempts to go legit are undermined by his boss's old-fashioned way of dealing with rival Jon Polito's outfit. Tom is also having an affair with Leo's girl (Marcia Gay Harden, a real tough femme fatale). It's an intricate plot, but hard, fast and witty as a Dashiell Hammett novel.

Fitzcarraldo (Werner Herzog, 1982) 12.35am, FilmFour Herzog's most grandiose, absurd project stars Klaus Kinski as Fitzgerald/Fitzcarraldo, an Irish visionary obsessed with the notion of bringing Enrico Caruso and the opera to the South American rain forests. This involves overseeing the transport of his steamship over a mountain; and fiction and reality blended when Herzog elected to film a real boat being manhandled over a real mountain (Les Blank's documentary Burden Of Dreams charts the awesome task). Herzog created a stunning portrait of a man following his dream and in many ways, it's a self-portrait.

Bob And Carol And Ted And Alice (Paul Mazursky, 1969) 3.35am, FilmFour It looks not so much dated as prehistoric now, but Mazursky's comic take on the 60s era of free love, and the upper middle-class California scene in particular, is well acted, funny, and at times even touching. Robert Culp and Natalie Wood are the couple learning to swing, but in bed with pals Elliott Gould and Dyan Cannon no one knows quite what to do, in a pious conclusion to an otherwise sharp satire.

Sports

Live Cricket 6am, Zee TV While Sky Sports push their coverage of England's tour of Sri Lanka, cricket continues elsewhere. Hindi channel Zee TV is covering Australia's tour of India, with the second Test ongoing at Eden Gardens in Calcutta. If that doesn't tickle your cricketing fancy, try West Indies v South Africa (Sky Sports Extra, 2pm) or coverage of Pakistan's tour of New Zealand on Sony TV Asia.

fields.headline: Ice girls finish first
fields.trailText: The South Bank Show | The God List
fields.body:
Melvyn Bragg promised us "the first major profile for British television" of Greta Garbo, which was enough to keep a certain section of the population up well past their normal Sunday bedtime. Unlike The South Bank Show (ITV), which kept us waiting till nearly midnight for the good bits, we'll cut to the chase: Garbo had a soul-stirring homosexual affair with Mercedes de Acosta, a besotted fan who stalked her with love letters and passionate declarations. De Acosta came with excellent references; she was, apparently, "a fabulous lover", and Garbo, who enjoyed sex largely as a form of horizontal Pilates, happily hopped on. Icy Swede met fiery Hispanic in a petal-strewn boudoir, and, in the words of the old advert, the ice melted

The heat, however, was short lived, and Garbo swanned off with Rouben Mamoulian, leaving the wrecked Mercedes to pour out her scorn in a kiss-and-tell book. Garbo never forgave her. (Nor did she forgive Cecil Beaton, another unlikely lover, who wrote about their affair in his published diaries.)

None of this came as a surprise to eager students of Kenneth Anger's indispensible Hollywood Babylon books, but it certainly added a refreshing new dimension to the conventional portrait of Garbo the Ice Queen. She emerged as a woman incapable of intimacy, a bitter cocktail of insecurity and self-regard who would go into massive sulks over the slightest hint of a rebuff. One such rebuff came in 1941, when Louis B Mayer dropped her from MGM. Garbo sulked so efficiently that she never made another movie for the remaining 43 years of her life. A tantalising screen test from the late 40s revealed her as bovine but still beautiful, the trademark eye make-up unchanged since the 20s.

As is customary with these things, a host of biographers, contemporaries and "friends" gathered to pick over the bones, giving tiny glimpses into the hermetically sealed world of the ageing Garbo. Walker Sam Green recalled how she would time her comings and goings from her East 52nd Street apartment to avoid her former lover's widow; there was much gurning in the lobby should the two rivals accidentally meet. Even more excitingly, Green revealed that Garbo was a secret troll collector; he once found a small stash of the long-haired plastic dollies under a sofa cushion. On a subsequent visit, they had been "moved around", raising the exciting suspicion that the divine Garbo acted out private dramas with her little friends. ("Drop me, would you, Mayer?" "Take that, Cecil, you bitch!").

Such fragmentary details were not enough to piece together any meaningful picture of the last half of Garbo's life; that she maintained such utter reclusion is a feat almost as great as her acting career. We were reminded of the real glory of Garbo in a few judiciously chosen clips from the major movies: mad vamping in Grand Hotel, bitter sadness in Camille, silent raunch in Love, with John Gilbert. Then, of course, there was Queen Christina, the emblematic moment of Garbo's career, the film in which all the key elements - androgyny, frustration, mystery - fused together. The scene in which Garbo goes around the room, saying goodbye to the furniture, said more about her glorious blend of pathos and absurdity than any amount of analysis.

Deities of a lower order were the subject of Channel 4's controversy-courting The God List (Sunday), which presented "the 50 people driven by religion who wield the most power in Britain today". Tony Blair, as the first "out" Christian prime minister for ages, topped the list, with Gordon Brown at number two and Cherie Blair at number four. Proving still further that our nation's faith has crossed the river from Lambeth Palace to Downing Street, George Carey was down at number six, because, according to the panel, he isn't really very influential. The Pope was even further down, at number eight, which may come as a surprise to millions of Catholics.

Despite the serious tone, there were moments of light relief. Destiny's Child (unplaced) gave thanks at an awards ceremony to "our heavenly Father Jesus Christ", betraying a loose grasp of the Nicene Creed. Narrator Jon Snow couldn't help saying things like "in at number 50, it's Lord Michael Levy" and "find out who's number one after the break".

fields.headline: Waiting for Aids drugs
fields.trailText: In response to Miranda Kavanagh of Pfizer (Letters, March, 10), I stand by everything in my article (People come before profit, March 5). The Treatment Action Campaign and I have been closely associated with the contest over the price of Diflucan, the offer of Diflucan to the South Africa government and the implementation of this agreement .
fields.body:
In response to Miranda Kavanagh of Pfizer (Letters, March, 10), I stand by everything in my article (People come before profit, March 5). The Treatment Action Campaign and I have been closely associated with the contest over the price of Diflucan, the offer of Diflucan to the South Africa government and the implementation of this agreement .

Ms Kavanagh says: "Pfizer is not a party to the law suit." Pfizer is not included in the list of applicant pharmaceutical companies in this suit. However, it is a member of the Pharmaceutical Manufacturers' Association (the first applicant). It has not said the PMA does not speak on its behalf. Unless it provides evidence, for example, of a resolution taken by Pfizer indicating that it is not represented by the PMA, the assertion stands.

Regarding the Diflucan partnership programme: as of last Thursday, not a single Diflucan pill donated by Pfizer had reached a poor person who needs this medicine. Thus, it is correct to state that the limited quantity of Diflucan supplied in South Africa's public hospitals is still purchased at the public sector tender price of 28 rand (£2.60). In the private sector, it is sold to the patient at between 80 and 120 rand (£7.30 - £11). These prices must be contrasted with the those of generic versions of Diflucan such as Biozole, which was imported by the Treatment Action Campaign from Thailand in 2000 at 1.77 rand (16p) per capsule.
Mark Heywood
Aidslaw project, Johannesburg

webTitle: Letters: Why Indira Gandhi got on with Margaret Thatcher

fields.headline: Why Indira Gandhi got on with Margaret Thatcher
fields.trailText: I admire Geoffrey Moorhouse's books, so I was disappointed to read his apologia for Indira Gandhi in his review of a new biography of her (Chronicle of a death foretold, Saturday Review, March 10). He was much too indulgent.
fields.body:
I admire Geoffrey Moorhouse's books, so I was disappointed to read his apologia for Indira Gandhi in his review of a new biography of her (Chronicle of a death foretold, Saturday Review, March 10). He was much too indulgent.

This "democrat" could not tolerate rival parties winning state level elections and (mis)used article 360 of the constitution to impose president's rule. For the same reason, this "secularist" built up and encouraged Sikh separatist extremism as a counterweight to a strong regional party, the Akali Dal, in the Punjab.

The irony, and her tragedy, was that she was consumed by the creature she created. She passed several acts to make legal strikes all but impossible and to imprison her opponents at will. She surrounded herself with sycophants and toadies - they told her that she should win the general election in 1977 - that is why she went to the polls, not because was a democrat. No wonder she got on well with Margaret Thatcher.

But what is truly awful is Moorhouse's casual defence of the Emergency. He wheels out the old lie that it was the only alternative to "chaos." Where have we heard that before? The Emergency "worked" he assures us: it meant forced sterilisation for thousands, dumping homeless pavement squatters in the middle of nowhere, prison for tens of thousands. All this was dressed up in radical rhetoric, but every South Asian leader at the time used the language of socialism to mask the pursuit of power. She was not Pol Pot, but to call her a democrat - no.

We feel sympathy for Mary Queen of Scots because of the manner of her death, and forget her disastrous record as ruler of Scotland. The appalling circumstances of Indira Gandhi's assassination should not blind us to the fact that she debased Indian politics. The current political elite in India are, as Moorhouse rightly says, lesser figures. But they are not Indira Gandhi's antithesis, they are her true heirs.
Stirling Smith
Bolton

 Geoffrey Moorhouse's review of Katherine Frank's biography of Indira Gandhi swallows whole the Nehruvian mythology that has sustained India's ruling dynasty. Most laughable is his statement: "The Nehru's were dedicated to the notion of a secular state." In Punjab, Kashmir, Kerala and countless other examples, Indira and her father Jawaharlal showed that the retention of power by Congress totally overrode any ideological considerations. fields.bodyText: I admire Geoffrey Moorhouse's books, so I was disappointed to read his apologia for Indira Gandhi in his review of a new biography of her (Chronicle of a death foretold, Saturday Review, March 10). He was much too indulgent. This "democrat" could not tolerate rival parties winning state level elections and (mis)used article 360 of the constitution to impose president's rule. For the same reason, this "secularist" built up and encouraged Sikh separatist extremism as a counterweight to a strong regional party, the Akali Dal, in the Punjab. The irony, and her tragedy, was that she was consumed by the creature she created. She passed several acts to make legal strikes all but impossible and to imprison her opponents at will. She surrounded herself with sycophants and toadies - they told her that she should win the general election in 1977 - that is why she went to the polls, not because was a democrat. No wonder she got on well with Margaret Thatcher. But what is truly awful is Moorhouse's casual defence of the Emergency. He wheels out the old lie that it was the only alternative to "chaos." Where have we heard that before? The Emergency "worked" he assures us: it meant forced sterilisation for thousands, dumping homeless pavement squatters in the middle of nowhere, prison for tens of thousands. All this was dressed up in radical rhetoric, but every South Asian leader at the time used the language of socialism to mask the pursuit of power. She was not Pol Pot, but to call her a democrat - no. We feel sympathy for Mary Queen of Scots because of the manner of her death, and forget her disastrous record as ruler of Scotland. The appalling circumstances of Indira Gandhi's assassination should not blind us to the fact that she debased Indian politics. The current political elite in India are, as Moorhouse rightly says, lesser figures. But they are not Indira Gandhi's antithesis, they are her true heirs. webTitle: Letters: Naked truth about those pictures

fields.headline: Naked truth about those pictures
fields.trailText: I wonder who could have drawn the attention of the art loving News of the World and the police to Tierney Gearon's photographs of her children on show in the Saatchi Gallery.
fields.body:
I wonder who could have drawn the attention of the art loving News of the World and the police to Tierney Gearon's photographs of her children on show in the Saatchi Gallery, thus guaranteeing acres of newsprint to a new Saatchi protege (Police obscenity squad raids Saatchi gallery, An inspector calls, Family snapshots show peculiar art, Mark Lawson, leader, March 10)? I'm sure it couldn't have been publicity-shy art dealer and advertising mogul Charles Saatchi himself.
John Keane
London

 It's all very simple. Nice lady takes nice pictures of nice kids and puts them in an art gallery. Smutty newspaper editor sees pictures and tells policemen, who, in return, give newspaper editor lady's private address and telephone number. Result: big fuss, big story for newspaper editor, and lady has to explain to kids why their photographs are an affront to public morals. Half time score: Gutter journalism 1, Common decency 0. In a comparable case 35 years ago, a home secretary told the police where to get off. Will Mr Straw even up the score this time? I don't think so.
Peter Nicklin
Newcastle Upon Tyne

 Mark Lawson suggests (Innocence observed or abused, March 10) that the display of Gearon's photographs of her naked children, though not a police matter, is a moral one, as it might cause embarrassment to the children now or later. Surely publishing one of the photographs on the front page of a newspaper, where far more people will see it, is even more inconsiderate of the children's feelings?

Susan Reynolds
London
smgreynolds@talk21.com

 As a parent, I find it unbelievable that Tierney Gearon would betray her childrens' innocence in such a cruel way. Their nakedness is their own as they cannot make an informed decision whether or not to be displayed in a gallery for all, including paedophiles, to see. These images should be banned. Let's hear less about the pomposity of the art gallery and more about protecting children. Children are beautiful, but their beauty should be guarded until they are legally old enough to give consent to being so used.
Dorry Lewis
Egham, Surrey

 If the images by Tierney Gearon, now threatened with prosecution are indeed indecent then, under the Protection of Children Act 1978, the Guardian itself committed an offence by reproducing and distributing them. Moreover, - under later revisions to the 1978 act - it would also be criminal merely to possess these photographs, in whatever form. This means that every reader who doesn't burn the relevant parts of Saturday's Guardian could, theoretically, be summonsed to appear before a magistrate. I hereby inform Scotland Yard that I have no intention of destroying such delightful images, and invite them to take me to court.
Roger Moody
London

 Tierney Gearson's photographs might or might not be pornographic but they still have to answer to the lesser charge of being banal, unoriginal, exploitative and (now successfully) opportunistic.
Root Cartwright
Radlett, Herts
root.cartwright@btinternet.com

 The only obscenity which is self-evident in this case is the perverse action of Scotland Yard officers. Their attack upon the artistic integrity of the photographer and her publisher should be investigated by the Home Office for the abuse of office and of public funds which it is. Sadly, their actions draw attention away from the real child pornographers whom they should be targetting.


Rev Paul Flowers
Arts critic, Methodist Recorder
paulflowers@lifeline.org.uk

 As a social services manager in the field of child protection, I was aghast that you found it necessary to publish copies of these sexually exploitative pictures of children. The photographer has clearly exploited her children. By publishing the accompanying pictures, the Guardian undermined a good article and an excellent approach by the Metropolitan police in tackling this.


Terri Johnson
Portsmouth

 I have a head and shoulders photograph of my children sharing a bath, but when my son's friends laughed at it, he asked us to remove it from the wall, and we did. Tierney Gearon's snapshot is certainly not pornographic, but she is foolish to have risked compromising the innocence of her children, a quality every parent holds in trust and has a responsibility to guard.


Catherine Baynham
High Wycombe, Bucks

 Are we to take it that if police were to visit the National Gallery or the British Museum, we would be short of several nativities, not to mention much of figurative sculpture from Ancient Greece onwards?
Ariella Popple
London
ariellavp@onetel.net.uk

 And how do you justify a picture of a semi-naked Demi Moore alongside an article about unit trust performance figures (Jobs&Money, March 10)?
Anne Foster
Beaconsfield
annef@beeb.net

fields.headline: Peter's law
fields.trailText: Mick Williams (Letters, March 10) was very unlucky not to get a reply from No 10 to his complaint about Peter Mandelson.
fields.body:
Mick Williams (Letters, March 10) was very unlucky not to get a reply from No 10 to his complaint about Peter Mandelson.

When I wrote to Tony Blair in 1998 warning him what a danger Mandelson would turn out to be to him, I got an acknowledgement from his office saying that they had passed my letter to Mr Mandelson's office(!) In due course, Mr Mandelson's then aide, Mr Wegg-Prosser, wrote to me to the effect that Mr Mandelson was the greatest thing since sliced bread.

On the occasion of Mr Mandelson's recent "resignation", I had the greatest difficulty in resisting the temptation to send an "I told you so" letter to Mr Blair.
Fred Brooks
Redgrave, Suffolk fred@redgrave.screaming.net
