fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Spirits sag as the sense of isolation deepens

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Spirits sag as the sense of isolation deepens
fields.body:
Our weekend was very hectic. First we had a big scare as the Ministry of Agriculture (Maff) vets were called to a farm not far from here. It was an extremely tense time for everyone, none more so than for the farmer involved, but mercifully he was given the all clear within hours. The collective sigh from the farmers here could almost have been heard in London. Now we wait to hear test results from another farm, just over three miles away from us in a westerly direction. Meanwhile, the Murray family has finally received a negative result from their initial sample, and is awaiting a second visit from a Maff vet in order to lift the tight quarantine restrictions.

This constant pressure of not knowing quite where the virus will pop up next takes its toll on us all. I can only surmise it is farming's equivalent of the blitz. In this case we know the bombs (the suspected and/or confirmed outbreaks) will fall, but not the exact location or when they will cease. When the chief vet, Jim Scudamore, told the nation that this could run for months, our hearts sank. Living in the hills is isolating enough, but with added restrictions it is far too hard. All the people we would like to see either live on a farm or next door to a farm. Shopping will become less of a headache as we've concluded there is not so much "risk" in the Hexham supermarket, but one trip a week is sufficient as the trek there and back takes ages.

The Sedgewick family lives on one of the next door farms, although their farmhouse is four miles away by road. Julie and David have spent years building up a second business, a successful fish and chip van, which has now been off the road for almost three weeks. They worry that their hard-won customer base is dwindling away. We sympathise with everybody caught up in all this.

A trip to the local agricultural merchants highlighted the effects. We saw hardly no vehicles on the road. Wallington Hall, a National Trust property, is closed and barred off. On arrival at the suppliers our wheels were sprayed with disinfectant. We all ask the same question - how long can we cope? The general reply: as long as it takes.

Lambing, calving and farrowing is now under way in all parts of the country, although naturally spring starts later up here. The effect of the movement restrictions could be catastrophic for us and we have only just begun to fully appreciate this. Although we have been building pens in preparation for the ewes and their lambs, we had overlooked the fact that all our farm buildings are beside a very minor public road. No one but us is using the road through the steading (farmyard), and it doesn't really go anywhere except to the church and then meanders, through lots of gates, way out bye (a Northumberland expression meaning in the middle of nowhere).

It is forbidden to bring an animal across the road for any reason, so we cannot even move the cattle from one shed to another (a distance of 75m) in order to clean them out as we frequently have to do. And unless we can get a special licence, we will not be able to make full use of our essential lambing sheds. This thought completely does our heads in, while the workload just increases day by day as lambing gets nearer.

One of our ewes has aborted her expected three lambs, as sheep can do just before lambing. All sorts of abnormalities and difficulties are expected in a flock this size and we were not surprised. However, owing to what we have been told about the symptoms of foot and mouth, instead of being left to quietly get over her trauma, the poor ewe endured a gentle yet thorough examination of her mouth, tongue, dental pad and feet. As far as we could tell she was clear, but she gave us a baleful stare when we left her.

This week we need to vaccinate the ewes and dose them for intestinal parasites. This will give us the opportunity to look at the flock very closely and examine every mouth as they pass through the pens. Like every other farmer, we've had to work out how to move animals around without touching the road. It has meant that throughout the countryside fences have been taken down and sections of stone walls dismantled.

Saturday was spent applying for an occupational licence. I downloaded the rules and regulations and application form and Peter took the forms to the vet in Hexham to be signed. We then wrote a covering letter explaining why we needed the licence and typed up every single ear tag number of every bovine on the place - because we cannot be certain which individual animal will need to be moved. At around 3pm I faxed nine pages to the relevant department at Maff, and now we wait. In theory this licence will allow repeated movement within a holding of a distance up to half a kilometre, but the licence must be carried at all times.

Meanwhile, we continue to wait and hope. We're all extremely grateful for the letters and phone calls that keep us going hour by hour, and that includes the team at the Breakfast Show on Radio 5 live.

fields.headline: I'm in the market, Tony
fields.standfirst: He was Thatcher's treasurer and adoring servant, but he isn't so impressed with William Hague. In fact, these days, Alistair McAlpine is beginning to sound like a very improbable Tory
fields.trailText: He was Thatcher's treasurer and adoring servant, but he isn't so impressed with William Hague. In fact, these days, Alistair McAlpine is beginning to sound like a very improbable Tory.
fields.body:
The sign on the door is confusing. Robert McAlpine, it says. A young man answers. No, he's not in, just popped out, is he expecting you? I ask whether I can leave a message, and trudge up narrow floor after narrow floor to the attic. The flat is in chaos. There are hammers and saws and wood shavings everywhere. Only the walls, decorated in gorgeous abstract paintings, look finished. Most people build their home first and then put up the pictures. Who is Robert McAlpine?

My phone rings. Alistair McAlpine is waiting for me at a cafe down the road. The sun is shining, McAlpine is smiling. He stands, like a landmark, in that checked suit that he's worn for ever. The former treasurer of the Tory party, Thatcher's jolly bagman, still looks as if his roly-poly body is going to topple over his tiny size six feet. Apart from Dennis, no one has remained as loyal to Thatcher as McAlpine. Dennis, Margaret and Alistair, they were a model family of sorts. Alistair, 20 or so years younger, the witty, smart, cultured son they never had.

We're walking down the street. McAlpine, 58, is apologising for his breathlessness. He says he has trouble breathing and talking at the same time these days, which can cause problems. Eighteen months ago he had a second heart bypass. It was supposed to be fairly routine, but things got nasty. McAlpine ended up having a deathbed conversion to Catholicism, calling for the bagpipes to revive him, and fighting like fury. He shows me a scar from the tracheotomy that saved his life. It looks no worse than a shaving rash, but this is why his voice has been reduced to a gravelly whisper.

" Robert McAlpine?" he says gnomically. "That's my grandfather." So the flat above the Notting Hill shop is his grandfather's? I'd heard that McAlpine had fallen on hard times."No, Robert McAlpine, the builder. I've got the builders in."

Ah. Robert McAlpine is the legendary Concrete Bob who made the McAlpines a formidably wealthy clan. So Alistair has got the family firm in to do some work on the cheap? "No, actually it ends up more expensive," he says. The builders expect a decent tip.

After leaving school with a couple of O-levels, Alistair McAlpine joined the building firm where he stayed for 16 years until he was called to politics by Thatcher. He raised the £100m that helped her win three elections. When all deserted her, he stood firm. He regarded her cabinet as minnows and traitors, and dismissed her successor John Major for "hanging about like a pair of curtains". Last election, he campaigned for the anti-European Referendum Party. Now he's on the turn again.

McAlpine has just read William Hague's speech, anticipating Britain as a foreign land. "I thought it was nonsense," he says. "The Tories were in power four years ago, and if they'd been so keen to save the pound they could have saved it then. Stroke of a pen, going through parliament - would have got it through in a moment. I just find it a bit hypocritical." He looks offended when I suggest Hague was trying to invoke Powell's river of blood speech. "No, no. Enoch was a man of massive intellect. He was a classical scholar. This was Hyde Park corner stuff, rabble rousing. I think Hague reads the editorial of the Daily Mail, and that's today's idea. He's a follower not a leader."

Whenever he talks about Major and Hague, you sense a golden shadow lurking. "The thing about Thatcher," he says suddenly, "love her or hate her, she had some philosophical ideas as to how to conduct her life and how to run a country." He loved her, of course. He won't say a word against her, just as he won't say a word in favour of those who knifed her. He has a penchant for one-liners, condemning his political foes (often former friends) with a velvet tongue. "Oh I like the one about Norman Lamont. Major said the recession is going to be shallow and short. I said the only aspect of this recession that is shallow and short is the chancellor of the exchequer. Hee! hee! hee!" He was always a bit of a one.

These days, post politics and with a peerage to his name, he makes his living as a writer. He has three books on the go. A typical McAlpine mix - a short philosophical guide to happiness, a short history of transport and trade, and an unfeasibly long guide to the world's museums. He says it's funny how often people have suggested that he never sticks to anything, whereas in fact he's only had three jobs in his life - builder, treasurer and writer. Admittedly, three very different jobs.

Change is important to him. All types of change - professional, political, personal. After being nursed back to health by his second wife, Romilly, he divorced her. There was no one else. He just felt the need to start again after 20 years' marriage. When he left his first wife and two daughters, his disabled mother hit him over the head with her walking stick. For years, his two daughters from the first marriage never spoke to him.

He and Thatcher made for an unlikely team: the joyless puritan and the urbane dandy. As a wealthy young man, he bought a series of paintings - six or seven of them - by a tyro called Rothko. He paid around two and a half grand for each of them, and everyone laughed at him. He talks about the terrible beauty of Rothko's death. "He cut his wrists in the bath and watched the bath water become a Rothko. Extraordinary that. Amazing way to die."

He never converted Thatcher to Rothko, but he did take her round galleries, encouraged her to dabble. "She had a very respectable collection of porcelain . . . figures, bowls and teacups." He casually mentions that, unlike her MPs, he always used to see her alone in the early days. It must have been a very special relationship, I say. "I don't know. It would be presumptuous of me to say so," he bumbles, lovestruck. "She was terribly kind to me, very thoughtful, very polite, very kind. Quite unlike the common picture that is painted of her at the time." Maybe she fancied him? "I don't think so!" He blushes. "No, I don't think so. I wasn't very fanciable in those days." He's talking very quickly. "Not that I am now. I was very big and fat and quite dishevelled."

A couple of years after Thatcher was dethroned, McAlpine wrote a book called The Servant, his take on Machiavelli's The Prince. To succeed in politics, he says, you need a prince and a servant and a Big Idea. Thatcher had been his prince, he had been her servant. He inverted the normal notion of a servant - a servant shouldn't be sycophantic, not a placeman, nor a ladder climber. He should be a man of independent means, as McAlpine had been.

When did he first realise Thatcher was a prince? "Margaret was always princely," he says. "But she never had a court in the way that Blair does." A few months ago the remaining loyalists organised a lunch for her to mark 25 years since she became Tory leader. "There were seven or eight people there in total. Just people who had been really close to her. Of them, certainly three had never been there at the start." Part-time supporters, he seems to be sniffing. Many of the original Thatcherites were dead - Keith Joseph, Ian Gow, Airey Neave. The last two were killed by the IRA, who also blew up his house. McAlpine was away at the time. He also came through the Brighton bomb unscathed. So many encounters with death, he says, so many escapes. He calls it a miracle.

Thatcher, Thatcherite, Thatcherism. A mantra. He calls her a true democrat, says her big idea was that anyone could be a patrician Tory, and that those who did well would look after those less fortunate. But wasn't Thatcherism about loadsamoney and I'm all right, Jack? "I remember talking to Margaret shortly after she lost power and her saying an aspect of the failure of her policies was that when she gave people responsibilities for their own affairs she also gave them responsibility to plough back the freedom that she'd given them so they would, for instance, support charitable things, and people hadn't really responded. You had the greed from cabinet ministers who went off and got good jobs, to the industrialists who made a lot of money, and money became a raison d'etre." The one person who remains blameless is Thatcher herself.

Political visions and visionaries always end up compromised, he says. He talks about the parallels between Thatcher and Blair - the way they reinvented their parties, made them electable, and then had to suffer the dilution of ideas. Is Blair the natural successor to Thatcher? "Well he's a damn sight more Conservative than John Major was." How? "Well Stephen Dorrell was never sacked by Major after saying that it's a very bad idea to own your own house. That's not conservatism for God's sake!" he says, spitting his cappuccino. The chocolate is stuck to his lips.

He explains the difference between a modern-day Tory - bigoted and crude - and a Thatcherite. Does he regard Blair as a Tory or a Thatcherite? "Oh I think he's a Thatcherite." He attacks those Tories who say Blair is an opportunist. "That's nonsense. I think he's more a man of principle than they realise." Perhaps Blair is his new prince? "Oh yes. I think there's something quite princely about Blair," he says excitedly. "Yeh, he could be a prince."

Not that he agrees with everything he's done. Take the bombing of Kosovo. "Completely detestable. The notion that you can fight a war where only one side gets hurt." And then there are Jack Straw's draconian policies. "I don't like this idea of double jeopardy being abolished, because the police will say, 'Bloody 'ell, he shouldn't have got off, we'll have him in the dock again.' Look, I couldn't stand Michael Howard as a home secretary, so imagine what I feel about Straw."

And drugs? "I'd certainly legalise pot. I took it once or twice. But I never found it satisfactory." That traditional line eh? Never inhaled, well not in front of the prime minister? He giggles. "Yes, not in the presence of the prime minister! " And finally, he's keen on a more progressive tax system. "I'd like to see a sliding scale of VAT where caviar was 100%, potatoes zero."

So he's somewhat more radical than Blair? "Possibly, yes." Eleven years is a long time in politics. He says of course he has changed since Thatcher resigned. "It's inconceivable when you think about something that you always come to the same conclusion. So you're bound to have a great stack of your life that you think that was wrong."

It's a quarter of a century since he found himself short of cash and sold his Rothkos. He received £10,000 for one of them and was rather chuffed. "About 15 years ago, the art dealer Lesley Waddington found an inventory of my art collection from the 60s. He had it valued, and it came to £80m. In those days a Rothko was a couple of hundred thousand. I think the last Rothko sold in New York for $24m." He also gave away much of his art to galleries.

I ask McAlpine what he's worth today. Well, he says, considerably less than the million he had as a young man. "I think most of that's gone". Does he regret not having made money from his art? "No," he says, "it's a vindication of all those years people said to my father, 'It's a shame about your son, he's a bit odd you know, I saw this blank painting in his house.'" You sense he would have been crippled by such wealth, that he was eager to unburden himself. In many ways, McAlpine has always been an unlikely Conservative.

So if Blair were to offer him a job in his cabinet would he accept? "Well look, half the Conservative party are in public positions for Tony Blair. Heseltine and Patten . . . If Tony Blair offered me a public position?" He deliberates. For a second. And then his eyes light up. "Course, I'd take it. Minister for the arts, why not?"

fields.headline: No 1836 Elvis
fields.trailText: That animatronic T-rex at the Natural History Museum is great. No, we're talking about another old fossil - Elvis Presley.
fields.body:
That animatronic T-rex at the Natural History Museum is great. No, we're talking about another old fossil - Elvis Presley.

Oh, the guy who works at my local garage during the day and then goes down to Tesco's for a night shift. Often to be seen on the moon as well. Yes, there have been several sightings since his death in 1977, mostly doing mundane things. But for many he is, and always will be, the greatest recording artist of all time.

My old man certainly thinks so. He transformed our spare room into a shrine to the old pretender. Well, your dad and the other million or so obsessives should start dusting down their diamante jumpsuits.

Why? Well for one thing, there's a film out about him on Friday. It follows his legendary performances at a Las Vegas hotel in 1970, thought by many to be his finest hour.

And? He's got a single coming out in a couple of weeks.

I knew it was him I saw at B&Q the other day! Quite possibly, though this is actually a re-release of Suspicious Minds, one of his old hits.

Any reason to bring it out now, nearly a quarter of a century after his death? Could be that he wants to get into the record books. At the moment he's only joint holder of the title for most UK number one singles, with 17.

But if this one goes to number one, he'll be outright winner, right? Uhuhuh.

With whom does he share his crown? The Beatles.

Some people blame the emergence of people like the Fab Four for the demise of the flab crooner. Will he be able to set the record straight? Quite possibly. One fan has already put in an advance order for 40 copies, and said he'd buy as many as it took to get Elvis to number one.

Don't say: Who ate all the pies?

Do say: The king is dead - long live the king!

webTitle: How the Irving case was won

fields.headline: First blood
fields.standfirst:
How the case was won before it reached court

An exclusive extract from The Holocaust on Trial
fields.trailText: How the case was won before it reached court
fields.body:
Lipstadt's lawyers needed access to Irving's material. "We decided that in order to win this case we needed to see what Irving had in his study," says James Libson, one of the lawyers from the firm of Mishcon de Reya, which represents her. But they also needed to get inside Irving's head, and documents alone wouldn't be enough. To Mishcon de Reya, discovery wasn't just about documents; it was about control.

Irving's complaint made clear that he intended to put the Holocaust on trial. Instead, Anthony Julius, who led Lipstadt's defence, would use discovery to put Irving on trial. He aimed to "run it as if it was a history seminar and Irving was a rather unintelligent student".

"We mounted a gigantic disclosure operation," says Libson. Both sides were required to make available to the opposing side any material either party had in its "possession, custody or power related to any matter in issue". Discovery itself is automatic. But if either side feels the other is holding back, they can apply for a court order to enforce "fuller and better" discovery.

"Irving's first discovery was just a list of his books, plus commendations of his work by other historians and some historical documents," says Libson. "There was no record of his contacts with rightwing extremists, and no diaries."

Julius would have to persuade a special judge, called a master, that Irving had held back documents, and that these were relevant.

The discovery hearings began on September 10, 1998 before Master John Trench. Over the preceding spring and summer, Libson and the two graduate students made regular visits to Irving's flat to inspect the material in his first list.

Some of what they wanted was in plain sight. The existence of Irving's diaries, for instance, was hardly a secret. Irving's position on the diaries - like his position on many other items - was minimalist. If the lawyers let him know which dates they wanted, Irving promised to take a look and see if there was any relevant material. If he found any, he would be happy to disclose it. Anything broader, he argued, would open his diaries to a fishing expedition by the defence.

Julius argued that since Irving brought this case, and the law said his client had a right to defend herself, that gave him a fishing licence. Irving's approach was to produce a mass of documents having little or nothing to do with the suit, but which Libson and his assistants were forced to read in order to rule them out. Included in Irving's first discovery, for instance, was a videotape recording the birth of his daughter, and audiotapes relating to the Kennedy assassination.

The hearings before Master Trench took two days. "When we got into court we were so well prepared," says Julius. "We broke down the kinds of documents into categories, and we gave the master a draft order we wanted him to make at the very beginning of the case."

In a way, from that point Irving lost the argument. With the master already in "I'm making an order" mode, the rest of the hearing just became a tussle over terms.

Irving knew he had been outboxed. It was time for a change in tactics. During the lunch break on the second day of discovery, he approached Penguin's lawyers. He would be willing, he told them, to settle the case for £500. Were they interested?

Later that evening, Irving sent his terms in writing to Davenport Lyons, Penguin's outside counsel: If Penguin would write him "an open letter withdrawing the allegations made" in Denying the Holocaust, would promise not to republish the book, and would "as a token of apology . . . pay the sum of £500 to the British Limbless ex-Servicemen's Association," Irving would drop Penguin from his action.

If Penguin did walk away from the suit - and there were sound business reasons to at least consider doing so - then that would be a serious blow to Lipstadt's credibility. Irving's offer came on a Friday. On Monday afternoon, Penguin turned him down.

How seriously had Penguin considered settlement? Anthony Julius had no way of knowing. But Julius wasn't taking any chances. He told Davenport Lyons that if Penguin settled on Irving's terms, he would move to have them bound back into the case - on Irving's side, ensuring a public relations disaster for Penguin. Cricket or not, this was hardball.

"Irving's first discovery was just a list of his books, plus commendations of his work by other historians and some historical documents," says Libson. "There was no record of his contacts with rightwing extremists, and no diaries." Julius would have to persuade a special judge, called a master, that Irving had held back documents, and that these were relevant. The discovery hearings began on September 10, 1998 before Master John Trench. Over the preceding spring and summer, Libson and the two graduate students made regular visits to Irving's flat to inspect the material in his first list. Some of what they wanted was in plain sight. The existence of Irving's diaries, for instance, was hardly a secret. Irving's position on the diaries - like his position on many other items - was minimalist. If the lawyers let him know which dates they wanted, Irving promised to take a look and see if there was any relevant material. If he found any, he would be happy to disclose it. Anything broader, he argued, would open his diaries to a fishing expedition by the defence. Julius argued that since Irving brought this case, and the law said his client had a right to defend herself, that gave him a fishing licence. Irving's approach was to produce a mass of documents having little or nothing to do with the suit, but which Libson and his assistants were forced to read in order to rule them out. Included in Irving's first discovery, for instance, was a videotape recording the birth of his daughter, and audiotapes relating to the Kennedy assassination. The hearings before Master Trench took two days. "When we got into court we were so well prepared," says Julius. "We broke down the kinds of documents into categories, and we gave the master a draft order we wanted him to make at the very beginning of the case." In a way, from that point Irving lost the argument. With the master already in "I'm making an order" mode, the rest of the hearing just became a tussle over terms. Irving knew he had been outboxed. It was time for a change in tactics. During the lunch break on the second day of discovery, he approached Penguin's lawyers. He would be willing, he told them, to settle the case for £500. Were they interested? Later that evening, Irving sent his terms in writing to Davenport Lyons, Penguin's outside counsel: If Penguin would write him "an open letter withdrawing the allegations made" in Denying the Holocaust, would promise not to republish the book, and would "as a token of apology . . . pay the sum of £500 to the British Limbless ex-Servicemen's Association," Irving would drop Penguin from his action. If Penguin did walk away from the suit - and there were sound business reasons to at least consider doing so - then that would be a serious blow to Lipstadt's credibility. Irving's offer came on a Friday. On Monday afternoon, Penguin turned him down. How seriously had Penguin considered settlement? Anthony Julius had no way of knowing. But Julius wasn't taking any chances. He told Davenport Lyons that if Penguin settled on Irving's terms, he would move to have them bound back into the case - on Irving's side, ensuring a public relations disaster for Penguin. Cricket or not, this was hardball.

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: The Observer
fields.body:
The Observer

Barclays paid out more than £150m in bonuses to executives in its investment banking division last year, infuriating the 50,000 high street staff who have borne the brunt of massive cost-cutting and branch closures.

Littlewoods has spent £500,000 on a luxury home for the use of its chief executive, Barry Gibson, at a time when the retailer is going through a cost-cutting and redundancy programme.

Sunday Telegraph

Nomura has entered the bidding war for the Midlands-based Wolverhampton & Dudley pubs and brewing business. The financing arm of the Japanese bank recently bought 1,000 pubs from Bass.

Joel Cadbury, the entrepreneur behind the bid for the Groucho Club, is planning a £20m float of his health club and leisure business within the next two months.

Liverpool Victoria, the country's biggest friendly society, is preparing to launch a £500m bid for National Mutual, the mutual pensions company which put itself up for sale last week.

Sunday Times

The Bank of England is on course to cut base rates to 5.25% this year, as inflation heads below 1.5% and America's economic slowdown is felt in Britain, analysts say.

Kingfisher's chief executive, Sir Geoff Mulcahy, is this week likely to pour cold water on hopes of an early sale for Superdrug, the retailer of chemists' sundries. The group is in talks with Kruidvat, a Dutch pharmacy chain, but hopes of a £300m-£350m early sale are evaporating.

Billionaire financier George Soros is supporting the introduction of a tax on foreign exchange transactions. The tax - known as the Tobin tax after the American Nobel prize-winning economist who invented it - is levied to help poorer countries.

Airtours is selling its hotels as new chief executive, Tim Byrne, attempts to improve the group's efficiency.

Mail on Sunday

Atomic energy company BNFL has drawn up plans to replace its eight Magnox power stations with a new generation of nuclear plans. BNFL plans to wait until after the election before announcing the plans.

Sunday Business

The Dutch-British oil company Shell is planning to increase its bid for US gas exploration company Carrett Resources to $2.8bn. Its $2.2bn bid last week was rejected.

Up to 10,000 City jobs could be lost if the current lull in corporate activity persists.

Sunday Express

Tesco is considering expanding in the Middle East as part of the supermarket chain's drive to become a global giant.

Terry Benson, chief executive of recruitment firm Michael Page, earned £2.4m last year, according to its stock market flotation prospectus to be published later this month. The pay deal means Mr Benson earned more than the Barclays boss Matt Barrett or Martin Sorrell at WPP.

Independent

Property group Chelsfield is preparing to sell off a half share in its much-delayed £1.5bn retail and leisure development at White City, west London.

Gerald Corbett, the new chairman of Woolworths, has agreed to a £100,000 cut in the £400,000 golden handshake he was due to receive from Railtrack, his former employer.

fields.headline: Teenfront thrives against all odds
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Last week's experience in the US brought home to us the global nature of the dot.com shakeout. Although delegates at the conference we attended were far from depressed, there was a far less jubilant atmosphere than just 12 months ago.
fields.body:
Last week's experience in the US brought home to us the global nature of the dot.com shakeout. Although delegates at the conference we attended were far from depressed, there was a far less jubilant atmosphere than just 12 months ago.

The overall picture may be bleak - the performance charts at www.nasdaq.com are proof enough - but there are some individual success stories. The home-grown talent at Teenfront.com is an example. They are using the downturn to expand their own business, having recently bought a couple of other teen-orientated sites. The network they are carefully building will soon encompass a more mature news site, a comprehensive chat network and the original all-singing, all-dancing Teenfront.com content and services.

After spending months developing content and enhancing the design of the site, they are seeing a significant increase in visitors to the site, with as many people visiting in the first week of March as in the whole of January.

Impressive figures, and big advertisers are starting to take note. Teenfront.com recently completed an important promotional deal with a government body and are in discussions with big teen brands. We work closely with Teenfront.com on strategy and have encouraged them to focus on their strengths -their unique proposition and loyal customer base.

It seems that their bottom-up approach is paying off. With more visitors they are able to afford more content, without significant marketing spend. Awareness is being built primarily by word-of-mouth recommendation, both off and online. It's been interesting to see from tracked visitor movements that the immediate online sources of most of the recent boost in traffic have been weblinks secured with major ISPs, and a couple of key cashless banner exchanges.

The business still faces major challenges. The chilly dot.com winds can not be ignored. It is not yet profitable. But at least it has a clear plan for getting there.

149&#; Adam Hamdy and Guy Mallison are co-founders of rools.com, an online payments service for teenagers.

fields.headline: Letter: Alan Ross
fields.trailText: Clayton Goodwin writes: Through The Caribbean, the cricket book which was written by London Magazine editor Alan Ross (obituary February 16) made a tremendous impression on me. I was a student and had never been outside of England. Three years later, I met the Jamaican girl who became my wife and I went on to become an adopted Jamaican.
fields.body:
Clayton Goodwin writes: Through The Caribbean, the cricket book which was written by London Magazine editor Alan Ross (obituary February 16) made a tremendous impression on me. I was a student and had never been outside of England. Three years later, I met the Jamaican girl who became my wife and I went on to become an adopted Jamaican.

Later, several of the people of whom I read of first in Alan's book became good friends - not least Professor John Figueroa - and in the early 1980s, I followed Alan's route around the major islands. Even Harry's Niterie - entrance permitted to everyone except "nuns, virgins and jackasses" - in Bridgetown. Thanks for the memory.

fields.headline: Sir Richard Foster
fields.standfirst: Curator renowned as Merseyside's first director of national museums
fields.trailText: In a museum world which sometimes seems obsessed with mission statements, marketing strategy, and visitor profiling, Sir Richard Foster, who has been found dead on a beach in Dorset aged 59, still spoke with passion of the wonderful objects, the superb paintings, and indeed the great buildings in his collection.
fields.body:
In a museum world which sometimes seems obsessed with mission statements, marketing strategy, and visitor profiling, Sir Richard Foster, who has been found dead on a beach in Dorset aged 59, still spoke with passion of the wonderful objects, the superb paintings, and indeed the great buildings in his collection.

The Victorian merchant princes of Liverpool left their city as richly endowed as any in the land, and for a century the city itself was rich enough, and proud enough, for the local authorities to buy lavishly. The result was a string of local museums with collections of national or international importance, but no national profile except among the most knowledgeable connoisseurs.

In 1986 the museums were brought together as the national museums and galleries on Merseyside, and Foster became their first director.

Just caring for the collections - ensuring that the roof over them was reasonably weather-tight, that there were enough working light bulbs to see them by, and enough staff to open the doors and let the people in - would have been more than enough to keep one man busy. This was Merseyside in the 1980s, remember.

But he kept adding to his task: the Maritime museum, and the first major gallery devoted to slavery within it - politically correct enough to be boringly worthy now, bitterly contentious when he championed it - the museum of Liverpool life, the complete renovation of the Walker art gallery and, above all, the conservation centre. The latter sounded dull, but was amazing, turning the tedious backstage routine of conservation work into thrilling public theatre: Foster called it his "hospital for sick objects". It won every museum award going the year it opened, including a major Unesco European award, though the judges had to invent new categories to describe it.

The revitalised Merseyside museums joined forces with the Tate's first outstation to transform the city waterfront from a graveyard of industrial jobs into a major cultural destination. The concept had seemed ludicrous in the 1970s, when I came from Dublin to see the first garden festival, and stood shivering in the shattered landscape, listening politely to a council tourism officer predict that tourism would eventually replace all the docklands jobs and more: the reality is there today for millions to visit.

I first spoke to Foster when the council was literally selling the family silver: a superb Georgian wine cooler which had stood in the city hall since it was made. It would have been a nice thing to have in his museums, and he could fairly easily have raised the grant aid to buy it - but he was full of a fine and proper rage at the council's shortsighted betrayal of the civic pride which put the splendid thing there in the first place.

He was a director with an unmistakeable belief that museums belonged to the people, not to the trustees.

Foster was educated at Kingswood School in Bath, then studied economics at the London School of Economics. His interest in museums started early and, in 1964 , at the age of 23, he became student assistant at Leicester museum.

It was the start of a decade of museum work, during which he learned his trade in a string of major local museums including, the Bowes, the Durham Light Infantry and Oxford county.

Behind their calm imposing, classical facades, a battle is still raging over whether national museums should be run by herbivore curators or carnivorous business managers: Foster, ran the business but was a museums man to his well-polished toe caps, and will be much missed.

He was knighted in the millennium honours list. He is survived by his wife Mary, whom he married in 1964, and his two sons and a daughter.

Sir Richard Anthony Foster, museums director, born October 3 1941; died March 8 2001.

A version of this obituary appeared in later editions of last Saturday's Guardian.

fields.headline: Recount shows Gore had won
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Fresh evidence has emerged in Florida that Al Gore might have won last year's presidential election under a less contentious voting system, and if the US supreme court had not stepped in to stop the recount.
fields.body:
Fresh evidence has emerged in Florida that Al Gore might have won last year's presidential election under a less contentious voting system, and if the US supreme court had not stepped in to stop the recount.

A comprehensive new survey of "undervotes" in Palm Beach county shows that Mr Gore would have gained 784 more votes than George Bush if every excluded paper bearing some kind of mark next to a candidate's name had been counted.

The butterfly ballot, which has candidates' names on opposing pages with a row of punch holes in the middle, confused thousands of voters in the Democratic stronghold, which was one of the areas at the centre of the post-election recount battle.

Those Palm Beach votes would have been enough on their own for Mr Gore to overtake Mr Bush, who was declared the winner in Florida by a statewide margin of 537 votes.

The Palm Beach recount figures came too late to be included in the official tally of votes certified by the Florida secretary of state Katherine Harris 19 days after the November 7 election.

The new survey, conducted by the Palm Beach Post, looked at all the 9,150 disputed undervotes of all kinds, including 5,736 which contained marks next to the names of Mr Bush and Mr Gore and which Judge Burton ordered should not be counted.

The researchers found that these dimpled chads held the key to Mr Gore's chances.

webTitle: Opticians angry over threat of £10 'eyesight tax'

fields.headline: Opticians angry over threat of £10 'eyesight tax'
fields.trailText: Opticians warned last night that the government is about to impose an "eyesight tax" on the dispensing of spectacles and contact lenses, including those for children.
fields.body:
Opticians warned last night that the government is about to impose an "eyesight tax" on the dispensing of spectacles and contact lenses, including those for children.

The tax, which would add about £10 to the cost of every purchase, was not mentioned by the chancellor in his budget last week. It is to be levied from June after a judgment in the House of Lords with far-reaching implications for VAT law.

The Royal National Institute for Deaf People said it was told by Customs and Excise on Friday that the judgment was also likely to lead to VAT on the private dispensing of hearing aids.

A Customs spokesman told the Guardian that its move was limited to opticians, but an official told the RNID that the judgment would eventually affect other services.

This could add 10-15% to the price of the latest digital hearing aids that are not yet available on the NHS in most areas and retail for about £2,500.

The decision by Customs to move against the opticians followed years of argument about whether their dispensing services should be exempt from VAT.

The tax was imposed in 1988, but lifted in 1995 after the courts ruled that VAT should only be levied on frames and lenses - not the cost of the advice given to customers before they decided on their purchases.

Customs decided to reintroduce the tax after a recent House of Lords ruling in an apparently unrelated case about credit card protection services. The department said this redefined VAT law. The implication for opticians was that their dispensing services should be regarded as an essential part of their sale of spectacles and therefore taxable.

The Federation of Ophthalmic and Dispensing Opticians said it was seeking an urgent meeting with health ministers to overturn the decision by "irresponsible" Customs officials that could force the closure of opticians in areas and small towns threatening the availability of eye tests.

Bob Hughes, general secretary of the federation, said: "The VAT imposed would have to be passed on to patients. The current average cost for a pair of spectacles at £108.19 would need to increase by more than £10 for opticians to retain their current level of return. One result would be that the recent introduction of free eye examinations for those aged 60 and over would be mostly negated by the need to increase spectacle prices.

"For children and those on low incomes, it will become increasingly difficult to obtain corrective eyewear without paying a supplement on top of the current NHS vouchers."

A spokesman for Customs said opticians gained £275m in 1995 when the department repaid VAT that he been levied over the previous seven years. "We said they should pass that saving on to their customers. They refused. If they kept the money then, they should not pass on the tax to their customers this time," he said.

The RNID said the ruling would have a serious impact on 180,000 people who buy private hearing aids every year.

Although 88% of aids were provided free on the NHS, people in most parts of the country had to buy privately if they wanted the latest technology.

The price was already expensive. Nearly three quarters of the cost of a hearing aid went to pay for the work done by the audiologist dispensing it that until now has been exempt from VAT.

James Strachan, chief executive of RNID, said: "Far too many people, in desperation and often having to go into debt, buy hearing aids privately because of the inadequacies of the NHS. To add to this a 10-15% tax burden is astonishing. Any caring government would eliminate the effect of this decision as a priority."

The decision by Customs to move against the opticians followed years of argument about whether their dispensing services should be exempt from VAT. The tax was imposed in 1988, but lifted in 1995 after the courts ruled that VAT should only be levied on frames and lenses - not the cost of the advice given to customers before they decided on their purchases. Customs decided to reintroduce the tax after a recent House of Lords ruling in an apparently unrelated case about credit card protection services. The department said this redefined VAT law. The implication for opticians was that their dispensing services should be regarded as an essential part of their sale of spectacles and therefore taxable. The Federation of Ophthalmic and Dispensing Opticians said it was seeking an urgent meeting with health ministers to overturn the decision by "irresponsible" Customs officials that could force the closure of opticians in areas and small towns threatening the availability of eye tests. Bob Hughes, general secretary of the federation, said: "The VAT imposed would have to be passed on to patients. The current average cost for a pair of spectacles at £108.19 would need to increase by more than £10 for opticians to retain their current level of return. One result would be that the recent introduction of free eye examinations for those aged 60 and over would be mostly negated by the need to increase spectacle prices. "For children and those on low incomes, it will become increasingly difficult to obtain corrective eyewear without paying a supplement on top of the current NHS vouchers." A spokesman for Customs said opticians gained £275m in 1995 when the department repaid VAT that he been levied over the previous seven years. "We said they should pass that saving on to their customers. They refused. If they kept the money then, they should not pass on the tax to their customers this time," he said. The RNID said the ruling would have a serious impact on 180,000 people who buy private hearing aids every year. Although 88% of aids were provided free on the NHS, people in most parts of the country had to buy privately if they wanted the latest technology. The price was already expensive. Nearly three quarters of the cost of a hearing aid went to pay for the work done by the audiologist dispensing it that until now has been exempt from VAT. James Strachan, chief executive of RNID, said: "Far too many people, in desperation and often having to go into debt, buy hearing aids privately because of the inadequacies of the NHS. To add to this a 10-15% tax burden is astonishing. Any caring government would eliminate the effect of this decision as a priority."

webTitle: Tube managers get new safety standards

fields.headline: Tube managers get new safety standards
fields.standfirst: Special report: Livingstone's London
fields.trailText: London Underground management will this week receive a new checklist of safety issues which must be cleared before the government's partial privatisation of LU goes ahead, on top of a list of 69 key issues on overcrowding and emergency evacuation which emerged last week.
fields.body:
London Underground management will this week receive a new checklist of safety issues which must be cleared before the government's partial privatisation of LU goes ahead, on top of a list of 69 key issues on overcrowding and emergency evacuation which emerged last week.

The new list from the health and safety executive is said to cover administrative matters and will not necessarily delay action already being taken by LU's management. But HSE officials believe that the exercise will take LU at least 10 weeks to complete and will damage government hopes of completing the partial privatisation by the end of March.

HSE staff are under pressure from John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, to hasten their approval of a new safety case for the government's public private partnership.

Official figures issued today by the Capital Transport Campaign, the independent organisation which lobbies for better public transport in London, confirm that safety remains one of the most important issues on the underground.

The figures, obtained from the Department of Transport, reveal the maximum number of passengers that can be carried in a single underground carriage. "Very crowded" on the tube is defined by the government as when there are five or more standing for every four seated. The government's "planned standard" is for one person standing for each seated.

Official LU figures for each line show that the Hammersmith and City line is allowed to have maximum crowding of 563%. A train of 212 passengers seated is allowed to carry 180 passengers standing.

The Central line is allowed to carry 210 seated and 180 standing (518%), the Bakerloo line 194 passengers seated and 158 standing (439%), and the Victoria line 192 passengers and 156 standing (433%).

Overcrowding is one of the main issues which has not been resolved to the satisfaciton of the HSE, although it cannot challenge government rules on overcrowding which are never enforced.

But the HSE has told London Underground that it must deal with the problem of overcrowding at stations. It wants information on crowd management, risk assessments for both employees and the public and the measures in place to control crowds.

It wants details on emergency routes, procedures for deciding the level of evacuation, and the arrangements for communicating through staff and the public in an emergency.

The HSE is aware that some stations are not manned at all times and that in the event of an emergency.

The HSE has been warning the industry for several months that it is unhappy at LU's safety case and it will reject the plan if significant improvements are not made.

fields.headline: Man held over boy's death
fields.trailText: A 35-year-old man is to appear in court in connection with the death of a four-year-old boy, police said yesterday.
fields.body:
A 35-year-old man is to appear in court in connection with the death of a four-year-old boy, police said yesterday.

Luke Gargan was reported missing after his mother found his bed empty at their home in Saltcoats, Ayrshire, at 7.20am on Saturday.

A huge search, backed up by divers and helicopters, followed. A child's body was later found in the Lochwinnoch area, a Strathclyde police spokesman said yesterday, and it was later identified as Luke.

The man will appear before Kilmarnock sheriff court today.

webTitle: Marchioness families furious at organ storage

fields.headline: Marchioness families furious at organ storage
fields.standfirst:
Relatives learn in wake of inquiries into riverboat disaster that victims' body parts were removed in hospital

More about the Marchioness disaster
fields.trailText: Families of victims of the Marchioness river boat disaster were yesterday devastated by new claims that tissue, and possibly whole organs, were taken from bodies without consent.
fields.body:
Families of victims of the Marchioness river boat disaster were yesterday devastated by new claims that tissue, and possibly whole organs, were taken from bodies without consent.

They want John Prescott, the deputy prime minister, to investigate allegations that body parts were stored for more than a decade in glass jars in a London hospital.

The development is bound to reignite the debate over the retention of body parts after the scandals at Alder Hey hospital and the Bristol Royal Infirmary.

Relatives of Marchioness victims have long harboured suspicions that in some cases the bodies were not returned complete. But it has always been denied that organs were removed.

Now, if it is proven, more than a decade on, that organs or tissue were taken, families will face the prospect of holding second funerals. Some are already considering legal action.

Fifty-one people died when the Marchioness sank after colliding with the dredger Bowbelle on the river Thames in 1989.

Two reports into the disaster, which were ordered by Mr Prescott and are being overseen by Lord Justice Clarke, are due to be made public within the next two weeks.

One report is a criminal report into who was responsible for the collision and the second is a non-statutory process examining the identification procedure, including why 25 victims had their hands cut off for fingerprinting tests.

The bereaved were originally told that only blood and urine samples were taken for tests for drugs and alcohol.

During the non-statutory inquiry a pathologist, Richard Shepherd, who at the time of the disaster was a lecturer in forensic medicine at Guy's hospital and took a leading role in the postmortem examinations, admitted that "if appropriate" tissue was retained for study.

However, Margaret Lockwood Croft, who has led the Marchioness Action Group for nearly 11 years, yesterday said she was told after the inquiries that containers holding tissues or body parts of four of the victims had been found in the mortuary.

She said that tissue from lungs, kidneys, hearts, brain and spleen was discovered. Mrs Lockwood Croft said it was possible that material had been taken from many more than four victims.

Mrs Lockwood Croft, who first became suspicious after not being allowed to see her son's body when it was returned to her, said: "Some families want to know exactly what was taken from their loved ones. Many now face the trauma of reburials."

Eileen Dallaglio, the mother of one of the youngest victims, 19-year-old Francesca, said: "It's appalling. I feel our human rights have been violated. There is something wrong with a society which fails to give parents the choice about what happens to their dead children." The 1961 Human Tissue Act made it lawful for a doctor to authorise removal of body parts for medical education or research purposes "if, having made such reasonable inquiry as may be practicable, he has no reason to believe" that any relative objects.

In scandals such as Alder Hey, where organs were systematically stripped from children, the crux was the way doctors interpreted the law and how much information was given to parents.

Many parents of children who had died at Alder Hey agreed to "tissue" being removed, only to find later that their child's entire organ system had been stripped out.

Following the publication of the Alder Hey report, Alan Milburn, the health secretary, announced a series of measures intended to make sure the scandal is never repeated.

A spokeswoman for Mr Prescott's Department of Transport, which ordered the Marchioness inquiries, said the tissue was removed as part of standard postmortem procedure. Lord Justice Clarke's report is due to be published this month.

 Doctors should spend more time explaining procedures to patients to ensure they have their full consent to treatment, according to guidelines published today by the British Medical Association.

A BMA working party charged with drawing up the guidance found that consent was seen too much as getting people to sign a form rather than as an ongoing process.

webTitle: Russia starts to make a legend

fields.headline: Russia starts to make a legend
fields.standfirst: Praise the face, the name, the very footsteps of Putin
fields.trailText: In Vladimir Putin's native city Alexander Palmin spends most of his time among the heroes of Russian history. His studio by the banks of the Neva is crammed with icons and statues, busts and torsos representing the Russian pantheon.
fields.body:
In Vladimir Putin's native city Alexander Palmin spends most of his time among the heroes of Russian history. His studio by the banks of the Neva is crammed with icons and statues, busts and torsos representing the Russian pantheon.

There is Peter the Great and Alexander Nevsky, Pyotr Stolypin and Fyodor Dostoevsky. But taking pride of place on a black pedestal, incongruous among the historic images, sits the chalk-white face of President Putin, the only likeness of a living man in the studio.

The incongruity is lost on Mr Palmin, a patriot who regards the president as the first Russian leader in his lifetime worthy of the name.

"Putin is a historic figure, too. He has already gone down in history," the sculptor enthuses at a studio table laden with hors d'oeuvres and vodka.

"Unlike the rest of my work, this," he says, pointing to the 25cm (10in) bust, "is not a memorial. It's a tribute."

Less than a year after his election as Russia's second president, Mr Putin is already being cast in bronze. He is also being immortalised in oil on canvas and in children's schoolbooks.

Village mayors commemorate his fleeting visits with "In Putin's Footsteps" tours of the muddy streets where the president trod.

Ski slopes are to bear the president's name, and there is talk of churches being blessed with it too.

Spin doctors say that Mr Putin is the only actor on Russia's political stage. Newspaper polls are organised to reveal that Russian women think Mr Putin the sexiest man in Russia. The pollsters liken him to a doctor with the Russian people as his patients.

In short, the phenomenon of Mr Putin, an unknown bureaucrat as recently as two years ago, is acquiring the proportions of a personality cult.

"We supported him, we support him now, and we will continue to support him unconditionally," says Viktor Yurakov, a St Petersburg politician who is the local cheerleader-in-chief for the president.

The myth-making that surrounds his inscrutable character echoes for many the personality cults erected around the Soviet Union's communist dictators: figures such as Lenin and Stalin acquired iconic quasi-religious status in a society that was officially atheistic.

The veneration of Mr Putin, whether genuine or engineered, is particularly evident in St Petersburg.

While Mr Palmin transforms his Putin bust from plaster to wax and then bronze, a local businessman has just discovered that Mr Putin planted a maple tree by the city's Canadian consulate nearly six years ago, when he was a city official.He has slapped a brass plaque on the tree which reads: Planted by V Putin October 7 1995.

In October Mr Yurakov handed out a cartoon booklet to the city's infants on their first day at primary school with snapshots from the president's childhood.

"No one knew he would be president," the booklet gushed. "But all the boys and girls knew that Volodya Putin was a real pal you could count on. Then he grew up, studied and worked hard, helped good people and did not like bad people at all."

Vladimir Ivchenko, who helped design the booklet, says: "We just wanted to show our pride that a good lad has taken over. He's good, he's strong, he's decent, he's ours and he's president now."

Outside St Petersburg, the little village of Izborsk was the site of an unscheduled stop by the presidential motorcade last August.

Visitors to the village are now treated to a walking tour which marks the spots "where Putin bought a cucumber", "where Putin took off his jacket and tried water from a spring", and "where Putin touched a tree and made a wish".

But if St Petersburg is leading the presidential myth-making, Moscow, too, is doing its part.

A gallery in the capital recently mounted an exhibition of presidential portraits, entitled Our Putin, featuring the leader as a stiff-jawed visionary.

Nikas Safronov, one of Moscow's most popular painters, is churning out oil paintings of a steely-eyed president peering out into Russia from the Kremlin's walls. They combine Stalinist socialist realism with Russian heritage kitsch.

Nostalgia, mood music, and popular psychology are clearly key ingredients in Mr Putin's recipe for success.

He has publicly discouraged the hero worship, telling Russian interviewers in December: "I understand that when somebody does such things, he or she is probably guided by the best of intentions, and that he or she thinks well of me.

"I would like to thank them, but ask them not to do this. [But] I cannot actively stop this."

Mr Yurakov has been reprimanded by the Kremlin for being too crude in his hero-worship. But he attributes that to Muscovite jealousy and the traditional rivalry between the two cities.

"Putin just said thanks, but I don't need this. He's modest. He didn't criticise us. He can't forbid us loving him."

Whether throwing combatants on the judo mat, leaping into jet fighters or cutting a dash down the ski slopes of Austria or the Caucasus, Mr Putin, despite his coyness, is acutely aware of cultivating the image of an action man on Russia's television screens.

His KGB past, too, however uneventful, is milked for all its mysterious allure.

In St Petersburg, Mr Palmin is plotting a little private party to unveil the first bronze Putin later this month, marking the president's election last March.

"Putin is the first living politician I've done. I'd refuse to do Yeltsin or Gorbachev," he says. "Maybe it recalls the Soviet era, but that's not so bad. Not everything was bad in Soviet times."

webTitle: Women fill the streets as Bogota corrals its men

fields.headline: Women fill the streets as Bogota corrals its men
fields.trailText: It was the first time for Ana Lucia Preciado, 42, unemployed, the mother of two. On Friday she left her electrician husband at home and headed off for a night on the town with some women friends.
fields.body:
It was the first time for Ana Lucia Preciado, 42, unemployed, the mother of two. On Friday she left her electrician husband at home and headed off for a night on the town with some women friends.

"It's marvellous. I've never been out in the night before. Normally it's too dangerous ... But tonight I feel free to walk, free from oppression," she said, strolling down a blocked-off avenue in Bogota.

To force its inhabitants to reconsider their attitudes, the eccentric mayor, Antanas Mockus, declared a voluntary men's curfew to leave the city free for a Night of the Women. The men were told to stay home and watch the kids.

Thousands went to women-only concerts, poetry readings and cycle rides, while 1,500 policewomen patrolled the streets. Despite the carnival atmosphere, it was a radical step for this decidedly macho society: a recent survey found that 40% of men will not let their wives go out alone.

Mrs Preciado's neighbour, for one, decided not to join in. "She could have come out, but her husband would probably beat her tomorrow."

Outside the nightclubs on stylish 93rd Street, crowds of women spilled on to the road, drinking, singing and dancing to salsa bands.

"We can have a good time without them, we don't miss them at all. We can even talk about them behind their backs," Sandra Moreno, a 25-year-old lab technician, said over cocktails with friends.

There were safe conduct passes for men who wanted to break the curfew, but they risked being pelted with flour and water by women shouting "Go home, there's housework to be done."

From the doorway of a bar, Mohammed Ali, a warder at the women's jail in the city, was unimpressed.

"I don't agree with the clowning of this idiot mayor," he growled. "They don't have the right to stop us going out. We own the street."

Mr Mockus, best-known for baring his buttocks to rowdy students when he was the rector of the National University, stayed in to read stories to his four-year old daughter.

He said the curfew was an attempt to make the people of Bogota confront its rampant street crime, domestic violence and absentee fathers.

"We want to let women take over the city's public space and increase men's participation in the domestic space," he said.

webTitle: Accusations fly as Uganda goes to polls

fields.headline: Accusations fly as Uganda goes to polls
fields.trailText: Thousands gathered at a disused airstrip in the Ugandan capital Kampala yesterday for the last rally by President Yoweri Museveni on the eve of presidential election. He promised lower taxes and road improvements if he was elected for a final five-year term.
fields.byline: Anna Borzello and Chris Tomlinson in Kampala
fields.body:
Thousands gathered at a disused airstrip in the Ugandan capital Kampala yesterday for the last rally by President Yoweri Museveni on the eve of presidential election. He promised lower taxes and road improvements if he was elected for a final five-year term.

At a press conference earlier yesterday, Mr Museveni denied opposition claims that his campaigners were intimidating voters. and said he would win the election easily. He said it was his challengers who were threatening the voters.

He accused the main oppo sition candidate, Kizza Besigye, of trying to restore to power those responsible for the brutal dictatorships of Idi Amin and Milton Obote.

webTitle: 120,000 damn the plan to transfer Spanish water

fields.headline: 120,000 damn the plan to transfer Spanish water
fields.trailText: A war for water reached the streets of Madrid yesterday as 120,000 protesters marched to demand the scrapping of the government's plan to build 110 dams and pipe huge amounts of water from the Ebro river in northern Spain to the parched south-east.
fields.body:
A war for water reached the streets of Madrid yesterday as 120,000 protesters marched to demand the scrapping of the government's plan to build 110 dams and pipe huge amounts of water from the Ebro river in northern Spain to the parched south-east.

The protesters, who had travelled hundreds of miles from towns and villages along the Ebro in Aragon and Catalonia, accused Jose Maria Aznar's conservative Popular party government of "ecological terrorism".

They said the plan to divert water to the fruit and vegetable growing regions of Murcia, Valencia and Almeria would cause incalculable environmental damage.

They warned that the vast freshwater wetlands at the mouth of the Ebro could disappear as the silt which maintains the delta became trapped by the dams.

The delta's rice farmers said that saltwater would creep inland, ruining their rice fields.

The protesters said lower water levels would damage both farming and the environ ment throughout the Ebro valley, which snakes for 600 miles from the Cantabrian mountains near Santander on the Bay of Biscay down to the Mediterranean near Tarragona, 60 miles south of Barcelona.

They urged the government to concentrate on making sure that that farmers do not waste water. The irrigation system in the Jucar valley in Valencia, one of the region's which will get water from the Ebro, loses 60% of the water pumped into it.

The protesters said that the plan, intended to end decades of protests about the unfair distribution of water in Spain, would force people to migrate from the Ebro valley.

"Are we all going to have to move to the coast and all work in the holiday industry for British and German visitors?" one said.

Opposition parties want to take water from the Rhne in France, where the authorities have said they are prepared to have it transferred across the frontier, or build a dozen desalination plants.

Madrid says these options as too expensive. The environment minister, Jaume Matas, says he plans to take only 20% of the water that the Ebro normally spills into the Mediterranean.

But one of the protester, a water engineer called Josep Franquet, said the water reaching the sea had already been halved in the past 40 years by irrigation systems and dams. The government's plans would halve that amount again, he said.

The secretary of state for water, Pascual Hernandez, insisted yesterday that the Ebro had produced excess water for 15 of the past 17 years.

"The Ebro has enough water to provide for its own needs and to supply those areas which do not have enough water to drink or for their other needs," he said.

Mr Aznar has set himself the task of solving a problem that has kept the north and south feuding for more than 50 years.

Previous governments shied away from pumping water south because of the protests in the north.

The agriculture minister, Miguel Arias Canete, has enraged the protesters by boasting that the Popular party has the balls to do it.

webTitle: Paris poised for the left turn of the century

fields.headline: Paris poised for the left turn of the century
fields.trailText: This time next week, for the first time in modern history, the Left Bank may actually be left and gay "Paree" may have as its mayor the first publicly declared homosexual French politician to hold a post of national importance.
fields.body:
This time next week, for the first time in modern history, the Left Bank may actually be left and gay "Paree" may have as its mayor the first publicly declared homosexual French politician to hold a post of national importance.

The French went to the polls yesterday in local elections whose results will be known only after a second round of voting next Sunday. But Paris already seems to have made up its mind about Bertrand Delanoe, the Socialist candidate poised to put an end to a quarter-century of conservative rule.

France, from the remotest hamlet in rural Provence to the capital, is electing 36,615 mayors. Although the Socialists, headed by the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, seem about to make big gains throughout the country, it is the Paris contest that has dominated the headlines.

Just over a year before the parliamentary and presidential elections, the loss of the capital would be a huge blow to the Gaullist party, the RPR, and President Jacques Chirac, who as mayor from 1977 to 1995 ran the capital as his personal fiefdom before moving on to the Elysée palace.

Colourless and determined, Mr Delanoe has been involved in Parisian politics for more than 20 years. He has run a campaign based mainly on his lack of ambition for a bigger political stage, and is on the brink of handing the Gaullists one of the most embarrassing defeats in their history.

He has been helped by his opponents' inability to get behind a single candidate, run a convincing campaign, or rebut evidence of vote-rigging, corruption and blatant cronyism during their years in power.

"The situation in Parisian politics at the moment is really quite extraordinary," said Dominique Moisi, a political ana lyst at the French Institute of International Relations.

"The right is going to end up losing in a city whose social make-up should mean that victory is guaranteed. The RPR has quite simply imploded."

Not surprisingly, Mr Delanoe has made transparency and accountability his most prominent policy planks.

"For 24 years Paris has been run by an organised system of fake jobs, kickbacks and phoney electors," he said. "I have always fought against this system. My first act as candidate was to define and impose a drastic moral code."

His other big issues are mainly about quality of life and the environment, including more green spaces and fewer cars. Parisians seem to have bought that, as well as the notion that here is a man who may be rather too serious but who can at least be counted on not to raid the public coffers.

Born in 1950 in Tunis, Mr Delanoe studied in Rodez and Toulouse before working his way up the Socialist party hierarchy. Dubbed le renard du Marais (the fox of the Marais, Paris's main gay area), he is open about his sexuality but says he is a politician who happens to be gay rather than a "gay politician".

The latest polls suggested that at one extreme the left, which has never previously held more than six of the city's 20 arrondissements, could seize a remarkable 17.

fields.headline: Afghan Buddhas lost for ever
fields.trailText: The Taliban's demolition of two giant statues of Buddha has been independently confirmed for the first time.
fields.body:
The Taliban's demolition of two giant statues of Buddha has been independently confirmed for the first time.

A reliable western source said that truckloads of dynamite were brought in on Thursday and Friday to complete their destruction.

The local militia drilled holes, planted the dynamite and shaved off layer after layer of rock by a series of explosions over 48 hours, the source said. "They have planed back most of what had been the bodies of the Buddhas."

The UN secretary general, Kofi Annan, flew to Islamabad on Saturday with a plan to save the Buddhas, which were carved in sandstone cliffs near the central city of Bamiyan almost 2,000 years ago.

Mr Annan met the Taliban foreign minister, Wakil Ahmed Muttawakil, yesterday.

Mr Muttawakil said he recognised that the destruction did not help the Taliban's image abroad, but external relations were secondary to religious interests.

He said the statues' demolition had begun and all other "moveable statues" in Afghanistan had been destroyed.

The Taliban said that 59 Buddhist images were destroyed in the national museum in Kabul on February 5 and 6.

After yesterday's meeting, Mr Annan said: "I must say if they do carry through this lamentable decision they will be doing themselves a great deal of disservice.

"I did discuss the statues with the foreign minister and I walked away from the meeting not very encouraged."

Mr Annan had brought a proposal from the Metropolitan Museum in New York to remove the statues to the US.

He told Mr Muttawakil that true faith demanded respect for the faith of others.

Mr Muttawakil asked why Mr Annan had inanimate objects at the top of his list rather than the living, a reference to the Afghan refugee crisis also under discussion.

webTitle: MG Rover 'on track' despite heavy losses

fields.headline: MG Rover 'on track' despite heavy losses
fields.trailText: MG Rover yesterday insisted that the group remains on course to at least break even next year despite reports that it is to unveil losses of around £300m during its first eight months of existence.
fields.body:
MG Rover yesterday insisted that the group remains on course to at least break even next year despite reports that it is to unveil losses of around £300m during its first eight months of existence.

The group is due to reveal details of its financial performance for the 12-month period from last May, when it was acquired from BMW. A spokeswoman for the company confirmed that the group would be in the red, though she declined to comment on the scale of the losses.

"There will be an operating loss. No one should be surprised by that. MG Rover has said all along that it was aiming to break even or make a small profit in 2002. It is on track."

She pointed out that in 1999 - its last full year under under BMW ownership - Rover had run up losses of some £880m though that figure included just over £100m losses at the Land Rover business which BMW sold to Ford.

Since MG Rover began life as an independent company "it has been achieving its plans in terms of sales, production targets and cost savings".

MG Rover unveiled a number of new models at the Geneva motor show earlier this month - including an estate version of the Rover 75 - which will be brought to the market in the autumn. The spokeswoman said the company was planning to take on a small number of extra staff.

This week will mark the first anniversary of the announcement that Germany's BMW had finally given up on its attempts to turn round Rover -dubbed 'the English patient' by some within its Munich headquarters.

After a series of top level departures at BMW, a raft of rumours that the German group itself could become a takeover target and the break down of talks to sell Rover to a venture capital group, the UK car maker was eventually sold in May to a rival consortium led by an ex-Rover executive, John Towers.

Under the terms of the deal the Towers team took on Rover's Longbridge plant for a nominal £10, while BMW retained the Cowley plant where the new Mini is being built.

The deal included a "dowry" from BMW in the form of substantial financial support for the new group, which gave MG Rover a strong balance sheet.

The Towers' deal was favoured by the Rover workforce and the UK government because its plans were based on the continuation of volume car production at Longbridge.

There have been questions about how MG Rover will meet the challenge of developing new models and whether it can do so without joining forces with another group.

webTitle: BT's rights issue deepens market gloom

fields.headline: BT's rights issue deepens market gloom
fields.standfirst: Desperate action opens way for further investor turmoil in telecom and technology sectors
fields.trailText: Desperate action opens way for further investor turmoil in telecom and technology sectors.
fields.body:
The prospect of a record-breaking rights issue at BT is likely to exacerbate the dismal mood that is engulfing world stockmarkets.

After a sharp slide in telecoms and other hi-tech companies' share prices last week, industry sources last night feared that the desperate action being considered by BT could herald the beginning of another rollercoaster ride for investors in this sector.

The £30bn flotation of Orange last month summed up the mood of the stockmarkets. The company had to cut the price of the issue to ensure the shares were taken up.

It is the problem of persuading investors to back this float that has undermined BT's plans to pay down some of its towering £30bn debt burden by selling or floating off parts of its operations, such as BT Wireless, its mobile phone business.

It had hoped to float 25% and raise some £5bn, but is now unlikely to raise anything like that amount. If it now presses ahead with a rights issue, either instead of or as well as the flotation, major institutional investors may be forced to liquidate other telecoms holdings in order to take part. That would produce new pressure on a market that is already under siege.

The £5bn cash call BT is understood to be considering, already being rumoured in City dealing rooms late last week, will require all the selling skills of the BT boardroom and its advisers. And it is likely to cost the jobs of its top two executives - Sir Iain Vallance and Sir Peter Bonfield. It is unlikely that Sir Iain would go willingly. He is due to retire from BT next year and would like to leave on a high note, having restored at least some of BT's reputation, rather than being pushed out - especially at a time when he also holds the high-profile position of president of the Confederation of British Industry.

However, at the weekend it appeared that the board was ready to consider the unthinkable. In an interview published in a Sunday newspaper, new finance director Philip Hampton said: "What the board decides will be what is in the interests of shareholders - that is the beginning and end of it. If what the board has decided has other consequences then they need to be addressed. If we are going to raise a lot of money, we have to write a convincing prospectus on the future of the business."

The rout in telecoms and internet stocks shows no sign of abating. Last week Intel in the US was blamed for the latest about-turn in sentiment, and the embattled Yahoo! is now regarded as up for sale.

Some of the biggest names in the business are warning investors to steer clear of the sector. Last night it emerged that Jeff Bezos, the founder of online retailer Amazon.com, has warned investors not to put their hard-earned cash into internet stocks. "For a short term investor, or for a small investor," he says, "I wouldn't invest in internet stocks."

Amazon.com shares surged to more than $100(£68) 15 months ago, but since then the group has lost much of its value, and last week they closed at just $12.

In an interview to be screened on BBC2's The Money Programme this Wednesday, he says: "We are not a stock you can sleep well with at night. We're a volatile stock."
