webTitle: Embarrassed firms slash Aids drug prices

fields.headline: Embarrassed firms slash Aids drug prices
fields.standfirst: Special report: Aids
fields.trailText: Aids patients in Ivory Coast will be the first to benefit from a price-cutting war that appears to have broken out among drug manufacturers, embarrassed by the outcry in recent weeks over the preventable deaths of millions and afraid of losing the potentially huge African market to copycat generics manufacturers.
fields.body:
Aids patients in Ivory Coast will be the first to benefit from a price-cutting war that appears to have broken out among drug manufacturers, embarrassed by the outcry in recent weeks over the preventable deaths of millions and afraid of losing the potentially huge African market to copycat generics manufacturers.

Merck, one of the world's leading pharmaceutical companies, has dramatically dropped the price of two antiretroviral drugs in the last few days. Crixivan (indinavir sulfate), which costs around $6,000 (about £4,100) a year in the US, is on offer to sub-Saharan Africa at $600 a year, and Stocrin (efavirenz) at $500. Merck says it will make no profit on the sale. Ivory Coast's minister for Aids, Assana Sangare, said yesterday her country would buy discounted drugs from Merck, Bristol Myers Squibb and GlaxoSmithKline, bringing the cost of the sort of three-drug combination used to combat HIV/Aids in the west down to around $1,200 a year.

The three drug companies, and two others, have in the past offered discounts of 85% but have not named figures. There has been only a limited response. Most of Africa said the prices were still unaffordable. Merck's more generous offer is being seen as a response to the low prices being offered by generics companies, which copy patented drugs. Cipla, the Indian generics company, has said it is willing to supply developing world governments with a cocktail of three Aids drugs for $600 and to drop the price to $350 for the volunteer doctors of Médecins sans Frontières. The same combination would cost over $10,000 a year in the west.

The prices are still too high to allow more than a small number of people to be treated in desperately poor countries. But the real significance of the Merck move is that it signals a downward spiral in drug prices, which looks set to open up the possibility of treatment for millions for whom HIV is now a death sentence.

Merck's offer comes within days of the opening and adjournment of a court case brought by 39 international pharmaceutical companies - Merck among them - against the South African government contesting legislation that would allow the import of drugs that are cheaper elsewhere.

International outrage over the spectacle of hugely wealthy drug companies trying to stop South Africa's access to cheap medicines has made the case acutely embarrassing for the companies. While they say they must fight on because the legislation in effect sweeps away all their patent rights in South Africa, they are under pressure to improve their public image. GlaxoSmithKline, for instance, has recently announced two malaria initiatives for Africa.

Whether or not Merck is trying to draw the sting of the court case, it is certainly motivated by the threat of Cipla walking into the African mar ket. Cipla has asked the South African government to grant it eight compulsory licences for Aids drugs - permission to make a cheap version in South Africa of a patented drug, which is allowable under international trade agreements in cases of dire human need.

Merck and the others are signalling that they will do all they can to fight the generics companies off, if not through law then by undercutting their prices.

"I certainly feel that compulsory licences are unneces sary in this case," said Jeffrey Sturchio, Merck's executive director for public affairs in Africa. "We are making these drugs available. We're willing to work with the government in South Africa."

Those campaigning to get Aids drugs to millions across sub-Saharan Africa are delighted at the price war. "We think prices can fall further, down to as low as $200 a year for a triple combination," said Nathan Ford of MSF. "For many countries drugs are still, and will be still, too expensive."

fields.headline: Mario Covas
fields.standfirst: Brazilian politician of high ethical and moral standards
fields.trailText: Mário Covas, who has died of multiple organ failure aged 70, was a giant of Brazilian politics and a favourite choice for the Brazilian presidency. In 1986, Covas was one of the main architects of Brazil's return from dictatorship to democracy, and during the 1980s he received what is still the record number of votes for a senator.
fields.body:
Mário Covas, who has died of multiple organ failure aged 70, was a giant of Brazilian politics and a favourite choice for the Brazilian presidency. In 1986, Covas was one of the main architects of Brazil's return from dictatorship to democracy, and during the 1980s he received what is still the record number of votes for a senator.

Since 1994 he had been governor of São Paulo, Brazil's richest, most populous state. It was only when his health recently deteriorated dramatically that power was transferred to his deputy.

Covas stood out in Brazilian politics as a combative, hardworking administrator who preferred to balance books rather than overspend on populist projects. This won him wide-ranging, cross-party respect, although the austerity measures he often had to adopt because of his predecessors' profligacy deprived him of popular affection.

Unlike many Brazilian politicians at his level, who often acquire unexplained fortunes during periods in office, and who readily switch convictions and parties, Covas neither personally profited from his positions nor deviated from his centrist political principles. He was a hard-talking, stubborn orator and, as the left-wing leader Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva observed, he was an example of ethical behaviour, dignity, morality, and of a man who kept his promises.

One of the seven founders of the Brazilian Social Democratic Party (PSDB) in 1988, Covas was its candidate for president the following year - the first direct elections for president since the end of the 1964-85 dictatorship. Campaigning on a platform that argued for a "capitalist shock", he came fourth.

However, after the resignation of President Fernado Collor in a corruption scandal in 1992, the PSDB finally won the presidency in 1994 with Fernando Henrique Cardoso, who was re-elected in 1998. Covas was the obvious choice for 2002 until he was diagnosed with bladder cancer, shortly after Cardoso's second victory.

A coffee broker's son, Covas was born in Santos, a port built on the export of coffee from the interior of south-east Brazil. He began his political career in 1962, entering Congress for the Brazilian Democratic Party. Four years later, as he started his second term, Brazil's new military regime stripped him of his political rights for publicly defending an opponent to the regime. He was briefly imprisoned, but then chose not to go into exile like many of his colleagues but to work as an engineer.

He returned to politics in 1979, after a general amnesty, entering Congress for the Brazilian Democratic Movement Party. In 1983, he was appointed mayor of São Paulo, one of the world's biggest cities, with an inner-city population of 10m.

Once the military relinquished power, Covas became majority leader of the Constitutional Assembly, which drew up a new democratic charter. For David Fleischer, a professor of political science at Brasilia University, the constitution was probably Covas's most lasting contribution to Brazil. But he was also, Fleischer suggested, the PSDB's moral conscience, holding it to the straight and narrow and keeping it from alliances with the right. In 1986, Covas was elected to the senate with 7.8m votes.

While at the helm of São Paulo state, whose population of 36m makes it as large as a medium-sized country, Covas restored it from near-bankrupcy to financial health. He made tough and unpopular decisions, such as dismissing nearly 200,000 civil servants in 1995. His main political failing was an inability to find solutions to the rapid rise in violent crime.

Covas's reputation for courage and transparency was evident in his approach to cancer. By making his struggle public, he won both widespread respect and sympathy.

He is survived by his wife, Lila, and his son and daughter.

 Mário Covas, politician, born April 21, 1930; died March 6, 2001 This obituary appeared in the first edition of last Saturday's Guardian

fields.headline: Fears over rail safety revealed
fields.standfirst: Report exposes widespread rule-breaking
fields.trailText: Widespread fatigue and rule violations throughout the railways, including a signaller working 30 days without a break, have been recorded by the confidential reporting system introduced by the industry to improve safety, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
Widespread fatigue and rule violations throughout the railways, including a signaller working 30 days without a break, have been recorded by the confidential reporting system introduced by the industry to improve safety, it was revealed last night.

The investigation, set up on a national basis last year, found that fatigue problems had got worse since the Hatfield rail crash last October. Contracting staff complain of falling asleep at the wheel when driving between jobs while others say they are being asked to attend training courses when they should be resting between shifts.

According to the report, which has been obtained by the Guardian, other problems include a shortage of staff for tasks such as lookouts on maintenance work, fears about overcrowding on some routes which could have serious implications in an emergency, a shortage of essential equipment, and worries that speed restrictions in force after the Hatfield crash are not clear enough to train drivers.

Ciras, the industry's confidential reporting and analysis system, has been developed from a similar arrangement in the airline industry where staff are encouraged to blow the whistle when they believe a threat to safety exists. It was first introduced in the railway industry in Scotland but, after the Paddington rail crash in October 1999, was rapidly installed nationally.

At one point the report says: "Some depots have a quarter of the staff they used to have, leaving managers and super visors with difficulty covering jobs." It also says: "Providing incentives to work rest days may not be compatible with safe working."

In the case of the signaller who worked 30 consecutive days, Railtrack said it received a weekly printout showing details of staff who might be in breach of their limits. For a signaller to work more than 28 consecutive days would require "the explicit authority of management".

In the first six months of this national reporting system, 36.8% of incidents notified were due to rule violation, and of 95 serious incidents, 24.2 % were due to fatigue. One of the main complaints on rule violation is the lack of look-outs on maintenance work due to staff shortages, posing a threat to safety on the track.

The Association of Train Operating Companies, representing 25 organisations including Virgin, National Express and Great North Eastern Railways, said last night that Ciras was "designed to provide lessons from industry and we intend learning from them".

A separate report from Ciras's zone no 1, covering Scotland and the north of England, criticises Railtrack for not erecting sufficient emergency and temporary speed restrictions to warn drivers of a 20mph limit, particularly following the Hatfield crash.

In many instances, drivers have been stopped and told by a signaller to "roughly estimate" where the speed restrictions might begin.

Railtrack's answer is that, post-Hatfield, there has been a "shortage of board and equipment. But this was a unique situation and hopefully will not happen again". It says that all speed restrictions in the zone are now all "properly boarded".

On overcrowding, Ciras reports the concerns of Northern Spirit and GNER drivers who are worried about evacuating a train in an emergency. One GNER staff member said that the number of passengers on a train from London was double that of available seats.

GNER told Ciras that there was no legislation or standard specifying the "acceptable levels of passengers standing on trains". The company's policy is that if the guard believes safety is being compromised and decides no more passengers should be allowed on board, he or she will be fully supported by GNER management.

GNER and Virgin Trains are singled out for allowing drivers to work more than their 12-hour shifts and Virgin drivers sometimes work more than 50 hours a week. Some GNER drivers want to be booked off the next day if they work more than a 12 hour day.

GNER's response is that disruption since Hatfield inevitably means that some drivers will have worked more than 12 hours. "A day off the following day because an unplanned incident has extended the hours of duty is not the solution. Compliance with the minimum rest period of 12 hours certainly is."

On drivers working more than 50 hours, Virgin says the subject will be considered soon as part of a new risk assessment on rostering.

The train drivers' union Aslef said last night it would press for the introduction of two drivers on Virgin trains when the company moves to speeds of over 140mph on its new tilting services to be introduced by 2005.

webTitle: Annan ready to dash Asian hopes by seeking new term

fields.headline: Annan ready to dash Asian hopes by seeking new term
fields.trailText: The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, is poised to announce that he intends to seek a second five-year term.
fields.body:
The United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, is poised to announce that he intends to seek a second five-year term.

His move will be welcomed by the US, Britain and other UN security council members who regard his stewardship of the unwieldy world body as more than competent, in spite of problems with peacekeeping operations in Sierra Leone and elsewhere.

But it will disappoint several east Asian countries who have been preparing for months behind the scenes to put forward alternatives. Thailand, the Philippines, Indonesia and Singapore were all jockeying to build up their own candidates, mainly former foreign ministers.

Some east European countries too thought that after two secretary generals in succession from Africa, they had a claim to a job that has never been filled by anyone from their part of the world.

Mr Annan's term in office ends on December 31 and he has until October to declare his intentions. But he has opted to make an early decision. According to UN sources, he has asked officials to pencil in a press conference for his return to the UN headquarters in New York next week at which he will end speculation about whether or not he will stand again.

Fred Eckhart, his spokesman, who is travelling with Mr Annan on a visit to the Indian subcontinent this week, said: "He is getting close to announcing his decision but even his closest aides do not know what it will be."

A senior UN official confidently predicted that he would go for another term: "Yes, I believe he will stand. Although he has misgivings about the impact of the job on his personal life and the strain of the security, his body language and all the other signs say he wants to continue in the job."

Mr Annan, preparing the ground, met half a dozen African ambassadors to the UN on Thursday. They told Mr Annan, a Ghanaian, it was inconceivable that he should do anything other than seek a second term. A meeting of the whole group of African ambassadors is being organised for this week that will almost certainly endorse him. The African countries constitute an important bloc, making up 50 of the UN's 189 members. Once he has announced his intention, most countries will back him, including even those in east Asia who had been manoeuvring to put forward their own candidates.

Mr Annan worked for the UN for 30 years before becoming secretary general and survived a disastrous spell in the 1990s when he was head of the organisation's peacekeeping division at the time of the Rwanda genocide and the humiliation of the UN in Bosnia.

He is now seen as having the potential to be the best secretary general since Dag Hammarskjold, the Swede who carved out a moral role for the UN in the 1950s and 1960s. One of Mr Annan's biggest challenges is to reform peacekeeping operations but his attempts so far have been undermined by a refusal of countries to provide enough troops.

He had a good relationship with the Clinton administration, which backed him in 1997 in preference to the incumbent, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, who was allowed only one term.

UN officials said Mr Annan had established a good relationship with the new secretary of state, Colin Powell, and "there is heavy telephone traffic between them".

fields.headline: Long haul
fields.standfirst:
A seven-year fight
From outlaw to folk hero, Mexico's masked man strides into the capital
fields.trailText: • January 1 1994: Zapatista uprising in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas begins, led by Subcommandante Marcos. Seeking improved conditions and rights for 10m indigenous Indian peasants, the rebels carry out a number of attacks.Government forces retaliate with a week-long heavy bombing campaign.
fields.body:
 January 1 1994: Zapatista uprising in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas begins, led by Subcommandante Marcos. Seeking improved conditions and rights for 10m indigenous Indian peasants, the rebels carry out a number of attacks.Government forces retaliate with a week-long heavy bombing campaign.

 January 22 1994: the government declares a truce. One month later, negotiations begin and conclude with a report detailing 34 Zapatista demands.

 January 1995: President Ernesto Zedillo orders the army to withdraw from two areas in Chiapas. Rebels agree to observe an indefinite ceasefire. A preliminary peace accord signed a year later breaks down when the rebels accuse the government of failing to implement it.

 December 1997: 45 Tzotzil Indians, mostly women and children, massacred by pro-government paramilitaries. The interior secretary and the governor of Chiapas resign over the incident.

September 1999: interior minister Diodoro Carrasco says the government will resume talks with the rebels, pass new legislation on Indian rights and investigate human rights abuses.

 July 2000: Vicente Fox wins presidential elections and declares peace with the Zapatistas a priority.

fields.headline: Wonders and blunders
fields.standfirst:
7. Michael Longley
Wonder: Opera House, Belfast
Blunder: Tollgate House, Belfast
fields.trailText:
7. Michael Longley
Wonder: Opera House, Belfast
Blunder: Tollgate House, Belfast
fields.body:
The Grand Opera House in Belfast shows the exuberance and generosity of spirit of its designer, Frank Matcham. Built in 1895, it is one of 150 theatres that Matcham built throughout Britain, including the Palladium in London. The Belfast opera house is one of the few such buildings left in Britain, having escaped demolition plans in the 1970s and a bombing in 1993. For me, it represents my first taste of serious drama and opera, and it was where, as a boy, I saw Laurel and Hardy.

Matcham produced elaborate design on a small scale, while ensuring space for the maximum number of bums on seats. The opera house had to be designed to host a range of events, including opera, variety shows, panto and circus. It is noted for its brilliant acoustics and has been much praised by actors and singers.

The plush red velvet and gilt interior have been lovingly restored in a style that manages to combine opulence and practicality. Both the interior and exterior have a wonderful eastern theme. Minarets and golden elephant heads contribute to an enchanting blend of the exotic and the cosy. When I worked for the Arts Council during the 1970s, plans to pull the opera house down and build a multi-storey car park were only narrowly defeated. I see it as one of Belfast's spiritual as well as physical landmarks. It is like a beacon in the city and is a vital part of life here.

Tollgate House on Bradbury Place in Belfast is named after a 19th-century toll gate that I used to cycle past when I was a boy. It is a relatively new building, situated on the edge of the Golden Mile area - a rosary of shops, restaurants and bars near the city centre. I see its location - where two main thoroughfares converge - as the southern gateway to the city of Belfast, and it is a shame that such a banal, brutal and depressing pastiche should be built there.

There are shops on the ground level and apartments above. The undistinguished exterior is made more drab by the clashing shop-fronts. It is a perfect example of how modern architecture in Belfast is a collection of compromises. There is no daring. It is just like the hundreds and thousands of nondescript, bog-standard constructions all over Britain that are turning our cities into visual deserts.

 Michael Longley's collection of poetry, The Weather in Japan, won the TS Eliot Prize and the Hawthornden Prize this year.

Minarets and golden elephant heads contribute to an enchanting blend of the exotic and the cosy. When I worked for the Arts Council during the 1970s, plans to pull the opera house down and build a multi-storey car park were only narrowly defeated. I see it as one of Belfast's spiritual as well as physical landmarks. It is like a beacon in the city and is a vital part of life here. Tollgate House on Bradbury Place in Belfast is named after a 19th-century toll gate that I used to cycle past when I was a boy. It is a relatively new building, situated on the edge of the Golden Mile area - a rosary of shops, restaurants and bars near the city centre. I see its location - where two main thoroughfares converge - as the southern gateway to the city of Belfast, and it is a shame that such a banal, brutal and depressing pastiche should be built there. There are shops on the ground level and apartments above. The undistinguished exterior is made more drab by the clashing shop-fronts. It is a perfect example of how modern architecture in Belfast is a collection of compromises. There is no daring. It is just like the hundreds and thousands of nondescript, bog-standard constructions all over Britain that are turning our cities into visual deserts.  Michael Longley's collection of poetry, The Weather in Japan, won the TS Eliot Prize and the Hawthornden Prize this year.

webTitle: 'Wide' verbal abuse of the mentally ill

fields.headline: 'Wide' verbal abuse of the mentally ill
fields.trailText: Most young people admit to hurling terms such as "loony" or "nutter" at people they think may have a mental health problem, according to government research published today.
fields.body:
Most young people admit to hurling terms such as "loony" or "nutter" at people they think may have a mental health problem, according to government research published today.

While two thirds of the 16 to 24-year-olds considered it wrong to use racist language, only one third thought it was unacceptable to call people "schizo" or "psycho", a poll by Opinion Leader Research showed.

The findings were published as the government launched a £1m campaign to challenge the stigma and discrimination suffered by people with mental health problems.

The poll findings were based on telephone interviews with a national representative sample of 500 young people. Some 80% thought that having a mental health problem would lead to discrimination and 55% would not want anyone else to know if they had a mental health problem.

When asked which words they had used to describe someone with a mental health problem, 61% said "nutter, psycho, schizo, loon", 51% said "mental", and 44% said "mad".

The government's "mind out for mental health" campaign is supported by the National Union of Students. Rachel Cashman, its vice-president for welfare, said: "The prevalence and severity of mental illness in students is increasing."

Paul Farmer, director of public affairs for the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said: "It's the fear of discrimination that perpetuates the stigma of having a mental health problem."

webTitle: Secretaries in the City of London

fields.headline: Going for gold
fields.standfirst: The city of London can be a lucrative place for secretaries, in perks if not in pay. Sarah Coates reports
fields.trailText: The city of London can be a lucrative place for secretaries, in perks if not in pay. Sarah Coates reports
fields.body:
It seems Dick Whittington was right; the streets of London truly are paved with gold. Well, sort of. The demand for secretaries in the City of London is greater than ever. About 400 companies have given an indication that the number of secretarial posts will rise by around 8% over the next year, bringing the secret arial population in this tiny area of the capital to almost 52,000.

Also known as the Square Mile, the City is the oldest part of London, and its financial hub, housing The Bank of England, Lloyd's, the Royal Exchange and the head offices of Barclays, Lloyds TSB, HSBC and the National Westminster. It is an exciting area, characterised by the stereotypical briefcased hustle and sharp-suited bustle of the business world.

The recruitment agency Joslin Rowe specialises in bringing secretarial staff to the City's financial institutions. Recent research by the company has displayed some interesting discrepancies about secretarial life in this part of London. Many City companies, especially those working in the insurance industry, have observed that secretaries are no longer remaining in the same job with the same company for lengthy periods.

There could be many reasons for this increased "fickleness", but the Joslin Rowe research suggests that it could be attributed to a general sense of job dissatisfaction. Two-thirds of the secretaries and PAs surveyed complained that they felt themselves to be "undervalued" in their day-to-day work. Furthermore, despite the phenomenal salaries paid to City executives, secretaries felt that their own financial reward was inadequate. Nearly all the City firms claimed to have some sort of appraisal system, yet 22% of secretaries felt that they were never given the opportunity to discuss concerns about their jobs. In those companies which did operate appraisal schemes, "salary review" was rarely a topic for discussion.

In addition, practically all firms stated that they offer inhouse training, but less than half the surveyed secretaries agreed with the claim. The vast majority were forced to rely on skills they had acquired elsewhere.

Not all sectors envisage a secretar ial boom-time. The insurance industry believes their need for secretaries will decrease - if only slightly. In the investment management sector, however, there is an anticipated 14% rise in secretarial and PA positions. Judging by current trends, the majority are expected to be permanent rather than temping posts.

Despite the grandeur of the City firms (and indeed the dauntingly impressive City buildings) the secretarial skills required are much the same as in any business. There is the usual demand for experience in advanced presentation, facilities management and statistical analysis.

Administrative staff working in the City can also expect sizeable perks. Of those secretaries employed in the banking industry, 83% can use the company gym, and most financial firms provide life insurance and free healthcare for their employees. Pay is a slightly stickier area - not all companies offer profit-related pay or even paid overtime. No insurance firms will hand over a share of the profits to their secretarial staff, whereas three-quarters of banking firms are happy to give admin staff a percentage of the takings. Only a quarter of insurance companies will pay their staff for working after hours, compared to around 60% of banks.

Yet a secretarial position in the City is an exciting and frequently challenging job with some of the country's most-respected companies, in some of the most exquisite surroundings. For the aspiring Whittingtons the perks are many. The cat, however, is optional.

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: * This morning WPM has been shirking her responsibilities and leafing through the copy of Marie Claire that she keeps for emergencies in the bottom drawer of her desk. "Leafing through" admittedly lends a misleading air of nonchalance to the proceedings. In truth, WPM has been gazing at the thighs of Renee Zellweger and wondering whether, if she started injecting neat vanilla Slimfast into her veins, she too might have the pins of a small, wonky-legged foal.
fields.body:
* This morning WPM has been shirking her responsibilities and leafing through the copy of Marie Claire that she keeps for emergencies in the bottom drawer of her desk. "Leafing through" admittedly lends a misleading air of nonchalance to the proceedings. In truth, WPM has been gazing at the thighs of Renee Zellweger and wondering whether, if she started injecting neat vanilla Slimfast into her veins, she too might have the pins of a small, wonky-legged foal.

The lovely Renee was chatting about her new role as Bridget Jones, and the hellish regime she had to endure to fit the part of a neurotic, Chardonnay-swigging thirtysomething. Perhaps it should be mentioned that during the course of the interview, Renee dismembers her turkey salad tortilla so that it is just, well, turkey. The freak. "I had to eat chocolate last thing at night. And pizza. And drink pints of Guinness," she twitters. "You should have seen my refrigerator - it was hysterical." One can only assume that if Renee Zellweger ever saw WPM's fridge she would wet herself.

As the whole world knows, Renee went "undercover" in a British publishing house to learn just how to be a bona fide skirt-wearing, chain-smoking Londoner, but without going all Dick Van Dyke on us. Not that Dick Van Dyke ever wore a skirt. To my knowledge. Anyway, Renee tells us that she was astonished to discover the gluttonous eating habits of her office colleagues. "The girls all ate cake!" she cried. Zellweger, Zellweger, of course we eat cake. It is only protein-assed fools like yourself who spurn the swiss roll in favour of soy-milk shakes with extra whittling juice. Start chomping the Battenburg, Renee, then you will have my respect.

WPM, who this morning ate a muffin for breakfast (and what is a muffin except a little cake baked for the tiny hands of a dwarf?), has gained a quite preposterous amount of satisfaction from discovering that "eel leer grew zen" is in fact an anagram of Renee Zellweger. What the hell "eel leer grew zen" actually means is beyond WPM's limited brain capacity. But don't it just sound the ugliest?

*WPM is sure she should be telling you about some rivetting new survey which has shown that swivel chairs damage your lovelife, or somesuch scintillating revelation, rather than the poultry consumption of a Hollywood starlet (or even the paltry consumption of a serious actress. Ha ha! Cross your legs, Zellweger). Perhaps the British Cream Cake Foundation (BCCF) could rustle up a survey about the most popular gateau in the nation's publishing offices. The smart money's on the cream horn.

Until all the data has been processed, however, we shall have to make do (and it's a pretty poor second, I agree) with a Lloyds TSB survey for the Employers for Work-Life Balance, which has revealed (they are very revealing, these surveys, aren't they? WPM often wonders how long it will be before Emma Noble starts sporting them as frocks) that we all want more flexible working hours.

WPM would give you the exact percentage, but she is certain she's not the only one whose mind starts roaming once the figures start rolling. And heaven only knows you'll be getting enough fractions and numbers-out-of-10s in the rest of Office Hours without WPM adding to them. Oh, all right then it's 70. Seventy per cent of us want a little more flexibility in our working lives.

According to the press release on WPM's desk, a more relaxed approach to working hours was particularly popular in the 18-24 age group, who said that it would "allow them to pursue their life outside work to the full". Which obviously means that they would like to go out dancing on a Thursday night and not have to shamble into work at 9am the next day.

Really you do have to worry about that 30% though, don't you? What unearthly chaos do they imagine will descend on us if we're all allowed to come and go as we please? Do they live in fear that we will all just spend the day moping around in our flannelette pyjamas watching Trisha and gorging ourselves on chocolate and pizza and pints of Guinness? Whatever will we be doing next? Eating cake? An exclusive survey commissioned for WPM has revealed that an astonishing three in 10 of us are total Zellwegers.

webTitle: Office juniors on the way out

fields.headline: As one door closes...
fields.standfirst: The post of office junior is on its way out. Now the best way onto the career ladder is as a temp, discovers Elizabeth Cripps
fields.trailText: The post of office junior is on its way out. Now the best way onto the career ladder is as a temp, discovers Elizabeth Cripps.
fields.body:
The role of office junior, already a thankless job, just got worse. According to the latest salary survey by recruitment consultants Adecco, the average pay for this largely administrative post has fallen by 14.8% over the past year. This is in the face of an increase of 5.4% for the commercial sector as a whole.

As if endless coffee-making, photocopying and opening everyone else's post weren't depressing enough, the office junior can now expect just £9,403 for his or her pains. Hardly enough to keep a girl (or boy) in nail varnish and fishnets.

Nor are things likely to get any better. According to Diane Bradbury, director of UK operations at Adecco, the pay is slipping because the job is on its way out. There isn't much, it seems, that the office junior can do that a machine can't do better - or at least cheaper.

It may not seem like something to cry over. Who, after all, wants to spend their days running errands and grappling with the fax machine? But with the death of the skivvy (sorry, assistant), there dies, too, an established way to break into the workplace.

It worked for Beth Clarke, now running a four-person team at a major company. "I photocopied and opened post for a few months," she says. "Then I got promoted. It was tedious, but it was a way in."

The alternative is what my friends at Office Angels call "temp to perm". And it does exactly what it says on the packet. According to Marcia Roberts, director of external relations at the Recruitment and Employment Corporation, temporary work is a recognised way onto the career ladder. "It's especially good for graduates with little work experience," she says, "or people returning to work after a career break."

In other words, if there are gaps in your CV, you have more chance of convincing an employer of your fantastic potential in three weeks of working for them than in five minutes on the other side of a desk.

Alex Walters started temping with little secretarial experience, but after six months of various posts, she got lucky at a London-based research house. "I was meant to be there for a week, as holiday cover," she says. "Then I was asked to stay another couple of days, then another week, and so on, until after four weeks I was offered a job."

The job was PA to the managing director, with a starting salary of £16,000, which went up again when she was promoted to research assistant.

That's not to say that temping doesn't have its downsides. No desk to call your own, no guaranteed salary, new people to impress every week. Vicky North, reluctantly returning to temping in her 40s, is decidedly unimpressed by her current placing: "I just get all the things that have been left for ages because no one else wants to do them. It's breathtakingly dull."

North, however, is being paid by the hour. Even at £5 or £6 a throw, it's more than a full-time office assistant would make. Next week, she'll be somewhere else, learning new names and, just possibly, getting something more interesting to do. And always with a chance to make an impression.

Walters adds: "I wasn't really looking for a full-time job through temping, but it is good because you get a sense of a company before you take a job there. I had temped in some places where I would never ever want to work."

There, of course, lies the crux. Try before you buy, as Roberts puts it. The absence of a contract and pension scheme might keep you awake at nights, but at least you don't have to come back next week if you don't want to.

But if you do want to, they like you, and the right opening is there, it can be a painless way in at the right level. With a bit of luck, the photocopier will never be more than an embarrassing accessory at the Christmas party.

fields.headline: Virtually an assistant
fields.standfirst: Skilled administrator urgently required. Choose your own location. Name your price. Admiring clients guaranteed.  Ian Boughton  on a new kind of secretary able to dictate her own terms
fields.trailText: Skilled administrator urgently required. Choose your own location. Name your price. Admiring clients guaranteed. Ian Boughton on a new kind of secretary able to dictate her own terms.
fields.body:
It will probably come as something of a surprise to British bosses that many of their PAs harbour a secret desire to leave the company and work for themselves. And temping agencies will be equally amazed to learn just how much of their business these new self-employed secretaries intend to take.

"I have just had a City company call me, absolutely horrified to discover that all four of its top secretaries had applied to join us," reports Bridget Postlethwaite of the International Association of Virtual Assistants (IAVA), Britain's newest and biggest cooperative body for administrators. City companies should take heed of this news, as it reflects the world's latest big move in business administration.

A Virtual Assistant (VA) is a top-level secretary who has had enough of office regimes and sells her skills from her home office. She is the freelance gunslinger of the admin world, already taking administrative business in shovelfuls, mainly from small and medium-sized companies.

"Corporations haven't quite realised how much better off they are with a VA rather than a temp," says Postlethwaite. "The reason temps are notoriously ineffective is not because of personal skills, but because they are badly briefed and managed - the first two hours of any Monday morning are wasted in working out who she is going to work for, and how. Eight VAs will probably do the work of 20 temps, and I've had a client tell me that I did in two days what his entire pool took a week to do."

Big businesses have a tendency to envisage VAs as "home typists", without realising that they do not come from the typing pool. Most VAs have already risen to the top of the administrative profession - as smaller companies have realised. Says Postlethwaite: "They know that paying a VA by the hour gets them the kind of professional PA that corporations pay £30,000 for."

The rise of the VA is worldwide. Chris Durst in Connecticut has been credited with starting the industry, and her Staffcentrix cooperative has more than 1,000 members in 27 countries, including around 60 in Britain. In Maryland, Stacy Brice of Assist-U created the first American "university" to prepare PAs for self-employment, and she brings her service here at Easter. In Australia, Kathie Thomas founded Clayton's Secretary, without knowing that other VAs existed, and now she, too, has British members.

The move is driven by PAs themselves. Last year, after two press articles in 48 hours, IAVA had 500 enquiries and 27,000 visitors to the website in one week. Today, it has 315 members, and 800 ask for advice on a casual basis. Chris Durst at Staffcentrix polled her members and discovered that 66% had been in business for less than a year, or were preparing to make the leap . There is, she concluded, a vast underswell of PAs on the move, building up part-time VA businesses as they prepare to leave the safety of the paycheque behind.

Everyday administrative work is at the heart of the industry, but the average VA can handle anything, from anywhere. Postlethwaite transfers stocks and shares, works for someone in prison who writes once a week with the jobs he wants done, handles website updates for an estate agent on a guaranteed 24-hour basis, and takes "virtual bookings" for two hairdressers, without the clients realising that she isn't their receptionist.

Internet research and website maintenance are becoming big earners, reports Chris Durst. "Software packages have made site-building simple, so web design is not getting the fees it used to, but keeping a site fresh is both critical and time- consuming, and our VAs indicate fees of more than $US35 (about £20) an hour."

This is a fair average. The British VA rates average £15 an hour, rising to £25 in London. For the employer, this is economical, producing top-level staff without overheads - the manager just picks the VA with the right skills, and if she's the wrong one, he can change instantly.

Location is irrelevant. From a Channel Islands base, Postlethwaite can work for clients anywhere. Kathie Thomas in Australia gives a classic example. She heard an American client complain about the time taken by transcribers in Paris, and taught him to email his dictation as an audiofile overnight from France to Australia. Because of the difference in time zones, he can now send a day's work off around the world, and by the time he wakes in the morning, the transcriptions are back on his desk.

Stacey Brice of Assist-U says that 400 experienced secretaries have now passed through her extremely testing 20-week course. "Many think of us as a finishing school. The people we train are already great administrative professionals who, tired of being abused, disrespected and underpaid, have simply had enough. We know how to show them to use their skills and do the work they love, but never again have to be in that position."

For the VA, the loneliness of self-employment rarely exists. A Virtual Assistant (VA) is a top-level secretary who has had enough of office regimes and sells her skills from her home office. She is the freelance gunslinger of the admin world, already taking administrative business in shovelfuls, mainly from small and medium-sized companies. "Corporations haven't quite realised how much better off they are with a VA rather than a temp," says Postlethwaite. "The reason temps are notoriously ineffective is not because of personal skills, but because they are badly briefed and managed - the first two hours of any Monday morning are wasted in working out who she is going to work for, and how. Big businesses have a tendency to envisage VAs as "home typists", without realising that they do not come from the typing pool. fields.headline: Secs in the City
fields.trailText: There's a new entry in my Top Ten of Things That Annoy Me About My Job. It has crashed straight in at Number One, elbowing out Clearing the Paper Jam. It's irritating, it's tedious, it's time-consuming and it's likely to send me into a festering rage. It's the 11 o'clock coffee run.
fields.body:
There's a new entry in my Top Ten of Things That Annoy Me About My Job. It has crashed straight in at Number One, elbowing out Clearing the Paper Jam. It's irritating, it's tedious, it's time-consuming and it's likely to send me into a festering rage. It's the 11 o'clock coffee run.

It's not that I object to keeping my colleagues refreshed through the working day. Well, actually, I do. But until recently the job was at least fairly simple - nothing more complicated than remembering everyone's desired ratio of milk and sugar to teabag.

Since the new Starbucks opened, though, it's all got out of hand. My colleagues - bless 'em - have greeted the latest manifestation of American Imperialism with enthusiasm, consuming as many ridiculous, fanciful and just plain revolting coffee-based concoctions as they can lay hands on. Never before have I seen a group of adults so excited over a hot milky drink.

Of course, the key to 21st- century coffee is customisation. That's what really gets them going - the prospect of a grande, skinny, half-caff, or flat vanilla latte is so much more enticing than a cup of instant. And if it gives me a migraine into the bargain, so much the better, hey guys?

Mark the Insomniac can't decide whether to go for that fourth shot in his espresso, Chloe is trying to work out how many calories are in a hot chocolate with whipped cream and marshmallows, and New Girl Sara, fresh from her yoga class, is wondering whether to push the boat out on a soy milk capp.

The staff at Starbucks fight to get out of my way. And no matter how clearly, how slowly, I place my order, Mr Barrista is always at a loss to understand. Ask for a skinny capp and his tongs hover expectantly over the muffin tray. Want some hazelnut syrup in your hot milk? We can do you coconut, because they're pretty much the same colour, right?

The final twist in the whole excruciating saga comes back at base when we discover that there is something of a gap between what I ordered and what I got. There follows a lengthy and tortuous game of swapsies, where everyone tries to bag something approximating what they wanted from the limited selection available. Herbal tea for steamed milk; Praline latte for americano . . .

Invariably, I'm left with a combination of foam, whipped cream, a teeth-rotting blend of sickly syrups, a sprinkle of nuts and a cocktail umbrella thrown in for good measure. Sod the coffee. When does the pub open?

fields.headline: Wycombe in wonderland
fields.standfirst: Izzet 68 | McCarthy 50, Essandoh 90
fields.trailText: Every so often there are moments in the FA Cup that remind us all why this old trophy, for all its detractors, remains a national treasure and how football is still the most intoxicating, emotive and captivating sport of all.
fields.body:
Every so often there are moments in the FA Cup that remind us all why this old trophy, for all its detractors, remains a national treasure and how football is still the most intoxicating, emotive and captivating sport of all.

Under leaden skies in the east midlands, as the players of Wycombe Wanderers cavorted in the glorious afterglow of the club's finest hour following their quarter-final win, it was apparent that this was such an occasion.

In those exhilarating, light-headed moments it was a time for pure emotion to take over. Steve Brown wiped tears from his eyes. Alan Parry, the television commentator and Wycombe director, embraced the players, kissing Paul McCarthy's hand and bowing in honour to Martin Taylor. Like a Japanese day-tripper, the assistant manager Terry Gibson was frantically taking snaps from a pocket camera. And there in the middle Roy Essandoh, the most unlikely hero, was posing for the press photographers, his toothy grin exposed by a thousand and one flash bulbs.

It was almost two minutes into stoppage time when this Belfast-born Ghanaian, with a most exquisite sense of timing, headed in his late, earth-shaking winner. When the dust settles, it will not be hours and minutes that matter but the date will be remembered.

The FA Cup may have suffered in recent years, but its capacity to throw up tales of the unexpected is clearly limitless. Essandoh's agent contacted Wycombe after reading on Teletext they were in the market for a stopgap striker.

Even so, he was given a contract for two weeks only because Lawrie Sanchez could not tempt Gianluca Vialli or Ian Wright to interrupt their retirement. And when he stepped off the bench with 17 minutes left, most of his new team-mates were struggling to remember his name. "He just turned up during the week and, to be honest, I couldn't even tell you who he is," said McCarthy.

Yet with one act of joyous heroism Essandoh, answering an SOS for a club with six strikers injured, had instigated the most raucous merriment in Buckinghamshire since Sir Francis Dashwood's Hellfire club in West Wycombe Caves.

"The guy on television had to ask me how I pronounced my name," he said smiling. Essandoh's deal is due to end on Wednesday and it is unknown if he will be at the club when they face Liverpool.

Gérard Houllier's team and Sunderland have both found Leicester's defence an impregnable barrier recently but the team 60th in the professional ladder not only breached it twice but out-thought, out-manouevred and, at times, out-fought their hosts.

By the time McCarthy stooped to head Brown's cross beyond Simon Royce early in the second half, a weight of foreboding was already descending upon Leicester.

The real drama, however, was yet to come. Once Muzzy Izzet had rounded off a neatly worked equaliser the Second Division side might have been expected to keel over. Yet still they kept on pressing, sniffing out openings and busying themselves in attack, only to be denied the most cast-iron penalty when Stefan Oakes was clearly culpable of handling Brown's cross.

Sanchez's touch-line histrionics evoked memories of some of Martin O'Neill's maddest moments on the same turf but the referee Steve Bennett was unimpressed, banishing him from the dugout and reporting him yesterday to the Football Association. First and foremost, the powers-that-be should take issue with the assistant referee who, 15 yards away from the offence, inexplicably declined to raise his flag.

All of which meant Sanchez watched the subsequent drama unfold from a television monitor and he was pacing the floor when Dannie Bulman spun a deep cross into the Leicester penalty area. Jamie Bates headed across goal and, with one twisting leap and header, Essandoh had entered FA Cup lore.

The only pity was that Brown peeled off his shirt in the celebrations and was red-carded for his trouble, having been booked earlier for fouling Robbie Savage. He left the field in tears, but later described it as the "best day of my life".

Wycombe, a dormitory town more famous for its furniture than football, are one match away from Cardiff and being the first side from their division to reach an FA Cup final.

webTitle: Wiltord sets the benchmark but may take back seat for Munich

fields.headline: Wiltord sets the benchmark but may take back seat for Munich
fields.standfirst: Wiltord 2, Adams 5, Pires 36
fields.trailText: This was just what le professeur had ordered ahead of Wednesday's game at Bayern Munich: victory with minimal exertion and not an injury in sight. The only shame for Arsène Wenger was that the referee could not declare a knockout after five minutes.
fields.body:
This was just what le professeur had ordered ahead of Wednesday's game at Bayern Munich: victory with minimal exertion and not an injury in sight. The only shame for Arsène Wenger was that the referee could not declare a knockout after five minutes.

By that stage Arsenal were 2-0 up and, when they went three ahead by half-time, it was game over before Blackburn could advertise for a striker on Teletext.

Sylvain Wiltord, who comes at the other end of the scale at £13m, had done much to destroy the First Division side.

After scoring the first he set up the third for the lively Robert Pires, enough, one might imagine, to secure a place in the team in Munich. Apparently not. "Away from home you need to keep the ball," Wenger said, "so it is important to have someone up front who can do that."

Poor Wiltord must wonder quite what he has to do to start a Champions League game after getting a hat-trick against West Ham the previous weekend and still finding himself on the bench against Spartak Moscow.

It seems Nwankwo Kanu or Dennis Bergkamp will line up with Thierry Henry on Wednesday for a match Arsenal must win to be sure of reaching the quarter-finals.

Wenger will announce today whether Bergkamp will be granted permission to be driven the "very long and tiring" journey to Munich, and Kanu's condition will presumably influence that decision.

The Nigerian is expected to be back in time from a World Cup qualifier in Ghana at the weekend, but his physical state remains to be seen, given that his journey home apparently requires three flights.

Long before Bergkamp departed 68 minutes into a flat encounter played in front of a below-capacity crowd, the overwhelming feeling was that the priorities of both managers lay elsewhere.

The sight of Patrick Vieira and Henry on Arsenal's bench was confirmation that Wenger was more concerned about Bayern, while among Blackburn's substitutes sat Matt Jansen and Damien Duff. With a league game at Birmingham on Wednesday and promotion to the Premiership the ultimate ambition, Graeme Souness was no closer to shedding tears in defeat than the umpire BC Cooray is to winning a popularity contest in Sri Lanka.

"I'm not taking anything away from Arsenal here," Souness said, "but our team selection and our substitutions were with Wednesday in mind. We want to try to keep them as fresh as possible." So much for the magic of the FA Cup.

Arsenal's recovery since their humilation at Old Trafford has been impressive, but they know a test of far greater intensity awaits at Bayern, who put aside the internal wrangles which followed last week's 3-0 defeat at Lyon by beating Energie Cottbus 2-0 on Saturday to go top of the Bundesliga.

It is unlikely the German champions will be as vulnerable defensively and as susceptible to pace as Blackburn were. After Wiltord had scored first time from a Pires cross to continue his record of scoring in every round, Tony Adams headed in an Ashley Cole corner and Pires finished off the job before half-time with a neat finish from Wiltord's pass.

The semi-final draw suggests a tougher test lies ahead.

webTitle: Straight man Sanchez has the last laugh

fields.headline: Straight man Sanchez has the last laugh
fields.trailText: As the straight man of the Crazy Gang, Lawrie Sanchez was seldom involved in the ritualistic burning of suits and scissoring of underpants in SE19. On the eve of the 1988 FA Cup final, when his footloose colleagues unwound with a night's boozing beside Wimbledon Common, the rugged old enforcer opted instead for lights out at 10pm.
fields.body:
As the straight man of the Crazy Gang, Lawrie Sanchez was seldom involved in the ritualistic burning of suits and scissoring of underpants in SE19. On the eve of the 1988 FA Cup final, when his footloose colleagues unwound with a night's boozing beside Wimbledon Common, the rugged old enforcer opted instead for lights out at 10pm.

On Saturday night, as Wycombe's players enjoyed a drink-fuelled celebration at the Leicester Hilton, Sanchez was absent again. Having left Filbert Street stating he would be celebrating in the "standard English fashion," the invitation from Match of the Day too good to turn down. Besides, he had something to clear up.

Earlier in the day he had watched Mark Lawrenson and Alan Curbishley sniffily dismiss Wycombe's chances on Football Focus. For Sanchez, this doyen of giant-killing exploits, it was one patronising act too many.

"Maybe there was a bit of history with Lawrenson," he said. "They were saying: 'Well done Wycombe, thanks for coming, it's a great story but see you around.'

"But people said that before the Cup final with Wimbledon. You would have thought Lawrenson would have known better after what happened to Liverpool that year."

Point made. And after nine ties, dating back to November 18 against Harrow Borough of the Ryman League, Sanchez would be only human now to believe the hitherto unthinkable could actually happen. "It's 11 against 11, anything's possible," he said. "Chesterfield would have done it if it were not for bad refereeing in 1997 and now it's our chance. I don't think anyone will dare under-estimate us now."

In the meantime Wycombe must deal with the fall-out of an extraordinary day. Sanchez will face a misconduct charge for the penalty protests that precipitated his spending the final 15 minutes of the game in the bowels of Leicester's main stand. Moreover, the club are to appeal against Steve Brown's second yellow card, citing Fifa's plans not to punish players who remove their shirts during goal celebrations.

"Unfortunate and sad as it was, I really had no option," the referee Steve Bennett said afterwards, although had he been privy to Brown's motives he might have been more inclined to turn a blind eye.

"Before we played Wimbledon in the fifth round my son Maxwell had a six-hour operation and I promised him that if we got through he would be coming with daddy to the quarter-finals," said Brown. "Under my shirt I had a T-shirt with a message for him.

"He was born with a condition that when he takes milk it went straight into his lungs and he has had 20-odd operations in his first 15 months. He was our mascot and the bravest person on the pitch. To be sent off with him here, I was in tears. It was a massive day for him and I was setting a bad example."

In fact, Brown could not have set a better example, the fulcrum of Wycombe's side and arguably the game's outstanding player.

"Twelve years ago I was playing for my local pub team, called Northampton Nexday and we beat Sunderland Humbledown Plains in the FA Sunday Cup final," he said. "I remember Bobby Robson was guest of honour. He came up to me afterwards and said: 'Son, you should be playing professional football.' Now I might be the only person ever to win an FA Cup winner's medal as well as an FA Sunday Cup medal."

The irony for Wycombe is that earlier this season the players renegotiated their bonus payments, reasoning that there was little chance of FA Cup success. Hence Roy Essandoh's late contribution earned them only £130 each, while winning their semi-final will net them just £200. Should they win the competition each player will get £1,000. But surely that couldn't happen. Could it?
fields.bodyText: As the straight man of the Crazy Gang, Lawrie Sanchez was seldom involved in the ritualistic burning of suits and scissoring of underpants in SE19. On the eve of the 1988 FA Cup final, when his footloose colleagues unwound with a night's boozing beside Wimbledon Common, the rugged old enforcer opted instead for lights out at 10pm. On Saturday night, as Wycombe's players enjoyed a drink-fuelled celebration at the Leicester Hilton, Sanchez was absent again. Having left Filbert Street stating he would be celebrating in the "standard English fashion," the invitation from Match of the Day too good to turn down. Besides, he had something to clear up. Earlier in the day he had watched Mark Lawrenson and Alan Curbishley sniffily dismiss Wycombe's chances on Football Focus. For Sanchez, this doyen of giant-killing exploits, it was one patronising act too many. "Maybe there was a bit of history with Lawrenson," he said. "They were saying: 'Well done Wycombe, thanks for coming, it's a great story but see you around.' "But people said that before the Cup final with Wimbledon. You would have thought Lawrenson would have known better after what happened to Liverpool that year." Point made. And after nine ties, dating back to November 18 against Harrow Borough of the Ryman League, Sanchez would be only human now to believe the hitherto unthinkable could actually happen. "It's 11 against 11, anything's possible," he said. "Chesterfield would have done it if it were not for bad refereeing in 1997 and now it's our chance. I don't think anyone will dare under-estimate us now." In the meantime Wycombe must deal with the fall-out of an extraordinary day. Sanchez will face a misconduct charge for the penalty protests that precipitated his spending the final 15 minutes of the game in the bowels of Leicester's main stand. Moreover, the club are to appeal against Steve Brown's second yellow card, citing Fifa's plans not to punish players who remove their shirts during goal celebrations. "Unfortunate and sad as it was, I really had no option," the referee Steve Bennett said afterwards, although had he been privy to Brown's motives he might have been more inclined to turn a blind eye. "Before we played Wimbledon in the fifth round my son Maxwell had a six-hour operation and I promised him that if we got through he would be coming with daddy to the quarter-finals," said Brown. "Under my shirt I had a T-shirt with a message for him. "He was born with a condition that when he takes milk it went straight into his lungs and he has had 20-odd operations in his first 15 months. He was our mascot and the bravest person on the pitch. To be sent off with him here, I was in tears. It was a massive day for him and I was setting a bad example." In fact, Brown could not have set a better example, the fulcrum of Wycombe's side and arguably the game's outstanding player. "Twelve years ago I was playing for my local pub team, called Northampton Nexday and we beat Sunderland Humbledown Plains in the FA Sunday Cup final," he said. "I remember Bobby Robson was guest of honour. He came up to me afterwards and said: 'Son, you should be playing professional football.' Now I might be the only person ever to win an FA Cup winner's medal as well as an FA Sunday Cup medal." The irony for Wycombe is that earlier this season the players renegotiated their bonus payments, reasoning that there was little chance of FA Cup success. Hence Roy Essandoh's late contribution earned them only £130 each, while winning their semi-final will net them just £200. Should they win the competition each player will get £1,000. But surely that couldn't happen. Could it?

webTitle: Credit union restrictions to be relaxed

fields.headline: Credit union restrictions to be relaxed
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: New powers allowing credit unions to make larger loans for longer periods will be unveiled by the Treasury this morning as part of its attempt to tackle the thorny issue of financial exclusion.
fields.body:
New powers allowing credit unions to make larger loans for longer periods will be unveiled by the Treasury this morning as part of its attempt to tackle the thorny issue of financial exclusion.

The move means that credit unions will be granted greater flexibility in handing out loans and taking in deposits from savers six months earlier than initially planned by the government.

Melanie Johnson, economic secretary to the Treasury, will use the changes to the rules governing credit unions to try to promote the government's goal of creating more of these institutions across the country.

The government hopes that the longer period of loans - up to 12 years in some cases -may make it easier for people to buy homes.

The government is aiming to increase the penetration of credit unions to levels reached in other countries, particularly Ireland where 40% of the population are members of such unions.

Attempts to foster growth are under way. High street banks are helping to run credit unions while the recent report into the future of the cooperative movement conluded that one of the areas for potential expansion was credit unions.

But, the rigid rules setting out the amount of lending credit unions are able to do were said by some industry experts to be inhibiting their development.

Ms Johnson hopes that by reducing the restrictions, more credit unions may be started.

From April 1, credit unions will be able to make unsecured loans for three years - rather than the current two - and secured loans, such as those for a house, for seven years rather than five. Some secured loans from credit unions which are able to meet tougher financial rules may also be made for 12 years, up from 10 years.

Under the changes, people under the age of 18 will also be able to increase the amount of money they save with credit unions to £5,000 from £750. This means they will be able to save as much as adults.

When it took office four years ago, the government pledged to tackle the issue of financial exclusion. It set up a task force on credit unions and, more controversially, has encouraged financial firms to contribute to the cost of setting up a post office-based bank to be known as Universal Banking Services.

The new credit union rules are in addition to measures which have already been introduced in the new Financial Services and Markets Act which will result in the financial services authority receiving new powers.

fields.headline: Feeder's punk-pop pandemonium
fields.standfirst:
Feeder
Manchester Academy
***
fields.trailText:
Feeder
Manchester Academy
***
fields.body:
"The last time we played here," Grant Nicholas recollects, "we were supporting Reef and there was about two people moving for us. So thanks. It feels good." Quite. The indignity of supporting Reef very much behind them, Feeder find themselves riding high on the back of a recent top five chart hit, Buck Rogers.

They had to upgrade tonight's venue to accommodate their fans, and expectation is high. Fervent chants of "Feeder! Feeder!" precede the Welsh trio's arrival. They greet their people with a flurry of (still crass) devil signs. The crowd return the salute unanimously, and opener Insomnia, a typical wired burst of streamlined punk-pop energy, triggers pandemonium. A few songs in and schoolkids with flushed faces and tattered grunge/nu-metal T-shirts are tumbling, unbowed, from the pogoing scrum up front. Others, barely into their teens, pant for water at the bar, while, further back, students, sixth-formers and 20-somethings quite simply freak out.

Only the most uptight musical snob would deny the infectious nature of Feeder's better tracks. Buck Rogers - basically growling, squealing Pixies rifferama welded to a Green Day chorus - is a little gem. Equally, the stop-start Seven Days in the Sun is a concentrated mix of velocity and hooks. For all the broken-fingered solos and explosive bursts of noise, however, Feeder are debilitatingly clean. Despite their ages - they're in their 30s, two are married - they look like a Gap ad for skate-kids, and have transformed themselves over the past four years from would-be nu-metallers to a highly melodic, occasionally reflective alternative-rock act. Their dogged pursuit of fame has paid off, but their broad appeal is at the expense of real wildness or musical innovation.

It's hard to take the angst-ridden, lyrically trite Standing on the Edge seriously, amidst all this glossy power-pop. Nor Yesterday Went Too Soon's sub-Oasis lighters-aloft melodic communality. "Love's the antidote we need," Nicholas advises. In fact, what we need are more of those moments when Standing... sounds like a platoon of chainsaws, and less of those pretty, phased segments where Feeder attempt a poignancy they can't quite pull off. The hurtling, urgent Crash is a far better conduit for adolescent frustrations. Like The Wonder Stuff before them, Feeder are a popular, perennially uncool band with a clutch of good pop songs. No one over the age of 16, however, is going to man the barricades in their name. The Wonder Stuff, at least, wanted to put Rick Astley in a noose. Feeder are so diplomatic it's a wonder they haven't been recruited by the Foreign Office.

webTitle: Art review:  Jo Lansley/ Helen Bendon

fields.headline: Murder and knitting in York
fields.standfirst:
Jo Lansley/ Helen Bendon
Impressions Gallery, York
****
fields.trailText:
Jo Lansley/ Helen Bendon
Impressions Gallery, York
****
fields.body:
Mushrooms are reflected in the mirror. A pair of naked legs dangle languorously from the ceiling. A half-dressed woman throws back her head in a pose of ecstatic abandonment. What's going on?

Jo Lansley and Helen Bendon demonstrate that there is nothing so seductive as the publicly shared secrets of life as it is lived between intimates. Their video and photo narratives tell the stories of a couple of close friends who don't get out much. When they do they tend to get up to perverse variations of no good. They abduct a man on the top deck of a bus, then take him home to knit him up in a woollen bodybag and drown him in the bath.

Through a wealth of quirky detail such fantasies go way beyond the usual brand of taboo-breaking sensationalism. The twinned protagonists wear identical bleached dresses. Their mischief is domestically ritualised and carried out in complicit silence. They take great care with the neatness of their knitting. That particularly dated yellow wallpaper comes to life as a swarm of paper butterflies. These girls might be nasty but they always clean up after themselves.

Their half private epiphanies are all the more intriguing for being so respectably disguised as nothing out of the ordinary. What's more, the works are meticulously edited and composed to balance out the banality and the horror, the silliness and transgression. Their videos are reminiscent of the low-budget beginnings of Bunuel or Lynch, film-makers who never quite managed to achieve the same frisson of psychological suspense in their hi-tech later productions.

This is a rare opportunity to catch a representative selection of Lansley and Bendon's recent work, after years in which they have impressed in thematic group shows. It was always interesting to imagine how much longer they could sustain their brand of fairytale subversion before it became a predictable formula of moral contrariness.

The most recent work here avoids this danger by being more subtly and mysteriously composed. Figures are glimpsed between curtains or behind half-closed doors. Narratives are barely suggested rather than taken to their surreal resolution. Lone figures now appear deprived of theatrical interaction with their phantom friends. A woman lies in pullover and tights amidst the fallen leaves of a park. She's now left there in her nocturnal vulnerability to prompt the morally dubious fantasies of the viewer. Somehow she still appears in control of the situation. The scenarios are getting more ambiguous. It's becoming more difficult to tell where Lansley and Bendon are coming from. What's for sure is that the weird woman double act is at last heading for long overdue international recognition.

 Until April 28. Details: 01904-654724.

fields.headline: Love in a lunch hour
fields.standfirst:
Some workers spend years married to the firm, and then find themselves single and with no social life. Never fear, the matchmaker's here, says Dolly Dhingra

<A HREF="http://www.work.guardian.co.uk/">Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Some workers spend years married to the firm, and then find themselves single and with no social life. Never fear, the matchmaker's here, says Dolly Dhingra
fields.body:
Adam and Eve Mews in London's Kensington is a romantic address. If you're in the singles industry, it's an address to die for. But the owners of Only Lunch, a singles introductory agency which is based there, confess that they came by their location by default rather than by scouring the A-Z. Coincidence or what?

"I'm a born matchmaker. I'm always trying to fix up my friends even if they don't want me to," says Debi Chaudheri, 31, lunch coordinator for Only Lunch. "I watch Blind Date, Singled Out, I read the glossy mags. Anything to do with singledom, demographics, relationships, marriages and I'm there. I home in on it. I'm fascinated by it - I keep a file on all the stuff," she says.

She also keeps a mental tally of exactly how many weddings she's been to. "Doesn't everyone?" she asks, surprised. She could probably recount each one, but we won't go there.

Chaudheri studied at Stirling University and has a degree in marketing and an MSc in public relations. After working for Zee TV, an Asian cable channel, and for the Crufts dog show, she became disillusioned with both work and London. For a change of scene, she packed her bags and travelled around the world for six months. "When I came back I thought OK, I've tried quite a few things. But what do I really, really want to do? And I thought I'd love to work for a dating agency. It was the first thing that came into my mind. I knew I'd be good at it. It had always been an ambition of mine," she says.

And following that realisation, she wrote a letter to what she considered the most reputable dating agency around - Drawing Down the Moon, Only Lunch's sister company. Her CV was kept on file, but then, finally, after a couple of years, the firm contacted her to ask if she was still interested in working for it. That's how she got her current job in which she organises lunch dates for singles.

From a database of 700 clients, couples are matched according to suitability, and personal tastes are taken into consideration. Chaudheri coordinates clients, tells them where, when and with whom they will be lunching. "It is only lunch. You don't have to go home to get changed, it's not a formal dinner. We encourage people to go with the intention of having a relaxed, fun meeting with another person, that's all," she says.

Meeting with a stranger for a brief meal during the day means the normal awkwardness of dating is removed. If you don't like the person, you can leave pretty sharpish. Few people are likely to get sloshed during lunchtime and, to avoid the trickiest obstacle of all, Only Lunch has solved the problem of who pays for the meal. "The bill is presented to each client separately. The restaurants that we work with know our format, which avoids any embarrassment,"explains Chaudheri.

Being single within the singles industry is tricky. "I suppose it's a bit like being let loose in a candy store, but not being allowed to eat any of the sweets. But it's OK because I've got a good social life," she says. For those who think that introduction agencies are for sad arses in search of a life, Chaudheri offers the following explanation. "More and more people are choosing to be single these days, often because of careers. It means lots of people have neglected their social life. It's a way of helping fate along."

Another of fate's conspirators is Julie Davies, 42, founder of Contacts, a dining party club for single people. Davies works full-time from home, coordinating events at the weekends. "I became divorced in May 1994 and by November that year I had set up Contacts. I had tried dating agencies and dinner dates myself, but didn't think much of them. I set up Contacts in a quest to find the right man for me," she says.

Six years later Davies is still single, but with a flourishing business. Contacts has a database of 2,000 people. Events, which were fortnightly, have now become weekly. Each week, dinners followed by parties are held at prestigious venues around London, and clients can attend one or both. With no membership charge and parties costing only £10, Contacts offers an affordable and spontaneous way to meet other singles.

"I work entirely from home except at the weekends, which is when I get my fix of people," says Davies. She has a computer, but considers the phone her greatest working tool. "I could never send people emails, they are so impersonal. I think this is a very personal business and I like to have direct contact with my clients," she says.

A calendar of events is organised well in advance and clients get friendly phone calls to remind them of coming events. Bookings for dinners have to be made and paid for in advance. Contracts with venues have to be arranged and settled and a guest list has to be organised. "I have to make sure that there is an even number of men and women at each event. I have to organise the DJ, sort out the table plan. On the night, we have to meet and greet people, introduce them to one another. The parties are straight after the meal so things can get a bit stressful if people are arriving late for the meal and early for the party," she says.

Running a club for singles means Davies has little time to sort out her own love life. "You have to set boundaries and I can't exactly go out with a client. It can get a bit lonely when you've organised an event for all these people who are going home with one another and you are going home alone," she admits. "But I do sometimes think that perhaps the reason I got divorced in the first place was so that all these other people could meet because of me."
