fields.headline: More stress, less sex
fields.standfirst: Success at work has its price - a failing sex life, says a new report.  Kate Hilpern  on why homelife is taking second place
fields.trailText: Success at work has its price - a failing sex life, says a new report. Kate Hilpern on why homelife is taking second place
fields.body:
Long hours, stressful working environments and dedication to their careers mean that people are increasingly successful in the workplace, but failing miserably when it comes to sex, according to a new report by the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development (CIPD). More than half the partners of people who work in excess of 48 hours in a typical week admit that it is damaging their sex life. A further third of partners claim that long hours have a negative effect on their personal relationships generally.

"While working long hours doesn't necessarily lead to marriage breakdown, it can put a strain on relationships with partners, children and friends," says Melissa Compton-Edwards, the report's author. For instance, 43% of partners claim they are fed up with having to shoulder the domestic burden.

And, she warns, don't assume you'd know if your partner was among them. "Long-suffering spouses and cohabiting partners tend to suffer in silence, tolerating the situation and trying to curb their criticism of their absentee other half. The Faustian pact seems to be that while they would rather their 'long hours' partner worked shorter hours, this is considered a price worth paying if it guarantees a decent living standard."

You may be equally in the dark when it comes to children or friends who feel undervalued, she says. "The culture of presenteeism means many individuals subconsciously expect people who work to have struck the wrong work-life balance."

According to careers consultancy Sanders & Sydney, it isn't only long hours that are responsible for the growing wedge between employees and their loved ones. "Our research shows that the vast majority of our friends are now made at work and that friendship, like pay and benefits, is becoming key in attracting and binding us to an organisation," says Sanders & Sydney director Sally Davis. The result, not surprisingly, is that employees spend more time at work, or at least with their workmates, and existing friends may consequently be disregarded. "We are increasingly reliant on the workplace to provide our sense of belonging," adds Davis.

The research found that employers are increasingly aware of the importance of a workplace community in influencing someone's decision to join an organisation, to stay with it, and to commit more to his or her work. In other words, they are employing people whom they predict will form strong bonds.

"It is part of our vision to develop a sense of community in all departments - with a focus on fun and socialising," says Mike Deohane, HR director at AWG, the former water utility Anglian Water. Hey presto, you have more of a laugh by the photocopier or in the work bar than you do down the pub or at home.

Other companies are introducing "corporate villages", which can result in employees not wanting to leave their self-sufficient workplaces. After all, why go home when work provides an on-site jogging trail, top-quality restaurants, massages at your desk, TV rooms and free counselling? Consider British Airways' £200m state-of-the-art Waterside business centre near Heathrow. Paul Parry, who was involved in the project from the start, explains: "Six four-storey buildings, each with an individually styled courtyard, are arranged on either side of a long, glazed atrium, known as 'The Street'. People can order their shopping electronically from an inhouse Waitrose supermarket, and keep trim and neat at the fitness centre and hairdresser. There are restaurants, bars, a bank and a flower shop. Employees are known as 'residents'."

The Industrial Society blames the obsession with business jargon, together with long hours, for causing a negative impact on employees' relationships and sex lives. "Despite being determined to share their work experiences, couples literally do not have a clue what their partners are talking about," says a spokesperson. "The new 'corporate family culture' automatically excludes, partly through its own 'secret' language, anyone not employed by the same firm."

And while employees once went home and moaned about work to their families, today they are more likely to rush into work to niggle about the shortcomings of their partner, says Compton-Edwards.

Judi James, author and adviser to the Industrial Society, says it doesn't help that today's employers rarely include families in company parties. "Nor do partners of working people get too excited about the fact that, even at weekends, they tend to contact colleagues via email or mobile phones. It's a sure passion-killer."

fields.headline: Ping Pong booed off yet brilliant
fields.standfirst:
Ping Pong Bitches
Time Tunnel, Bournemouth
****
fields.trailText:
Ping Pong Bitches
Time Tunnel, Bournemouth
****
fields.body:
These newest signings to Alan McGee's Poptones label describe themselves, presumably in all honesty, as "scumbags and sex addicts", but time-worn shock tactics are not enough to get a new band noticed in this era of pop horrors. Nor is a propensity for song titles like I Love You Necrophiliac - not when everyone from Alice Cooper to Cradle of Filth has already been there and worn the Lycra britches. The London female trio's best hope for the world domination they claim to crave is to play the gender card for all their worth. PVC bondage gear, riding crops and hell-bent aggression make them a photo-negative of the remaining Spice Girls - the Vice Girls, if you will.

The reaction they provoked in Bournemouth, the sixth date of their first tour, suggests they're doing something right. Essentially, Louise Prey (leather biker chaps, robust swearing), Emily Hell, (duct tape covering breasts, Scottish) and Mandy Wong (man-mangling stilettos, kung fu dance moves) hit the stage at midnight, looking like a cross between Ann Summers and Riot Grrrl - and within five minutes are booed off. The venom of the audience, burly rugby types to a man, is extraordinary, evoking images of the Sex Pistols being bottled off by similarly incensed crowds 25 years ago.

What seems to set them off is the three singers' confrontational stance, semaphored by unwavering stares and curled lips, before they sing a note, and the music itself. The first and only song of what should have been a 30-minute show, appropriately titled Beat You Up, is raw punk-metal that raises hackles as soon as the first spiteful lines ("You've got more funk than a Shaolin monk, you ugly cunt") are out. The locals don't appreciate being insulted by three tornadoes who make Courtney Love's group Hole sound like Atomic Kitten, and a stuttering PA system doesn't help. The jeering begins and Prey responds by snatching someone's lit cigarette and throwing it back in his face. Within seconds 300 beefy blokes are baying for blood and the club manager cuts in over the PA: "Ping Pong Bitches are a load of bollocks. Get off!" The bitches are bustled to the dressing room, where they exchange conspiratorial smiles. "I thought it was a triumph," drawls Emily Hell. Ten out of ten for attitude: this could be the girl group of 2001.

fields.headline: Ecstasy and Grace
fields.standfirst:
Finborough, London
*
fields.trailText:
Finborough, London
*
fields.body:
The young director Stephen Henry has an absolute genius for attracting publicity, but so far in his short career there is no evidence whatsoever that he has the slightest talent for picking a good new play. Two years ago in Edinburgh, the pickets and tabloid press were out in force for his premiere of Terrence McNally's Corpus Christi, a limp and entirely inoffensive attempt to depict Jesus as gay.

His latest effort, written by James Martin Charlton, has already had acres of newsprint devoted to it because it features a child actor in a story about paedophiles, pimps and snuff movies. Ecstasy and Grace is only shocking because it fails to address the issue of paedophilia with any purpose, insight or honesty, and only newsworthy because it falls into the category of those ball-crunching, back-breaking nights that Richard Eyre recently identified as giving the theatre such a bad name. Apparently, the police have paid the theatre a visit but the only arrests that seem likely are for boring the audience to death.

In fact, Ecstasy and Grace turns out to be a laughingly improbable, badly made, excruciating and sadly-written drama about spiritual death and rebirth. Davy used to be a leading light in the Salvation Army but after the general's 18-year-old son rejected his advances, he scarpered to Amsterdam. Now he is shacked up with Kai, a German neo-Nazi. Together they run a gay porn shop and procure drugs and teenage boys for greasy English perverts who claim that all they are doing is "loving boys". But when 13-year-old Pullet is killed by a client who takes the view that as he's paid for the boy he can do what he likes with him, and film it too, Davy suddenly finds his conscience.

The absurdity of Charlton's play is that we're supposed to believe that it has never crossed Davy's mind that Pullet might be in danger; its gratuitousness is that it treats a subject as serious as paedophilia merely as plot device as Davy undergoes his transformation from cynical businessman trading in flesh to born again Sally Army recruit.

The final 15 minutes, which feature serious reference to Rolf Harris's Two Little Boys song and a spiritual duel between the half-naked Salvation Army follower Rae and the all too easily convinced Davy, is actually rather memorable. But only because it is so loopy.

 Until March 31. Box office: 020-7373 3842.

fields.headline: Bennett the secret jazz singer
fields.standfirst:
Britten Sinfonia/ Bennett
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.trailText:
Britten Sinfonia/ Bennett
Queen Elizabeth Hall, London
***
fields.body:
Richard Rodney Bennett turns 65 later this month. This programme by the Britten Sinfonia (of which he is president) spotlighted his own works alongside a few by composers that have inspired him. As Bennett himself admitted, it was all "slightly self-indulgent", but then indulging composers is not always a crime, and nobody could begrudge this ebullient and enjoyable tribute to a musician who remains impossible to categorise.

Although Bennett has carved out a presence in the worlds of "serious" and "light" classical music as well as jazz, it can't be said that he is equally at home in all three of them. The first of his own works on this programme (which opened with a Fantasia by Purcell) was the Nocturnes for Chamber Orchestra (1963), an early composition influenced by the unlikely combination of the intellectualism of his teacher Pierre Boulez and the warmth of his mentor Elisabeth Lutyens. In these three pieces Bennett employed the 12-note technique, but one could always hear his own love of lyricism trying to push through the serialist net. He used the modernist musical language with competence, yet the Nocturnes left the impression that it was not Bennett's mother tongue.

Next to these pieces, the 1995 Partita made his later departure into the world of light classical music seem less a foray than a homecoming. Bennett has a rare talent for writing scores that, despite being the classical equivalent of easy listening, largely avoid getting bogged down in cliche and schmaltz. Although written in memory of a close friend, the outer movements of the Partita are celebratory, recalling Walton's film music or even Stravinsky; it is only the extended Lullaby between them that hints at a feeling of loss. Under Nicholas Cleobury's solid yet buoyant conducting, the Sinfonia's lively playing conveyed their own enjoyment of the score.

Nicholas Daniel's oboe is a distinctive and dominant feature of the Sinfonia at any time; as soloist in Bennett's new work, Seven Country Dances, he was as eloquent and persuasive as ever. Bennett's settings of these folksy tunes at times verges on the formulaic, and the pastoral harmonies owe much to Vaughan Williams, but nonetheless they have a deft, imaginative polish that is all his own.

Bennett joined the orchestra as pianist for Aaron Jay Kernis's vivid orchestrations of three of Debussy's piano preludes, an unexpected treat. The lights reddened for the final items, doing their best to turn this staid hall into a cabaret venue as a jazz trio further augmented the Sinfonia for some of Bennett's film music and arrangements. An encore of Sinatra's In the Wee Small Hours of the Morning finally revealed Richard Rodney Bennett the jazz singer, crooning like his namesake Tony - yet another face of this many-sided, multi-talented musician.

webTitle: Virgin One hopes for maiden profit

fields.headline: Virgin One hopes for maiden profit
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: Richard Branson's loss-making Virgin One financial services business is expected to nudge into the black for the first time later this year, three years after launch.
fields.body:
Richard Branson's loss-making Virgin One financial services business is expected to nudge into the black for the first time later this year, three years after launch.

The first profits at the operation, where AMP of Australia and Royal Bank of Scotland also have stakes, come after Virgin One doubled its business in 2000 as customers became used to its all-in-one current account and mortgage product.

Virgin One said yesterday it had taken 3.5% of all the new mortgage business in the country last year as a result of the account, which allows holders to over-or underpay their mortgages as their circumstances allow.

A spokesman for Virgin One refused to reveal the extent of the business's losses in 2000 but insisted that this time next year it would be making a profit.

The acknowledgement that it is edging towards to profitability came as its sister company, the internet portal Virginmoney.com, revealed it could be the first British company to launch a US style on-line service enabling people to access all their financial information in one place.

The company has devised a service it has named "v-safe" which pulls together information about all the different accounts an individual runs on-line and presents it on a single web page.

Virginmoney has not yet committed itself to a date for launching v-safe but said it was keen to be one of the first players in the UK to launch a so-called aggregation service, and indicated it could go live by this summer.

In the US aggregation services have been described as on-line "one-stop shops" that allow people to log on to one place to view and monitor their current account, savings account, investments, mortgage and credit card, plus see their e-mails and any bills they pay over the internet.

fields.headline: Pick of the week
fields.standfirst: A new take on the story of Red Riding Hood and a sharply scripted look at the advertising game.
fields.trailText: A new take on the story of Red Riding Hood and a sharply scripted look at the advertising game.
fields.body:
Red Riding Hood
(www.6amhoover.com)
If you go down to the woods today, you're sure of a big surprise. Donna Leishman's sly, modern fairy tale is a delicious mix of deceptively simple animation with trippy interactive sequences. Like Red Riding Hood, take a little time and wander off the story path, to discover the cunningly hidden pockets of interactivity which hold secret diaries and moody dream sequences. Leishman strikes just the right balance between plot and charming distractions, packing enough secret scenes under the skin of her story to make repeat viewing a must. Biggest surprise of all, this fresh but assured work is her MA project for the Glasgow School of Art. A star is born. (KS)
 View the film

The Truth in Advertising
(www.ifilm.com)
'Viral' films, like this one currently doing the rounds of media industry inboxes, are usually as much fun as gastric flu. What kept my finger off the 'Delete Mail' button in this case was the snatch of stiletto-sharp script that reached me before the images did. Created for the Canadian Marketing Awards by a Toronto ad agency, these outrageous brand meetings and director briefings are played as if the participants had taken truth serum. Fear, loathing, references to German Expressionism - it's all here, plus a micro-performance from the deadpan Colin Mochrie (Whose Line Is It Anyway) as the agency boss. Anyone who'd rather be burned alive than go for an awkward, uncomfortable drink with a client, should be watching this. (KS)

fields.headline: RLPO/ Schwarz
fields.standfirst:
Philharmonic Hall , Liverpool
****
fields.trailText:
Philharmonic Hall , Liverpool
****
fields.body:
Gerard Schwarz will take up his appointment as the Royal Liverpool Philharmonic's new music director in September. The changeover is coming at a good time - the RLPO are flourishing. How far Schwarz's programme of Mahler and Sibelius will prove to be a foretaste of the RLPO's repertoire over the next five years is difficult to guess. If more Mahler performances like their Tenth Symphony Adagio are the result, audiences have much to look forward to. It was apparent from the outset that nothing was being taken for granted: not until you see and hear every member of the strings playing with equal intensity do you realise what a rare event it is. A rich, homogenous tone was the stunning result.

If the Tenth Symphony Adagio seems the epitome of tragic lyrical intensity, Mahler's song-cycle Kindertotenlieder evokes something almost too intimate. What gives these songs their beauty is their unearthly tenderness: Mahler's settings draw out the exquisite poignancy of Ruckert's poems with a delicacy that is almost unbearable. Angelika Kirchschlager's mezzo has a contralto's richness and depth in the lower register which invested her brief phrases with an anguished intensity. This lent itself to some striking characterisation: Wenn dein Mütterlein came close to sounding like a march where the voice enters, notwithstanding Mahler's cautious "Flieender" (flowing). The bitterness Kirchschlager brought to this song overflowed in the anger of the last setting, In diesem Wetter: its closing lullaby was sung and played with heartbreaking tenderness.

Sibelius's Second Symphony is weighty enough to balance an all-Mahler first half, and easy-going enough to allow the orchestra to relax a little. Schwarz does not over-exert himself on the podium and what emerges is the sound of an orchestra at ease with their conductor and basking in the sheer joy of playing.

A full-bodied brass sound is an integral part of this symphony, but it is possible to play too loudly, and there were moments when the RLPO brass sounded harsh. But this was not a performance lacking in refinement: the wind section, in particular the principal oboe Jonathan Small, made every solo worth waiting for.

But this was not a performance lacking in refinement: the wind section, in particular the principal oboe Jonathan Small, made every solo worth waiting for.

fields.headline: 'Lifestyle' credit cards on the way
fields.trailText: 10.30am: Your hobbies could soon be reflected in your credit card as companies target consumers according to their lifestyle, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
Your hobbies and interests will soon be reflected in the credit card you carry, as the credit industry gears up to target consumers according to their lifestyle.

Parents may have a card that allows them low interest rates and promotions in children's clothes stores or toyshops, while sports fanatics could have a card giving them similar discounts in sportswear stores or at events.

According to a report from market analysts Datamonitor, by 2005 there will be many "lifestyle" credit cards on the market.

The innovation is made possible by new marketing techniques such as data warehousing, which allows companies to tailor databases to reveal lifestyle information.

Specific audiences can then be picked out and marketed to.

An early example is already available. Prompted by the popularity of TV shows such as Changing Rooms and Ground Force, Barclaycard launched the "Home" card, targeting home buyers by offering lower interest rates in stores they are likely to visit as well as associated promotions.

The research dispels fears about saturation in the UK credit card market; by 2005 the number of credit and charge cards in circulation will have doubled to 92.7m.

But the high level of spending on plastic - from £18.7bn in 1997 to £41.1bn in 2000 - is causing concern.

Consumers are becoming hooked on credit and debit cards at an earlier age, according to the report, because teenagers are getting used to paying by plastic with the advent of pre-pay mobile phone vouchers.

The Office of Fair Trading has expressed concern about young borrowers and the National Association of Citizen's Advice Bureaux wants the small print about the price of borrowing made more obvious.

fields.headline: Tribunals are judged wanting
fields.trailText: Employment lawyers are on a roll. Every month - every day almost - brings the announcement of new employment rights.
fields.body:
Employment lawyers are on a roll. Every month - every day almost - brings the announcement of new employment rights. From working time regulations to part-time working, from union recognition to paternity leave, the ingenuity of the lawmakers in Brussels and at Westminster is harnessed to the cause of employment protection.

What is going to stem the flow? This is not primarily a legal or even a political question. It would be unsafe to assume that either politicians or lawyers will set out to establish the limits on employment law. On present trends, it seems likely to be the machinery for enforcement that will reveal the fault-lines in our approach to employment regulation.

When employment tribunals were established in the 1960s, they were seen as a mechanism for resolving workplace issues that would be informal, speedy and inexpensive. The subsequent expansion in the scale of employment legislation, and increasing dependence on legal representation by both employer and applicant, have undermined this aspiration.

The spiralling numbers of claims to tribunals - 118,000 in the past year - reflect the extension of their jurisdiction to support new employment rights. Employer concerns focus on the costs involved in defending claims. DTI figures show that tribunal cases cost employers more than £2,000 as long ago as 1992. Many employers today will be paying several times that figure.

Even if cases do not proceed to a hearing, employers will generally have incurred significant costs in collecting evidence and taking legal advice. They may be bombarded by requests for documentation whose relevance to the claim remains unclear. This may sometimes be no more than a tactic by lawyers engaged on a "no win, no fee" basis to put pressure on employers to settle.

But unhappiness with the volume of cases is not limited to employers. Many trade unions are also feeling the strain of servicing claims by members, and would be happy if their numbers could be reduced. The average compensation award in unfair dismissal cases is only about £2,500. Three-quarters of employees who make claims never get to a tribunal hearing at all, but withdraw their claim or accept a compromise offer from the employer. Claimants are in any case highly unlikely to get their job back; reinstatement or re-engagement is awarded in only a handful of cases.

In practice, tribunal claims look increasingly like part of a "compensation culture", in which employees who lose their job often have little to lose by claiming - but not much real benefit from winning either.

So what can be done?

When the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, announced his intention recently to increase the level of costs tribunals can impose on "unreasonable" claimants, he got some predictable responses. Unions accused the government of pandering to whingeing employers, while the CBI welcomed the proposals.

Both reactions are based on an exaggerated view of the impact the changes are likely to have. Similar efforts to discourage weak cases in the past have had little effect. This is not least because tribunals are reluctant to behave in what might look to be a heavy-handed way towards individuals who claim to be exercising their statutory rights.

Mr Byers' proposals may represent a last throw at "mending" the system. If, as seems likely, they have at most a limited impact, more radical solutions will need to be considered. What might they look like?

Acas, the advisory, conciliation and arbitration service, is expected to introduce a scheme under which unfair dismissal claims can be resolved by arbitration if both parties agree. This approach looks fairly close to the original conception of tribunals as informal labour courts. The scheme has, however, been held up for technical reasons. Doubts have also been expressed about how far it will reduce the number of hearings, and how far it will simply suck in cases that are currently resolved by agreement.

More could be done to promote the use of in-house procedures. Although most employers already have some form of grievance procedure, there is no statutory requirement for this. More effective in-house procedures could significantly reduce the number of claims to tribunals. Indeed, if employers were required to have such procedures it would not seem unreasonable to require employees to have exhausted them before making a tribunal claim.

This is the kind of agenda that needs to be addressed, and sooner rather than later. Failure to stem the tide of employer unhappiness with the growing burden of tribunal claims will only increase resistance to the ever-expanding "minimum rights" agenda. This is no criticism of the people who serve as tribunal chairmen and members, who exercise their statutory functions in what is generally seen as a fair-minded and impartial way.

Curiously, no comprehensive evaluation of the costs and benefits of the employment tribunal system has ever been undertaken. Rather than simply tinkering at the edges, the government should announce its intention to undertake a really radical review of the tribunal system.

 Mike Emmott is an adviser on employee relations at the Chartered Institute of Personnel and Development.

fields.headline: Cut-rate Nationwide jeopardises future
fields.standfirst:
Building society plays dangerous game with its savers

Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: The Nationwide Building Society is playing a dangerous game with its savers which could reverberate on its crucial members' vote in the summer on the issue of whether it should convert from a mutual to a bank.
fields.body:
The Nationwide Building Society is playing a dangerous game with its savers which could reverberate on its crucial members' vote in the summer on the issue of whether it should convert from a mutual to a bank.

Industry observers say that in the battle for mortgage customers the Nationwide's savers are being unfairly penalised. And many could show their dissatisfaction by backing calls by businessman Andrew Muir, who is leading the challenge against the society's determination to remain mutual.

There is a frenzied battle under way for customers in financial services - sparked by Halifax and Nationwide's high-profile home loan rate cuts last month - and savers are quickly emerging as the losing side.

Nationwide, which has more than 8.5m savers, has cut the rates on its top saving accounts faster then the reduction in the Bank of England's official interest rate.

While the Bank's benchmark rate was cut to 5.75% last month, the building society has reduced the rates on its savings accounts by almost three times that amount in some cases, according to Moneyfacts, which monitors financial products.

Most other high street savings institutions have reduced their rates too, including the Halifax, Abbey National and Cheltenham & Gloucester, part of the Lloyds TSB group. But industry experts believe that attention is starting to focus on Nationwide, which as a building society cannot ask shareholders to share the pain of savers who might otherwise be left stranded as a result of mortgage rate cuts.

Earlier this month Brian Davis, Nationwide's chief executive, fired off a furious letter to his counterpart at the Halifax, James Crosby, accusing its rival of misleading customers over its mortgage rate cuts.

While the battle for mortgage business has been so high profile, less attention has been paid to savings rates. Last year Nationwide lured in a vast number of deposits by offering attractive rates. But a spokeswoman admitted yesterday that it has been quietly lowering its savings rates.

"We were taking a large slice of the savings market and had to balance the books to stem those inflows. We try to remain competitive, though," the spokeswoman said.

Industry observers believe this is this a crucial period for the Nationwide, which faces yet another demutalisation campaign this summer by a group of its 10m members who would receive handsome windfalls if it was forced to convert into a bank.

Its savers outnumber mortgage customers by a ratio of almost eight to one and it is savers the building society needs to keep sweet in the face of rebel members.

The Nationwide insisted yesterday that savers were not being asked to carry the burden of the reduction in home loan rates.

The real impact of the trade-off between savers and borrowers will be reflected later this year when the crucial vote takes place.

As new customers have been asked to sign away their rights to any proceeds of a stock market flotation, industry observers believe the Nationwide may start to distort the rates on some of the products held mainly by the longest-standing customers.

fields.headline: Standing ovation for the two sides of Morricone
fields.standfirst:
Ennio Morricone
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.trailText:
Ennio Morricone
Barbican Hall, London
*****
fields.body:
So this dapper little man, who looks as though he has visited the same barber and eaten the same food at the same restaurant every day of his working life, this is the one whose music added the mythic dimension to the stories of Leone, Pontecorvo, Malick and Tornatore. His arrival on stage in London on Saturday night, giving his first concert in Britain at the age of 72, evoked applause suffused not just with admiration but with gratitude for all those evenings - decades of them - spent in the dark but illuminated by his extraordinary gift.

Many fine composers have made careers in the movies. Some, such as Bernard Herrmann and Nino Rota, have left their fingerprints on the history of the cinema. Only Ennio Morricone, however, has produced a body of work which entitles him to be considered as much of an auteur as those directors whose work he has so consistently enhanced in the 40 years since he sat down to write his first film score.

For this concert, at which he conducted the 90 musicians of the Rome Sinfonietta and the 100-strong Crouch End Festival Chorus and Folk Choir, the composer was clearly obliged to concentrate on the sort of work for which he has become famous. But first, and quite properly, he wanted to show us what Ennio Morricone does when he is writing music for his own satisfaction rather than for someone else's strip of celluloid.

The two pieces of chamber music which preceded the interval were the product of his commitment to the avant-garde of the mid-20th century, to the music of the serialists and their successors. Ombra di Lontana Presenza featured two violas - the first, that of Fausto Anzelmo, in person, and the second, that of the late Dino Asciola, the piece's dedicatee, on tape.

Quiet, ruminative, moving from a sustained intensification of simple materials to a narrative based on interlocking fragments, it formed a sharp contrast with Fragment of Eros, a setting of five poems by Sergio Miceli. Performed in Latin, Italian, German, French and English by the soprano Susanna Rigacci, the piece made use of an astringent chromaticism strongly contrasting with the pungent earthiness of some of the verse: "On n'a... on a... on-a-niste," for example, or "I want my rapture like a snake /Between your bosom - between your thighs."

After the interval, we were allowed to see what Morricone does with his day job, organised into three thematic medleys, the first dedicated to Sergio Leone's spaghetti westerns, the second to films of political protest, and the third to films characterised as "tragic, lyric, epic". Anyone still disconcerted by the first half was immediately reassured by the ghostly ululation introducing the theme from The Good, The Bad and The Ugly, the first part of a triptych in which the glorious ballad theme from Once Upon a Time in the West provided a fine bridge to the galloping climax of A Fistful of Dynamite.

Many among the audience would probably have been happy for that sort of thing to go on all night, but Morricone is understandably sensitive about the closeness of his identification with Leone. The section dedicated to political cinema included an ominous passage from Gillo Pontecorvo's The Battle of Algiers, the lovely adagio from Brian de Palma's Casualties of War, and Dulce Ponte's fine singing of the lush ballad from Giuliano Montaldo's Sacco and Vanzetti and the Bolero-based A Brisa do Coracao from Roberto Faenza's Sostiene Pereira.

For the final scheduled sequence the Crouch End singers split themselves into two groups, creating an antiphony exploited in the finale, On Earth as it is in Heaven from Roland Joffe's The Mission, in which the smaller of the two choirs sang along with the beat of conga drums while the remainder were paced by the full orchestra, graphically reflecting the film's examination of a collision between "primitive" and "civilised" societies.

A standing ovation was rewarded by five encores, the first of which - the exquisitely serene Dorothy's Theme from Once Upon a Time in America - was the shortest, the simplest and the most affecting of the evening's offerings. Who would have thought that a disciple of Berio and Nono would turn out to be one of the 20th century's greatest melodists?

It is, sadly, impossible to go and see Once Upon a Time in America again for the first time, or The Battle of Algiers, or Cinema Paradiso, which provided the final encore. But this remarkable evening was certainly the next best thing.
